DIV1.P: THE HISTORY OF THE REIGN OF King GEORGE, From the Death of her late Majesty Queen ANNE, 16 the First of August, 1718.
Collected from the most authentick Vouchers; supported by Evidence of Fact, and entirely Unconcern'd in the separate Interest of Persons or Parties.
To be Continued YEARLY.

P.HI: Oculatae nostrae sunt Manus, Credunt quod vident.

DIV1.P: LONDON Printed by N. MIST in Carter-Lane, 1719.

DIV1.HEAD: AN Impartial HISTORY Of the REIGN of King GEORGE.

DIV2.HEAD: INTRODUCTION.
DIV2.P: IT would be a Satyr upon the Reign of the King, to suggest that it would not bear an Im∣partial History; and it would be much more a Satyr upon those who read these Sheets, to say they should dislike them for their being Impartial.

As if it was impossible to write as an Historian, without mingling with the relations of Fact, the Reflections, the Reproaches, and the Excursions
of the Passions of Men, who on one Side or other, have carried Faction and Party-Quarrel to such an extravagant height in this Reign.

If I meet with these unhappy Things in my way, as who can trace the Actions of contend∣ing Parties, without jostling sometimes with their Failings and Follies, I shall endeavour to repre∣sent them in the most favourable manner on either side, and make no Reflections upon them, except in such Cases wherein they shall acknowledge those Reflections to be natural and just.

I cannot promise to oblige those Readers who had rather be deceived than inform'd, who can∣not read with Pleasure, except they find their Author as warm in History as they are in their Discourse, and unless one Party is crush'd, and the other espoused: Such Gentlemen would do well to take up with those who write after that manner: And I doubt not but each Side may find Authors to please them, especially as Times now go.

As for this Work, its Title is an Impartial Hi∣story, and such they shall find it: The King shall have all that Justice and Regard which Duty commands, as well to his Majesty's Person and Interest as to the just Merit of his Administration: His Servants and Friends shall be spoken of with Honour, with Truth, and with good Manners; and yet all shall be unmix'd with surfeiting Panegy∣rick, and the unmanly Flattery which truly glorious Princes abhor to receive, and Men of sense to give.

I shall have no Reserve here in Favour of any Party, if any Expression shall be subject to a double Construction, and Party-Malice shall guide the un∣charitable Thoughts of any to take the worst: Be the Shame to themselves, who mean evil, and suspect others. I shall, as much as possible, avoid giving such any Advantage, or laying my self o∣pen to their Gensure.

The Work is a History, not a Satyr; Relation of Fact is the Business, not Rallery at Parties or Persons. If any Gentlemen have fallen under the Weight of Publick Justice, it is enough that I give an Account how they came to the Disaster, and what End their Miscarriages have brought them to; without following their Me∣mories with Reproaches beyond the Grave, or Descanting in Tryumph over their Miseries.

Men of Misfortune should be treated with Decency, let their Crime be what it will; 'tis enough to Record the Mistake they fall under, and leave them at the Place of Execution, where the Law has left them.

And all this I hope may be without taking Part with any Body. As to the Pretender, I shall speak of him as he ought to be spoken of, without entring into any Disputes about him: In which I shall no more favour his Interest, than a Painter may be said to take part with an Enemy, when he describes a Battle, because he does not Picture the routed Side in the Shape of Devils and Mon sters.

Rebellion shall be treated with Justice, and yet even the Rebels not be insulted; their Follies, their Temerity, and the inexpressible Error of their Conduct, shall not be hid in Favour of them, or ex∣patiated in Triumph. I shall even venture to pity their Misfortunes, and yet not fear being so much as suspected of favouring their Designs.

The Clemency of the Government shall not be lessen'd by Reflections upon its being too late, or advanc'd beyond it self for being too soon; Nor shall I hide the Mistakes of those, to whose Folly their own Friends acknowledge they owe its com∣ing no sooner.
In a Word, and to shorten all Preambles, Friend and Enemy shall, with the utmost Impar∣tiality, have Justice done them in this History, and as little Offence be given to any Side as possible.

DIV2.HEAD: AN Impartial HISTORY.
DIV2.P: QUEEN Ann of truly English Memory, Dy'd the 1st of August, 1714, about 8 a Clock in the Morning. The Council had been assembled in an Extraordinary Manner for 2 or 3 Days before, upon Intimation from the Duke of Shrewsbury, Lord High-Treasurer, that there was no room left to expect Her Majesty's Life, and the Physitians go∣ing and returning continually between the Coun∣cil Chamber, and the Queen's Bed-Chamber, to give an Account how Things were.

During this mournful Interval, as it may very justly be call'd, the Queen being as it were nei∣ther dead or living, but drawing her last Breath, the Doors of the Council Chamber were set open, and many of the Nobility that appear'd, at least of those who bore the Character of Privy-Coun∣cellors, though not summon'd in the Ordinary Way, were admitted; there being no more now before them, but to sit still, and expect when the News should be brought, That the Queen was expir'd, and then to act as the Constitution directed.

It must not be omitted here, this being the proper Place for it, That among all the Nobili∣ty that appear'd on this Occasion at Court, as well those in the Administration, and nearest to the Queen, as others; there was not the least Hesitation in, or so much as an Enquiry about what was before them; I mean as to the Successi∣on of the Crown: The House of Hanover was so natural to the Establishment made in Parliament, that no Man so much as ask'd the Question, Who was next Heir? or, Who ought to succeed? But the Eyes of the Nation, as one Man, turn'd all the same Way; and if any secret Wishes were en∣tertain'd, there was not the least room to bring them out, no not so much as in Words.

As soon as Word was brought to the Council, that the Queen was dead, the Lords broke up, and adjourn'd to the Cockpit, where there was quickly a General Appearance of all the Nobili∣ty, and Persons of Rank that were in Town, as is usual on such Occasions; and where it was una∣nimously agreed, That the Elector of Brunswick, Duke of Hanover, was the only True Lawful and Rightful Successor to the Crown: What Designs there were to destroy that Settlement, or who were guilty of such Designs, if any were, seems rather the Subject of future History, than of Political Reflections before-hand: As far as such Designs are judicially prov'd, so far it will be the Business of an Historian to record them; and what ap∣pears of that kind, shall be stated with the same Impartiallity that we Profess in the whole Series of this Work. A Proclamation being order'd to be immediately prepar'd, and the Heralds attend∣ing, the King was accordingly proclaim'd at White-Hall-Gate, with all the usual Ceremonies;
and all the Nobility and Gentry present, having first sign'd the Proclamation, went in their Coaches to attend the Proclaiming His Majesty in the Ci∣ty, at the usual Places, and last of all, at the Royal-Exchange; and thus the Day which begun in Sorrow, ended with Joy, and the People gave all possible Demonstrations of their Satisfaction, in Bonfires, Illuminations, and the usual Extrava∣gancies of such Occasions.

While these Things were doing, Expresses were dispatch'd in the Heels of one another to Hanover, as well First, To give His Majesty, then Elector of Hanover, notice of the Queen's Condition, and that there was no Probability that Her Majesty could recover; as also to intimate in what good Dispositions every thing stood in Relation to His Electoral Highness's Succession, and that there was no room to doubt its being effectually secur'd; as afterwards to let His Majesty know, That the Queen was dead, and how not only peaceably, and without the least Reluctance, much less Di∣sturbance; but with an Universal Appearance of Joy, and Satisfaction, His Majesty's Accession had been receiv'd, and His Title Proclaim'd, in∣viting His Majesty with the greatest Expressions of Duty and Affection, to come over with what speed his Affairs would admit, to take Possession of the Crown.

The Earl of Dorset was the Person sent over by the Council with this last Message, and the Baron Bothmar had signify'd the first Part by his Secre∣tary, with whom, or immediately before, went another Person of Quality, Mr. Craggs, since made Secretary of State, sent over by the particular Friends of His Electoral Highness, and since ad∣vanc'd to several Posts of Trust in the Government.

In order to make this History be a compleat Record of Fact, it is needful to set down more fully than ordinary, the first Steps of the King's Accession, that remarkable Transaction being such, as is not likely to occur again in many Ages, and perhaps never.

The Act of Settlement of the Succession, in which those Things were specifically expressed, and by which the Measures of Conduct on both Sides were prescrib'd, had directed the Establish∣ment of a Regency, which upon the Demise of the last Heir in Possession, should take Place, and should be empower'd to act in the Name of the Successor, till the said Successor should ar∣rive, which Regency were to consist of seven of the chief Officers of the Crown, for the Time be∣ing, and such other Persons, as by an Instrument under the Hand and Seal of the Successor, should by Virtue of that Act be nominated and appoint∣ed; the said Instrument to be seal'd up in three several Parts, one Part to be committed to the Custody of such Persons as the said Act directs, not to be open'd till the Succession was to take Place; but least this Account should not fully describe this, because of the Constitution, and the Proceedings, I refer to the Words of the Sta∣tute, which are easily to be found.

Pursuant to this Act, an Instrument in Form was sign'd, in three Parts, by the Elector of Han∣over, and was committed to the keeping of the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Lord Chancellor, and Monsieur Kreyenberg, then Resident here from the Elector; and these Persons severally produ∣cing the same in Council, the said Council being met at St. James's; as soon as the Queen's Death
was known, the Regency was immediately known also, and took Place accordingly.

But it must be noted, That after the said Instru∣ments were read and receiv'd, and yet before the Lords Commission'd thereby, and by the Act of Settlement began to Act, the Lords of the Coun∣cil having invited, as is usual in such Cases, all the Nobility, Persons of Quality, the Lord-Mayor of London, and Principal Citizens to joyn with them, proceeded to proclaim the King; and this not only by Form of a Proclamation, but by the reading the said Proclamation with Sound of Trumpet, at the Gate of the Palace; and so on in all the usual Places of the City: All the said Nobility and Persons of Note attending in Ca∣valcade, as usual; which also was attended with the usual Acclamations of the People, and fol∣low'd by the like Publick Proclaiming the King all over the Kingdom.
The Proclamation with the Names annex'd to it, is as follows,

WHEREAS it hath pleased Almighty God to call to his Mercy, our late Sovereign Lady Queen Ann, of Blessed Memory, by whose Decease the Imperial Crowns of Great Britain, France and Ire∣land, are solely, and rightfully come to the High and Mighty Prince, GEORGE, Elector of Brunswick-Lunenburg: We therefore the Lords Spiritual and Temporal of the Realm, being here assisted with these of Her late Majesty's Privy Council, with Numbers of other Principal Gentlemen of Quality, with the Lord-Mayor, Aldermen, and Citizens of London; do now hereby, with en full Voice, and Consent of Tangue, and Heart, Publish and Proclaim, That the High and Mighty Prince, GEORGE, Elector of Brunswick-Lunenburg,
is now by the Death of our late Sovereign of Happy Memory, become our only Lawful and Right∣ful Liege Lord. GEORGE, By the Grace of God, King of Great Britain, France and Ireland, Defen∣der of the Faith, &c. To whom we do acknowledge all Faith, and constant Obedience, with all hearty and humble Affection; beseeching God, by whom Kings and Queens reign, te bless the Royal King GEORGE, with long and happy Years to Reign over us.
Given at the Palace of St. James's, the first Day of August, 1714
God save the King.

From, and immediately upon this, the Lords Justices, or Lords of the Regency, began to act; and the first Matter of Note, proper to the pre∣sent purpose, which came before them, was to dispatch their Orders into Scotland to have the like Proclamation published there, according to the Usage of the Kingdom; which was perform'd accordingly, by the Orders of the Earl of Isla, then Lord Justice General of Scotland; the Duke of Montross, one of the Lords of the Regency, be∣ing present, and at the Head of the procession. This was the 4th of August.
The Proclamation there, I omit for want of room here, as also not being so absolutely need∣ful, it being the same, Mutatis Mutandis, as the above Proclamation for England; to which I refer.

The same Measures were taken for Proclaming the King in Ireland: And such speed the Messen∣gers made, and so good a Passage they had, that the Orders of the Lords of the Regency arrived at Dublin the 6th, and the King was immediately Proclaimed there, with all the usual Solemnity, and with the same Proclamation Mutatis Mutandis as above.

Due Measures having thus been taken for Pro∣claiming the King in all Parts of his Dominini∣ons, the Lords of the Regency proceeded in the necessary Administration of the executive Power;
and first they dispatch'd the proper Military Offi∣cers to their respective Posts, in all Parts of the Kingdom, in order to preserve the Peace, and to be ready upon every Exigence for the Defence of the Places they had in Charge. The Garrisons upon the Coast were also order'd to be reinforced by Detachments of Troops, particularly that of Portsmouth and Shereness, as the Two Keys of the Royal Navy; And Vessels were order'd, one to View the Sea Ports of France, to see if any Arma∣ment was in hand there, or any Preparations at which Umbrage might be taken; but they report∣ed, That all was quiet there, and no appearance of any Preparations of any kind.

These Orders being issued, they chose Mr. Ad∣dison, the same who has since been made Secretary of State, to be Secretary of the Regency, and order∣ed all the Dispatches directed to the Secretaries of State to be sent to him, superceding thereby the Offices of the Lord Bolingbroke and Mr. Bromley, who were Secretaries of State at the time of the Queen's Decease, and continued in the Office of Secretary by Vertue of the Act of Parliament for Six Months.

On the 5th they Issued a Proclamation for Con∣tinuing all Persons in their Employments and Of∣fices, till his Majesty's Pleasure should be farther known, appointing them to take the Oaths re∣quir'd by Act of Parliament, and to perform such other Things as the Law requir'd them to per∣form, to qualifie them for keeping their said Posts respectively.

And that we may take all things with us as we go, it must be observ'd, That pursuant to the Act of Settlement, which appoints that the Parlia∣ment in Being, at the Demise of the Prince, shall
immediately assemble, without any Summons or Call, in the same manner as if they were not un∣der any Prorogation or Adjournment: I say, Pur∣suant to the said Act, the Parliament assemembled, that is to say, as many Members as were at hand, the very same day that the Queen died. It took them up some time to requallifie their Members; du∣ring which Interval, the Speaker, Mr.—, be∣ing then absent in the Country, had Notice sent him by Express, and came up Post to the House, where he appear'd the 4th; so the House being constituted, the Lords of the Regency went in a Body the next day to the Upper-House, and the Commons being sent for, the Lord Chancellor made, or rather read, the following Speech to both Houses: I say Read, because the Contents were perus'd, approv'd, and the Expressions limi∣ted, in the Council of the Regency, before they went up. The Speech is as follows,

P.Q: My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.HI: IT is with great Satisfaction we can now tell you, That we have this Morning received a Letter from the King, wherein his Majesty is graciously pleased to acquaint us, That his Majesty is hastening hither to employ his utmost Care for putting these Kiagdoms into a happy and flourishing Condition.

He has commanded us in the mean time, to continue our Care of every thing that may conduce to the Peace and Safety of his Dominions: And we are assured, That if this had required his more immediate Presence, he would without delay have repaired hither for the Sup∣port of so Dutiful and Faithful Subjects: For his Majesty does very particularly express his great Satis∣faction in the Loyalty and Affection which his People have universally shewn upon his Majesty's Accession to the Crown

At the opening this Session, we did not mention to you the Apprehensions we then had from the Smallness of the Sum at that time advanced, that the Lottery would not be full, being desirous in the first place to try to make it effectual in the manner the Parliament had established it; but we are obliged now to acquaint you, That all our Endeavours have failed of the desired Success, tho' the Contributions have been thereby conside∣rably increased.

DIV2.P: We must therefore earnestly recommend to you, Gen∣tlemen of the House of Commons, to take this into your Consideration, and to give such further Encourage∣ment as you shall think proper for raising the whole Sum which was intended, and is absolutely necessary for car∣rying on the Service of the Year.

The Loyal Proceedings of this Parliament, their readiness in Concurring with every Proposal made to them for the Publick Good, the Unanimity in which they acted in every thing for the King's In∣terest, was such, as that tho' few Writers have done Justice to them, yet the most prejudiced have not been able to fasten the least Omission or Commis∣sion upon them, or upon their Behaviour, or so much as told us why they have been so unwilling to do them that Justice which so needful and sea∣sonable an adherence to the King's Interest re∣quir'd.

I have nothing to do to enquire here whether or no the Complaint was just, which some have made of this Parliament's being treated with disrespect; or that the Returns made them were not suitable to the Zeal and Alacrity which they shew'd for his Majesty's Interest; it is enough to re∣cord their Dutiful and Affectionate Behaviour to the King's Interest, and to that of his
Succession; and let other Enquire concerning the Returns which were made them.

Certainly whoever shall Read the Proceedings of the short Session of Parliament in which they acted, will own that they omitted nothing on their Part, to testify their Duty and Affection to King George, or for securing his Interest and the Publick Peace in every part: And because this Point has been so little dwelt upon, it may be needful, and Justice seems to require it, that I should be as particular in this Case as the Brevity of this work will admit.

Upon the Return of the Commons to their House, and taking a Speech into Consideration, they immediately resolved Nemine Contradicente that an humble Address should be presented to his Majesty, to Condole and Congratulate, &c. And the Lords at the same Time resolv'd upon ano∣ther: Both which Addresses were presented to the Lords of the Regency, and were by them transmitted to the King. The Addresses were as follows, (viz.)

P.HI: Most Gracious Sovereign,

WE your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal Subjects, the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, though deeply sensible of the great Loss these Nations have sustained by the Demise of her late Ma∣jesty of blessed Memory, think it our Duty at the same time, with thankful Hearts to Almighty God, to con∣gratulate your Majesty upon your happy and peaceable Accession to your Throne: And we do with the utmost Loyalty and Duty assure your Majesty of our zealous and firm Resolutions to Support your undoubtedly Right∣ful and Lawful Title to the Crown, against all Enemies and Pretenders whatsoever.

Our Zeal and Affection for Your Majesty's Service, engage us to exert our selves with all Vigour and Una∣nimity for securing the publick Safety: And we will always, to the utmost of our Power, maintain the Ho∣nour and Dignity of Your Crown. And we do with faithful Hearts, beseech Your Majesty, as soon as possi∣ble, to give us Your Royal Presence; which we are per∣swaded will be attended with all other Blessings to Your Kingdom.

Q.P: Most Gracious Sovereign,

WE Your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal Sub∣jects the Commons of Great Britain in Parlia∣ment assembled, having a just Sense of the great Loss the Nation has sustain'd by the Death of our late Sove∣reign Lady Queen Anne of Blessed memory, humbly crave Leave to condole with Your Majesty on this sad Occasion.

It would but aggravate our Sorrow particularly, to enumerate the Virtues of that Pious, and most Excellent Princess, The Duty we owe to Your Majesty, and to our Country, oblige us to moderate our Grief, and heartily to Congratulate Your Majesty's Accession to the Throne; whose Princely Virtues give us a certain Pros∣pect of future Happiness in the Security of our Religion, Laws, and Liberties; and engage us to assure Your Majesty, that we will to our utmost, support Your un∣doubted Right to the Imperial Crown of this Realm against the Pretender, and all other Persons whatso∣ever.
Your faithful Commons cannot but express their im∣patient Desire for Your Majesty's safe Arrival and Pre∣sence in Great Britain.

P.HI: In the mean Time, we humbly lay before Your Maje∣sty, the unanimous Resolution of this House to maintain

tho publick Credit of the Nation; and effectually to make good all Funds which have been granted by Parliament for the Security of any Money which has been, or shall be advanc'd for the publick Service; and to endeavour by every thing in our Power, to make Your Majesty's Reign Happy and Glorious.

DIV2.P: The King receiving these Addresses with an agreeable and gracious Acceptance, return'd the following Answers.

Q.P: GEORGE R.
I Take this first Opportunity to return you my hearty Thanks for your Address, and the Assurances you have given me therein.

P.HI: The Zeal and Unanimity you have shewn upon my Accession to the Crown, are great Encouragements to me, and I shall always esteem the Continuance of them, as one of the greatest Blessings of my Reign.

No one can be more truly sensible, than I am, of the Loss sustain'd by the Death of the late Queen, whose exemplary Piety and Virtues so much endeared Her to Her People, and for whose Memory I shall always have a particular Regard.

My best Endeavours shall never be wanting to repair this Loss to the Nation; I will make it my constant Care to preserve your Religion, Laws, and Liberties, inviolable, and to advance the Honour and Prosperity of my Kingdoms.
I am hastening to you, according to your Desire, so affectionately express'd in your Address.

Q.P: GEORGE R.

YOUR Dutiful and Loyal Address is very accep∣table to me, the Unanimity, and Affections my Commons have shewn upon my Accession to the Crown, are most agreeable Instances and Pledges of their Fide∣lity to me. I have a just sence of your inexpressible Loss, by the Death of your late Sovereign; you may be assured of my constant Endeavours to secure to you the full Enjoyment of your Religion, Laws, and Liberties; and that it will always be my Aim, to make you a hap∣py and flourishing People; to which your Resolution to maintain the publick Credit of the Nation, will greatly contribute. I am hastening to you, according to your earnest Desire, and the just Expectations of my Peo∣ple.

DIV2.P: These Matters of Ceremony being over, the Commons fell immediately to taking into Conside∣ration the Speech of the Lord Chancellor in the Name of the Regency, and came to several vigorous Reso∣lutions for the publick Service, particularly, they immediately Voted the Bill of Supply for the Sup∣port of His Majesty's Houshold, and the Honour and Dignity of the Crown, that is, in a few Words, the Civil List Bill. This was perticularly ordered to be the same that the Queen Enjoy'd, that is to say, 700000 l. per Annum, and to begin from the Death of the Queen, only with Exception to the Revenues of the Dutchy of Cornwall, which are vested by Law in the Person of the Prince, as Duke of Cornwall.

This Bill met with such a hearty Concurrence in the House, and was so unanimously carry'd on, that tho' it was the 7th of August when it was
first mov'd, it was finish'd, pass'd through both Houses, and receiv'd the Royal Assent the 14th.

But before I give an Account of that, I must observe, that on the 13th Mr. Craggs, Jun. the same who, at the time of the writing this Hi∣story, is one of the Secretarys of State, and who had been dispatch'd by some Persons, as above, the Evening before the Queen's Death, to give the King an account of Things, return'd from Hano∣ver, and brought the King's Letter to the Lords of the Regency; upon which, the said Regents came the same Day to the House, and the Lord Chancellor, in their Names, as before, made the following Speech to both Houses.

Q.P: My Lords, and Gentlemen,

IT hath pleased Almighty God, to take to himself our late most gracious Queen, of Blessed Memory, we hope that nothing has been omitted which might contribute to the Safety of these Realms, and the Preservation of our Religion, Laws, and Liberties, in this great Con∣juncture. As these invaluable Blessings have been se∣cured to us by those Acts of Parliament which have settled the Succession of these Kingdoms in the most Illustrious House of Hanover, we have regulated our Proceedings from those Rules which are therein prescrib'd.

The Privy-Council, soon after the Demise of the late Queen, Assembled at St. James's, where according to the said Acts, the three Instruments were produc'd and open'd, which had been deposited in the Hands of the Arch-Bishop of Canterbury, the Lord Chancellor, and the Resident of Brunswick. Those who either by their Office, or by Virtue of these Instruments, had the Honour of being appointed Lords Justices, did in Conjunction with the Council, immediately proceed to the Proclaim∣ing
of our Lawful, and Rightful Sovereign King GEORGE, taking at the same time, the necessary Care to maintain the publick Peace.

P.HI: In pursuance of the Acts, before-mention'd, this Parliament is now assembled, and we are perswaded you all bring with you so hearty a Disposition for His Majesty's Service, and the public-Good, that we can∣not doubt of your Assistance in every thing which may promote those great Ends.

Q.P: Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

P.HI: We find it necessary to put you in mind that several Branches of the publick Revenue are expired, by the De∣mise of Her late Majesty, and to recommend to you the making such provisions in that Respect, as may be requisite to support the Honour and Dignity of the Crown. And we assure our selves, you will not be wanting in any thing that may conduce to the establishing, and advanc∣ing of the publick Credit.

Q.P: My Lords, and Gentlemen,

P.HI: We forbear laying before you any Thing that does not require your immediate Consideration, not having re∣ceiv'd His Majesty's Pleasure. We shall only exhort you, with the greatest Earnestness, to a perfect Una∣nimity, and a firm Adherance to our Sovereign's In∣terest, as being the only Means to continue among us our present happy Tranquillity.

DIV2.P:
Upon this Speech, the Houses severally Voted Addresses of Thanks, and Assurances of Loyalty; the Vote of the House of Commons run thus, to re∣turn the Humble Thanks of the House to His Ma∣jesty, for the Satisfaction his Majesty has been pleas'd to express in the Humble Duty and Affecti∣on which His Loyal Commons have unanimously
shewn upon His happy Accession to the Throne; and for His gracious Assurances of His Royal In∣tentions, to make His People speedily happy by his Presence; assuring His Majesty of the continu∣ance, of their Zeal for His Service, and Affection to his Person and Government, upon all Occasi∣ons; and that they would contribute their utmost Endeavours for preserving the publick Tranquili∣ty, until His Majesty shall arrive.
This Address was also order'd to be presented to the Regents, in order to be transmitted to His Majesty. The Lord's Address was also to the same Purpose.

These Matters of Ceremony being dispatch'd, the House proceeded to take into Consideration the Lottery Bill, this Lottery it seems, being laid in the Ministry of the late Lord Treasurer, the Earl of Oxford, at a Currant Interest but of 4 per Cent. and the able Hand that undertook it at that Rate, and would no Question have carry'd it through, as he had done other things more difficult by far than that, being withdrawn, and displac'd; the Job∣bers and mony'd Men in the City blow'd upon it; and notwithstanding, the Court and all its Dependencies, on that critical Occasion, for∣warded the Subscription in a publick Manner, going down in a Body to the City to Subscribe, by which Means a very great Sum of Money was Subscrib'd; yet there being still several hundred thousand Pounds wanting, the Lords of the Re∣gency found it absolutely necessary to lay it before the House, who immediately pass'd an Act to raise the Interest from 4 to 5 per Cent. upon the Subscription: And this gave Life to the Business, and the Money was subscrib'd in a few Hours, with the greatest Allacrity possible.

Both these Bills, viz. That of the Civil List, and this of adding 1 per Cent. Interest to the Lot∣tery, together with a Bill for rectifying some Mistakes in the Names of the Commissioners of the Land-Tax, were all pass'd and ready for the Royal Assent by the 17th, which, as was even then observ'd, was such a Testimony of the Zeal. Chearfulness and Steadiness of that Parliament in the Service and Interest of the King, as de∣serves to be recorded to Posterity, together with the open Testimony which the King himself gave to their Loyalty and Affection in all his Majesty's Letters and Answers, and on all Occasions where∣in he thought fit to make mention of them. How it came to pass afterwards, that some People en∣deavour'd to represent this very House of Commons as dangerous and disaffected, and to lessen the Re∣putation of their Conduct, I know not, or at least care not to enquire; nor is this said, to lead the Reader to any Reflections upon the sudden Dissolu∣tion of the House afterwards, even without giving them the Honour of seeing the King's Face among them, for whose Interest they had so heartily em∣bark'd: all those things I leave as they come to Hand, for every one to judge of as they think sit.

However the Commons have not left themselves without a Testimony of their own Behaviour, in that eminent Speech which the Speaker made at the Bar of the House of Lords, when he presented the Bills abovenam'd, to the Lords the Regents, for the Royal Assent; in which the Speaker boldly asserts, the Zeal and Fidelity of the House of Commons; and is not afraid, even to make some Pretences to it, from the Pledge or Earnest which he brought then to his Majesty, as well of what was past, as of
their Resolution to continue it, and to recom∣mend it to his Majesty for his Acceptance. But I refer to the Speech it self, as follows, viz.

Q.P: My Lords,

THE Knights, Citizens and Burgesses of Great Britain, in Parliament assembled, under the present Happiness they enjoy by His Majesty's peaceable and quiet Accession to the Throne, could not enter upon any Work more satisfactory and pleasing to themselves, than the providing a sufficient Revenue for the Occasi∣ons of His Majesty's Civil Government, in order to make His Reign as easie and prosperous, as the Begin∣ning of it hath been secure and undisturb'd.

They are sensible, that the Peace of the Kingdom is not to be preserv'd, nor the Rights and Liberties of the Subjects to be protected, without supporting the just Au∣thority and Dignity of the Crown; and therefore they have thought it their Interest, as well as Duty, to make such a Provision as may not barely suffice to the Necessity of the Government, but may be suitable to the State, the Honour, and the Luster which the Crown of Great Britain ought to be attended with.

P.HI: Whatsoever is superfluous in that Provision, and more than the ordinary Services of His Majesty shall require, will but enable Him to exert His highest and most va∣luable Prerogative of doing Good; And we can give no greater Proof of the Trust we repose in His Majesty's gracious Disposition, than putting the same entire Revenue into His Hands, which Her late Majesty died possess'd of; whose Virtues we all admir'd, and of whose Affection and Concern for the Religion, Laws, and Liberties of this Kingdom, we had had so long Experi∣ence.

Q.P: As the Crown it self descends immediately, and knows no Vacancy, the Commons have taken Care, that the Revenue should follow it as close as possible; for they have given all the Dispatch to this Grant which the Forms of their Proceedings would allow; So that when His Majesty shall please to answer the Impatient Desires of His People, by coming to take Possession of His Kingdoms, he will find Himself equally establish'd in these Revenues, as if he had succeeded to all by an uninterrupted Right of Inheritance: The only Difference is this, That if he had inherited them, he would have wanted one single Proof of the Duty, and Affection, and Unanimity of His Subjects.

Our desire is, That this may be look'd upon as an Earnest and a Pledge of that Zeal and Fidelity which we shall always retain, and which, upon every Occa∣sion, we shall be ready to demonstrate to His Majesty's Person and Government: As such, we hope His Maje∣sty will graciously accept it at this Time; and here∣after, when He shall have had Experience of this first voluntary Offering of His Loyal Commons, we hope He will find it to His Satisfaction, as large and as ample as He could wish; might but the Term of the Grant be as long as we could wish; since it is to have equal Con∣tinuance with His Majesty's Life.
My Lords,

The Bill which the Commons have pass'd for the Purposes I have mention'd, is intituled, An Act for the better Support of His Majesty's Houshold, and of the Honour and Dignity of the Crown of Great Britain.

They have also prepar'd another Bill, as well for rectifying Mistakes in the Names of the Commis∣sioners for the Land-Tax, as for raising so much as is wanting to make up the Sum of Fourteen
Hundred Thousand Pounds, intended to be raised by a Lottery, for the publick Service in the Year 1724. This having been recommended to their Care, and appearing to them to be necessary for His Majesty's and the publick Service, they have Reason to think they have now abundantly supply'd the Defects in the former Provision; and in this Assurance, they humbly present this Bill also for the Royal Assent.

I add here, and to confirm the Character of this Parliament, the Acknowledgment return'd by the Regents to the Parliament for all this which was given in the King's Name; when the Bills being Presented and Sign'd, the Houses were Adjourn'd to the 25th.
My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.HI: WE cannot but express our greatest Satisfaction, and, in His Majesty's Name, return you Thanks, for the convincing Proofs which you have given, in this Session, of your Duty and Affection to His Majesty, and of your Zeal for His Government.

Q.P: We must particularly thank you, Gentlemen of the House of Commons, for the Aids which you have granted to His Majesty, for the better Support of the Honour of the Crown, and for preventing any Disappointment in the Supplies given in the last Session for the Service of this Year. You may be assur'd, that the Unanimity, the Cheerfulness, and the Dispatch with which you have proceeded in granting these Aids, will render them yet more acceptable to His Majesty. And you may depend upon our making a faithful Representation thereof to Him.
My Lords and Gentlemen,

All necessary Business being now happily concluded, it will be proper for us to put a speedy End to this Session. We think fit, at present, in His Majesty's Name, to desire you forthwith respectively to Ad∣journ your selves until Wednesday next.

DIV2.P: At the Return of the House, the King's An∣swer to the Addresses above-mention'd, was pre∣sented to the Houses by the Secretary of State, and then the Houses were Prorogu'd to the 23d of September, and in a Word, never sat more.

The Reasons the King had for Dissolving this Loyal House of Commons, which had given such Testimonies of their Zeal for the Interest, and Person of the King, were variously spoken of; some reflecting on the House, some on other People: What I shall mention on this Account is, in short, this only, viz. 1. Whether the Reflections on the House, are just, or no? The past Account of their Proceedings, and of His Majesty's Re∣turn of Thanks to them, for their Loyalty, Zeal, and Affection, is a full and sufficient Answer. And 2. As to other Reflections, That Power, who only has, and ought to have a Right to Call, and Dissolve, without being accountable to any for so doing, did Dissolve them; and it is to be suppos'd might have Reasons for so doing, which it is none of my Business to enquire into.

I have been longer in this particular Trans∣action, than the Compass of this Work will al∣low in any other Session of Parliament, because of the remarkable Circumstances mention'd above; which as we shall meet with no more, so I shall make amends for this Excursion, in the Brevity of the rest.

The Regents having thus carry'd on their Busi∣ness, through the short Session of Parliament with Success; the Government began to settle, and e∣very thing went on smooth, and easy: The People were indeed a little Tumultuous, but it was at first rather on the Side of the Government, than against it. For not a Hand stirr'd, or offer'd to lift it self up against the Succession, or against the Administration. The Rabbles which were at all disturbing, were from some hot People who were willing to have shewn their Resentment at the Ministry of the late Reign their own Way, and those were not a little ex∣cited and stirr'd up to Disorder by the scurillous Li∣bels and Pamphlets publish'd at that time, reflecting upon the whole Proceedings of the Ministry, and Friends of the latter End of the late Reign, as one united, concerted Plot and Conspiracy against the Protestant Succession, and the Person of King GEORGE.

It is enough to mention these things as Matter of History, it is not my Business to debate with them, or about the Justice or Injustice of them. The first Evidence of the Truth of this, was in the Person of Mons. D' Ibberville, the French Resident here, who found himself oblig'd to apply himself to the Lords of the Regency, to protect him from the Insults of the Rabble; which they readi∣ly granted, ordering a Detachment of the Guards to do Duty at his House, for that Pur∣pose; and the said Mons. D' Ibberville, in return, assur'd the Regency, that his Master would give no Disturbance to the Establishment of His Majesty on the Throne: But would inviolably maintain the Ar∣ticles of the Treaty of Utrecht, which related to the Settlement of the Crown on the Illustrious House of Hanover. It was suggested, maliciously enough, by some, that Mons. D' Ibberville, did this with∣out
Orders, and even before he had receiv'd any Answer from France to the Account he had trans∣mitted thither of Her late Majesty's Death. But they who insinuated this spoke without Book; Mons. D' Ibberville having receiv'd an Express from France the Evening before, and they must under∣stand very little of the Duty of a publick Minister, or how punctually the King of France is serv'd on all Occasions, or have a very mean and unworthy Opinion of Mons. D' Ibberville, to suppose he would have made such a Declaration, in the Name of his Master, without particular Orders so to do: But this Reproach was immediately taken off from his Excellency by two concurring Testimo∣nies to the same Purpose; 1. That the Earl of Peterborough, who arriv'd in England the next Day, viz. the 7th of August, assur'd the Regency, that being at the French Court when the News of the Queens Death came thither, by Express from Mons. D' Ibberville, the King of France had sent for his Lordship, and had assur'd him of the same, from his own Mouth, and in the very same Words, or to the same Purpose, that Mons. D' Ibberville had done. 2. That Mr. Prior, then the British Resident at the Court of France, having notified the Death of the Queen to the French Court, had signified to the Lords of the Regency, that he had receiv'd Assurances in the like Terms from the King's own Mouth.

Besides all this, the Lords of the Regency, receiv'd a few Days after, a Letter from the French Court, Sign'd by his most Christian Majesty's own Hand to the same Purpose; importing farther, that the Elector of Brunswick, having some time before the Queen's Death, signify'd to his most Christian Majesty, that when ever his Succession should take place, he
would Cultivate a Friendship with his said Ma∣jesty; His said Majesty, on his part, assur'd the Lords of the Regency, that he would do all that lay in his Power, to maintain a good Intelligence and Amity between the two Crowns, and to pre∣serve the Treaty of Utrecht in all its Parts, and particularly in that part of it which related to the Renunciations, which he resolv'd to suffer no Al∣terations in, and that he had signify'd the same already to his Grandson King Philip.

As these things concurr'd to make the King's Affairs easie Abroad, the Necessity of the King's speedy coming over was not so great, as to hin∣der His Majesty from dispatching all such other Affairs in His German Dominions, as requir'd his stay. And this, no Question, the Lords of the Regency meant, in the Expressions to the Par∣liament, in the Speech mention'd above, which relates to this, viz. “We are assur'd, that if this, (viz. the Peace and Safety of his Dominions) had requir'd his more immediate Presence, he would, without the least Delay, have repair'd hither, for the Support of so dutiful and faith∣ful Subjects.” But all was quiet at Home, and clear Abroad, not a Hand mov'd, or Tongue spoke against the Succession of King GEORGE, either at Home, or Abroad: and his Majesty, except for the Appearance, might with the same Safety have come over, as an ordinary Passenger in the Pac∣quet-Boat, as with a Squadron of Men of War.

However, that His Majesty might have all things ready for His Voyage, when His Foreign Affairs were settled, and might have it in his Power to Embark when he pleas'd, and to Sail as His Occasions requir'd, Wind and Wea∣ther presenting. I say, For this Purpose, all the
Yachts were ordered to be got ready, with all pos∣ble speed, and a strong Squadron of Men of War, under the Command of the Earl of Berkley, was appointed for their Convoy, and such Expedition was used in this Equipment, that they arriv'd in Holland the 17th of August, and caus'd an Express to be sent to Hanover, to acquaint the King with his Arrival, and that he was there attending His Orders.

On Board the Yachts, were all the proper Officers of the Green-Cloth, whose Business it is to appoint the Kitchin, the Table, the Furniture, and Lodgings for the Royal House; and they had with them, all necessary Officers, and Provi∣sions accordingly, for the Use of the King and His Retinue.

While this was doing, the Lords of the Regency had before them, the ordinary Business of the Administration, which was all in perfect Order, nor did any thing uncommon, or difficult, or un∣usual occur to them; except such things as related to the placing or displacing some particular Men, in which they acted neither one way or other, but as they receiv'd positive Directions from the King: As to what was Extraordinary, the principal Thing before them, was the Funeral of Her late Majesty, and the Mourning on that Occasion.

Her Majesty Died on Sunday the 1st of August, in the Morning, as has been observ'd; on the Tuesday after, Her Body was open'd, and by the Re∣port of the Surgeons, all the Vitals, the Bowels, and Stomach, were exceeding sound and firm, and nothing was to be found there, which had any Symptoms of Disease; so that it was suppos'd the Cause of Her Death was to have been found in the Head, which Her Majesty having expresly
forbid to be open'd, the Surgeons ceas'd any far∣ther Enquiry: The Body was Embalm'd, and the Bowels buried the next Night, in the Royal Repository at Westminster. On Thursday the Earl Marshal publish'd an Order for a General Mourn∣ing, as usual in such Cases.

In the mean time, the Lords waited the King's Orders, for the Interment, which arriv'd soon af∣ter; Importing, that the Body should be Interr'd with all Decency and Magnificence, such as, how∣ever, was to consist with the Form of a pri∣vate Funeral; which was accordingly done the 24th of August.

It was intended to have buried Her Majesty the 22d, nor could I ever be inform'd of the true Reason why it was put off, and appointed the 24th, unless I should be so uncharitable as to judge, as some have said, that it was on Purpose so contriv'd, by designing Men, that the Funeral might be attended with all the unhapy Circum∣stances of that Day, which has been esteem'd among those we call Dies Infaustaus, being the Day of the Massacre of Paris, and the Day of the turning out the Dissenters from the Benefices they Injoy'd in the Church; which turning out they are pleas'd to call Persecution, and on that account to stile the Day, by the Name of Black Bartholomew. Nor should I have mention'd this, had it not been taken notice of by themselves, and the Memory of the Queen insulted on that very Account in a pub∣lick and detestable manner.

This Book being a History of the Reign of King GEORGE, allows not an Entrance into the Person and Character of the Queen, which must carry us back to things beyond the Beginning of our Work. But another Reason of
more Moment obliges me to leave that subject, viz. That I am inform'd it is doing at this Time by a Pen so much abler to do Her Majesty's Memory Justice, upon the scandalous Abuses of Her Cha∣racter and Conduct, and so much better acquain∣ted with the particular Circumstances of Her Reign, than those, who with Ignorance, equal to their Malice, have insulted and reproach'd Her; I think it therefore much better to omit any farther Enrance upon that Subject, except only this, that the Treatment Her Majesty's Memory has re∣ceiv'd from some People in this Reign, as well in Print, as otherwise, has not only been unjust and unworthy, but inimitably Rude; and such, as I believe, no Age can shew us the like in History: When at the same time, Malice it self cannot de∣ny Her Majesty to have been a Princess of spotless Vertue, fill'd with Charity and Clemency; of an universal Benignity and Goodness; of exemplary Piety, Tenderness, and Affection, for the Good, Peace, and Prosperity of Her People, unpara∣lell'd, and inimitable.

But I leave the ungrateful Subject, such a Queen so treated, obliges me indeed to call it so: I leave it, I say, and shall conclude all that relates to Her Majesty, in the following Account of Her Funeral.

Her Majesty's Body being thus Deposited, and the Counterfeit Mourning of many put on, the Hypocrisy of which they were not asham'd to ac∣knowledge; which, indeed, is my Authority for
into the Palace-Yard, and thence to the South-East Door of the Abby, one of the great Guns at the Tower firing every Minute, until Her Majesty was interr'd. The Royal Corps was born under a Canopy of Purple Velvet, preceded by a great Number of Her Servants, the Judges, Privy-Councellors, the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and the great Officers. The Pall was supported by Six Dukes. Her Grace the Dutchess of Or∣mond, (in the Absence of the Dutchess of Somer∣set, who was indispos'd) was chief Mourner, sup∣ported by the Dukes of Somerset and Richmond in long Cloaks, wearing their Collars of the Or∣der, her Train born by Two Dutchesses, assisted by the Vice-Chamberlain, and follow'd by Two other Dutchesses, at the Head of Fourteen Coun∣tesses as Assistants, all in long Veils of black Crape; and after them the Ladies of the Bed-Chamber, and the Maids of Honour in like Veils; then the Bed-Chamber Women, and the Gentlemen Pensioners, closed the Proceedings. At the Enterance into the Church, the Dean, Prebends and Choir re∣ceiv'd the Royal Body with an Anthem, and marching before Norroy, King of Arms, who car∣ried the Crown and Cushion, they proceeded singing to King Henry the Seventh's Chappel; where being arriv'd, the Body was deposited on Tressels, while the Service of the Church was perform'd by the Bishop of Rochester, Dean of Westminster, and afterwards interr'd in the same Vault, with King Charles the Second, King William, Queen Mary, and Prince George of Denmark.

Her Majesty's Body being thus Deposited, and the Counterfeit Mourning of many put on, the Hypocrisy of which they were not asham'd to ac∣knowledge; which, indeed, is my Authority for
making such mention of it. The Lords of the Re∣gency continu'd their necessary Care of the Admini∣stration, but waiting, as the Nation did also most im∣patiently, the King's Arrival, They acted nothing more than Duty and Necessity oblig'd them to, except what they receiv'd immediate and express Orders for from the King.

However, in Execution of those Orders some∣thing Extraordinary was then necessary, as parti∣cularly, a Patent was order'd to pass the Seals for Creating the Electoral Prince, the King's eldest and only Son, Prince of Wales, this was accord∣ingly prepared, and brought through all the ne∣cessary Steps, except Sealing with the Great Seal, which was, it seems, reserv'd for an Ho∣nour to the new Chancellor, which was to be, and as will be seen in its Place.

Also, at the same time, came over an Order to re∣move the Lord Bolingbroke from his Office of Secre∣tary of State, which was done with this Addition, as the Prelude to that noble Person's Misfortunes, viz. That by Order of the Lords of the Regen∣cy his Lordship's Papers were Seized, and his Office Sealed up. However, his Lordship receiv'd these Marks of the King's Displeasure with a becoming Decency, and even his Enemies do not charge him with Missbehaviour upon the Occasion. The Persons sent to him to demand the Seals from his Lordship, were the Dukes of Shrowsbury and Somerset, and the Lord Cowper, since made Chancellor; all the three which is something remarkable, having in a little time lain under the same Circumstances of being remov'd from all publick Employment, and afforded us Occa∣sion to mention them in this History on that Account.

The remaining Part of the time of this Regency af∣fords us more Matter of History from Abroad, than
at Home, the King having been thus Pro∣claim'd, and Establish'd on the Throne at Home had new Negotiations to set on Foot, and new Interests to cultivate Abroad, for the Secnrity of his Affairs, as King, and for the making proper Alliances, as King of Great Britain. And these took up much time.

The first thing the King Ordered was a publick Thanksgiving, or Te Deum to be Sung after the manner of the Lutheran Church, through all his forreign Dominions, for his Accession to the Throne. The next was to subjoyn Prayers to be made at the same time for his peaceable and prosperous Reign. After this follow'd the Congratulations of his own Subjects, the Nobility, and Persons of Quality who throng'd to Herenhausen, the King's Country Seat or Palace, where there was a very numerous Court, to felicitate his Majesty, and Kiss his Hand.

From these Ceremonies of the Court, they pro∣ceeded to those of the State, viz. To notify the King's Accession to the Crown, to all the Courts, Princes, and States of Europe, which was done as well by the Lords of the Regency, from London, in his Majesty's Name to some, as from the King himself to others; the Earl of Strafford at the Hague, Mr. Prior at Paris, notify'd it by Order of the Regency to the States-General, and to the Court of France, and both were receiv'd as pub∣lick Ministers of the Crown of Great Britain, at the respective Courts where they reside. Espe∣cially the Earl of Strafford, who was Ambassa∣dor and Plenipotentiary, and was continued in the same Post, by his Majesty's special Com∣mand from Hanover.

Between the King and the States-General, as well directly, as by the Hands of the said Earl of Scrafford, there pass'd several Civilities, tending to the Planting and Cultivating an indissoluble Friendship between His Majesty and that State. And the States-General in Compliment to His Majesty, ordered eight Men of War to attend and join the British Squadron for His Convoy, and by a Letter on purpose, solemnly Invited the King to pass through their Country in His Way to England. In Answer to which the King himself wrote them the following Letter, viz.

OPENER.SALUTE: High and Mighty Lords, most dear Friends and Allies.

LETTER.P:
THE Letter of the 15th Instant, which your High Mightinesses have written to Us, as our good Friends and Neighbours, has been delivered to Us by an Express. As nothing more agreeable could hap∣pen to Us, upon Our Accession to the Throne, than to receive from your High Mightinesses such obliging Assur∣ances of your good Intentions for Us, and the publick Good; so nothing is wanting in our Acknowledgment in that Respect, and in the high Esteem We have for your High Mightinesses, and your Friendship. Your High Mightinesses are to be entirely perswaded, that seeing it has pleased God to call Us to the Throne of Great Britain, We shall make it one of our most serious Applications, to embrace all Opportunities to acknow∣ledge, by all possible Means, what you have done for Us, on this Occasion; to contribute to the strengthening and Increase of your Prosperity, and Security, and that of your Republick; to live with you in an indissoluble Union; to concur with a Concert of Zeal and Forces to the Preservation of the Protestant Religion, and the
Liberty of Europe; and to support and second the laudable Intentions of your High Mightinesses. Upon Our Arrival in Holland, where, with the Assistance of God, We intend to be in a few Days, We shall have the Satisfaction, in a more ample manner, to con∣firm all this to your High Mightinesses, by Word of Mouth. We thank you in a particular Manner for your obliging Invitation, and are much obliged to you for the same. We remain, High and Mighty Lords, Your Affectionate for ever, &c.

DIV2.P: The Princes and States to whom the King no∣tify'd his Accession to the Crown, more immedi∣ately from himself, were, first, The King of Prussia, then the Emperor, and afterwards the several other Princes of Germany, including the King of Poland, the King of Denmark, and the like. And now His Majesty prepared to leave His Domini∣ons in Germany, where he Establish'd a Council of Twelve, with Orders to have some of their Body always in Great Britain, to receive Instructions, and expedite the Dispatches necessary for the Administration of their Affairs.

In return to the Notices of this great Affair, the Court of Hanover was immediately throng'd with Princes, Envoys of Princes, Deputies, Persons of the first Rank for Royalty, and Nobility, who came to take part in the Joy of the Court, Con∣gratulate, and take Leave of the King. The Concourse was so great, that the King was oblig'd to put off His Departure for some Days, even when all things else were ready. In a Word, on the 30th of August Old Stile, the Nobility attend∣ing
on the King began to set out from Hanover, and the next Day the King Himself follow'd ac∣compained by the Prince of Wales, and having appointed the Princess, with her Family, to come some time after News should be return'd that the King was safe Arrived. The Persons ap∣pointed to attend the King in his Journey, were thus.

LIST.ITEM: Baron Bernsdorf, First Minister of State.
Baron de Goritz, President of the Finances, i. e. Lord High Treasurer.
Baron de Kilmanseg, Master of the Horse.
Baron de Hattorf, Councellor of War.
Mons. Schraden, Secretary of the Embassies.
Mons. Hammerstein, Gentleman of the Bed-Chamber.
Mons. Kempe, ditto to the Prince, with Two other Gentlemen of the Bed-Chamber, to each.
Two Valets, or Pages of the Chamber, which some say are two Turks.

DIV2.P:
On the last of August Old Stile, the King be∣gan his Journey, with the Prince his Son, and lay that Night at Doepenau, the next Day through Osnaburgh to Ippenburgh, on the 2d of September to Twickell, where they were Entertain'd by Count d' Opdam; and on the 3d to Voorst, a Town and
County belonging to the Earl of Albemarle; On the 4th, He was received by the Deputies of the States-General, appointed to Compliment Him upon their Frontiers, and that same Night the King enter'd the said Territories of the States-General, and went on to Utrecht; where they only staid to receive the Compliment of the States of that Province, and going on Board a Yacht appointed by the States to receive them, reached as far as Woorden that Night: Here His Majesty was again received by the Earl of Albe∣marle, and the Deputies of the States of Holland, and was Saluted with 54 Pieces of Cannon, being as many as he was Years Old.

On the 5th the King went into the Earl of Al∣bemarle's Coach, His Attendants following in other Coaches, and a Detachment of the Horse Guards appointed to attend Him to Ley∣den, where he was again Saluted with 54 Guns, and making no Stay there, arriv'd at 5 a Clock at Night at the Hague.

Here he was attended by a solemn Deputation from the States-General, to welcome His Majesty and the Prince into their Country, and His Court was throng'd with the British Nobility and Gentry, who had crowded over thither upon the Occasion; and here his Majesty held a very great and magnificent Court; here His Majesty was waited on by, and gave Audience to all the Foreign Ambassadors: Such as the Duke d' Ossuna, Ambassador of Spain; the Marquis de Chateau∣neuf, Ambassador of France; the Count de Tarouca, Ambassador of Portugal; and others.

In the Middle of these Ceremonies, several Matters of State were concerted by His Majesty's Direction, with the States General. And News
of the grand Affair of the Peace being concluded between France and the Emperor, at Baden, Crown'd the Assembly.

The King continu'd at the Hague till the 16th of September Old Stile, when the Wind presenting fair, the whole Retinue embark'd, the King went on Board the Peregrine Yacht, Capt. Saunderson Commander; the Prince in the William and Mary, and having a very fair Wind, they Weighed imme∣diately, and Stood out to Sea, the Squadron of English and Dutch Men of War, 15 in all, joyning them at the Mouth of the Mase; they were but one Night at Sea, for in the Morning early, the Men of War came into the Mouth of the Thames, in Sight of Margat; and as the Weather was exceed∣ing Pleasant, the Sea smooth, and the Wind fair, the King order'd the Yachts to go on, declining to go on Shore: That same Evening, the Yachts with the King reach'd to the Hope, below Gravesend, where the Men of War came to an Anchor. And it being a thick Fog, the King lay on Board all Night; the next Day, about Noon, the Yachts weighed, and came up as high as Long-reach, where Night coming on, the King and Prince went into their Barges, and came to Greenwich that Evening, where they Landed about six a Clock, having been met by an infinite Throng of People, in Boats upon the River, even quite as low as Gravesend, encreasing still, as they came nearer the Town, and by a Prodigious Crow'd on Shore; who, it being too Dark to distinguish the King, were greatly disappointed.

The Ceremonies of the meeting, and Reception of the King, and the Acclamations of the People, being always such, on such Occasions, must be past over here; they are too long to give a parti∣cular
Account of, in this Work, nor are they Es∣sential to our Business. But some Account of this two Nights Court at Greenwich, is absolutely necessary to the Story in Hand, for here, and in this short time, are said to begin all those Steps which have been, if some say true, the main Spring and Occasion of all the Mischiefs which happen'd since.

The Moment His Majesty set his Foot on Shore upon English Ground, the Commission of the Regency Dissolv'd of Course, and the Executive Power no longer to be exercis'd by Deputation, revolv'd immediately upon His Majesty's own Hands.

This had been long'd for many Days, and it may be truly said, that the Nation in General wish'd earnestly for the King's Coming; not that the Regency acted out of their Duty. But it could be no Reproach to them, to say that it was not doubted, but, that when the King came to take the Administration into His own Hands, it would be better, and that their Management might be called indifferent compared to those Shoulders on which, fitted by Nature, the Load of Govern∣ment was appointed to be laid: In which Case one said at that time.

Q.L: Great GEORGE, what Weights must on thy Shoulders lye,

L.HI: Which Six and Twenty Kings so ill Supply?

DIV2.P:
The Particulars of the King's Reception in foreign Parts, as he pass'd to the Sea Side to Embark, the Speeches and Compliments made to him at the Hague, and in other Places, before he arriv'd there, are too many and too remote from
the Design of this Work also to be plac'd here; be∣ing sufficiently touch'd at already, I come at once to the King's more immediate Administration.

The Evening that the King Arriv'd, no Busi∣ness was done, the King being fateigu'd, if I may call it so, with Ceremony, as well as with the Voyage, Dismiss'd the Court early, and retired into His Apartments; some indeed were admit∣ted there, but they were only such select Persons, who it was apparent shar'd of His Majesty's particular Favour and Confidence.

The first Act of Government the King exerted, at least which was publick, was a Message sent by the Lord Townshend to the Duke of Ormond, to this Purpose, viz. That the King had no longer Occasion for his Service, in the Quality of Captain General of the Army; it is said, that it was further added, to shew some Respect, that however, the King would be glad to see him at Court. But how true that may be, I do not affirm.

It is not much doubted, but as this Step was taken the first Night of the King's Arrival, so the whole Scheme of the new Ministry was settled there also, the next Day; seeing it was easy to discover, the next Morning, when the King shew'd himself in the Apartments, who were IN, tho' not so evidently who were OUT.

About 10 a Clock the King came out of His Bed-Chamber, and appear'd in open Court, which was at that time, promiscuously throng'd with the Nobility, and Gentry, of every Denomina∣tion; who had, without Exception, the Honour to Kiss His Majesty's Hand. Yet, as above, though all were admitted, it was no hard thing to distinguish who had the Honour to be more immediately acceptable.

It was even there also known, tho' not parti∣cularly declar'd, that the Duke of Marlborough was to have the Battoon, or Command of the Army; that Mr. W—would be at the Head of the Treasury; that the Lord Townshend would have the Seals of Office, as Secretary of State; and also, that the Lord Cowper would be made Lord Chan∣cellor: The Duke of Argyle, who had now recon∣cil'd himself with the Duke of Marlborough, ap∣pear'd next to the Prince, as the other did next the King.

In this manner Things went those two Nights, when all Matters seem'd to receive some Interrup∣tion by the necessary Dispositions which were to be made for the Royal Entry, or the Cavalcade through the City, which was appointed for Mon∣day the 20th of September. The Earl Marshal was consulted, for the Order of this Entry, and Di∣rections given him to issue out his Orders for the Precedency, and manner of the Procession, which was accordingly done. And is as follows:

Q.P: WHERE AS the Solemnity of the King's Roy∣al Entry from Greenwich, through the City of London, to His Royal Palace of St. James's, is appointed to be on Monday the 20th of this Instant September,; This is therefore to give Notice to all the Nobility, and others, who are to attend the King in their Coaches, that they repair to Greenwich Park, so as to be there by Ten of the Clock that Morn∣ing at farthest; where their Coaches will be put in Order by the Officers of Arms appointed for that Purpose.

And that the Lord-Mayor, Aldermen, Recorder, and Sheriffs of London, with such as have serv'd or fin'd for Aldermen or Sheriffs of the said City; the City
Officers, and the Detachment of the Artillery-Com∣pany; as also the Knight Marshal's Men, the King's Kettle Drums and Trumpets, the King's Heralds, and Serjeant at Armes, the Gentleman-Usher of the black Rod, and the Officers and Yeomen of His Maje∣shy's Guards, amp;c. do meet in Southwark, about Twelve of the Clock, and extend themselves in the Order they are to March from the Foot of London-Bridge to St. Margaret's-Hill, and there wait His Majesty's Arrival; and so soon as Notice is given that the Coaches are coming into Kent-Street, they are all to be marshalled in their due Order by the Officers of Arms.

DIV2.P: Accordingly on the 20th of September, the King made His Entry through the City, with the usual Form, and with all the Tokens of a most joyful Reception; the Particulars of the Ceremony are too tedious for this Work, in which I hasten to things of the greatest Consequence.

The next Morning, there was a numerous Throng of the Nobility and Gentry, to pay their Compliments, and to Kiss the King's Hand, as also the Ministers of France, Sicily, Prussia, Po∣land, Portugal, and others; the same Day in the Evening the Privy-Council assembled, where His Majesty appear'd, and took the Oath, and sub∣scrib'd the Instrument of Security relating to the Church of Scotland, as requir'd by Law, the Lord's of the Council present, Signing the same as Witnesses; there were Duplicates of the Instru∣ment sign'd, one whereof was entered in the Books of the Council, and lodg'd in the Records here, and the other sent down to be preserv'd in the publick Register in Scotland, and to be enter'd in the Books of the Court of Session there, which is,
what they call their College of Justice. After this, the King made the following Declaration to the Council, and in a full Meeting. And the Lords, in Return, requested that it might be made pub∣lick, which was order'd accordingly. And is as follows, viz.

P.HI: HAving in my Answers to the Addresses of both Houses of Parliament, fully express'd my Reso∣lution to defend the Religious and Civil Rights of all My Subjects, there remains very little for me to say up∣on this Occasion.

Q.P: Yet being willing to omit no Opportunity of giving all possible Assurances to a People, who have already deserved so well of Me; I take this Occasion also, to express to you my firm Purpose to do all that is in My Power, for the Supporting and Maintaining the Churches of England and Scotland, as they are severally by Law Establish'd; which, I am of Opini∣on, may be effectually done, without the least im∣pairing the Toleration, allowed by Law to Protestant Dissenters, so agreeable to Christian Charity, and so necessary to the Trade and Riches of this King∣dom.

P.HI: The good Effects of making Property secure are no where so clearly seen, and to so great a Degree, as in this Happy Kingdom; and I assure you, That there is not any among you, shall more earnestly Endeavour the Preservation of it than My self.

DIV2.P:
The same time, the King nam'd several new Privy-Councellors, as first the Prince, who was introduc'd in Particular, and took his Place on the Right Hand, next to the King, after which, the Arch-Bishop of York, the Earl of Nottingham, the Lord Hallifax were Nam'd by the King, and
were immediately Sworn, and took their Places at the Board.

Then the King declar'd the Lord Viscount Townshend, Secretary of State; the Earl of Notting∣ham, Lord President of the Council; the Earl of Wharton, Lord Privy-Seale; the Earl of Sunderland, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland; and the Lord Cowper, Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain.

Addresses now began to croud in from all Parts, to Congratulate the King's Accession, as is Natu∣ral on such Occasions, and in Particular, the two Universities, the Lord Mayor, Aldermen, and Common Council of the City of London, and par∣ticularly the Clergy of London; these led the Way. It would be endless to give the Detail of the Places from whence, much less the Petitions themselves, nor is it at all necessary, they being generally things something a-like in their Manner, as they are in their End.

One of the first things of Moment, which oc∣cur'd in the Sphere of the New Lord Chancellor, and the first Patent which past the Great Seal in this Reign, was that of Creating the King's eldest and only Son, Prince of Wales. This was order'd soon after his Lordship had the Seals, and was declar'd in Council, his Name and Titles run thus, viz.

GEORGE AUGUSTUS, (Prince of Great Britain, Electoral Prince of Brunswick Lunenburgh, Duke of Cornwal and Rothsaye, Duke and Marquiss of Cam∣bridge, Earl of Milford-Haven and of Carrick, Vis∣count North-Allerton, Baron of Tewkesbury and of Renfrew, Lord of the Isles, and Steward of Scot∣land, and Knight of the most noble Order of the Garter) Prince of Wales, and Earl of Chester.
The Preamble of this Patent is upon that Ac∣count worth Recording, and is, as it was then publish'd, in Latin and English, as follows, viz.

Q.P: QUum Muneris nostri fit, Regnis, quorum Dei Gratia nuper ad nes Jus & Imperium perve∣ner, non solùm in praesens consulere, sed etiam in po∣sterum prospicere; nihil prius magis in Animo fuit, quam ut Georgium Augustum, Filium nostrum uni∣cum, Populis nostris, quibus regendis aliquando desti∣netur, gratum reddamus & acceptissimum; ipsum proinde Titulis Prunogenito Magnae Britanniae Regis Filio propriis augeri volumns; quò magis erga Haere∣dem nostrum dilectissimum Patris Benignitas, & erga Subditos fidelissimos Principis elucescat Cura. Nobis interim & Britannis nostris de illo gratulamur, quem ob egregiam in nos Pietatem semper charum, habumus, & qui, ob res Odenardi Praelio preclarè gestas, illis dudum innotuit. Quod superest, ut Virtutibus à Majo∣ribus derivatis indies inclarescat, Honoresquo à nobis ac∣ceptos pergat mereri, Deum Optimum Maximum pre∣camur. Sciatis igitur, &c.

DIV2.P: Which in English runs thus:

“IT being incumbent on Us, not only to pro∣cure the present Good of the Kingdoms, to the Government whereof it has pleased God to call Us, but also to provide for their future Se∣curity; our first and principal Care was, to re∣commend as much as possible, our only Son, George Augustus, to the Affection of our People, whom he is one Day to Govern: Our Will is therefore, that he be Honoured with the Titles peculiar to the Eldest Son of the King of Great Britain; to evince both our Paternal Affection to
our most dear Son, and the Care We take of our most faithful Subjects. Hereupon we con∣gratulate with our Britains, on Account of a Prince, whose eminent filial Piety, has al∣ways endear'd him to Us, and who has long ago made himself known to them, by his gal∣lant Actions in the Battle of Oudenarde. We beseech Almighty God, that the Virtues he de∣rives from his Ancestors may daily shine out in him, with additional Splendor; and that he may go on to merit the Honours which We have” confer'd on him.Be it known there fore, &c.

Much about the same time, farther Promo∣tions of great Officers were declar'd though it was true they were determin'd several Weeks before; as particularly, the Duke of Marlborough was de∣clared Captain General of all the Land Forces, Colonel of the First Regiment of the Foot Guards, and Master General of the Ordnance. Mr. Stan∣hope, afterward, Lord Viscount Stanhope, and the Duke of Montrose, Secretaries of State, in the Room of Mr. Bromley, and the Earl of Mar. The Duke of Somerset, Master of the Horse. The Duke of St. Albans, Captain of the Band of Pensioners. The Duke of Argyle, General of Foot, and Ge∣neral and Commander in Chief of the Forces in Scotland. The Earl of Berkeley, Lord Lieutenant of the County of Gloucester, Constable of the Castle of Brianels, and Keeper and Chief Ranger of the Forest of Dean. William Poultney Secreta∣ry at War, in the Room of Francis Gwyn, Esq General Earl, Lieutenant General of the Ord∣nance, and Governor of Portsmouth and South-Sea Castle. Robert Walpole, Esq to be Receiver and Pay-Master General of the Forces, and Pay-Master
of Chelsea College, in the Room of Mr. John How, and Mr. Moor. After all these things were read, and the Names declared in Presence of the King, His Majesty Dissolv'd the Privy-Council, and Named a New Council, whose Names are as follows, viz.

LIST.ITEM: His Royal Highness George Prince of Wales.
William, Lord Cowper, Lord Chancellor of Great Britain.
Charles, Duke of Shrewsbury, Lord High Trea∣surer of Great Britain, and Lord Chamberlain of His Majesty's Houshold.
Daniel, Earl of Nottingham, Lord President of the Privy-Council.
Thomas, Earl of Wharton, Lord Keeper of the Privy-Seal.
William, Duke of Devonshire, Lord Steward of His Majesty's Houshold.
John, Duke of Marlborough, Captain General of His Majesty's Forces.
James, Duke of Montrose, one of His Majesty's
Robert, Marquis of Lindsey, Lord Great Cham∣berlain.
Henry, Earl of Suffolk, Deputy-Earl-Marshal of England.
Charles, Earl of Sunderland, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland.
Charles, Viscount Townshend, one of His Majesty's Principal Secretaries of State.
Thomas Cooke, Vice Chamberlain to His Majesty.
James Stanhope, Esq one of His Majesty's Prin∣cipal Secretaries of State.
Sir Thomas Parker, Knight, Lord Chief Justice of the Court of King's Bench.
Thomas Erle, Esq Lieutenant General of the Ordnance.
Robert Walpole, Esq Pay-Master-General of His Majesty's Forces.

DIV2.P: This Council met for the first Time, on the first of October, when some Alterations in Ireland were appointed, especially in the Judges; for Example, Allen Brodrick, Esq was made Lord Chancellor of Ireland; William Whitshed, Lord Chief Justice of the King's Bench; John Foster, ditto of the Com∣monpleas; John Dean, Esq Lord Chief Baron of the Exchequer; And James Mackartney one of the Judges of the King's Bench.

It is observable here, that some very good Offers of great Posts, were made to Gentlemen of the other Party, as, Sir Thomas Hanmer, and Mr. Bromley; the first was offer'd to be made Chancellor of the Exchequer, and the last
a Teller; but both of them refus'd or declin'd it.
The next main Thing was the King's Corona∣tion, which it was declar'd in Council, should be on the 20th of October, in order to which a Proclamation was order'd to appoint both the Time and Manner.

The next Council Day, more Alterations were declar'd, viz. The Earl of Dorset was made Constable of Dover Castle, and Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports. The Lord Paget to be Captain of the Yeomen of the Guards. William Cadogan, Esq Master of the Robes. And Samuel Hill, Esq to be Secretary of the Latin Tongue. The Lieu∣tenancy also was chang'd all over England, new Lords Lieutenants establish'd, almost every where; and a new Lieutenancy was also appoint∣ed for the City of London.
New Commissions also were Issu'd for the Trea∣sury, and the Admiralty: As follows,
Commissioners for the TREASURY.
Charles Earl of Halifax, Sir Richard Onslow, Sir William St. Quintin, Baronets, Edward Wortley Montague, and Paul Methuen, Esqs;
Commissioners for the ADMIRALTY.
Edward Earl of Orford; Sir George Bing, Knight; George Doddington, Esq Sir John Jennings, Sir Charles Turner, Knights; Abraham Scanyan, and George Baillie, Esqs;
Also, the Earl of Cholmondeley, was made Trea∣surer of the Houshold; Mr. Boscawen, Comp∣troller, and Edmund Dunkley, Esq Master of the Houshold.
The Lord Guernsey, was made Chancellor of the Dutchy of Lancaster.
Also in Ireland, the Privy Council was Dis∣solv'd, and another call'd, to meet the 9th of October.

On the 11th of October, the Princess of Wales, with Her two Daughters, Landed from Holland; She came on Shore at Margate in Kent, and Coaches being ready, she came away immediately for London, the Prince met her beyond Rochester. On the 13th they arriv'd together, and pass'd through the City, the Tower Guns Firing as the Coaches pass'd the Bridge.
The Coronation approaching, some Honours were thought Proper to be bestowed, as follows.
James, Lord Chandois, Earl of Caernarvon; but that Lord dying, his eldest Son James was created Viscount of Wilton, Com. Hereford, and Earl of Caernarvon.
Lewis, Lord Rockingham, Baron of Throwley, in the County of Kent, Viscount Sondes of Lees-Court, in the same Country, and Earl of Rocking∣ham.
Charles, Lord Ossulston, Earl of Tankerville.
Charles, Lord Halifax, Viscount Sunbury, in the County of Middlesex, and Earl of Halifax.
Heneage, Lord Guernsey, Earl of Aylesford, in the County of Kent.
John, Lord Harvy, Earl of Bristol.
Thomas, Lord Pelham, Viscount Haughton, in the County of Nottingham, and Earl of Clare.
Henry, Earl of Thomond, of the Kingdom of Ireland, Viscount Tadcaster, in the County of York.
James, Viscount Castleton, of the Kingdom of Ireland, Baron Saunderson of Saxby, in the County of Lincoln.
Bennet, Lord Sherrard, of the Kingdom of Ire∣land, Baron of Harborough, in the County of Lei∣cester.
Gervase, Lord Pierrepont, of the Kingdom of Ire∣land, Baron Pierrepont of Hanstope, in the County of Bucks.
Henry Boyle, Esq Baron of Castleton, in the County of York.
Sir Richard Temple, Baron of Cobham.
The same Day, the King was pleas'd to Sign a Commission for Lieutenant General William Cadogan, to be Colonel of the Second Regiment of Foot-Guards, in the Room of General Church∣hill.

On the 16th of October was held at St. James's a Chapter of the most noble Order of the Garter, where the King, and several of the Knights Com∣panions being present, Charles Duke of Boulton; John Duke of Rutland; Lonel Cranfield, Earl of Dorset and Middlesex; and Charles Earl of Halifax; were elected Knights Companions of the said Order, having been first introduc'd into the Chapter, and Knighted by the Sovereign, with the Sword of State; and then withdrawing, were afterwards, severally sent for in, (according to the Order above-mention'd) and invested with the Garter and George, with the usual Ceremo∣nies.

The same Day, Sir Richard Temple, Lord Cob∣ham, was appointed His Majesty's Envoy extra∣ordinary to Vienna; and Colonel Henry Killigrew
was Declar'd Master of the Robes to the Prince of Wales.

On the 18th of October, Sir Michael Warton, who had been mention'd to be Created a Baron, having though with great Expressions of Duty and Gratitude to the King, declin'd that Ho∣nour, His Majesty was pleas'd to accept his Ex∣cuse.
