At the same Time the King also appointed, Wil∣liam Lord Cowper, Chancellor of Great Britain, to be Lord Lieutenant of the County of Hert∣ford; Hugh, Earl Cholmondeley, to be Governor of Chester; Lieutenant General William Sey∣mour, to be Lieutenant of the Band of Pensioners; the Duke of Richmond, the Duke of Grafton, the Duke of Kent, the Earl of Lincoln, the Earl of Dorset, the Earl of Manchester, the Earl of Berke∣ley, the Earl of Selkirk, the Earl of Stair, the Earl of Orrery, the Lord Carteret, to be Gen∣tlemen of the Bed-Chamber to His Majesty: And the Honourable Mr. Howard, Brigadier Dormer, Brigadier Breton, Colonel Kerr, Colonel Tyrrel, Colonel Fielding, Colonel Cornwal, to be Grooms of the Bed-Chamber. The King was likewise pleas'd to appoint the Earl of Stair to go to the Court of France.

On the 20th the Coronation was perform'd with all the Pomp and Ceremony usual on such Occasions, the whole was very Magnificent, but was attended with some unhappy Accidents, viz. the fall of several Scaffolds Stages erected. for Spectators, by which, the Crowd being great, many were hurt, and some kill'd out∣right; the Scaffolds in the Palace-Yard fell, just as the Procession was coming by.

By this time, the Dissatisfactions of the people began to discover themselves a little; the Methods which the Court had taken, and seem'd resolv'd to take, in the displacing one Side, and putting in the other, almost universally, could not but disoblige many; and the Coronation Day being celebrated all over the Nation, the Mobs and Tumuits which appear'd on that Occasion, were, as I may say, the Beginning of that Temper which afterwards spread it self almost over the whole Kingdom.

Nor was the bare displacing the Old Ministry, and all the Friends of that Side, or the putting in the New Men, the main Spring the Peoples Dissatisfactions, so much as the Warmth of those People who pretended to be gratify'd in the Change; those were not content to be in Power, or to see their Friends wholly possess'd of the Royal Favour, and have Opportunity to xert the Power of the Government in the Interest of their Party; but they immediately turn'd upon those who they now look'd upon as under Foot, with bitter Reproaches, Taunts, Threatnings, and all manner of Triumph that could be thought of; or could indeed be practis'd, by a conquering Enemy, over a vanquish'd Prisoner; insul∣ing them with opprobious Language, unsuffer∣able to Men of Honour and Spirit, and threat∣ning them with the utmost Revenge and Resent∣ment.

Let no Man mistake this, to signify that either the King, or any of His Ministry did thus, or en∣courag'd the doing of this. His Majesty having fill'd up the great Employments of the Court, with Mn who he thought best capable to execute the Trust reposed in them, most deserving of, and
attacht to the Interest of himself, and the Royal Family, might well in the Infancy, or at least, the Youth of His Government, give them a Loose in their Conduct, to judge for him in many things what was fittest to be done, and whether Lenity or Severity were the most proper to begin the Schemes of the New Administration with, in respect to those who went before them.

Clearing therefore, entirely, the King and all His German Ministry of being any way the Occa∣sion of any Measures which might be taken to en∣courage the Passions of Men in Power, to carry on the Party Resentments mention'd above, and from which, many of the Misfortunes which fol∣lowed may be said to derive. Clearing, I say, the King, and His Friends, from the Charge en∣tirely, and leaving it undetermin'd, who of the New Ministry, were, or were not mistaken in their first Measures, I choose to speak of the Fer∣ment of Parties without Doors, from whence, as from a troubled Fountain, issued afterwards, Dis∣content, Faction, Rage, Tumult, Riot, Fight∣ing, Plundering, Demolishing Houses, &c. and in a Word, all kind of Popular Distraction. At Court, this was follow'd with Flight of Discon∣tented Lords, Throanings, Impeachments, Im∣prisonments, &c. till at length, altogether Issued in bidding Defiance to the Government. And Men of Dignity being made Desperate, sought Shelter very unhappily in Treason and Rebellion.

I might follow Truth too close at the Heels, as was said of a much better Historian, if I should Trace the Causes of all these things nearer than I have done in this brief Recapitulation of the first Movemente in this Reign. I return to the History in which the Relation it self will disco∣ver
without any farther Paraphrase, whether it be true or not, that all the future Distractions took their Rise as above.

The Coronation being over, Matters of Ceremony Ended, and the great Offices fill'd up, with Men of the highest Figure and Cha∣racter, on that Side, they began to enter upon the Administration. Frequent Councils were held upon the Measures in which, even in the Infancy of Things, they did not agree perfectly; there happen'd to be ONE Person plac'd at the Head of Business, who still retain'd true Principles of Go∣vernment; and who having by his extraordinary Genius, and long Experience in the Administration of Affairs under the like Agitation of Parties, in former Reigns, seen the mischievous Consequences of Arming the Parties one against another, feeding the Fire of Men's Passions on the one hand, or pushing Men to Desperations on the other; and being a Friend to moderate Councils, on every Hand, opposed himself though with Calmness, and powerful Reasonings, to the Heat of some other People, who were for carrying on the Govern∣ment upon the Basis of Justice, as they call'd it, to their Enemies.

When, I say, there was ONE Person of such noble and superior Principles, in this first Mini∣stry, I do not suggest that there was BUT ONE; but I may be allow'd to say, that I believe there was none stood so firm to the last, in his Judgment of the best Measures which were to be taken for the fixing and establishing the King in the Throne, and for preventing the evil Consequences which fol∣low'd.

He had, indeed, this Advantage above most Men of that time he liv'd in, viz. That his Zeal
and Sincerity was unquestion'd; his Understand∣ing and Capacities unexceptionable; and his Attachment to the Royal Family unsuspected; and above all, he was a Man who had never chang'd, which few in that Body of People, I am now speaking of, could say of themselves.

It was with some Warmth, that his proposals of a more moderate Proceeding were received, and the new Managers began not only to argue against it, with some Reflections upon things past; but let the Dispute take Vent among the Com∣mon People, with whom the Moderation of Pro∣ceedings in former Times, were run down with great Clamour; and even King William's Prudent Conduct, was now call'd a criminal Lenity.

This Method of putting the Argument into the Mouths of the People, was indeed very Particu∣lar, and strongly intimated, that they were put to it, by the Opposition they met with, not∣withstanding the Majority in Number; and they had no better way to support their Opinion, than that of making it Popular: Having thus first cry'd out to the People, from within, as if they had bespoke then Clamour, The People tost the Ball back again to them, crying out to the Court, for Justice; and thus those moderate Things, were very unhappily over-rul'd in the Beginning; what the Consequences of these Measures were, History will discover.

I say no more of this, for these Reasons. 1. Because the excellent Person I mention'd, who was then over-rul'd, was soon after snatch'd a∣way by a lamented Death, before he saw his Op∣posers convinc'd, or come over to be of his O∣pinion. 2. Because the Warmest of them after∣wards
grew wiser, were convinc'd by their own Experience, having liv'd to see that the Measures they began with, when Circumstances came to discover them further, were not sopracticable, or so Capable of procuring the publick Tranquillity, as they expected; and some of them have, though late, alter'd their Conduct. But to return to the Relation of Fact.

Immediately after the Coronation, some fur∣ther Alterations in the Employment, of great Men, remain yet to be mentiond; which I name now because the whole Body of the New Court, might appear, before they might be said to en∣ter upon Actiount. These were, as follows,
1. The Duke of Kent, was made Constable and Governor of Windsor Castle, and Keeper of the Park, and Forest of Windsor, in the Room of the Duke of Northumberland.
2. The Earl of Stairs, and Paul Methuen, Esq Sworn of the Privy-Council.
3. The Duke of Shrewsbury, made Chamber∣lain of the Houshold.
4. The Dukes of Bolton, Rutland, Kent, and Argyle; with the Earls of Dorset, and Hali∣fax, were declar'd Knights of the Garter, and were install'd the 9th of December.

The usual and needful Time, for the meeting and sitting of the Parliament, began now to advance; the Government was fully fix'd; the Administration was wholly now in the Hands of those who the King design'd to entrust it with; and the Common People began on several Oc∣casions, and in several Places to be very Tumul∣tuous and Uneasy, as has been mention'd.

The Parliament in being, which had so effectu∣ally shewn their Zeal for His Majesty's Inte∣rest and Succession, in the Beginning of His Reign, and when, if ever, that Succession might be said to be capable of receiving any Attacks from any Person whatsoever, were adjourn'd from the 19th of November, to the 15th of January; and many People entertain'd Hopes that they would then Sit, at least for a while, that they might have had further Opportunities to have exerted themselves in the Service of His Majesty, and their Country; in which case, it was believ'd, the tumultuous Disposition of the People, might have receiv'd a Due, because an early Check; and the evil Con∣sequences which follow'd have been prevented, or at least things might, by the wise Dispositions of the Parliament between the Extreams on all Sides, been so moderated, as that the Reason and Occasions, or Pretences of those Discontents should have been remov'd.

But things took another Turn, and the Tem∣per of those People, mention'd before, seem'd not to desire Accommodations, but run all upon pun∣ishments of the Mismanagers in the preceding Reigns; upon Resentments, and Revenge; censur∣ing all those who recommended more moderat Measures, as Enemies to the House of Hanover; which furious Treatment stopt the Mouths of many, who were as sincere Friends to the Go∣vernment, as any of them were; but who yet were of Opinion, that it was not the true Interest of the Kingdom, to carry Matters on to such Extreams, as they found some Men had in View.

But it was not a Time for such Men to give their Opinion, the Stream running, as I have ob∣serv'd, another Way. So a few Days after, it was apparent, a New Parliament was resolv'd on, and accordingly, on the 15th of January a Proclama∣tion was publish'd.

This Proclamation being very Extraordinary, for the Form, and great Exceptions being taken at some Expressions in it, as if it was unduly In∣termeddling with the Election it self, and direct∣ing the Electors what Persons they should choose, I cannot omit inserting here, because great Con∣tention follow'd among the Parties on both Sides, upon this Subject.

Q.P: GEORGE R.

IT having pleased Almighty God, by most remark∣able Steps of his Providence, to bring Us in Safety to the Crown of this Kingdom, notwithstanding the De∣signs of evil Men, who shew'd themselves disaffected to Our Succession, and who have since, with the utmost Degree of Malice, misrepresented our firm Resolution, and uniform Endeavours to preserve and defend our most excellent Constitution, both in Church and State; and attemptted by many false Suggestions to render Us suspected to Our People; we cannot omit, on this Oc∣casion of first summoning Our Parliament of Great Bri∣tain, (in justice to Our Selves, and that the Miscarri∣ages of others may not be imputed to Us, at a Time when false Impressions may do the greatest and irrecove∣rable Hurt before they can be cleared up) to signify to Our whole Kingdom, That we were very much concern'd, on our Accession to the Crown, to find the publick Affairs of Our Kingdoms under the greatest Difficulties, as well in respect of Our Trade and the Interruption of our Na∣vigation,
as of the great Debts of the Nation, which we were surpriz'd to observe, had been very much in∣creased since the Conclusion of the last War. We do not therefore doubt that if the ensuing Elections shall be made by our loving Subjects with that Safety and Freedom which by Law they are entitled to, and we are firmly resolv'd to maintain to them, they will send up to Parliament the fittest Persons to redress the pre∣sent Disorders, and to provide for the Peace and Hap∣piness of Our Kingdoms, and the Ease of Our People for the Future, and therein will have a particular re∣gard to such as shew'd a Firmness to the Protestant Succession, when it was most in danger: We have there∣fore found it necessary, as well for the Causes aforesaid, as for other weighty Considerations concerning Us and our Kingdoms, to call a new Parliament; and We do accordingly declare, That with the Advice of Our Privy-Council, We have this Day given Order to Our Chan∣cellor of Great Britain, to issue out Writs in due Form for the calling a new Parliament; which Writs are to bear Teste on Monday the 17th Day of this instant January, and to be returnable on Thursday the 17th Day of March next following.
Given at our Court at St. James's, the 15th Day of January, 1714, in the first Year of Our Reign.

DIV2.P:
I do not lead my Readers to make their Judg∣ment of this Proclamation, one Way or other, by my Opinion, but telling them the Objecti∣on only, without any Explanations; leave them to make what Judgment their Reason dictates. Only adding, that the Pen was set to Work on both Sides in these Disputes, to the great disquieting and disturbing the Peace of the
Kingdom, and to an entire Breach of Charity, and good Manners, as to Persons; all which, ten∣ded still, to the farther ripeningup the Animosities of the Parties, and bringing them to the fatal Rupture, that follow'd soon after. But to return to the Affair of a New Parliament, which was now the main thing that Occupy'd the Parties.

It was at this Time, that a Pamphlet was pub∣lish'd, and dispers'd privately over most parts of the Kingdom, nay and of Ireland too, which gave great Offence to the Government, and in∣deed did a great deal of Damage to the Interest. It was call'd, English Advice to the Freeholders of Great Britain. The Contents of the Pamphlet it self, the Mischief it did, and the Concern the Go∣vernment was in to counter-act the Design of it, are as well to be seen in the Proclamation for sup∣pressing it, as if I were to give an Abstract of the Book it self. And therefore I think this Procla∣mation absolutely necessary to be recorded also, in this Place; as also, because it may give the Reader Occasion to form in his Mind just Ideas of the State of the Times, the Questions in Dis∣pute, and the Temper of both Parties in car∣rying them on.

Q.P: GEORGE R.

WHereas We have received Information, that a most malicious and Traiterous Libel, intitled, English Advice to the Freeholders of England, has lately been printed and dispersed throughout our King∣doms with the utmost Industery; nevertheless, by the Care and Vigilance of Our Magistrates, great Numbers thereof are interrepted in Our City of Exon, some being directed to Sir John Coriton, Sir Nicholas Morice,
Jonathan Elford, Esq Philip Rashley, Esq Fran∣cis Scobell, Esq John Williams, Esq Mr. Gran∣ville Piper, Mr. Welshman, Mr. William Cary, Mr. Prousse, Mr. Philips, Mr. Tonkin, Mr. Con∣nock Kendall respectively, in our County of Cornwall; others thereof to the Reverend Mr. Shute, the Reve∣rend Mr. Hughes, the Reverend Mr. Collyer, and the Reverend Mr. Bedford respectively, in Our said Coun∣ty; and others thereof to the Mayor of Our Borough of Westloe in Our said County; whereby, as well as from the Contents of the said Libel, We are convinced, that the same is a wicked Contrivance, meant not only to spread Sedition, and to inflame the Minds of Our loving Subjects, but also by alienating their Affections from Us and Our Government, to promote the Interest of the Pretender; and in order thereto, to raise Distur∣bances in the approaching Elections of Members to serve in Parliament; We being resolved, as far as in Us lies, to bring the Authors and Contrivers of such Traiterous Designs to condign Punishment, and to deter all others from the like Attempts for the future, have thought fit, by the Advice of Our Privy-Council, to issue this Our Royal Proclamation, hereby promising a Re∣ward of One Thousand Pounds to any Person or Persons, who shall discover the Author or Authors of the said trai∣terous Libel, to any one of Our Principal Secretaries of State, and the Sum of Five Hundred Pounds, to any Person or Persons, who shall discover the Printer or Printers thereof, as aforesaid, to the End that such Author or Printer may be Prosecuted according to Law; which respective Rewards, Our Commissioners for executing the Office of Treasurer of the Exchequer, are hereby directed to pay accordingly. And we do here∣by strictly charge and command all Our Magistrates, in and throughout Our Kingdom of Great Britain, That they do make diligent Search and Enquiry after the said
Author, Printer, or Publishers; and that they do ap∣prehend and seize the said Persons, and all others whom they shall find dispersing the said Libel, and give proper Information thereof, so as the said Offenders may be dealt with as the utmost Rigour of Justice requires.

And whereas there is nothing which we so earnestly desire, as to secure the Peace and Prosperity of Our King∣doms, and to preserve to all our loving Subjects the full Enjoyment of their Rights and Liberties, as well Reli∣ as Civil, and in a most particular manner the Freedom of their Elections of Members to serve in Par∣liament; and being satisfied that the same hath been of late Years greatly invaded, by the Encouragements which have been given to Tumults, Riots and other indirect Practices in the Elections of Members to serve in Par∣liament; and it being most apparent, that such evil∣minded Persons are now fomenting and carrying on the same dangerous Practices, We do hereby declare Our highest Resentment and Displeasure against all such ille∣gal Proceedings, strictly Prohibiting the same, as being most injurious to Our Government, and to the Funda∣mental Rights of our People. And We do further charge and command all our Sheriffs, Justices of the Peace, chief Magistrates in our Cities, Boroughs, and Cor∣porations, and all other Our Officers and Magistrates, throughout Our Kingdom of Great Britain, That they do, in their several and respective Stations, take the most effectual Care to suppress and prevent all Riots, Tumults, and other Disorders, which shall be rais'd or made by any Person or Persons whatsoever, at, or in the approaching Elections of Members to serve in Parlia∣ment, and that they do put the Laws in Execution a∣gainst all Offenders in that behalf. And we do further require and command all and every our Magistrates a∣foresaid, That they do, from Time to Time, transmit to one of our Principal Secretaries of State, due and full In∣formations
of all such Persons who shall be found Offend∣ing as aforesaid, or in any Degree aiding or abetting therein, it being Our Royal Resolution to punish the same according to the utmost Severity of the Law.
Given at Our Court at St. James's, the 11th of January, 1714. In the first Year of Our Reign.

DIV2.P: It was acknowledg'd, the Piece was Artfully written, and that one of the best Pens of that Par∣ty was Employ'd in it; and the Zeal of the Parties appear'd, in that not the Reward of 1000 l. for the Author, or 500 l. for the Printer, could ever tempt any of those who were Privy to it, as some of Necessity must be, to make the Discovery.

It is true, that during this whole Interval, that is to say, from the placing the new Ministry, to the meeting of this new Parliament, the King∣dom felt unsufferable Convulsions: The Ferments which the Parties were come to, the Animosities with which they oppos'd one another, the Riots, Tumults, Rage, and ill Conduct, was such, as nothing but a Hand of Power seem'd capable of Suppressing; and any Man, tho' of but small Pene∣tration, might perceive it would unavoidably come to Blows, and that no End could be put to it on both Sides without Blood.

It would take up more Room, not only than can be spar'd here, but even than this Book con∣tains, to give a true Account of all the Feuds, Disputes, Quarrels, Riots, Tumults, &c. and the Consequences of them which happen'd, from the celebrating the Joy of the Coronation-Day, for there the Rabbles began, to the meeting of this Parliament. But as they all ran like Rivers into
the great Ocean of War and Rebellion, I need enter no farther into the Detail of them, than just to mention, that at London, Bristol, Oxford, Man∣chester, Shrewsbury, and many Towns more, in Shropshire, Cheshire, Staffordshire, Lancashire, &c. the Mobs were outragious, pull'd down Meeting-Houses, broke Windows, and Heads, and even at length came to Fire at one another with Mus∣quets and Pistols, whereby much Mischief was done, and several People kill'd, and more wound∣ed; but of these things, I shall find too much Occasion to speak again hereafter.

According to the Return of the Writs for Electi∣on, the Parliament was to meet the 17th of March, Previous to their Meeting, and in Conse∣quence of the Resolution mention'd of entring in∣to the Resentments of the former Reign, and ex∣amining the Conduct of the Ministry of Queen ANNE, several Steps were taken, which more and more alarm'd all those Gentlemen, who had been concern'd in those Affairs

The first more open Step to those things was, that on the 11th of January, the Lord Townshend, and Mr. Stanhope, both at that time Secretaries of State, were sent by Order of Council, to the Earl of Strafford, late Ambassador and Plenipotentiary at the Hague, and at Utrecht, to Demand from him the Original Instructions, and Orders sent him upon the Publick Account, during his Mini∣stry Abroad; all Letters written by him, or to him, to, or from, any Person whatsoever, relating to the Negotiations from the time of his being first at the Hague. They were to be seal'd up with his Lordship's Seal upon Delivery, and to be seal'd with the Lord President's Seal, when brought to the Council, and so to remain till the Parliament
should meet, and give Orders about them. They brought away two Trunks which the Earl told them contain'd what they came for. But it being said, there were more on Board a Ship come from Holland, and not then landed, Orders were issu'd to demand them also; but I do not hear they were found.

The 20th of January was appointed for a Day of General Thanksgiving, for the peaceable Accessi∣on of the King to the Throne, and the King and whole Court came in Procession to St. Paul's upon that Occasion; Te Deum was sung to Musick within, and clos'd with Guns fired from the Tower without; the Sermon was Preach'd by the Bishop of Gloucester, and at Night God was thank'd again, as is our usual Custom in England, with Bells, and Bonfires, Illuminations, shouting of Rabbles, &c.

On the 17th of March the Parliament met, the King attended by the Prince of Wales, appear'd for the first Time, in the House of Peers, and the Commons being sent for up, were Order'd to re∣turn, and choose a Speaker, and to present him to the King. On the 21st, when they appear'd again, having chosen Spencer Compton, Esq Speaker of their House, they Presented him to the King, with the usual Ceremony; when the King having approv'd the Speaker, open'd the Session, with the following Speech, which was read by the Lord Chancellor.

Q.P: My Lords, and Gentlemen,

THIS being the first Opportunity that I have had of meeting my People in Parliament, since it pleased God, of his good Providence, to call me to the Throne of my Ancestors, I most gladly make use
of it to thank my faithful and loving Subjects, for that Zeal and Firmness that hath been shewn in Defence of the Protestant Succession, against all the open and se∣cret Practices that have been used to defeat it: And I shall never forget the Obligations I have to those who have distinguish'd themselves upon this Occasion.

It were to be wish'd, that the unparallell'd Successes of a War, which was so wisely and cheerfully supported by this Nation, in order to procure a good Peace, had been attended with a suitable Conclusion: But it is with Concern I must tell you, that some Conditions, even of this Peace, essential to the Security and Trade of Great Britain, are not yet duly executed; and the Performance of the whole may be look'd upon as precari∣ous, until we shall have formed defensive Alliances to Guaranty the present Treaties.
The Pretender, who still resides in Lorrain, threa∣tens to disturb Us, and boasts of the Assistance, which he still expects here, to repair his former Disappoint∣ments.

P.HI: A great Part of our Trade is render'd impractica∣ble: This, if not retriev'd, must destroy Our Manufac∣tures, and ruin our Navigation.

The Publick Debts are very Great, and surprizingly encreased, even since the fatal Cessation of Arms. My first Care was to prevent the farther Increase of these Debts, by paying off forthwith a great Number of Ships, which had been kept in Pay, when there was no Occasion for continuing such an Expence.

Q.P: Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

P.HI: I rely upon you for such Supplies as the present Cir∣cumstances of Our Affairs require for this Year's Ser∣vice, and for the Support of the Publick Faith. The Estimates shall be laid before you, that you may consider
of them; and what you shall judge necessary for your Safety, I shall think sufficient for mine.
I doubt not but you will concur with me in Opinion, that nothing can contribute more to the Support of the Credit of the Nation, than a strict observance of all Parliamentary Engagements.

Q.P: The Branches of the Revenue, formerly granted for the Support of the Civil Government, are so far in∣cumber'd and alienated, that the Produce of the Funds which remain, and have been granted to me, will fall much short of what was at first design'd for maintaining the Honour and Dignity of the Crown: And since it is my Happiness (as I am confident you think it yours) to see a Prince of Wales, who may, in due Time, suc∣ceed me on the Throne, and to see him bless'd with ma∣ny Children, the best and most valuable Pledges of our Care and Concern for your Prosperity; this must Occa∣sion an Expence to which the Nation has not of many Years been accustom'd; but such as surely no Man will grudge: And therefore I do not doubt but you will think of it with that Affection which I have Reason to hope from you.
My Lords and Gentlemen,

The Eyes of all Europe are upon you, waiting the Issue of this first Session. Let no unhappy Divisions of Parties here at Home, divert you from pursuing the Common Interest of your Country. Let no wicked In∣sinuations disquiet the Minds of my Subjects. The establish'd Constitution in Church and State shall be the Rule of my Government; the Happiness, Ease, and Prosperity of my People, shall be the chief Care of my Life. Those who assist me in carrying on these Measures, I shall always esteem my best Friends; and I doubt not but that I shall be able, with your Assistance, to disappoint the Designs of those who would
deprive me of that Blessing, which I most Value, The Affection of my People.

DIV2.P: The Addresses, and Answers, usual on these Occasions, from, and to both Houses, are too long for this Place, nor at all needful, being per∣fectly customary, and much the same, as happen every Session, mutatis mutandis as Circumstances direct.

In the very first Speech made in this House of Commons, the Mismanagements of the former Reign were fallen upon by a Person who has since had Occasion to see farther into the Designs of Persons and the Conduct of Things, than at that Time his Passions would permit him to do; and the Wording their first Address introduc'd it into both Houses, where it soon became familiar; for the warm Party carry'd this Point in every De∣bate.

By this time also, the general Cry, without Doors as well as within, ran so much upon the late Mis∣managements, and the farther Inquiry into the Conduct of the late Reign, grew so Popular, and Consequently seem'd so Necessary, that it was easie to see who they aim'd at.

The Lord Bolingbroke, late Secretary of State to the Queen, tho' he appear'd openly and spoke boldly, in the House of Lords, yet as he saw there would be no resisting a Torrent, and that the part he had in the Treaty, might very easily be carry'd into what Constructions those who had Numbers on their Side might direct, was advis'd by all his Friends, to keep himself out of their Hands, who, as if they were desirous he should Fly, openly profess'd to aim at his Head.

He took their Advice accordingly, and with∣drew the 26th, having before secured a Vessel to meet him at Dover, and carry him over to France, where accordingly he Landed the same Evening. It was said, he left behind him, written with his own Hand, the following Letter, directed in no Name, but written to a Friend.

P.Q:
“I Left the Town so abruptly, that I had no time to take Leave of you, or any of my Friends: You will Excuse me, when you know, That I had certain, and repeated Informations, from some who are in the Secret of Affairs, That a Resolution was taken, by those who have Power to execute it, to pursue me to the Scaffold. My Blood was to have been the Cement of a new Alliance; nor could my Innocence be any Security, after it had been once demanded from Abroad, and resolv'd on at Home, that it was necessary to cut me off. Had there been the least Reason to hope for a fair and open Trial, after having been already prejudg'd, un∣heard by the two Houses of Parliament, I should not have declin'd the strictest Examination. I challenge the most inveterate of my Enemies to produce any one Instance of criminal Correspon∣dence, or the least Corruption in any Part of the Administration, in which I was concern'd. If my Zeal for the Honour and Dignity of my Royal Mistress, and the true interest of my Country, has any where transported me to let slip a warm or unguarded Expression, I hope the most favourable Interpretation will be put upon it. It is a Com∣fort
that will remain with me in all Misfor∣tunes, that I serv'd Her Majesty faithfully and dutifully, in that especially, which She had most at Heart, relieving Her People from a bloody and expensive War: And that I have always been too much an Englishman, to sacrifice the Interest of my Country to any Foreign Ally what∣soever; and 'tis for this Crime only, that I am” now driven from thence.
“You will hear more at large from me short∣ly.”

DIV2.P: As soon as the House of Commons had settled their Committees, voted the Supply, call'd for the Estimates as usual, enter'd upon the particular Sums requir'd; and in their Debates of Ways and Means had voted the Land Tax of 3 s. per Pound; they began to fall to Work, with what had been so often Threaten'd, viz. calling People to an Ac∣count.

They had already Address'd the King to have laid before the House all the Powers, Instructions, Memorials, Letters, and Papers, relating to the late Negotiations of Peace, &c. and these being very large, and particular, were the Ground of the Motion made by Mr. Secretary Stanhope, (viz.) that a Secret Committee might be appointed, to which they should all be referr'd, which was ac∣cordingly agreed to, and a Committee of 21 was chosen by Ballot; and they again, when chosen, elected Mr. Robert Walpole to be Chairman; and thus the Affair of the late Reign was put into a Kind of Method for a judicial Process.
The Names of this famous Society, may not be omitted in this History. As follows,

To these were, at several Times, referr'd all the Papers which the House thought fit to call for, relating to the Publick Administration in the late Reign; those particularly about the Demolishing Dunkirk; Establishing the South-Sea Company; the Treaties of Peace, and Treaties of Commerce.
They sat de Die in Diem, during the Recess of the House at Easter, and went on with incredible Application.

In this Interval, happen'd that famous, and in∣deed remarkable Eclipse of the Sun, viz. April 22. the most perfect and total Darkness that has been known in the World from such a Cause; the Day being bright, and warm, perfectly clear, and not one Cloud seen in the Horizon; it began at six Minutes after Eight in the Morning, and the whole Body of the Sun being shut in, as it were behind a Curtain, about Nine the Stars appear'd,
the Birds astonish'd sunk to the Earth, and to their Roosting Places, and the Sun continu'd cen∣terally eclips'd and totally darken'd for about three Minutes, to the great Terror and Amazement of the Vulgar and Ignorant part of the People, and even to the Surprize of others; for all the Schemes drawn and publish'd by the most Eminent Astro∣nomers allow'd, that a small Part of the Verge of the Suns Circle would be left open, which it was not, no not the least Part of it.
But I return to the Parliament.

The Voting the usual Supplies, I need not men∣tion, it being what of course goes on in every Session. But the main thing which occasion'd Debate, was settling the Revenue of 700000 l. per Annum, for the Maintenance of the King's Houshold, called, The Civil List; there were some Objections made to the Sum, as being too great, and more than Queen Anne possess'd, because of the Payments, made then by her Majesty upon several Extraor∣dinary Occasions.
However, as the Court Party had now a Lead∣ing Majority in the House, they were thought able to carry every Demand which they thought fit to insist on, and this in particular.
Some more great Officers were now made, particularly in the Army. As follows,

LIST.ITEM: The Duke of Montague, was made Captain of the First Troop of Horse Guards; formerly call'd, the Duke of Ormond's Troop.
The Earl of Hertford of the Second.
The Lord Newburgh had the Third.
The Lord Lumley had the First Troop of Horse Grenadiers.
The Earl of De Lorain, the Second.
The Earl of Stairs, had General Ecclin's Dra∣goons, who was publickly Dismiss'd.
William Kerr, Esq Brother to the Duke of Roxburgh, was made Colonel of Dra∣goons. And,
William Harrison, Colonel of a Regiment of Foot, formerly the Earl of Hertford's.

DIV2.P: About this Time died three Leading Men indeed on the Court Side, one in the Church, and two in State; viz. First, Dr. Gilbert Burnet, Bishop of Salisbury, who died the 17th of March; Thomas Earl of Wharton, who died the 12th of April; and Charles Earl of Halifax, first Commissioner of the Treasury, who died the 19th of May; this last, an honourable Mention has been made of for his Moderation; I cannot say, that the other were any way to be charg'd with that Sin.

The Parliament Affairs went on without any considerable Opposition, the Land Tax, the Malt Tax, and a Bill for regulating the Forces, had alrea∣dy receiv'd the Royal Assent; and the House seem'd indeed, to be kept sitting, principally upon Account of the Party Affairs, mentioned be∣fore.

In the Committee of Secrecy Matters run high, and they began to promise to make their Report ready very speedily: On the 9th of June, the Chair-Man acquainted the House, that the Report was ready, but before they presented it, the Committee thought fit to exert in some Particular manner, the Power of the House. “It is true, they had Power in themselves to send for Persons as well as Papers, and Records, yet they thought it necessary rather (to give their own Words) in order to bring Offenders to Justice, that some
Persons should be secur'd before 'twas possible they should know what they were to be examin'd to; and lest they should have Notice to make their Escape: Then the Chair-man added, That he was commanded (according to former Precedents) to move, that a Warrant may be Issued by Mr. Speaker to apprehend certain Persons who shall be named to him by the Chair-Man of the said Committee; and that no Members may be per∣mitted to go out of the House. Hereupon it was Ordered, First, That the Lobby be clear'd of all Strangers, the back Doors of the Speaker's Chamber lock'd up, the Key brought, and laid upon the Table. And that the Serjeant do stand at the Door of the House, and suffer no Mem∣ber to go forth. Secondly, That Mr. Speaker do Issue his Warrant to the Serjeant, to take into his Custody such Persons as shall be named by the Chairman of the Committee of Secresy, in order to their being examin'd before them.”

Hereupon Mr. Speaker issued his Warrants, to take into Custody several Persons that were named by Mr Walpole, particularly Mr. Matthew Prior, and Mr. Thomas Harley, the first of whom was im∣mediately apprehended, and the other some Hours after.

Then Mr. Walpole acquainted the House, “That the Committee of Secrecy had perused the Books and Papers referr'd to them, and had agreed upon a Report, which they had commanded him to make: That it was contain'd in two Books, one of which was the Report, and the other an Appendix to it, which contain'd at large those Letters and Papers which were referr'd to in the Report.” He read the Report, and deliver'd it in at the Table, with the Appendix, and the
Books which were referr'd to the said Committee. The reading of the Report having taken up from One 'till about Six in the Afternoon, a Motion was made by the Friends of the late Ministry, and the Question put, That the further Consideration of it be adjourn'd 'till the next Morning, it was carry'd in the Negative, by 282 Votes, to 171; and or∣der'd, that the Report be now read: Upon which the Clerk of the House having read 'till half an Hour past Eight, the further Consideration of it was adjourn'd 'till the next Morning.

The apprehending Mr. Prior, and Mr. Harley, being thus done, with so much Ceremony, and the Report read, which contain'd so many Sheets, that it was said to be eight Hours in Reading them, as above, and the House could not go through it that Night; the next Day it was finish'd, and read a second Time, and order'd to be Printed; which has been done ac∣cordingly, and therefore need not to be repeated in this History.

As soon as the second Reading was over, the Grand Affair began, for the Chairman stood up, and Impeach'd the Lord Viscount Bolingbroke of high Treason, and high Crimes and Misdeme∣nors: after which, the Lord Coningsby, as it had been concerted, Impeach'd the Earl of Oxford, ma∣king some Flourishes to introduce it.

It is remarkable here, that even at the Time this Impeachment was brought in, a certain Mem∣ber, not only of the House, but of the Secret Com∣mittee also, was said to acknowledge the Defici∣ency of the Charge, in the Terms following, or to that Purpose.

That as to the Lord Bolingbroke, They had more than sufficient Evidence to convict him of high Treason, upon the Statute 25 Edw. III. But that as to the Earl of Oxford, he doubted whether they had either sufficient Matter, or Evidence to Impeach him of Treason.

But the Resolution was nevertheless pass'd, not∣withstanding so ingenious an Acknowledgment, and so the Earl was also Impeach'd. A certain Gentleman, saying, that they had other Evidence, and other Facts, which, however, never yet appear'd, and if it had, it must be observ'd that it did not appear then, and yet, that the Resolu∣tion for the Impeachment pass'd without Divid∣ing.
These Evidences we have of the Warmth with which things were carry'd on at that Time, of which I shall say no more, 'till I come to the Issue of the Impeachment it self.

Upon the Voting these Impeachments, the House order'd the Committee of Secrecy to draw up Articles, and prepare Evidence, as usual in such Cases, and then adjourn'd their farther prosecuting that Part for a Week.

But Time had no Influence yet to cool their Vigour in these Proceedings, or at least, the In∣tervals being too short for such an Effect, the Time which was taken, rather serv'd to Fer∣ment them to a greater Degree; for the next Days were taken up in the farther Pursuit of the same Point. And on the 19th the Duke of Ormond was Impeach'd of high Treason. Also the next Day the Earl of Strafford was Impeach'd of high Crimes and Misdemeanors.

Here they thought fit to make a Stop; there was a great Struggle to have saved the Duke of Ormond from this Blow. But it was in vain. Not
the past Sufferings of his Family for the Mo∣narchy; not his steady Adherance to the Church; not his long Services in the Field; not his excellent Conduct at Vigo: No past Merit could Weigh against the publick Resentment, or ward the fatal Blow off from him, which very unhappily precipi∣tated him into Measures which have since finish'd his Ruin; and which, whatever others may think, I never saw Cause to believe he had entertain'd the least Thought of before.

It must be acknowledg'd here also, that the ill tim'd indiscreet Affection of the Common People to the Duke, had too much Share in his Fall; For the Mobbs and Rabbles, of which mention has been made, and which even the wisest Men among those who were against the Measures of the pre∣sent Administration did not approve of, were in∣excusably to Blame, in making use of the Duke's Name, as the Characteristick to the Party; crying in the Street, Ormond, Ormond, for ever! In Op∣position to the Cry of the Whiggish Mobbs, of King GEORGE, forever!

This setting the Duke's Name in a direct Op∣position to the King's, tho' no Man could ever say he consented to, or approv'd of it, did him a manifest Injury, and had, I believe, too great a Share in his Misfortunes. However, let that be as it will, the Duke's unhappy Conduct since has too much justified all the Measures of his Ene∣mies, and entirely ruined him and his Family. and not one Word can be said, but what Pity extorts, for the Loss of some of the Finest and Greatest PERSONAGES amongst the English Nobility.

The Duke finding it was impossible for him to stem this Current, and that he could not expect any Favour when Things run thus high, withdrew al∣so, and conveyed himself over to France, as the Lord Bolingbroke had done before.

As Things were thus warm in the House, so the Tumults, of which I have made mention be∣fore, encreased to that height, in the Northern Parts especially, that they wanted little of an open Re∣bellion: And indeed, had the Duke of Ormond, with any Number of Troops from Abroad, land∣ed in the Interim, as it was given out he would, it would certainly have been a Rebellion at that time: But they were utterly distitute of Support from Abroad. And it must be acknowledged, to the exquisite Management of the King, that by his Influence and Intelligence Abroad, all the At∣tempts made in any part of the World, to get As∣sistance, Ships, Men or Money, were effectually disappointed.

These Tumults, however, made the Nation ve∣ry uneasy; even those who were as male-contented as any body, with the present Measures, yet trembled at the Rage of the Rabble; knowing well that an enflam'd Multitude distinguish not Friends from Enemies. None but such whose Circumstan∣ces were desperate, or Principles directly Jaco∣bite, could be pleased with the confused Circum∣stances which the Nation seemed to be in upon that Occasion; Every body else dreaded the Con∣sequences: However, as the Parliament was sitting, Relief was expected from them; and accordingly Information being given of some of those Riots just then happening in Staffordshire, where they were carried on to an Extravagance scarce credi∣ble, the House took it into their Consideration,
and Address'd the King, that the Magistrates, Ju∣stices of the Peace, and others, should be encou∣raged to do their Duty in suppressing Tumults; that those who fail'd in their Duty might be pu∣nished; and that an Account of the Damages suf∣fered by any of his Majesty's Subjects should be brought in, and the Loss made good to them by the Publick. This was a great Encouragement to the Dissenters in particular, who had suffered in∣deed deeply in the Demolishing of their Meeting-Houses, &c. by the Mobs; and who in Virtue of this Resolution received, some time after, very ample Satisfaction in Money for the same.

Upon this Occasion also, that well-known Law was pass'd by the House of Lords first, and after∣wards by the Commons, Entituled, An Act for preventing Tumults, &c. and which is still in Force; whereby the County or Hundred is made answer∣able for the Damages committed by the Rabble; and the Rioters who shall continue together after Reading to them certain Words express'd in the Act, are guilty of Felony; upon which very Act, several Persons have been since Executed; as par∣ticularly 2 in Worcestershire, and Five in Fleetstreet, London.

But Things were by all these degrees only ri∣pening up for worse; for on the 20th of July, the same Day that the King came to the House to pass the abovemention'd Act for Preventing Tumults, his Majesty gave them an Account that he had certain Advice that the Pretender from Abroad, and a Party at Home, were preparing for an At∣tempt against the Government. This Speech o∣pened the first real View to the Nation of the ap∣proaching Rebellion, and is as follows:

Q.P: My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.HI: THE Zeal you have shewn for preserving the Peace of my Kingdoms, and your Wisdom in providing so good a Law to prevent all riotons and tumultuous Proceedings, give me great Satisfaction; but I am sorry to find that such a Spirit of Rebellion has discover∣ed it self as leaves no Room to doubt but these Disorders are set on Foot and encouraged by Persons disaffected to my Government, in Expectation of being supported from Abroad.

The Preservation of our excellent Constitution, and the Security of our holy Religion, has been, and always shall be, my chief Care; and I cannot question but your Concern for these invaluable Blessings is so great, as not to let them be exposed to such Attempts as I have certain Advices are preparing by the Pretender from abroad, and carrying on at home by a restless Party in his Favour.

Q.P: Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

P.HI: In these Circumstances, I think it proper to ask your Assistance, and make no doubt but you will so far consult your own Security, as not to leave the Nation, under a Rebellion actually begun at home, and threatned with an Invasion from abroad, in a defenceless Condition. And I shall look upon the Provision you shall make for the Safety of my People, as the best Mark of your Affe∣ction to me.

Q.P:
The House of Commons, upon this surprizing News, Voted, as they could indeed do no less, an Humble Address to Thank his Majesty for com∣municating to them, the Advices he has received of an Attempt preparing to be made upon the Nation from abroad, aletted and encouraged by treasonable Practices
at home, in favour of a Popish Pretender; and to assure his Majesty, that this House will, with their Lives and Fortunes, stand by and support his Majesty against all his open and secret Enemies; and to desire his Majesty, that he will immediately give Directions for fitting out such a Number of Ships as may effectually guard the Coasts, and to issue out Commissions for augmenting his Forces by Land; assuring his Majesty, this House will, without Loss of Time, effectually enable him to raise and maintain such a Number of Forces, both by Sea and Land, as shall be necessary for the Defence of his sacred Person, and for the Security of his Kingdoms.

DIV2.P: The Lords also presented an Address to the same Purpose.

To back those Addresses with suitable Supplies, they immediately Voted Money for the raising Three Thousand Dragoons, and Four Thousand Foot, besides Four Companies of Foot to be ad∣ded to the Coldstream Regiment, call'd the Second Regiment of Foot Guards, to make it up Two Batallions.

But this was not all; for the House, zealous for the Publick Safety, in so critical a Time, went immediately upon an Act, which nothing but the imminent Danger of a Rebellion could have pre∣vail'd upon them to have pass'd; I mean, an Act to suspend the Habeas Corpus Act for a certain Time, by Empowering the King to secure and detain such Persons as his Majesty shall suspect are Conspiring against his Person and Govern∣ment.

This Act has so much in it, that may be Matter of Precedent in like Cases, and was so much ob∣jected against, that I cannot omit, at least some part of it; in particular, that which relates to the Imprisoning of the Subject: The latter part,
relating to the Seizing and Selling Horses, I omit, as of least Consequence. The Act is as fol∣lows:

Q.P: WHereas there has been a traiterous and detestable Conspiracy formed and contrived, and is still car∣rying on by Papists and other wicked Persons, for in∣vading this Realm, and to raise Insurrections and Re∣bellions within this Kingdom, to the utter Ruin and Subversion of the Protestant Religion, and the Laws and Liberties of this Kingdom; for the better Preser∣vation of his Majesty's sacred Person, and for securing the Peace of this Kingdom in this Time of imminent Danger, against all Attempts and Conspiracies whatso∣ever, be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiri∣tual and Temporal, and the Commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That every Person or Persons that shall be in Prison within the Kingdom of Great Britain, at or upon the Three and Twentieth Day of July, One Thousand Se∣ven Hundred and Fifteen, or after, by Warrant of his said Majesty's most honourable Privy-Council, signed by Six of the said Privy-Council, for Suspicion of High Treason, or treasonable Practices, or by Warrant signed by any of his Majesty's Secretaries of State, for such Causes aforesaid, may be detained in safe Custody with∣out Bail or Mainprize until the Four and Twentieth Day of January, in the Year of our Lord One Thousand Seven Hundred and Fifteen; and that no Judge or Justice of Peace shall bail or try any such Person or Persons without Order from his said Majesty's Privy-Council, signed by Six of the said Privy-Council, till the said Four and Twentieth Day of January, in the Year of our Lord One Thousand Seven Hundred and Fifteen; any Law or Statute to the contrary notwithstand∣ing.

And be it further enacted by the Authority aforesaid, That the Act made in Scotland in the Year of our Lord One Thousand Seven Hundred and One, intituled, An Act for preventing wrongous Imprisonment, and against undue Delays in Tryals, until the said Four and Twentieth Day of January, in the Year of our Lord One Thousand Seven Hundred and Fifteen, be suspended as to all Cases of Treason and Suspicion of Treason.

Provided always, That from and after the said Four and twentieth Day of January, in the Year of our Lord One thousand seven hundred and fifteen, the said Persons so committed shall have the Benefit and Advantage of all Laws and Statutes any way relating to, or providing for the Liberty of the Subjects of this Realm; And that this present Act shall continue until the said Four and twentieth Day of January, in the Year of our Lord One thousand seven hundred and fifteen, and no longer.

P.HI: Provided always, and be it enacted, That nothing in this Act shall be construed to extend to Invalidate the ancient Rights and Privileges of Parliament, or to the Imprisonment, or Detaining of any Member of either House of Parliament, during the sitting of such Parlia∣ment, until the Matter of which he stands suspected be first communicated to the House of which he is a Mem∣ber, and the Consent of the said House obtained for his Commitment or Detaining.

DIV2.P:
On the 23d of July the King gave the Royal Assent to this Bill, and at the same Time a Bill was brought in for the farther Security of the King's Person, and the House then proceeded to address the King to take all the Half-pay Officers into whole Pay for a Year, least the Army should not be sufficient, and to assure the King that the House of Commons would supply the Extraordi∣nary
Expence of it out of the first Aids next Sessi∣on.

On the 28th, this Bill, entituled, For the farther Security of his Majesty's Person and Government was finished, and sent up to the Lords. In a Word, Nothing could be done or desired of any Parlia∣ment, to engage and assist the King, which they did not with the greatest readiness and alacrity come into; And in this Posture Things stood at the First of August, 1716, when the King entred into the Second Year of his Reign, a Year of Trouble, of early Anxiety, and of much Disor∣der, Civil War, and Blood, tho' ending in Victo∣ry and Triumph.

DIV1.HEAD: ANNO 1716.
DIV1.P: AS was express'd in the Close of the last Year, the Second Year of the King was a Year of Victory and Triumph; that is, it Ended in Triumph.

But alas! What Triumph, what Joy has a Father of a Family in the Ruin of the most Disobedient of his Children? What Triumph can a King, who is, or should be, a Father of his Country, make over his ruin'd, tho' rebellious, Subjects? Small Joy can be conceived, to a Mer∣ciful Prince, in the Destruction of his own People, whose Blood is the Strength of the Body Politick, and whose Sorrows and Sufferings must needs (sympathetically speaking) be his own.

However, Rebellion must be resisted; and be they Political Children or Natural Children, 'tis all one, the Disobedient must be reduced, and that even at their own Expence, if it can be done no other way.

This remarkable Year begins so evidently with the Beginning of the Publick Distractions, that this part of our first Volume will be of Course a Histo∣ry of the Rebellion; and tho' I shall be obliged to treat these Subjects in a more concise manner than ordinary, being obliged to bring the History of Four Years into the Compass of One, yet I pro∣mise my self it shall be a more Compleat History of the Rebellion than any that has yet been be∣stow'd upon this Age.

The Beginning of this Second Year of the King, I say, has a different Aspect from the First: At his first Accession the whole People, as one Man, seem'd to be with him; all concurr'd with the Succession of King GEORGE; and so forward to make their Court, that many who thought themselves a little weak in Interest, scrupled not to make that Court at the Expence of one ano∣ther.

But now the Court had, as I may say, a fiery Tryal to go through, and a New Part to act: Every Day brought in Accounts of Tumults, Ri∣ots, Breaches of the Peace, and open Preparati∣ons for War, as well Abroad as at Home, till at length it broke out into open Rebellion, Battle and Bloodshed.

The Parliament having, as I have said, given the King Assurances of their readiness to Support his Interest against all his Enemies at Home or Abroad, gave a full Demonstration of it in pas∣sing that Eminent Act, which I just now na∣med,
for empowering the King to secure and detain such Persons as should be suspected to be conspiring against his Person and Government: This Act, in a word, put the Liberty of every British Subject absolutely into the King's Power, for Six Months; and in Virtue of this Act, abun∣dance of Suspected Persons were taken into Cu∣stody, whereof some lay a great while in Pri∣son.

This was the happy Severity, which, as was ta∣ken Notice of afterwards by the Lord Chancellor, prevented some Gentlemen from falling into the Misery which it was probable would have been the Consequence of their Liberty, if they had join'd in the Rebellion, as it was very likely some of them would have done.
The House having settled this Point, in the next place Voted Supplies for the Troops, which by a former Vote they had consented to have rais'd.

The Government was now Intent upon their Warlike Preparations, and the King applied himself with a peculiar Vigor, to put himself in a Posture to meet the Dangers which threatned him. Sir George Byng was appointed to Command the Squadron of Ships which were ordered to be fitted out on this Occasion, and their Rendezvous was order'd to be in the Downs, that they might be ready as Occasion might require; for it was not known yet where the impending Cloud would break.

General Erle was order'd to Portsmouth, where he was Governor, and a Detachment of Troops were sent to Reinforce the Garrison, there having been some Rumours of Designs to Surprize that Fortress: A Camp having been appointed in Hyde-Park, the Regiments of Guards, as well Horse
as Foot, Encamp'd there; and this it was said, was done as well to secure the Fidelity of the Soldiers, as to have them ready at hand for any Service as Occasion might require. It was said this Camp was to be made up to Ten Thousand Men; but the other Troops had Employment found them farther off.

The Train'd Bands of the City, and the Mili∣tia of several Counties, were ordered to be ready in order to suppress Tumults, the chief Thing perhaps which they were Serviceable for. And the King sent an Order to the Lord-Mayor, &c. to take care of the Publick Peace.

The Country Towns and Corporations, led on by the Bishop and Clergy of London, then by the City of London, (viz.) the Lord-Mayor, Alder∣men and Common Council, crowded up to Court with their Addresses, wherein, even Prodigal of Words, (which cost little) they lay'd Life and Fortune at his Majesty's Feet in a most extraor∣dinary manner: And if the Loyalty was to be Calculated by the Appearance of, and Language in the Addresses, all Things were out of Danger on the King's Side.

I hope it will be concluded, that I am not so empty of Matter as to take up any of these Sheets in repeating those Unmeaning things call'd Ad∣dresses, or the Customary Answers given to them; 'tis enough to say, they were Generally receiv'd very well, and answer'd in the most obliging Terms.

The University of Oxford had the Misfortune to be the only Body whose Address was not receiv'd: But it seems some of the Universities back Friends were pleased to represent them so, as that
they had some Intimation that their Address would not be acceptable; so it was not presented at all.

The Vigor of these Proceedings gave Credit to the Publick Affairs, and was partly the Reason why the Court of France did not care to meddle, nor to appear, at least in assisting the Party; nay, so Pusillanimous some Great People abroad ap∣peared, that the Regent of France perfectly aban∣don'd the Pretender, and neither gave him any Assistance, or so much as protected those who sol∣licited his Affairs.

The Parliament in the mean time, to make themselves Terrible to the Party, began to push on their Judicial Proceedings. The Secret Com∣mittee fell to work with their Impeachments, and particularly, they exhibited 5 new Articles against the Earl of Oxford, and seem'd to breath out the Extream of Resentment against that noble Per∣son, who had now, with an inimitable Courage, put himself into their Hands, and was actually a Prisoner in the Tower. These Articles were said to be those which some Persons had reserv'd in Petto against the Earl, and which were to secure his Prosecution; but they were all too short in their aim at this Great Man, who, we have since seen, by a wonderful Turn of Providence, fully deliver'd out of the Hands of all his Enemies, Whether by the Folly of his Opposers, or the Strength of his own Merit and Innocence, the Se∣quel may make appear at large. These particular Articles, however, were thought of Moment, and therefore I take this Notice of them by way of abstract. It seems it was the affair of the unfor∣tunate Expedition to Canada, that brought these farther Enquiries upon the Stage; which seeing
they appear'd to be under the Earl's Direction, they were willing to lay as much of them to his Charge as they thought might belong to him, though the Articles made no mention of that Af∣fair neither. The Substance of these Articles was as follows:
1. That he had misapplied 12000 l. which was receiv'd on the Earl's Account, by a Warrant from the Queen, obtain'd to one John Drum∣mond, Esq

2. That he had sent abroad Agents of his own, without the Communication of the Allies, to set on foot separate and dangerous Negotiati∣ons, giving them unlimited Credit to draw Bills on him as Treasurer, and had in that manner paid 17920 l. to Mr. Prior and Mr. Harley, &c.
3. That he advised the paying 47000 l. per Ann. to the Queen Dowager.

4. That he advised the receiving Sir Patrick Lawless as a Minister from the King of Spain, and did negotiate with him the most Important Affairs, notwithstanding he was a Subject of the Crown, and under the guilt of High Treason, coun∣tenancing thereby the Emissaries of the Preten∣der.

5. That he had advised her Majesty to abandon the Catalans; at the same time amusing them with Hopes of Care being taken of their Inte∣rests, and treating with the King of Spain with∣out making any Provision for them.

This Month the King came twice to the House in less than Twenty days, to pass Bills, occasion∣ed principally by the weight and import of the Bills which were prepared, and the unusual Expe∣dition
which the House made in passing them: The particular Things I refer to in this, were, the Im∣peachment of the Earl of Bolingbroke, and of the Duke of Ormond; which having not been effectu∣al, by reason of their being withdrawn from the Storm which they saw falling, were follow'd with special Acts of Attainder upon them both.

It was for some time hoped the Duke, at least, would have been excused, having a great stock of Merit for former Services to plead in his Favour; but it would not over-ballance the Charge now brought against him: And his Impeachment be∣ing first carried in the House of Commons by—Voices, he fled, as is said above, and the Attainder was a thing in course.

Some have said, that his Majesty himself had a mind to have Excused the Duke of Ormond; but as the House of Commons seemed very much en∣clin'd to push the Prosecution of these Things without any Respect of Persons, it was not thought convenient to Interpose: So the Duke was left to his Fate.

The Articles of Impeachment against them both, as they are too long for this Tract, so be∣ing publickly Printed on so many several Occasi∣ons, it would be needless to take up any of the Room in this Work. As to the Acts of Attain∣der, they are upon Record, and being Things of course, it is enough to say they were attaint∣ed.
The several Acts pass'd on these Occasions, were as follows:

ITEM.HI: An Act for the better preventing Mutiny and Deser∣tion.
An Act for making more effectual her late Majesty's Intention for augmenting the Maintenance of the Poor Clergy.

LIST.ITEM: An Act to oblige all Waggoners, &c. to draw with no more than Five Horses.
An Act for Repairing the Highways from Barnet to St. Albans.

ITEM.HI: An Act for Enlarging the Fund of the Bank.

LIST.ITEM: An Act for making the Militia of England more useful.

ITEM.HI: An Act for the farther Security of his Majesty's Person and Government.

LIST.ITEM: An Act for Attainder of Henry, Lord Viscount Bolin∣broke.
An Act for Attainder of James, Duke of Or∣mond.

ITEM.HI: An Act for making a former Act more effectual for Regulating the Manufacture of Medly Cloth.
An Act for preventing the Importation of Foreign Fresh Fish.

DIV1.P: All this while the Government were not Idle; indeed it could not be supposed that any Govern∣ment could be Idle in the Circumstances they were in; for every Post brought repeated Accounts of the Disaffection of the People, and of the for∣wardness of the Pretender's Friends, as well a∣broad as at home. As, therefore, they were a∣larm'd every Day with the approaches of Mischief, so they spar'd no Pains to let their Enemies see they would be soon in a Posture to receive them, and to give them occasion to repent any rash At∣tempt they might make; and thus I am brought even to the Beginning of the Rebellion.

The first Publick Thing done, which throughly convinc'd us that the Government had some In∣sight
into what was contriving against them, was, That as the King had formerly notified to the States General the just Reasons he had to believe Designs were forming to disturb the Publick Peace, and to intimate that his Majesty expected their Assistance in the Terms of the several Treaties at that time subsisting (viz.) that they would send over 6000 Men to his Assistance; so now his Ma∣jesty resolved to demand the said 6000 Men.

Nor was this a fruitless Demand, for the Dutch readily and cheerfully granted it, and sent back word immediately to his Majesty, that they should be ready at his Service, whenever his Occasions requir'd them.

As the King was thus gathering together a Force to ward off the Blow when it came, so his Servants and Ministry were busy in diving secretly into the most retir'd Combinations and Cabinets of his E∣nemies, that if possible by alarming them at first, their Measures might be disconcerted, and they might be Disabled from the Undertaking it self.

In this, they were so Vigilant, and withal so Fortunate, that had they but struck one Blow more, and secured one Man more, (viz.) the Earl of Mar, it has been thought by many, the Rebel∣lion had not been undertaken at all; or at least, had not been undertaken at that time.

And on the other hand, had not the Measures which the Ministry took, been thus vigorous and timely, it was very probable that the Rebellion which follow'd had not been so Cheap a purchase to the Conqueror: And though it seems hardly probable, that they could have prevailed effectual∣ly to have set the Pretender actually upon the Throne; yet it was more than probable, that
they would have made this Nation the Seat of a long and bloody War, in which the Country must have been too much a Prey to the Foreign Troops, who, perhaps, on both Sides would have come over as Auxiliaries to their respective Parties.

In order to these Discoveries, the vigilant Mi∣nistry were not wanting of either Secret Agents at home, or Intelligence from abroad; by which they fail'd not to know what was doing in every Place. All the Measures the Pretender took a∣broad to get Arms and Ammunition, to engage Officers, and obtain Troops; to hire Ships, and load Necessaries, were every where Detected, Counter-acted, and Disappointed; Ships procur'd in France were discovered, and by the Regent, who began to act a New Part, (not often heard of in France) forbidden to stir; Ships hir'd, Arms, &c. bought in Holland, Hamburgh, and other Parts, stop'd, and the Persons obliged to scour off, and make the best of their way, for fear of being apprehended: So that in a Word, the Pre∣tender had not a Port where he could openly make any Preparations, or where either himself or any of his Friends could Embark, other than Incogni∣to, and with the greatest Privacy: And this is the reason why, (if it were true, as the E. of Mar him∣self declared in Print) that all that was done, was purely brought to pass by the Zeal and Ardour of those who engag'd on this side; not one Ship with Arms, or Ammunition, or Money, arriving from any of their Friends abroad to their Assistance, all the while they were in Arms.

It is true, we were told otherwise; and it was certain, that several Vessels did arrive, tho' we knew not what they brought; but it seems, tho' we were told much of the great Quantities of Arms, Cannon,
Powder, Ball, Money, &c. which they brought over with them; yet, according to the Earl of Mar, it must be all a Mistake.

But to return to the Earl of Mar, and with him to the beginning of the Year; for it is observed, that the Earl of Mar having taken his Measures before, entered upon his fatal Undertaking the very First of August, the Day Twelve Month of the King's Accession. It is reported, how true I know not, that he went from the very Court, where there was a Ball, and great Appearance of the Nobility and Gentry, on the Occasion; that he made his Complement, and from that Hour commenc'd the Rebellion, going that very Even∣ing down the River, having received his Com∣mission from the Pretender, and sail'd directly for Scotland, where he set up the Standard of his Ma∣ster, as he then call'd the Pretender, and proclaim∣ed him King.

Here it is said again, that the Earl of Mar would gladly have fallen in with the Government, had the Ministry here, either known his Inclinati∣ons so much, or thought him so considerable as to have believ'd it worth while to have received him: And perhaps it might have been so far worth their while to have, by that Means, kept his Hands out of a Work which brought so much loss of Trea∣sure and Blood upon the Nation.

I do not say, as some have suggested, that they saw it, and thought it not worth their while; for certainly had they not thought it worth while to have prevented the Rebellion by entertaining him in the Service, they would have thought it worth while to have done it by detaining him in Custody: And for this Reason, I rather believe the Government had no Notion of his Resoluti∣on,
much less any Intimation or Intelligence of his Design: Neither do I find any thing of his Design laid so deep as some have published, (viz.) That he had Concerted the several Risings which were afterwards spoken of; or that he had re∣ceived a Remittance of 100000 l. Sterling from France.

For, in the whole Management of his Under∣taking, it appeared, there was a manifest Defici∣ency of Money, till he found means to levy Con∣tributions in the Country, and intercept some of the Publick Money; and that he had by no means, any such Encouragement, in the whole, as an Hun∣dred Thousand Pounds Sterling would have been to his Undertaking.

But to go back to his particular Proceedings, He embark'd the next Morning, having with him only Lieutenant General Hamilton, and two Gen∣tlemen more. They landed in Scotland, on the North Shore of the Firth of Forth, at a little Sea∣port call'd Creil, from whence passing by Land to the Bank of Tay, they came to Dundee, where being a little more Master of his own Safety, he had some Conference with his Friends; but made little stay, making his way into the County call'd by his own Name, or rather from whence he takes his Title, (viz.) The County of Mar.

Being arriv'd at Killdrummy, a Seat of his own, he sends private Summons, or Invitations, to such of his Vassals as he thought convenient, and to several Gentlemen in the Counties adjacent, who he knew were in the same Interest, to meet him at a Great Council, as they call'd it, to be held the 16th.

The Assembly was indeed very Great, and, if my Account is Right, was much greater than any of our Accounts represented it to be: Here in par∣ticular assembled the Marquis of Huntley, Eldest Son to the Duke of Gordon; the Marquis of Tul∣libardin, Eldest Son to the Duke of Athol; the Earl of Nithsdale, the same who afterwards made his Escape out of the Tower of London; the Earls of Marischal, Traquhair, Errol, Southesk, Carnwarth, Seaforth, Lithgow, and several others, with the Viscounts Kilsyth, Kenmure, Kingston, and Stor∣mount, and the Lords Rollo, Duffus, and Drum∣mond, and about Twenty-six Gentlemen of Interest in the Highlands, whose Names we have not had Opportunity to get a List of: Among whom were, in particular, the Two Generals Hamilton and Gordon; Glengary, Glenderule, Auchterhouse, Drummond, Don Donald, and others, from the Clans.

Many People have pretended to give us a for∣mal Copy of the Earl's Speech to this Assembly; but I see nothing authentick enough of that kind to be depended upon; the best Abstract which I have met with, of what pass'd, is as follows, (viz.)

That here the Earl of Mar, in a set Speech, excited them all to take up Arms for King James VIII. as he then called the Pretender, and let them know what part he resolved to take with them; (viz.) That he resolved to set up the Pretender's Standard, and to Summon all the fencible Men of his own Tenants, and with them to hazard his Life in the Cause. He encouraged them likewise by giving them assurances, 1. That there would be a General Rising in England upon the same Foot, and perhaps nam'd the particular Places and Per∣sons who really intended, tho' afterwards disap∣pointed,
to have been Raised. 2. That they should certainly have powerful Assistance from France, and from other Parts whence their King, as he call'd him, had already had large Supplies, and Promises of more. 3. That he shewed them the Letters he had received from Lorrain, under the Pretender's own Hand, promising to come o∣ver to them in Person, and put himself upon the Valour and Fidelity of his Scots Subjects, and that in the mean Time they should be sure of Ships, with Arms, Ammunition, and all Military Stores, come to them; with Officers, Engineers, and Voluntiers, as soon as they could give him an Account to what Port they would direct them to be sent. 4. Shew'd them his Commission under the Pretender's own Hand, nominating him Lieu∣tenant General, Commander in Chief, and Di∣rector of the War. And lastly, He assur'd them that he was furnish'd with Money, and should from Time to Time be supplied with sufficient Sums to levy Men, and regularly to pay the Troops that should be raised: So that no Gentlemen should be at any Expence to subsist his Men; but that both they and the Country should be eased of all Burdens of that kind.

If all these Things were represented to them, in a manner suitable to the Occasion, as we have good Assurances they were, we may the less wonder that so many Gentlemen were imposed upon, and drawn into this Insurrection, which, perhaps, would otherwise have reserved themselves to bet∣ter Fortunes: But such Pretences as these, and follow'd immediately by Performances of several Parts of them, it must be confess'd, were as well Calculated to draw the People of that Country in, as could be expected even by themselves.

This Speech, or whatever farther the Earl might say to animate a Set of Men already prepar'd for the Work, and who perhaps waited for nothing but to see a Person Authorized, as they may call it, from the Pretender to head them, had the desi∣red Effect; for they all separated with assurances to one another, to go immediately to work to arm their Men, and put them in a readiness to appear at such Time and Place as the Earl by farther Notice should appoint.

The Earl, who had now made himself Head of the Undertaking, had no more to do but to begin the War himself, and therefore, making no Delay, but drawing his own Men together, with the Assistance of those Gentlemen who were near∣est hand, he appoints the General Rendezvous at Aboyn in Aberdeenshire, on the 3d of September, and having found a considerable Number of Men ready at the Place, they march'd by Concert to the Hills, and Proclaimed the Pretender, setting up his Standard at Brae-Marr, and giving him all the Titles of King, as used before the Union; (viz.) of Scotland, England, France, and Ireland, &c. They had with them about 2000 Men, most Horse, and among them a great many Gentlemen, some Clergymen of the Episcopal Church, and two or three Noblemen, of whom hereafter.

The Dye being now cast, and the Sword drawn, the Scabbard behoved to be thrown away. They were not ignorant of the Power they had to deal with; that they had no Time to lose; and that the first thing they had to do was to Strengthen themselves in such a manner as that they might not be attack'd by such Forces as the King had then in Scotland, and to march and possess them∣selves of some Place of Consideration, which might
serve them as a Place of Arms, and for a Retreat where they might make a stand, and by which means they might have Leisure to cut off the Com∣munication with the rest of Britain, and so the more effectually reduce all the Country behind them.

In order to this, they immediately separated their Forces, which where now Encreasing every Day, and the Heads of the Conspiracy, as it might be call'd, caused the Pretender to be Proclaimed in all the most Considerable Parts of the Country, as at Aberdeen by the Earl Marischal; by the Mar∣quis of Tullibardin, at Dunkeld in the Entrance of the Highlands of Athol; by the Marquis of Hunt∣ley, at Castle-Gordon in the North Highlands; by the Earl of Penmure, at Brechin; by Brigadier Mackintosh, at Inverness; by Graham of Claverhouse, at Montrose; and the like.

The Earl of Mar himself, whose Body of Troops began now to be Considerable, and were said to be 6000 Men, advanced Southward to∣wards the River Tay, and stiling himself Lieuten∣ant General, sent a Detachment of Troops under the Command of the Earl of Southesk to seize upon the City of Perth; whereby he was not only master of the Pass over the Tay, but soon after made him∣self so far Master of the County of Fife, as to lay it under Contribution. And soon after possest himself of all the North-East Shore of Scotland, all the North Shore of the Firth, and all the Towns and Ports as well on the Firth as on the Sea, from Brunt-Island to Aberdeen, and from thence to Inver∣ness, and even of Inverness it self.

The Progress of the Earl of Mar being thus far accounted for, I come to look into the Measures taken at Home, and what particular Steps the
Government took for the Publick Security. It was plain, the whole Succession, as well as the Person of the King, was aim'd at in this Insur∣rection; and the King understood his Danger and his Interest also, too well to sit still in a Case which so particularly concerned both the Honour of his Government and the Safety of his Person; it must be acknowledged, that the King shew'd a very remarkable Steadiness, as to the Event of the Thing, and yet neglected nothing which Pru∣dence dictated to apply suitable Remedies to eve∣ry Part of the Distemper. But above all, it must be observ'd, That the Progress of the E. of Mar did not so alarm the Government as to cause them to leave any part of the Kingdom naked; which was, perhaps, one considerable View of those who made their Risings be in the most remote Parts another way.

But the Government rather seem'd to give a loose for some time to the Extravagancies in the North, than not with the utmost Vigilance and Application to secure every thing and every Part by which the Party could reap any Advantage, or break in upon them on any side nearer Home. Insomuch, that the Scots not seeing the Necessity of these Measures, began to complain, and to think themselves, as it were, abandon'd too much to the Ravages of the Earl of Mar's Army, a great Detachment of which passing the Firth, insulted them even at the Gates of Edinburgh; as shall be seen in its place.

But the Government soon made it appear, that this was absolutely necessary, and that Care should be taken of the South, as the animal Spirits, in Case of an Attack, fly to the Heart; for that it was apparent, the same Temper reign'd in these
Parts, and especially in the South-West Parts of the Kingdom, and threatned not only a powerful Insurrection at Home, but the landing of Help from Abroad; and particularly, the Duke of Or∣mond not only was expected, but did actually come in a French Frigat of Forty Guns, to Tor Bay, and landed there; but finding, by good Intelligence, that all Things were so well guarded that no At∣tempt was to be made, his Grace made off again so timely as not to be intercepted; though some Men of War were immediately dispatcht in quest of him.
