In Pursuance of these Measures, leaving the Earl of Mar to do his worst for a while, the Go∣vernment dispatch'd Troops down into the West and North-West Parts of the Island; as to Bristol, Bath, Exeter, Oxford, and other Places; in which Parts the Disaffection of the People had really appeared so very open, that they had avowed their Readiness to take Arms, if an Opportunity offered, and had more than declar'd, that such an Opportunity was expected by them: For in some Places they had gone so far as to provide Arms and Ammunition, Horses and Men, to be in rea∣diness for the Juncture which they look'd for, or the Watch-word that was to be given. In a word, the Forces were dispers'd through the whole Kingdom, and the Half-pay Officers were sent to proper Places, where they might be useful, as well to manage and discipline the Militia, as to encourage and direct the Gentry, in Case of any Surprize. And yet all was done in such a manner as that a small march, the Troops might upon any alarm be drawn into considerable Bodies, to assist one another: The Wisdom of this Disposition was its own Justification afterwards, when it ap∣peared
that this only was the Safety of the whole Nation; whereas, had an Army been drawn to∣gether at first, and sent into Scotland to have sup∣pressed the Rebellion on that side, England had without doubt been exposed to Insurrections in several Places, and perhaps too strong to be sup∣pressed, without Recalling part of that Army be∣fore their Work had been finish'd in Scotland.

While the Military Dispositions were thus di∣rected, the Civil Government was not Idle; Sus∣pected Persons were taken up in all Parts of the Kingdom, according to the Power granted by the Act of Parliament mention'd before; and this was done at Edinburgh as well as at London. Nor did the Government take their Aim wrong, as afterwards appeared; most, if not all, the Persons taken up, having given good Grounds to believe they had been actually in Arms, if they had not been thus prevented.

The chief Persons apprehended at this Time, were, the Duke of Powis, the Earl of Jersey and Scarsdale, the Lords Lansdown, Dunbar, and Du∣plin, Son-in-Law to the Earl of Oxford; Sir Mar∣maduke Constable; Sir William Wyndham was nam'd, but fled, and was apprehended by a Messenger, but made his Escape; and a Proclamation being publish'd for apprehending him, he surrendered, and was committed to the Tower. Col. Landown, Mr. Harvey of Coomb, Sir George Brown, Mr. An∣stis, since King at Arms; Mr. Kynaston, Mr. Mackartney, Mr. Macdonald, Mr. Hibert, and ma∣ny others, some at London, some at Oxford, and some at the Bath.

Mr. Forster of Northumberland, the Earl of Dar∣wentwater, the Lord Widdrington, and several other North Country Gentlemen, were order'd to be
taken up; but they prevented it, to their own Misfortune, by flying to Arms; And this began the Second Irruption, of which I shall speak in its place.

Some of the above-nam'd Gentlemen being Members of the House of Commons, the King was very tender in that Point, it being Parliament Time; so his Majesty, by Message, acquainted the House of it, September 21 st, signifying, “That having just Cause to suspect those Six Gentle∣men were engag'd in a Design to support the in∣tended Invasion of this Kingdom, his Majesty had therefore given Order for apprehending them, and desired the Consent of the House to Commit and Detain them, if he finds it necessary, in Pursuance of the late Act of Parliament Em∣powering” him so to do.

In Answer to this, the House immediately gave up their Six Members to his Majesty's Pleasure, as to the Committing and Detaining them, in an Address to that Purpose; Returning Thanks to the King for his tender Regard to the Privileges of the House; And desired his Majesty would give Order for the Committing and Detaining the several Members mentioned in the said Message, pursuant to the Act of Parliament; which was af∣terwards accordingly done, tho' all of them were not immediately found; nor were all that were found, detain'd.

In Scotland they proceeded by another Method, (viz.) Summoning those they Suspected, to come in by a certain Day, and to give such Assurances of Fidelity to the Government, as the Law di∣rected; and this upon Pain of Imprisonment, and Confiscation of Estate, as by the Laws of that
Country. The Number of those who were Sum∣mon'd was exceeding Great; and because among them was to be seen almost all the Considerable Persons in the Rebellion, it may not be unprofi∣table to have the Account of them made publick, as follows:

DIV1.P: While these Measures were taken here, such Troops as could be spared were sent Northward, especially into Cheshire, Lancashire, and to the Bor∣ders of Northumberland, (viz.) to Newcastle upon Tyne; which last Place went within a little of be∣ing Surpriz'd, as I shall observe in its order.

What Forces were in Scotland, were ordered to take Post at Sterling, to secure the important Pass of Sterling-Bridge; and in the Capital City of E∣dinburgh, where a Design to Surprize the Castle had been newly discovered, and the Persons who attempted it beaten off, a Serjeant of the Garri∣son who had assisted to Betray the Castle, with some of the Soldiers, were seized; the first of them, some time after the Rebellion was sup∣press'd, was Hang'd over the Wall of the Ca∣stle.

It must be confess'd, had the Earl of Mar suc∣ceeded in the Design of Surprising Edinburgh
Castle, and Mr. Forster in that of Surprising New∣castle upon Tyne, both which were, as it might be said, within an ace of being brought to pass, the Rebellion had been much more formidable than it was: For as one would have been effectu∣ally Master of the Capital City of Scotland, and thereby indeed of all Scotland it self; and the o∣ther of the Second Town in Britain, for Numbers of Men, Number of Ships, and Utensils of War; they would have had not only Time, but Means to have raised a great Army, and have for some Time been Masters of half the Island of Britain. But Fate had other Events appointed, as well on one Side as on the other.

Now, to carry on the Face of a War in a Regu∣lar manner, the King, tho' more Forces could not yet be spared to Scotland, sent down thither the Duke of Argyle, with the Honour of General of all the Forces in that Part of Great Britain call'd Scot∣land, and Two Regiments of Foot and One of Dragoons were ordered to be sent from Ireland to Reinforce the Troops there; also the 6000 Men which were expected every Day from Holland, were determin'd to be sent thither. For, as for England it was resolved, that no Troops should be spared from thence yet, cost what it would.

All this while the Earl of Mar went on streng∣thening himself in Scotland, extending his Quar∣ters, taking in Towns, and putting himself in a Posture for Action. And it must be confest, that notwithstanding his being disappointed in the Surprising the Castle of Edinburgh, yet he had time enough as well to encrease his Army as to fortify his Post; which had he done, he had not been so ea∣sily forced, and might perhaps have made better Conditions for himself, and the unhappy Body that
attended him, when he found himself unable to resist any longer.

And this makes me more apt to give Credit to what the Lord Mar publish'd; (viz.) That he was not assisted from abroad as he expected, and as was reported. For this is most certain, that had he fortify'd the Town of Perth, as it was once said he had, with a Line, and five Bastions, and a double Counterscarp; I say, had he done this, and had been furnished with Artillery, and a Magazine of Ammunition for its Defence, the Royal Army either would not have attempted it in that desperate rigorous Season in which they did, or must have been ruin'd in the Attack; see∣ing it was impossible the Men could have born the vehemence of the Cold two Nights more than they did, in the open Field.

But it appear'd, they had only 4 Pieces of Can∣non in the whole Town, and not Ammunition enough to have serv'd the Cannon, which the De∣fence of such a Town requir'd, no not for Four Days; so that it is apparent, they abandon'd that Place meerly by the necessity of their Circumstan∣ces: Not for want of Men, but want of Means for a Defence.

To give the Earl of Mar therefore his due, it is certain he made the best of it; he put a good Face upon every Thing; and having a visible Superiority of Forces, he pusht as far as lay in his Power; by which, and by all the other Circumstances of his Conduct, it appears, that he depended upon the Rising of other Parties in Eng∣land at the same Time.

He had, as is observed, taken Perth, which was indeed a great Blow to the publick Affairs; not only as it secured him the whole Country be∣hind,
but as it elevated the Spirits of his Men to expect greater Matters, gave Reputation to his Undertaking, and made him appear formidable abroad. Nor was it a little advantage to him in the main Article of raising Money; for now he laid all the Country between the Firth of Forth and the Firth of Tay, under Contribution.

By this Step he had Opportunity also to make some very successful Excursions; as particularly, that of Brunt-Island, which was an Affair very well foreseen, and very well executed; the Case was this: “About 400 small Arms, with Ammunition in Proportion, and several other Military Stores, were order'd by the Government out of the Magazine at Edinburgh-Castle, for the Use of the Earl of Sutherland, who was going to Dunrobin, in the Noth, in order to raise a Force in the Rear of the Earl of Mar, as shall be seen in its” Course.

P.Q: “These Arms and Warlike Stores were put on Board a Vessel belonging to Brunt-Island, a Town on the North-side of the Firth, directly opposite to Leith; and the Vessel being loaden, lay some Days for a fair Wind in Leith Road; but the Wind blowing hard at North-East, which makes a foul Road in the offing of Leith, the Master weighed, and stood over to the Shore of Fife near Brunt-Island, which was then the Weather-Shore: As the Ship was known in the Town, the Ma∣ster and Owners being all Inhabitants; so the Earl of Mar got Intelligence of it, and of her” Loading also.

“Immediately, upon this Advice, he made a Detachment of 400 Horse and 500 Foot, to seize this Booty; part of the Horse went before, carrying every Man a Footman behind him,
they order'd their March so, as to come to Brunt-Island in the middle of the Night, to pre∣vent any Boat going off the Ship to give her Notice to cut and be gone, or to the Men of War to come in to her Rescue: But by their entring in the Dark, they surpriz'd the Town; and immediately the Foot, knowing their Bu∣siness, seiz'd upon all the Boats upon the Shore, or in the Harbour, the Horse, in the mean time, surrounding the Town, to prevent any one go∣ing out to carry the News to other Parts, so as that any Boats might go off from Kinghorn, which” was a Town within two Miles.

“Having thus seized upon the Boats, they em∣bark'd about 120 of their Men, and boarded the Ship, seiz'd and secur'd her without any Opposition; they weighed her Anchor, as some say, with Design to bring her into the Har∣bour; but the Tide not serving, they dropt the Anchor again, and fell to work with her Cargo; in short, they soon handed out the Arms and Stores, &c. into their Boats; and pressing Carts and Horses in the Country round, they carried off their Booty the next Day, with∣out any Opposition. It seems this Detachment march'd so silently, or the Duke of Argyle's Spies, or Scouts, did their Duty so ill, that he had no Intelligence of their March till the next Day in the Afternoon, when the same Per∣sons that acquainted him of their March, assu∣red him of the Success of it, and that it was to no Purpose to attempt to intercept them in their Retreat, for that they were already gotten great Part of the Way; carrying their Booty, for their greater Safety, directly to Dundee: Tho' that Part of the Intelligence was wrong
too, if the rest of the Story be right; which was” this:

“That the Earl of Mar, not doubting but the Duke of Argyle would have Notice of their March, and would make a strong Detachment to intercept them in their Return, resolved to march in Person to a Town call'd Arva, within four or five Miles of Sterling, with 6000 Men, in order to alarm the Duke, and divert him from attempting to send any Detachment out to intercept his Men with their Booty; or that if such Detachment was made, then to face the Left, and cut of the Retreat off that Detach∣ment.”

“This Stratagem took as well as he could wish; for the Duke of Argyle hearing that the Earl of Mar was to be at Arva with a strong Detach∣ment that Night, the willinger laid aside his Design of sending a Party to intercept the Men that had the Booty, order'd out the Piquet, both of Horse and Foot, to fall upon the Rebels, and kept the rest of the Army under Arms all Day, to be ready to sustain them, if the Enemy” were too strong for them.

“But the Earl of Mar had done his Business; for the Booty being seized according to his De∣sire, and the Troops gone with it directly for Perth, and past Danger, he gave himself no Trouble to go to Arva, as was intended; but having amused the Royal Army with Expectati∣ons of an Action, he did his own Business with∣out any visible Difficulty; and the Duke's Men having found that no Enemy had been at Arva, or was to be heard of, retir'd to Sterling. These Things were done the second and third of Octo∣ber,” 1715.

DIV1.P: Thus far the Earl of Mar went on with great Success, and his Party were hearten'd to a Degree greater than they themselves expected; and these Things had this particular Effect also; That it encouraged the march of their Friends from all Parts to join them; and Troops came to them eve∣ry Day; as particularly, they publish'd, That Brigadier Mackintosh joined him, the 5th of Octo∣ber, with 500 Men, almost all of them of the same Name. On the 6th, the Marquis of Huntley came in with 500 Horse and 2000 Foot. On the 10th, the Earl Marischal brought him 300 Horse, and 500 Foot, and abundance of Gentlemen a∣mong them. The Earl of Scaforth continued with 4000 Men, Horse and Foot, in the North, to face the Earl of Sutherland, who arm'd there for the King, having been sent by Sea thither for that Purpose, with Arms, Ammunition, and a Com∣mission for Raising Men.

Being thus encouraged, they rang'd over the whole Country, and lived at large for some time. The Accounts made publick at that Time, gave several Particulars of Ships coming daily in with Arms, Ammunition, Money, Officers, and Volun∣tiers; but as the Earl of Mar positively denies that ever any such Ships came in, and that, as before, it appear'd plainly enough, that they never were supplied with either Cannon, Ammunition, or Arms, I cannot but think what the Earl of Mar publish'd, was so far at least True.

Indeed, as they were now possess'd of near Two thirds of Scotland, their Friends, if they had any Interest abroad, had a fair Advantage to have push'd the Cause: But 'twas evident, the King's Interest, and the Vigilance of his Agents abroad, was such as effectually prevented any thing being
done for them: And even in France it self, what Attempts were made to supply them with Arms and Ammunition, Men and Money, was discou∣raged, and forbidden even by the Regent him∣self.

All this while the King's Army, which drew together at Sterling, under the Command of Ma∣jor-General Wightman, could not, with the addi∣tion of Two Regiments of Dragoons, make up full 1800 Men: And tho' there was some talk of a great Body of Western Highlanders coming in, yet they never came up; at least, not to any Action. However, this small Body kept the Rebels from passing the River Forth, and Ravaging the South of Scotland, as they would otherwise have done, but were not able, without extream Hazard, to do, as appeared afterwards. There was indeed another Bridge over the Forth, higher up the River, call'd the Bridge of Down; but this the King's Troops sent a strong Detachment to De∣molish and break down; which was accordingly done. And as for the Fords, they were all un∣passable at that Season, by Reason of the great Rains and Snows which fell continually for some Weeks together.

Thus Providence, and the Care of the General, kept the Earl of Mar and his Army from coming over the Forth; which had they done, the Low∣lands of Clydsdale, and the City of Glasgow, with all the West Part of Scotland, had been over-run by them, and they would have had an open Pas∣sage into England by the way of Drumfriesshire and Carlisle.

Nor can the Earl of Mar ever be excused by his Party, either of want of Courage, or want of Conduct, that he being so strong as was reported,
(viz.) 10 or 12000 Men, and the King's Army not full 2000 Men, that he should not march and have forced his way at Sterling, or at Alloway, his own Hereditary Seat, where he might have ferried over his Army, the River being narrow enough, and might have driven the few Troops the King's Officers had there, either all into the Castle, where they must have perished for want, or have obliged them to Surrender. But it was not done; and indeed they did little more than sit still for several Months, and consume themselves, as will appear in the rest of the Sto∣ry.

It is true, the King's Men were entrench'd un∣der the Cannon of the Castle of Sterling, and the Bridge was easily defended: But on the other hand, the Enemy might have only fac'd the Bridge with one Part of their Army, while they had pass'd the River with the other, and they could not have met with any Disturbance, at that Time, from the Royal Army, their Number was so small: Nor durst they have divided their Troops for fear of the Bridge being attackt on one hand while they might have marcht to have obstructed the Landing on the other. The Earl of Mar, therefore, can never be excused by his Friends, that he had not marcht with his whole Army while the Royal Army was so small; in which Case, had he past the Forth at Alloway, and marcht directly to Edinburgh, the City had been in no Condition to have shut her Gates against them. But the Saying of the Ancients was verified in them:
DIV1.Q: Qui Jupiter Vult perdere hos dementat.
DIV1.P: I return now to the History of Fact. The Re∣bellion was now in its full Strength in the North of Scotland, the Earl of Mar being, as I have said, fully possest of the whole Country North by Forth; and tho' the South Parts were not yet in his Hands, yet even they, were in a very un∣settled and precarious Condition: Even the City of Edinburgh it self, tho' the Sum of the affair consisted in their Safety, were yet without Arms, without Artillery, and without Troops to Cover and Defend them. The Duke of Argyle indeed was sent down; and his very Presence, joined with his Authority, was a great Encouragement to the Citizens. But alas! he brought no Troops with him; not one Regiment; and bare Words would have gone but a little way with them, if the Enemy had appeared in any Numbers suffici∣ent to have forced them.

The Duke however did what he could, and, in particular, published an Order for the Encou∣raging of Voluntiers; of whom great Numbers were talk'd of, but few appear'd. However, that it might be seen the General did what lay in his Power, to bring them together, he published the following Order:

Q.P: John, Duke of Argyle, General and Commander in Chief of his Majesty's Forces in North-Britain, to the Lords Lieutenants, Deputy Lieutenants; and in their Absence, to the Well-affected Heritors in the Western and Southern Shires in Scotland, and in particular to the Justices of Peace, Magistrates of Burghs, and other Judges and Officers, Civil and Military.

P.Q:
“WHHEREAS great Numbers of well-affected Noblemen, Gentlemen, and others, in the
Southern and Western Shires of Scotland, being in readiness to march to such Places as they shall be appointed, may be desirous to have a par∣ticular Order for that Effect These are there∣fore, in his Majesty's Name, and by his Autho∣rity, requiring, ordering, and authorizing the Lord Lieutenants, Lieutenant-Deputies; or, in their Absence, all well affected Heritors, and each of them, in the Western and Southern Shires aforesaid, to march forthwith their sen∣cible Men, with their best Arms, and what Ammunition they have, and with Forty Days Provision, towards Glasgow; and to quarter there, or in the adjacent Towns or Villages on the North-side of the River Clyde, in order to be ready to assist in the opposing and extin∣guishing the Rebellion, now rais'd against our Laws, our Liberties, and the Protestant Religi∣on. Given at our Camp at Stirling, the 2d of” October, 1715.

DIV1.P: ARGYLE.

But as the Duke found few come in, and the Earl of Rothes, and the Voluntiers which were assembled at Lsh, (his Lordship's House) were obliged to abandon it, and disperse again; the Duke plainly saw that nothing but regular Disci∣plin'd Forces could do the Work, and wrote at large to the King, to lay before his Majesty the Necessity of sending speedy Succours.

But all that the Court could do at that time, was to assure him, that the Dutch Troops, which were expected every hour, should be dispatch'd to Scotland as soon as they arrived. The Duke then apply'd himself to raise Men there by Beat of Drum, to fill up the Companies who were up∣on
the old Foot, and to raise each Company to 50 Men each; but this did not answer the End any more than the other, the Drum bringing in very few Voluntiers.
The Sword of War being now drawn, the Votes and Speeches of Parliament began to De∣crease, and the Houses drawing their Business to a Crose, all Things tended to a Recess.

In order to this, the King came to the House the 21st of September, when the Speaker present∣ed the Money Bills, he made a Speech to the King, which, for Brevity's sake, I omit. After the Speaker had presented his Bills, the King gave the Royal Assent to the following publick Acts:
1. An Act to enable his Majesty to settle a Revenue upon her Royal Highness.
2. An Act for enlarging the capital Stock, and yearly Fund of the South-Sea Company.
3. An Act for making Provision for the Mini∣sters of the Fifty New Churches.
4. An Act for preventing Disturbances by Sea-Men, &c.
5. An Act for appointing Commissioners for examining Debts due to the Army.
6. An Act for stating the Debts due to Scotland for the Equivalent.
7. An Act for continuing several Laws near expiring.
8. An Act concerning the Yule vacance in Scot∣land.
9. An Act for allowing a Time for the Pala∣tines, who were settled in Ireland, to take the Oaths.
10. An Act to make the River Kennet naviga∣ble.
11. An Act for repairing the High-ways be∣tween Tyburn and Uxbridge.
And to Seven private Acts; and then his Ma∣jesty made a Speech to them, which was read by the Lord Chancellor, and is as fol∣lows, viz.

P.HI: My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.Q: “I Am perswaded you are all by this time very desirous of some Recess; and that it cannot be deferr'd longer, without great Inconveniency” to your private Affairs.

“But before I can part with you, I must return you my most sincere Thanks for your having fi∣nish'd, with so much Wisdom and Unanimity, what I recommended to your Care: And par∣cularly I must thank you, Gentlemen of the House of Commons, for the Provision you have made, as well for the Support of the Honour and Dig∣nity of the Crown, as for the other necessary Occasions of the Publick; especially for your having done it by Means so little burdensome to my People; which, I assure you, recommends the Supplies to me above any other Circumstance” whatsoever.

P.HI: My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.Q: “The open and declared Rebellion, which is now actually begun in Scotland, must convince all, who do not wish to see us given up into the Hands of a Popish Pretender, of the Dangers to” which we have been, and are still expos'd.

“I thought it incumbent upon me, to give you the earliest Notice of the Designs of our Ene∣mies; and I cannot sufficiently commend the Zeal and Dispatch with which you empower'd me, at a Time when the Nation was in so na∣ked and defenceless a Condition, to make such Preparations as I should think necessary for our Security. You shall have no Reason to repent of the Trust and Confidence you repose in me, which I shall never use to any other End, than for the Protection and Welfare of my” People.

“It was scarce to be imagined, That any of my Protestant Subjects, who have known and enjoyed the Benefits of our excellent Constitu∣tion, and have heard of the great Dangers they were wonderfully deliver'd from by the happy Revolution, should, by any Arts and Management, be drawn into Measures that must at once destroy their Religion and Liberties, and subject them to Popery and arbitrary Power; but such has been our Misfortune, that too ma∣ny of my People have been deluded, and made instrumental to the Pretender's Designs, who had never dared to think of invading us, or raising a Rebellion, had he not been encouraged by the Success his Emissaries and Adherents have already had, in stirring up Riots and Tumults, and by the further Hopes they entertain, of raising Insurrections in many Parts of my King∣doms.”

“The endeavouring to perswade my People, that the Church of England is in Danger under my Government, has been the main Artifice employed in carrying on this wicked and trai∣terous Design. This Insinuation, after the so∣lemn
Assurances I have given; and my having laid hold on all Opportunities to do every Thing that may tend to the Advantage of the Church of England, is both unjust and ungrateful: Nor can I believe so groundless and malicious a Ca∣lumny can make any Impression upon the Minds of my faithful Subjects; or that they can be so far misled, as to think the Church of England is to be secur'd by setting a Popish Pretender on the” Throne.

P.HI: My Lord, and Gentlemen,

P.Q: “The Proofs this Parliament has given of their unshaken Duty and Affection to me, and of their Love and Zeal for the Interest of their Coun∣try, will recommend you to the good Opinion and Esteem of all, who have their Religion and Liberty truly at Heart, and has laid a lasting Obligation upon me; and I question not but by your further Assistance in the several Countries to which you are going, with the Blessing of Almighty God, who has so frequently inter∣posed in Favour of this Nation, I shall be able to disappoint and defeat the Designs of our E∣nemies.”

“Our Meeting again to do Business early in the next Winter, will be useful on many Ac∣counts; particularly, that the Sitting of Parlia∣ments may be again brought into that Season of the Year which is most convenient; and that as little Delay may be given as is possible to your judicial Proceedings; and I shall at present give such Orders to my Lord Chancellor, as may not put it long out of my Power to meet you on any” sudden Occasion.

DIV1.P: After this Speech, the Houses were order'd to adjourn themselves to the 6th of October; from whence, by farther Adjournments, they had a Recess to the 14th of December, when, by Procla∣mation, they had Notice to sit again to do Busi∣ness, as we shall see in its Place.

It began now to appear, by the Face of Affairs in England, that the Heart of the Rebellion was broken, and that not by the King's Forces; for there had been no Action yet, in which the King's Interest had not been rather Loser than Gainer, except that of the Castle of Edinburgh. But the breaking the Measures of those who had lay'd their Schemes for making the Rebellion General, or rather Universal, this, I say, was a Great Blow given to the Interest, and did more than over∣throwing the Earl of Mar and all his Army would have done.

The Surprising Sir William Wyndham, and Mr. Harvey of Coomb, who endeavour'd to de∣stroy himself by stabbing himself into the Body; the Dispersing the Gentlemen at the Bath, and seizing their Arms; the crushing the Correspon∣dences at Oxford; and in a word, posting Soldi∣ers in every Corner of the Kingdom, so that no∣thing could stir. These were the Disappoint∣ments; these were the Blows that wounded the Earl of Mar, tho' at a great Distance, in the most sensible Part, and which in effect Overthrew the whole Undertaking: For it is evident, the main Dependance of the Earl of Mar, and his whole Army, was not that they were able fight or grap∣ple with the King's whole Power; but that they expected the whole Party should rise throughout the Kingdom, and should so divide the Royal
Forces as that he should be able to do his Work without being obliged to fight with a Superior Number of Troops before he was ready to en∣gage them.

This the Government was aware of, and this was the most essential Point the Ministry had to guard against; and which was so effectually done, that nothing could stir in the remotest Cor∣ner, but the King had Troops at hand to attack and suppress it, even in its Bud, in its Infancy; as was the Case at the Bath, at Bristol, at Shrews∣bury, at Excester, in Cornwal, at Manchester, at Ox∣ford, and several other Places, where the Common People shew'd their Dispositions to Revolt.

The North seem'd the only Place where the Rebellion, being gotten to a Head, requir'd more Troops to reduce it than could be spar'd at that time, from the other more Necessary Work of se∣curing the more dangerous Parts of the Kingdom. And this Place being so remote, there appear'd less Hazard in letting them go on a while without being formally attackt, than would have been in other Places; and therefore, they were suffered, for a while, to Range about the Country, and do a World of Mischief, more than they would otherwise have been permitted to do, Unfought with.

This Relates, particularly, to the Rising of Mr. Forster and his Party, in Northumberland; the Rising of the Earl of Kenmure and his Party, in the West of Scotland; the Landing of Brigadier Mac∣kintosh on the South-side of the Firth of Edinburgh. And these 3 Bodies joining together afterwards up∣on the Borders, and Marching into England; which makes together the Second main Branch of the Rebellion; an Abstract of whose Story I have re∣serv'd
for this Place, that it may come as whole together as I can, and the Reader may not lose himself in the frequent Interruptions of the Rela∣tion.

There had been some Measures concerted at London for this Rising, some time before it broke out; to which Capt, John Shafloe, a Half-pay Officer, since executed at Preston, and Capt. John Hunter of North-Tyne, in the County of Northum∣berland, who had a Commission from Queen Anne to raise an independant Company, but did not, assisted: Besides these two, there was one Captain Robert Talbot, an Irishman, formerly in the French Service, who likewise being ac∣quainted with the Design in August, 1715, took Shipping at London, and went to Newcastle. By this Gentleman, the Resolutions taken at London were first communicated to their Friends in the North of England, and Means used to persuade and prepare the Gentlemen they had embark'd with them, to be ready to rise upon Warning given. Other principal Men entrusted with these Negotiations, were, Colonel Oxburgh, Mr. Nich. Wogan, Mr. Charles Wogan, and Mr. James Talbot, all Irish Gentlemen: A second Class of Agents consisted of Mr. Clifton, Brother to Sir Gervase Clifton, and Mr. Beaumont, both Gentlemen of Nottinghamshire, and Mr. Buxton a Clergyman of Derbyshire. All these rid like Gentlemen, with Servants and Attendants, and were arm'd with Sword and Pistols. They kept always moving, and travelled from Place to Place, till Things ri∣pened for Action. The first Step towards their appearing in Arms, was, when, about the latter end of September, the Lord Derwentwater and Mr. Forster had notice that there was a Warrant out
from the Secretary of State to apprehend them, and that the Messengers were come to Durham that were to take them.

Upon this News, they had a full Meeting of the Parties concern'd, in Northumberland; where consulting all the Circumstances of their Friends, and of the Interest they were embark'd in, they boldly resolv'd, That since there was no Safety any longer in shifting from Place to Place; but that in a few Days they should be all secur'd, and clapp'd up in several Prisons, or hurried away to London; where as they should be severally confin'd, so they would be severally examined, and none could say what the other should answer: So that for fear of betraying one another, they should be really brought to do it; That now was the time to shew their Loyalty to their King (Pretender,) and that if this Opportunity was lost, they had no room to hope for another; and that therefore they would immediately appear in Arms.

Pursuant to this Resolution, an Appointment was made, and Notice of it sent to all their Friends, to meet the next Morning, which was the 6th of October, at a Place called Green-rig, where Mr. Forster, with about Twenty Gentle∣men, met as at the Rendezvous; they made no stay there, thinking the Place inconvenient, but rode immediately to the top of a Hill called the Waterfalls; from whence they might discover any that came either to join them, or to oppose them. They had not been long here, before they disco∣vered the Earl of Derwentwater, who came that Morning from his own Seat at Dilston, with some Friends, and all his Servants, very well mounted and arm'd. They were now near 60 Horse, most Gentlemen and their Attendants; when, calling a
short Council, it was concluded to march towards the River Coquett, to a Place called Plainfield: Here they were join'd by others, who came strag∣gling in, and having made some stay here, they resolved to go that Night to Rothbury, a small Market-Town: Here they stay'd all Night; and next Morning, being the 7th of October, their Number still encreasing, they marched to Wark∣worth, another Market-Town upon the Sea-coast, and strong by its Situation, famous formerly for a Castle, the Body of which still remains, and an ancient Cell cut out of a solid Rock: Here they continued till Monday; during which time, no∣thing material happened, except that on Sunday Morning Mr. Forster, who now stiled himself Ge∣neral, sent Mr. Buxton their Chaplain to Mr. Ion the Parson of the Parish, with Orders for him to Pray for the Pretender as King; and in the Litany, for Mary Queen-Mother, and all the dutiful Branches of the Royal Family; and to omit the usual Names of King George, the Prince and Princess; which Mr. Ion declining, the other, viz. Mr. Bux∣ton, did it for him. The next thing they did, was openly to Proclaim the Pretender as King of Great Britain, &c. It was done by Mr. Forster in Disguise; and by the sound of Trumpet, and with all the Formality that the Circumstances and Place would admit. It may be observed, that this was the first Place where the Pretender was so avowed∣ly Pray'd for and Proclaimed as King of these Realms.

On Monday the 10th of October, they marched to Morpeth, where their Number got a considera∣ble Addition: At Felton-Bridge they were joined by 70 Scots Horse, or rather Gentlemen, from the Borders; and they had been considerably encreas∣ed
before, in their March from Warkworth, at Alnwick, and other Places; so that at their en∣tring this Town they were 300 strong, all Horse; for they would entertain no Foot, else their Num∣ber would have been very large: But as they neither had nor could provide Arms for those they had mounted, they gave the Common People good Words, and told them that they would soon be furnished with Arms and Ammunition, and that then they would List Regiments to form an Army: This was upon the Expectation they had of surprising Newcastle; in which case, they did not question to have had as many Foot as they pleas'd. Here Mr. Forster received an Account that Mr. Lancelot Errington, and some others, had surprized the Castle in Holy Island; which is a small Fort guarded by a few Soldiers sent Weekly from the Garrison at Berwick. Errington, undisco∣vered, took Boat, and went to Sea, and with his Companions landed under the Cover of the Wall, and got into the Fort by Surprize; though he kept the Possession but a very little while, for the Go∣vernor of Berwick having an immediate Account of the Action, and resolving, if possible, to reco∣ver the Place before Errington could be supply'd with Men and Provisions, detach'd a Party of 30 Men of his Garrison, with about 50 Voluntiers of the Inhabitants, and marching over the Sands at Low-water-mark, attack'd the Fort, and took it Sword in hand; Errington himself attempting to make his Escape, was wounded, and taken Prison∣er, with several others. N. B. He with his Brother, afterwards got out of Berwick in Disguise. The Design of taking this Fort was, to give Signals to any Ships that seem'd to make to the Coast to land
Soldiers; for by the Assurances they had from Friends beyond Sea, they expected them to land on that Coast with Supplies of Arms and Offi∣cers; but they never came till they were gone for Scotland, and then 2 Ships, as it is said, appeared off at Sea, and made their Signal; but having no An∣swer from the Shore, made sail Northward. The Rebellion was now formed, and they were all in a Body at Morpeth, promising themselves great Things at Newcastle, also several Gentlemen join∣ed them there, and several of the Country People came in, and offer'd to List; but they still de∣clined them, and prepared to march to Newcastle; and here also they Proclaimed the Pretender. Here it was that they receiv'd their first Disappoint∣ment, (viz.) in the Affair of Newcastle, which they expected should open its Gates to them; whereupon they changed their Course, and Marched to Hexham, a Pass upon the River Tyne: Here they were joined by some more Scots Horse. From this Town they all march'd, few or none knowing whither, and went three Miles distant to a Heath or Moor adjoining to Dilston, the Seat of the Lord Derwentwater, and there they made a Halt; this was with Design, as was thought, to go back to Newcastle, which Town they still had some Hopes of Surprising; but being afterwards fully informed, that their Measures for Surprising the Town were quite broken, they went back again to Hexham, where they staid but three Days, tho' they were not idle during that time; for first they seized all the Arms and Horses they could lay they Hands on Next, here their Chaplain again went to the Minister of the Town, and desired him or his Curate to read Prayers, commanding that in them he should mention the Pretender by Name,
as King James III. The Minister modestly de∣clined it; so Mr. Buxton officiated, and perform∣ed as usual. The Night before they left the Town, they were all drawn round the Cross in the Market-place, where the Pretender was Pro∣claimed, and the Proclamation fixed to the Cross; which remain'd there several Days after they were gone; which, some say, is an Evidence of that Town's good Inclination to one side or other. Here they had notice of the Vis∣count Kenmure, Earls of Nithsdale, Carnwath, and Wintoun, who had taken Arms in Nithsdale, Dumfreisshire, and other Places in the West of Scot∣land, having entred England to join them, and that they were come to Rothbury. The Viscount Ken∣mure, the only Nobleman in that part of Scotland capable of commanding Forces upon that Account, set up the Pretender's Standard at a small Town in Annandale called Mophet. This Standard, suppo∣sed to be made by his Lady, was very handsome, one side being Blue, with the Scot's Arms done in Gold; the other side a Thistle, with this under, No Union; above the Thistle, the usual Motto, Nemo me impune lacesset. This Standard had Pen∣dants of white Ribbon; upon one of these was written, For our Wronged King, and Oppressed Coun∣try; the other Ribbon had thereon, For our Lives and Liberties. This Standard was set up the first Night they made their Appearance. Being late, next Day being the 13th of October they marched towards Dumfreis, with a Design to surprize that Town; but the Marquis of Annandale, whom they had followed the Day before, having none but his Servants along with him, entred the Town, and concerted such Measures as made that Design
abortive; which obliged them to alter their Rout, tho' many Disputes happen'd hereupon, but at last they agreed to march to Loughmaben that Night, where next Day they set up their Standard again, and proclaimed the Pretender. This Town was the first Place, on this side the Forth of Scotland, where the Pretender was proclaimed, and his Stan∣dard set up. That Day the Standard was carried by John Dalziel Esq Brother to the Earl of Carn∣wath. On the 14th of this Month they march'd to Achelfechen. On their March thither, on a Common, being in all near 200 Horse, they were formed into a Regiment, divided into two Squa∣drons. The chief Command to Viscount Ken∣mure, that of each Squadron to the Earls of Win∣toun and Carnwath. Hence they marched regular∣ly, and sent their Quarter-Master-General Mr. Calderwood to take up Quarters for them. Next Day they continued their March to Langholm, be∣having themselves all along Civil in their Quar∣ters. From thence they continued their Rout to Hawick. Upon these Marches their Number en∣creased. At this Place they were alarm'd, which raised some Disputes whether they should proceed. They agreed to return, but had an Express from Mr. Forster about two Miles from Hawick, towards Langholm. This Messenger, Mr. Duglass, had an Invitation from the Northumberland General to my Lord Kenmure and his Followers, to meet him at Rothbury: So they faced about, and marched that Night to Jedburgh. Here they received In∣telligence of the Mackintosh's crossing the Forth, and the Duke of Argyle's Resolution to attack them; which put them into mighty Pain how the Consequence would prove. It is to be observed,
that they were alarmed in marching to Jedburgh; Being late, their Advance Guard was surpriz'd by the Shouts of one who called out, That the Grey Horse were ready to fall on them, and had cut the Quarter-Master and those with him into pieces. Those acquainted with the Quarter-Ma∣ster assured Lord Kenmure, that he would by no means be so easily ensnar'd, being better used to Military Affairs; so they continued their March, and entred the Town without Opposition. Here, as in most other Towns, they proclaimed the Pretender; next Morning proceeded to Rothbury, perhaps such a March as few People are acquaint∣ed with, being very mountains, long, tedious, and marshy. From Rothbury they dispatch'd Mr. Burnett of Carlips to Hexam, to Mr. Forster, to know his Mind, Whether he would come towards them, or they should advance? He returned an Express, that he would join them, and according∣ly prepared to march; and the rather, because they heard from Newcastle, that General Carpenter was preparing to attack them They left Hexham on Wednesday the 19th of October, and making a long March, they joined the Lord Kenmure that Night; and both of them next Day march'd to Wooler, in the Country of Northumberland. Here Mr. Errington brought them an Account of the Highlanders being also coming to join them, and that they were advanced to Dunse, of which a full Account has been given already. On this News they march'd for Kelso in Scotland. On this Day's March they seiz'd several Horses, and made Mr. Selbye, a Gentleman of that Country, Prisoner. A little before they came to Kelso, they made a Halt upon a Moor; and there the Gentlemen formed
into Troops, were drawn out by themselves, and called over; not only by their Names, but by their design'd Offices for the several Troops: And it is to be observed, that to each Troop they as∣signed Two Captains, being the only way they had to oblige so many Gentlemen. Next Morn∣ing the Highlanders were drawn up in the Church∣yard, and so march'd in Order to the Market∣place, with Colours flying, Drums beating, and Bag-pipes playing, and there formed a Circle, the Lords and other Gentlemen standing in the Centre: There was an inner Circle formed also by the Gentlemen Voluntiers. Then Silence being enjoined, the Trumpet sounded; after which the Pretender was proclaimed by one Sea∣ton Barns, who assum'd the Title of Earl of Dumferling. The Proclamation was to this Ef∣fect:

P.Q: “Whereas by the Decease of the late King James the VIIth, the Imperial Crowns of these Realms did lineally descend to his lawful Heir and Son our Sovereign James the VIIIth: We the Lords, &c. do declare him our lawful King” over Scotland, England, &c.

DIV1.P: Then was read the following Manifesto of the Earl of Mar.

Q.P: MANIFESTO by the Noblemen, Gentlemen, and others, who dutifully appear at this Time in asserting the undoubted Right of their lawful So∣vereign James VIII. by the Grace of God, King of Scotland, England, France, and Ireland, Defen∣der of the Faith, &c. and for relieving this his an∣cient Kingdom from the Oppressions and Grievances it lies under.

P.Q: “HIS Majesty's Right of Blood to the Crowns of these Realms is undoubted, and has never been disputed or arraign'd by the least” Circumstance of lawful Authority.

“By the Laws of God, by the ancient Consti∣tutions, and by the positive unrepeal'd Laws of the Land, we are bound to pay his Majesty the Duty of Loyal Subjects. Nothing can ab∣solve us from this our Duty of Subjection and Obedience; the Laws of God require our Al∣legiance to our rightful King; the Laws of the Land secure our Religion and other Interests; and his Majesty giving up himself to the Sup∣port of his Protestants Subjects, puts the Means of securing to us our Concerns Religious and” Civil in our own Hands.

“Our Fundamental Constitution has been en∣tirely altered and sunk amidst the various Shocks of unstable Faction; while in the searching out new Expedients pretended for our Security, it has produced nothing but daily Disappoint∣ments, and has brought us and our Posterity un∣der a precarious Dependance upon foreign Councils and Interests, and the Power of foreign” Troops.

“The late unhappy Union, which was brought about by the mistaken Notions of some, and the ruinous and selfish Designs of others, has prov'd so far from lessening and healing the Differences betwixt his Majesty's Subjects of Scotland and England, that it has widened and increased them; and it appears by Experience so inconsistent with the Rights, Privileges, and Interests of us and our good Neighbours and Fellow-Subjects of England, that the Continu∣ance of it must inevitably ruin us, and hurt them. Nor can any Way be found out to relieve us, and restore our ancient and independent Constitution, but by restoring our rightful and natural King, who has the only undoubted Right to reign over us: Neither can we hope that the Party who chiefly contribute to bring us into Bondage, will at any time endeavour to work our Relief; since it is known how strenu∣ously they opposed, in Two late Instances, the Efforts that were made by all Scotsmen by them∣selves, and supported by the best and wisest of the English, towards so desirable an End, as they will not adventure openly to disown the Disso∣lution” of the Union to be.

“Our Substance has been wasted in the late ruinous Wars; and we see an unavoidable Pros∣pect of having Wars continued on us and our Posterity, so long as the Possession of the Crown” is not in the right Line.

“The Hereditary Rights of the Subjects, tho' confirm'd by Conventions and Parliaments, are now treated as of no Value or Force; and past Service to the Crown and Royal Family, are” now look'd upon as Grounds of Suspicion.

“A pack'd up Assembly, who call themselves a British Parliament, have, as far as in them lies, inhumanly murder'd their own and our So∣vereign, by promising a great Sum of Money as” the Reward of so execrable a Crime.

“They have proscribed, by unaccountable and groundless Impeachments and Attainders, the worthy Patriots of England, for their ho∣nourable and successful Endeavours to restore Trade, Plenty, and Peace, to these Nati∣ons.”

“They have broken in upon the Laws of both Countries, by which the Liberty of our Persons was secured; they have empower'd a Foreign Prince (who notwithstanding his Expectation of the Crown for 15 Years, is still unacquainted with our Manners, Customs, and Language) to make an absolute Conquest (if not timely prevented) of the Three Kingdoms, by invest∣ing himself with an unlimited Power, not only of raising unnecessary Forces at Home, but also of calling in Foreign Troops, ready to promote his uncontroulable Designs: Nor can we be ever hopeful of its being otherwise, in the Way it is in at present, for some Generations to come; and the sad Consequences of these un∣exampled Proceedings have really been so fatal to great Numbers of our Kinsmen, Friends, and Fellow-Subjects of both Kingdoms, that they have been constrain'd to abandon their Country, Houses, Wives, and Children, or give themselves up Prisoners, and perhaps Victims to be sacrificed at the Pleasure of Foreigners, and a few hot-headed Men of a restless Faction” whom they employ.

“Our Troops Abroad, notwithstanding of their long and remarkable good Services, have been treated, since the Peace, with Neglect and Contempt, and particularly in Holland; and it is not now the Officers long Service, Merit, and Blood they have lost, but Money and Favour, by which they can obtain Justice in their Pre∣ferments; so that it is evident the Safety of his Majesty's Person, and Independency of his Kingdoms, call loudly for immediate Relief and” Defence.

“The Consideration of these unhappy Circum∣stances, with the due Regard we have to com∣mon Justice, the Peace and Quiet to us and our Posterity, and our Duty to his Majesty and his Commands, are powerful Motives that have engaged us in our present Undertakings, which we are firmly and heartily resolved to push to the utmost, and stand by one another to the last Exrtemity, as the only solid and effectual Means of putting an End to so dreadful a Prospect, as by our present Situation we have before our Eyes; And with faithful Hearts, true to our only rightful King, our Country, and our Neigh∣bours, we earnestly beseech and expect (as his Majesty's Commands) the Assistance of all our true Fellow-Subjects, to second this our first Attempt; declaring hereby our sincere Inten∣tions, That we will promote and concur, in all lawful Means, for settling a lasting Peace to these Lands, under the auspicious Govern∣ment of our native-born rightful Sovereign, the Direction of our Domestick Councils, and the Protection of our Native Forces and” Troops.

“That we will in the same manner concur and endeavour to have our Laws, Liberties, and Properties secured by the Parliaments of both Kingdoms: That by the Wisdom of such Par∣liaments, we will endeavour to have such Laws enacted, as shall give absolute Security to us, and future Ages, for the Protestant Religion, against all Efforts of Arbitrary Power, Popery, and all its other Enemies. Nor have we any Reason to be distrustful of the Goodness of God, the Truth and Purity of our Holy Religion, or the known Excellency of his Majesty's Judg∣ment, as not to hope that in due Time, good Example and Conversation with our learned Divines, will remove these Prejudices, which we know his Education in a Popish Country has not rivetted in his discerning Mind; and we are sure, a Justice is a Vertue in all Religions and Professions, so the doing of it to him, will” not lessen his good Opinion of ours.

“That as the King is willing to give his royal Indemnity for all that is past, so he will cheer∣fully concur in passing general Acts of Oblivion, that our Fellow-Subjects who have been misled, may have a fair Opportunity of living with us in the same friendly manner we design to live” with them.
“That we will use our utmost Endeavours for redressing the bad Usage of our Troops Abroad, and bringing the Troops at Home to be on the same Foot and Establishment of Pay as those of” England.

“That we will sincerely and heartily go into such Measures as shall maintain effectually, and establish a right, firm, and lasting Union betwixt his Majesty's ancient Kingdom of Scotland, and
our good Neighbours and Fellow-Subjects of” the Kingdom of England.

“The Peace of these Nations being thus settled, and we thus freed from Foreign Dangers, we will use our Endeavours to have the Army re∣duced to the usual Number of Guards and Gar∣risons; and will concur in such Laws and Me∣thods as shall relieve us of the heavy Taxes and Debts now lying upon us, and at the same time will support the Publick Credit in all its” Parts.

“And we do hereby promise and engage, That every Officer who joins with us in our King and Country's Cause, shall not only enjoy the Post he now does, but shall be advanced and preferr'd according to his Rank and Station, and the Number of Men he brings off with him to us; and each Foot-Soldier so joining with us, shall have Twenty Shillings sterling; and each Trooper or Dragoon, who brings Horse and Accoutrements along with him, Twelve Pounds sterling Gratuity, besides their” Pay.

“And in general, we shall concur with all our Fellow-Subjects in such Measures as shall make us flourish at Home, and be formidable Abroad, under our rightful Sovereign, and the peaceful Harmony of our ancient fundamental Consti∣tution, undisturbed by a Pretender's Interests and Councils from Abroad, or a restless Faction at” Home.

“In so honourable, so good, and just a Cause, we do not doubt of the Assistance, Direction, and Blessing of Almighty God, who has so often succour'd the Royal Family of Stuarts,
and our Country, from sinking under Oppres∣sion.”

DIV1.P: This Manifesto being ended, the People with loud Acclamations shouted, NO Union! NO Malt, NO Salt-TAX! Then the Highlanders returned to their Quarters, where they continued till Thursday.

Matters were now run their full Length; and the King, who began now to appear more than Equal to all the Attempts that could be made against his Government, had Troops ready to engage them in every Place. N. B. The same Day the Attack was made at Preston, that very Day the Two Armies in Scotland came to a pitch'd Battle.

As for those at Preston, their whole Conduct secur'd their Overthrow: And they might easily have seen from the beginning, that they were never in any Condition to resist the attack of Regular Troops; that they had neither Men disciplin'd, Officers experienced, or Magazines furnished; and which was more than all, no Subordination, no Subjection, no command among them. So that indeed they were rather a Crowd than an Army; and they could not without a Madness next to that of Desparation, have marcht, as they did, into the Heart of the Country, where they were sure to be surrounded, and to have no Possibility left them of escaping. But their Fate hurry'd them on, and there was no preventing it, as shall be seen in the farther relation of these things.

I return to the Progress of the Earl of Mar in Scotland, whose Circumstances now appear'd very Encouraging indeed. He had with him, as they
reported, near 12000 Men, well appointed, bold and resolute for Action: Indeed they had need to be so, for they were imbark'd in an Underta∣king full of Terrors, which requir'd not Courage only, but even the Rage of Despair to carry it on.

They had long talk'd of marching Southward, passing the Forth, attacking the Duke of Argyle, and the like; and the Earl of Mar, who knew very well the Courage of his Men, as well as the Reputation of his Undertaking, could not but be upheld by lying still, finding he was now joined by most of the Troops that he expected, resolv'd to march, and accordingly caused the Army to Rendezvous at a small Town call'd Auchterarder, near Perth, at once to amuse the King's Ar∣my, and execute his Design; He had all the Reason in the World to attempt this now, because the King's Troops were still very weak, all the Men the Duke of Argyle having yet with him, not exceeding 1500 Men, besides a few Volun∣tiers, which at best never were above 200 at a time; nor were they above 100 at the Battle of Sherriffmuir. The Particulars of that Force, to explain this more fully, was thus set forth even at that time.

First, Some Regiments having a little before been sent to Ireland, all the Troops left in Scotland, at the breaking out of the Rebellion, were no more than the Regiments of Dragoons of Portmore and Stair; the latter call'd the White-Horses; and the Regiments of Foot of Shannon, Montague, Grant, Wightman, Orrery, Irwin, and Forfar; all which when together, some Detachments being made for Garrisons at Inverlochy and Edinburgh, made up 1850 Men; and were afterwards rein∣forc'd
from Ireland with Evan's Dragoons, Clay∣ton's and Morison's Regiment of Foot, making to∣gether about 850 Men more: There was indeed a great Appearance of the Nobility and Gentry, and great Talk of a large Number of Voluntiers from Glasgow, and the West; the former indeed made up a handsome Body of about 150 Horse, all Persons of Distinction, and appear'd forward enough for Service; but of the latter we do not find, whatever Shew they made, that they ever came to any Action.

The Earl of Mar therefore, whose Troops were now hearty and numerous, far Superior to the King's Army, found that now was his time to enter upon Action, and to attack the King's For∣ces, if possible; or if not; to amuse them, and pass the Forth, that he might succour and join his Friends in the South, and so push on the Grand Design before his Enemies were strengthen'd with more Forces.

With this Resolution he drew his Army toge∣ther, and advanc'd with a Body of his Men to have a nearer View of the Situation of the Duke of Argyle; but finding he lay with his little Army, under the Cannon of Sterling, the River in his Front, and no Passage but at the Bridge, which the Castle commanded; that on the other hand, he was not provided with Boats for a Passage, or with Materials for a Bridge, or time for building it; in a word, finding an Attempt there Impracticable, he resolv'd upon sending over a Body of Foot lower down, where the Passage indeed was more difficult and dangerous, but where there were no Troops to oppose him, and where he should sooner bring his Men to Action with more Advantage: This being resolv'd on; the Place he pitch'd up∣on
was towards the Mouth of the Forth, where the Sea was no less than Ten or Twelve Miles over.

Though this was a hazardous Enterprize, there being several Men of War in the Firth; yet he both undertook and perform'd it with Success; and had he sent over 5000 Men instead of 2000, he had done his Business; for the Forces at hand to oppose him, was no way able to have with∣stood him; but he began his own way, and for what he did it was well enough managed: For having secretly caused all the Boats on the Coast to be seiz'd and secur'd, he sent Brigadier Mac∣kintosh, a bold and soldierly Man, to the East Part of Fife, with all the Secrecy possible, having with him the Lord Strathmore, and several other very able Officers, and about 2000 Foot, most Nor∣thern Highland Men, with Orders to watch their Opportunity, when the Tide was coming in, that so the Men of War might not be able to in∣tercept them, to embark, and land themselves on the other Shore; while this was doing, he caus'd another Body to march openly to Brunt-Island, and getting several Boats together there, makes a Feint of embarking his Men there; the Men of War having Notice of his Design at Brunt-Island, mann'd out their Boats, and sent them to attack them, slipping their Cables, and standing in for the Shore, in order to second the Boats; at which the Rebels, as if they were afraid of being taken, retir'd to Brunt-Island; the Men of War stood in after them, and let fly several Shot among them, but with little Damage; while, in the mean Time, they discover'd from their Top-Masts, tho' but too late, that the main Body of the Re∣bels were actually passing the Firth 12 Miles be∣low;
and that they appear'd in the mid Channel, almost half over.

It was in vain for the Men of War to stir, the Tide of Flood being very strong against them, and little or no Wind, and that Wind that was, not very fair for them; all they could do, was to man out some Boats, which they did; who row∣ing under Shore, came up time enough to inter∣cept one of the Boats, with 45 Men in it, who labour'd under the Misfortune of having broken one of their Oars; this Boat they took, and the Men were carried Prisoners into Leith, and put in∣to the Talbooth; where, in a few Days, their Friends reliev'd them.

But the Men of War, as soon as the Tide turn'd, falling down, came time enough to cut off Eight Boats, who were too far behind the rest, and who had embark'd in another Place, and giving them Chase, they put back to the Isle of May, a small Island on the South-East Point of Fifeland; where, being near 400 Men, the Men of Wars Boats durst not land their Men to attack them; and the next Day or two they landed again in Fife, with my Lord Strathmore at the Head of them.

The foremost Boats set their Men safe on Shore at Tantallon, Aberlady, North Berwick, and on the Shores between, to the Number of about 1600 Men, and Brigadier Mackintosh at the Head of them; this was the 12th of October in the Morn∣ing; and the same Day they march'd to Hadding∣ton, a wall'd Town, and large, but not strong, within 12 Miles of Edinburgh.

It is easy to believe, that this surprising News put the People of Edinburgh into a terrible Con∣sternation; the Friends to the Government made no Doubt, but they would march directly to
Edinburgh; and they knew great Numbers in that City waited only an Opportunity of such a Body of Men, to protect them in their appearing; so they doubted nothing, but that they would make a general Revolt upon this Occasion.

But this was the least of the Danger; for had the Earl of Mar, as was expected, advanced at the same Time with the Gross of his Army to face the Duke of Argyle, or to force his Way over the Forth, and at the same Time sent over 2 or 3000 Men more, at the Queens-Ferry, or at Cul∣ross; all which it had been most easy for him to do; I say, had he done either of these, it had been impossible that the Duke could have been spar'd from the Army, or have spared any of his Troops for the Relief of Edinburgh; and his fail∣ing in this, was not only a Disappointment, but a Confirmation of what was not known till after∣wards, viz. that the Design of the Earl of Mar, in sending over Brigadier Mackintosh, was not to attack Edinburgh, but to march to the South, to encourage the Viscount Kenmure, and the Friends they had on that Side; and then to march in a Body to join the Northumberland General, as they call'd him; and so to march into England, to at∣tempt a Diversion; and therefore in a Letter which the Earl of Mar wrote to Mr. Forster, which was afterwards intercepted, he calls Mac∣kintosh's March to the Citadel of Leith, a wrong Step.

However it was, this wrong Step of the Lord Mar's sav'd Edinburgh, and, perhaps, all Scotland; for Brigadier Mackintosh being come to Hadding∣ton, had such Accounts given him of the Surprize of the Citizens of Edinburgh, and the dreadful Consternation the People were in; and such Assu∣rances
given him, of the Certainty of surprising the City, that he resolv'd to march directly to Edinburgh; which accordingly he did the next Day, and came to Carstorphen, a Village within a Mile of the City, about 6 that Evening. But not finding any Numbers come out to him, as he expected; but, on the contrary, hearing that the Citizens had shut the Gates, and were in Arms to defend themselves; and that a Detachment of Dragoons were expected every Minute in the Ci∣ty from Sterling. These Reasons, and, which was more than all the rest, his own want of sufficient Numbers to force the Gates, oblig'd him to alter his March, and to turn to the Right, marching directly to the Town of Leith; which he entred, and where he immediately released the 45 Men, which, as I said, were taken coming over the Firth.

Nothing is more certain, than that if they had been but 2000 more Men, he would not have fail'd of being Master of the Town that Night; but his whole Strength was not above 14 or 1600 Men; and yet it was the Opinion of most Peo∣ple, that if he had push'd at it, he would have carry'd the Place; the Citizens being at that time in no Condition to have repuls'd him, and the Friends to his Design too ready to have join'd him, if he had been strong enough to have made the Attempt.

In the Interim of all this Hurry, the Citizens of Edinburgh sent away Express upon Express to the Duke of Argyle for Succour; and the Duke immediately sent away 300 Dragoons to Lithgow, half way to Edinburgh, to lie there till he heard again, and till he got some Light into their De∣sign; but when, by the very next Express, he
understood they were advancing to Edinburgh, he comes away himself with 100 Dragoons and 200 Foot; and he was so expeditious in this March, that about Two a Clock in the Morning of the 15th he came to Edinburgh; being the Morning after Mackintosh with his Men was in Possession of Leith.

The Duke being resolv'd to give the Revels no Rest, having refresh'd his Troops a little, who had been fatigu'd very much with a hasty March, thro' a whole Winter Night, began to draw out his little Army, which he found compos'd of se∣veral sorts of People: 1st, There was 400 Dra∣goons, and 200 Foot, of regular Troops, on whom he could depend; there was next the New Re∣giment of 400 Men, rais'd by the City, and 150 Granadiers, call'd the Town-Guard, all good for little; next there was about 500 Men of Militia Horse, and Voluntiers on Foot; but ill arm'd, and not very fit for Service, especially the Foot.

With this Army the Duke march'd to Leith, where the old Brigadier, having Notice of their Design to attack him, had quitted the South Part of the Town, and was retir'd into the Citadel, where he began to fortify; and having taken six or eight small Pieces of Cannon out of some Ships in the Road, with what Powder and Ball he could find, he planted two Pieces of Cannon on the Bridge, and two more at proper Places, by the Entrance into the old Works, and prepar'd to de∣fend himself.
The Citadel of Leith is an old demolish'd Forti∣fication, formerly call'd by that Name; it was built by Oliver Cromwel, to guard the Port; the Scituation is good, having the Sea on the North

side, and the Haven and River on the East side, winding round Part of the South; so that it was to be attack'd, when the Works were good, only on the West side, where the Country is a Plain. When this Fort was, as they call it, demolish'd, it was not done by undermining and blowing up the Works, as is now the Usage in such Cases; but by throwing the Top of the Lines and Basti∣ons into the Ditches, and breaking down the Gates, taking up the Bridges, and the like; by this Means the solid Parts of the Works remain, and so it is at Leith; nor would it require much Time or Charge to restore the Citadel to a regu∣lar, compleat Fortification.

By this the Reader may judge, that the Works were so high, and the Ditches still so plainly seen, and so low, that the Port being secur'd, the Horse could be of no Service in an Attack; and the Duke being too weak in Foot for an Assault Sword in Hand, he soon found there was no∣thing to be done without more Forces, and without Cannon; so he halted, and resolv'd to retreat.

But before he did so, he summon'd them to lay down their Arms, and surrender, upon Pain of High Treason; declaring withal, that if they o∣blig'd him to bring Cannon to force them, and they kill'd any of his Men in resisting, he would give them no Quarter. However, he receiv'd a resolute Answer from a Highland Laird, call'd Ki∣nackin; who told the Duke, that as to Surren∣dring, they laugh'd at it; and as to bringing Cannon, and assaulting them, they were ready for him; that they would neither take or give any Quarter with him; and if he thought he was able to force them, he might try his Hand.

The Duke seeing there was no good to be done with them without Cannon, and without more Foot, retir'd to Edinburgh; and immediately gave Orders for Four Pieces of Cannon to be drawn down to Leith from the Castle, and intend∣ing to make the 400 Dragoons serve on Foot, he resolv'd to attack them early the next Morn∣ing.

But old Mackintosh had other Things in his Head; for, having fail'd in his grand Design upon Edinburgh, he intended no more by his Re∣treat into the Citadel of Leith, than to keep him∣self from being oblig'd to fight with Disadvantage, he having no Horse; and as little therefore did he intend to stay there, till he was surrounded with more Forces than he was a Match for; and therefore resolv'd to put an End to the Preparati∣ons of the Duke of Argyle, by a sudden and unex∣pected Retreat that same Night; for about Nine a Clock at Night, the Tide being out, and the Mouth of the Harbour being so easily passable at low Tide, as sometimes to be scarce over Shoes in Water; they went silently out of the Citadel, and not passing thro' any Part of the Town, went di∣rectly down to the Sands, pass'd the Mouth of the Harbour a great way below the Peers, march∣ing due East, close by the Edge of the Sea, the Sands being there so flat and broad, that they could neither be seen or heard in the Night; thus they went off with such Secrecy, and were gone so far before any one had Knowledge of it, or at least before the Duke could make any Dispo∣sitions to follow them, the Night being very dark, that it was to no Purpose to think of pursuing them till Morning; when Advice came to the Duke, that they had taken Possession of Seaton-House,
the Dwelling of the Earl of Wintoun, about nine Miles from Edinburgh; a House strong built, and wall'd round; so as neither there, any more than at the Citadel of Leith, could they be at∣tack'd without more Forces than the Duke had at Hand, nor without the Help of Cannon. A∣bout 50 of their Men, who were drunk with Li∣quor, or with Sleep, and were left in the Citadel, including 15 or 16 that were left by the Way, not able to march with the rest, were brought Prisoners to Edinburgh; and this was their next Halt.

Here being secure again for a few Days, they entrench'd the Avenues to the House, and forti∣fy'd the Gate so as not to be in Danger of Sur∣prize; and sent out into the Country to bring in Mutton, Cows, Salt, and Meal, which they took in such Quantities, as made the Country afraid they intended to wait there for more Men to come over the Firth to them; but they had no such View, it seems; neither if they had, would it have been to any Purpose; for the Men of War, and arm'd Smacks, had so spread the Firth, that it was scarce practicable for any open single Boat to pass them, much less a Fleet of Boats.

The Duke of Argyle finding where they were Roosted, now resolv'd to give them as little Rest here, as he had done at Leith; and therefore sent out immediately a Detachment of Dragoons, with a Body of the Voluntier Horse, to alarm them. This Detachment came up to the House; but finding the Scituation and Posture of the E∣nemy such, as that nothing could be attempted without more Forces, they return'd the same Night.

In the mean Time, the Earl of Mar hearing of this false Step of his Detachment, and not doubt∣ing but they would be fallen upon from Sterling, took that Step now for their Deliverance, which, had he taken at first by Concert with them, had been a fatal Blow to the Affair in general, as is noted above; for he advanc'd from Perth to Dum∣blain with all his Cavalry, and 3000 Foot being order'd to follow, made a motion also in order to join him: This March of the Enemy alarm'd the Royal Army at Sterling, and they sent Ex∣presses of it to the Duke of Argyle; who, upon this Advice, leaving the City of Edinburgh no more than 100 Dragoons, and 150 Foot, with General Wightman to defend them, went back immediately with the rest of the Forces to the Camp.

Had the Rebels in Seaton-House known either of this Movement of the Earl of Mar, or of the go∣ing back of the Duke, they would soon have taken more Freedom than they did with those that were left. But, to amuse them, the Earl of Rothes, with 300 Voluntiers, the Lord Torphichen with the 100 Dragoons which the Duke had left, and some o∣ther Troops, such as they had, making in all about 600 Men, marched up to Seaton-House again, where old Mackintosh kept himself close in his Fortifications, which they, without Cannon, and a good Body of regular Troops, were in no Condition to attack; This was the 17th of October.

By this Time the Earl of Mar had Intelligence of the Retreat, and hearing that the Duke of Ar∣gyle was come back to Sterling, he left Dumblain, and march'd back again to Perth; and thus, for five or six Days, the poor Men on both Sides were
harrass'd backward and forward to little or no other Purpose than to amuse and prevent one ano∣ther; nor was there hardly a Musquet fir'd on all these Occasions.

But the poor Country was left naked by this Means, and the fruitful rich Provinces of East and Mid Lothain, the Mers, Tiveotdale, &c. were un∣happily left to be ravaged by a little, and other∣wise a contemptible Body of 1400, or at most 1500 Men; this the Scots complain'd loudly of; but the Circumstances of Things admitted no Remedy at that Time, all the Troops being employed, and every one's Hands full.

Old Mackintosh was now at Leisure; and indeed had his Intelligence been good at Edinburgh, he would have been more sensible of the Advantage of his present Circumstances; for tho' it was true, that he was not strong enough to attack the City of Edinburgh; so neither were they in any Condi∣tion to attack him; and had he sally'd out with 7 or 800 of his Men upon their Body of Horse, who were no other than private Gentlemen Vo∣luntiers, except about 80 Dragoons, he would have made but too easy an Experiment of their Weakness; for though they visited him two or three Times, and alarm'd him at Seaton-House, yet they were never above 600 strong at a Time, or thereabouts, and among them no regular Men, or not above 100. But it seems, the Brigadier did not know that the Duke of Argyle was gone back to Sterling, or that the Earl of Mar had made any Motion in his Favour; otherwise he might have insulted them again at the Gates of Edinburgh as often as he had pleased; but he expecting every Day to be invested, and Cannon to be brought down against him, very happily for the City of
Edinburgh, though unluckily for him, resolved to pursue his first Direction, viz. to march towards the English Border, and join that Body of Men who were risen in Dumfreisshire, under the Viscount Kenmure; with whom were the Earls of Nithis∣dale, Winton, and Carnwarth, and the Lord Nairn, with Abundance of Gentlemen of Quality; such as Lord Murray, Son to the Duke of Athol; the Master of Nairn, eldest Son to the Lord Nairn, and several others. These being at first said to be 300 Horse, were advanc'd to Moffat, in Pur∣suit of a Design to intercept the Marquis of Anan∣dale, and very narrowly miss'd him; and having fail'd of that Design, lay about Moffat, expecting to hear from their Brethren in the Rebellion in Northumberland, who, about this Time also, as we had observ'd before, were march'd from Hex∣am to Morpeth, and now advanc'd to the Border, and entering Scotland, cross'd the Tweed at Kelso, where soon after they all met; for Brigadier Mackintosh quitting Seaton-House on the 19th, march'd to Duns, within six Miles of Berwick, the same Day that the Northumberland Men came to Morpeth; where he lay two or three Days; and from whence, on the 22d, they march'd to Kelso, where they were all in one Day join'd by the Viscount of Kenmure with his Body from the West of Scotland, and by the new General Forster, and the Northumberland Men, from the Border; and thus we have brought them all into one Body, making, as was reported by the most exact Ac∣counts, about 2300 Men.

The Rebellion was now come to a Head, and the two Principal Bodies of them being thus drawn together from all Parts, began to look for∣midable: Nor indeed were they to be dispised, had
they been well directed; for they miscarried in no Part of their Undertaking, but for want of Council, and want of Intelligence: Not taking right Measures, as they themselves acknowledg'd afterwards, when they could look back, and cooly reflect upon their Mistakes.

I have not Room here to trace every Step of the Parties which drew together to Form these Bodies; as particularly, of General Gordon with the Highlanders from the Side of Inverary; the Lord Kenmure with a Body of Gentlemen from the Side of Dumfries; and the like: But I hasten to the General Action, when all Parties made up their Strength, and brought it to a Day with this remarkable Circumstances, that it was a Day in∣deed; for the Battle at Sherriff Muir or Dumblain, and that at Preston in Lancashire, were fought on the very same Day, as will appear by and by.

To bring them then to Action, I return to the Northumberland Men, who being marcht up to the Border of Scotland, as before, were joined at Kelso upon the Tweed, by the Scots Gentlemen un∣der the Lord Kenmure, and by the Forces which pass'd the Firth with old Brigadier Mackin∣tosh.

Here, being in Council what to do, and hear∣ing that General Carpenter advanced towards them with three Regiments of Dragoons and one of Foot, they resolved to march to the South. It had been proposed to march into the West of Scotland, which had, without doubt, been very much to their Advantage, as they were strong e∣nough to have forced their way, and perhaps have at last opened a Way to the Earl of Mar to have join'd them, or else have surrounded the
Royal Army at Stirling: But Fate and English Councils prevail'd.

Having resolv'd to march for England, and at∣tack General Carpenter, who in all had not above 700 Men with him, they accordingly advanced from Kelso on the 27th of October, and passing the River, march'd to Jedburgh. It is true, this was not the way to attack General Carpenter, who lay at Wooller, about 12 Miles from Kelso: But it seems they had altered their Mind, and fatally for them it was; for had they boldly attack'd Gene∣ral Carpenter, they would have gone fair to have defeated him, his Number being so small, and the Battalion of Foot which he had un∣der his Command not being come up at that time.

They Halted at Jedburgh two Days, considering what Course to take: Three ways offered to them; one was Marching into the West of Scot∣land, the other attacking General Carpenter, the third was Marching into England; and this last they chose, though the worst of the three.

The Highlanders and some of the Scots Gentle∣men, especially the Earl of Winton, urged the First with stronge Arguments, and so Embarked the Highlanders in it, that when other Measures were resolv'd on, they Mutiny'd, and would not march. His Scheme was, to cross the Western Dales, and join the Clans about the Scourse of Forth; or to send Word to the Earl of Mar, that they would fall upon the Duke of Argyle's Rear, while he advancing they might surround and defeat him, his Number being at that time but very small.

This was so good a Scheme in it self, and so well argued by the Scots Noblemen, that when
the other Resolutions were taken, at the pressing desire of the English Nobility, the Scots Highlanders resolved that they would not pass the Border; but if it was insisted on, they would separate, and go back into Scotland; however, as they resolv'd to keep together to the Borders, they march'd from Jedburgh to Langholm.
