It was on this March that the English Lords resolving to march for England, they recalled a strong Detachment made to attack Dumfreis, and then drew up at Howick Moor, and held another Council of War, where the Highlanders refused to march, unless it was to attack General Carpenter; nor was this Mutiny ever appeased, but the High∣landers positively insisting, and not to be prevail'd with to stir over the Border, 500 of them separa∣ted into small Bodies, and went off, resolving to surrender themselves to the King's Troops; which they did, and were for some Months after kept Prisoners at Glasgow, and at Edinburgh; but at length released.

The rest of the Highlanders being, by Perswa∣sions, and some Money given them, prevailed with to keep together, they all took Resolution to give General Carpenter the slip, and to march for England, having, as they plainly saw, the ad∣vantage, by their Scituation, of three Days march of him: With these Resolutions, and the Hopes of a great Insurrection in England to favour their Designs, they decamped from Howick, and by a very long and swift March reached to Longtoun that Night, which is within Seven Miles of the English Border, leaving the Four Pieces of Can∣non they had with them at Langholm, that they might not retard them in their March.

Next Day, the 30th of October, they entred England, and march'd to Brampton and Cumber∣land. Here Mr. Forster opened his Commission from the Pretender, empowering him to act as General in England; and, the Highlanders were from this time regularly paid as Soldiers Six-pence a Day.

They halted one Night at Brampton, to refresh the Men after their hard Marches, having march'd above 100 Miles in five Days. The next Day they advanced towards Penrith: They expected to have met with some Friends here to join them; for it was reported that Mr. Dacre of Ab∣beylanner-Coast, a Papist, had promised to raise 40 Men; but he was taken with a fortunate Fe∣ver, which hindred him of his Design, and pre∣vented him and his Family from Ruin: He died since; his Name, which was very ancient, is now extinct in that Estate. As they drew near Penrith, they had notice that the Sheriff, with the Posse Comitatus, were got together, with the Lord Lonsdale, and the Bishop of Carlisle, to the Number of 14000 Men, who resolved to stand and oppose their penetrating farther into England. The first Part of this was very true, viz. that the Posse was drawn together, nor was their Number much less. But they gave the Highland Army no occasion to try whether they would stand or no; for as soon as a Party, who the Country People sent but for Discovery, had seen some of the Men coming out of a Lane by the side of a Wood, and draw up upon a Moor, and then ad∣vance, and that they had carried an Account of this to their Main Body, they broke up their Camp in the utmost Confusion, shifting every one for themselves as well as they could, as is gene∣rally
the Case of an arm'd, but undisciplin'd Mul∣titude.

On the 5th they came to Appleby, having be∣hav'd themselves very well to the Country in ge∣neral, on their March; for I do not hear of any extraordinary Violences they exercised to any People on the way; the most Mischief I hear of, was, (1.) The taking up the Publick Moneys; such as the Excise, Land-Tax, and all the Mo∣ney belonging to the Publick Revenues, that they could meet with; which was, in the whole, very considerable too. (2.) The taking what Arms, Ammunition, and Horses, they could meet with, which were fit for Service.

These were Things which might indeed be ex∣pected from Men in Arms against the Govern∣ment; but as to other Violences, such as Burn∣ings, Plunderings, Murthers, Rapes, &c. the usual Practice in like Cases, where the Soldiery are under no Discipline, I do not find that they have been charg'd with any: And the Account pub∣lished by one of their own Party, since turn'd a∣bout, acknowledges, that it having been moved to Mr. Forster to Burn the Presbyterian Meeting-House at Perth, he forbid it, and said, They were to Conquer by Clemency, not by Cruelty.

From Appleby they advanced to Kendal, from thence to Kirkby Launsdale, and from thence to Lancaster; and having thus push'd near Four∣score Miles into the Country, without fighting, they were greatly encouraged, and their Friends began now to appear and join them.

At Lancaster they seized at the Custom-house some small Arms, with a quantity of Wine and Brandy, which was divided among the Soldiers; they also took Six Pieces of Cannon out of a Ship
in the River. Being pretty much encreased by the Addition of several Gentlemen, and their Servants and Attendants, they resolv'd to ad∣vance to Manchester, where they expected great Numbers to join them; and which, had they not been prevented by the coming in of the King's Troops, would certainly have been so, as I shall soon observe.

Here it is observed, that if they had staid at Lancaster, a Place strong by Situation, they had not only encreased their Strength, and been well supplied with many things they wanted, but they could not have been attack'd, as they were, without Cannon: Nor had they been worsted, would they have been obliged to so an entire Surrender; but might either have made better Terms for themselves, or have made their Escapes by Sea.

But Fate and their own Mistakes hurry'd them on; and on the Ninth of November they march'd for Preston, having first released some of their Friends who had been confin'd in the Castle of Lancaster, by Virtue of the late Act of Parlia∣ment mentioned before. Their Design now was plain; (viz.) to seize upon the Pass of Warrington Bridge, and the Town of Manchester there.

The 10th they entred Preston, and ended their March; for they were presently informed here, that the King's Troops were advancing to attack them; this was on the 12th; upon this News they alter'd their Resolution of marching to Bol∣ton, as they had before intended, and resolved to fortify themselves in the Post they were in, and expect the King's Troops there.

The Alarm being now given, a Body of their Foot marched out of the Town as far as Ribble-Bridge, posting themselves there, and Mr. Forster, with a Party of Horse, went beyond it to get a certain Account of Things; when dis∣covering the Vanguard of the Dragoons, he re∣turned another Way, not coming back by the Bridge; but sent with all hast to give an Account of the Approach of the King's Army, and to give Orders to prepare to receive them, whilst he went to view a Ford in the River, in order for a Passage to come behind them. The Foot that were advanced to the Bridge were about an 100; but they were choice, stout, and well-armed Men, and commanded by Lieutenant-Colonel John Farquharson of Innercall, belonging to Mac∣kintosh's Battalion: He was a good Officer and a very bold Man, and would have defended that important Pass of the Bridge to the last Drop, and till the rest had advanced and drawn them∣selves out of the Town; but he was order'd to retreat to Preston: This Retreat was another wrong step, and has been condemned on all hands as one of the greatest Oversights they could be guilty of; for the River is not fordable but a good Way above and below the Bridge, which they might have made impassable also, by several Methods practised on like Occasions. As for the Bridge, they might have barricado'd it so well, that it would have been impracticable to have pass'd there, or to have dislodged them from it; also they had Cannon, which General Wills wanted: And here alone indeed it might be said they were in a Condition to have made an effectual Stand; for here the King's Forces would have been entirely exposed to their Fire, having
no Cover; whereas the Rebels could have very much secured themselves against the other's Fire, by the Bridge, and by the Rising-Ground near it. General Wills did indeed expect some Difficulty and Opposition at this Place, believing, by their Situation, that the Rebels would have made their greatest Effort at that Place; but under∣standing by his Advance-Guard that the Rebels had abandon'd that Post, he was surprized, and suspected that then they had some Stratagem in hand, and perhaps had lined the Hedges, and so made the Lane unpassable for his Men. The Lane is indeed very deep, and so narrow that in several Places two Men cannot ride abreast. Ge∣neral Wills, on those Suppositions, proceeded with Caution, and caused the Hedges and Fields to be view'd, and the Ways laid open for his Caval∣ry to enter; but finding the Hedges also clear, he concluded then, that the Enemy was fled, and expected that they had abandon'd the Town and all, and would endeavour by long Marches to re∣turn to Scotland, tho' he thought it impossible for them to do that too: But he soon understood that they were retreated to the Town only, and that they resolv'd to receive him there with a re∣solute Countenance; so he had nothing to do but to prepare for the Attack, which he went about immediately. Having advanced nearer the Town, he ordered his Troops to pass at a Gate which leads into the Fields which lie on the back of the Town, and immediately spreading the Enclosures with the utmost Expedition and Diligence, so disposed of his Forces as best to be able both to attack them in the Town, and to prevent them from Sallying or making a Re∣treat.

During this time, they were not idle in the Town, nor did they appear in the least discoura∣ged, but applied themselves resolutely to their Business, barrocading the Streets, and posting their Men there, and in the bye-Lanes, and Houses, to the greatest Advantage, for all Events. The Gentlemen-Voluntiers were drawn up in the Church-yard, under the Command of the Earl of Derwentwater, Viscount Kenmure, Earls of Win∣toun and Nithsdale. The Earl of Derwentwater signally behav'd, having stript into his Wastcoat, and encouraged the Men, by giving them Money to cast up Trenches, and animating them to a vigorous Defence of them. They form'd Four main Barriers; one a little below the Church, commanded by Brigadier Mackintosh; the Gentle∣men in the Church-yard were to support that Bar∣rier in particular, and Lord Charles Murray that which was at the End of a Lane leading to the Fields: The third Barrier was called the Wind-mill; this was commanded by Colonel Mackin∣tosh: And the Fourth was in the Street which leads towards Liverpool, commanded by Major Miller and Mr. Douglass. The three former were all attack'd with great Fury by the King's For∣ces: The first Attack was made upon the Barrier below the Church, commanded by Brigadier Mackintosh; but they met with such a Reception, and so terrible a Fire was made upon them, as well from the Barricado as from the Houses on both sides, that they were obliged to retreat back to the Entrance of the Town. During the Heat of this Action, some of Preston's Officers being inform'd that the Street leading to Wigan was not barricado'd, and that the Houses were not posses∣sed on that side, they presently entred that Street
with great Bravery, pushing all before them Preston's Regiment of Foot were commanded up∣on this Service, supported by Honnywood's Dra∣goons. It is true, Mr. Forster had at first taken Possession of that Street, and posted Men in the Houses on both sides; but they were, against their Inclination, called off to other Service; nor were they left, as some desir'd, to post themselves at the extreamest Ends of the Town, even at that End which leads to the Bridge, where the first and hottest Attack was made. Several Houses were left, particularly one which belonged to Sir Henry Haughton: Captain Innis with Fifty High∣landers had taken Possession of this House; and had he been allowed to have continued there, he might have given a good Account of it; but he also was call'd off from that Post, some of Preston's Men got Possession of that too, tho' it cost them dear, for many of their Men were kill'd there from other Houses. It is a high House, over∣looking the whole Town: There was also ano∣ther House opposite to it, which they entred, and posted several of their Men in it. And from these two Houses came almost all the Loss the Northern People sustained during the Action. Mr. Forster cannot be blamed for this Oversight, but it must be charged upon the Brigadier, who a little while before Preston's Foot made this brave and bold Attack, withdrew his Men from those Houses. The Attack was thus, Preston's Men, led by their Lieutenant-Colonel the Lord Forester, did not come up to the Head of the Street, but marched in∣to a straight Passage behind the Houses, and then made a Halt 'till their Lieutenant-Colonel the Lord Forester came into the open Street with his drawn Sword in his Hand, and faced Mackintosh's
Barrier, looking up and down the Street, and viewing how they were posted. There were ma∣ny Shots fired at him, but he returned to his Men, and came up again at the Head of them into the middle Street, where he caused some to face the Barricade where the Brigadier was post∣ed, and ply them with their Shot, at the same time commanding another Party to march cross the Streets, to take Possession of those Houses. Whilst this was doing, the other from the Bar∣rier, and from the Houses on both sides, made a terrible Fire upon them, and a great many of that old and gailant Regiment were killed and wound∣ed: The Lord Forester received several Wounds himself. Besides the Damage they received on that side, they were sore galled from some Windows below them, by Captain Douglass and Captain Hunter's Men. Preston's Foot fired smartly upon the Barrier, but did little Execution, the Men being generally cover'd from the Shot, and deli∣vering their own Shot securely, and with good Aim; yet some were kill'd, and some also wound∣ed, particularly two very gallant Gentlemen were wounded here, and both dy'd of their Wounds; the one was Captain Peter Farquharson of Rochaley, a Gentleman of an invincible Spirit, and almost inimitable Bravery. This Gentleman being shot through the Bone of the Leg, endured a great deal of Torture in the Operation of the Surgeon. When he was first brought into the Inn call'd the White Bull, the House where all the wounded Men were carry'd to be dress'd, he took a Glass of Brandy, and said, Come, Lads, here is your Ma∣ster's Health; though I can do no more, I wish you good Success. His Leg was cut off by one who I may call a Butcher, rather than a Surgeon, and
he presently died. The other was Mr. Clifton, Brother to Sir Jervas Clifton, he was also a gal∣lant and throughly accomplish'd Gentleman; he receiv'd a shot in the Knee, of which he died some Hours after. There was another Gentle∣man call'd Colonel Brereton, who had formerly serv'd in the Army; he had many Wounds, one of which, by the vast Flux of Blood, was not discover'd soon enough by his Surgeon, or else it's thought he might have outliv'd his Fate that Day: After he was bury'd, he was ta∣ken out of his Grave, to satisfie the Curiosity of a Commanding Officer, who could not be per∣swaded that this Gentleman was in the Rebel∣lion.

The next Barrier which was attack'd, was commanded by Lord Charles Murray: He behav'd very gallantly, but being vigorously attack'd, wanted Men, and sent to the Earl of Derwent∣water for Help, who immediately sent him a Re∣lief of 50 Gentlemen Voluntiers from the Church∣yard to reinforce him, who came in very seasona∣bly. Immediately Parson Patten was order'd over the Barrier to view the King's Forces, who ap∣pearing in a Clergyman's Habit, was not suspe∣cted, nor fired at. He soon returned back, and gave Lord Charles an Account, that by what he saw, they were resolved to attack him again; whereupon Lord Charles gave Orders to his Men to be ready to receive them: Accordingly they came on very furiously, and tho' the King's Forces that made this Attack, were, for the most part, raw, new-listed Men, and seem'd unwil∣ling to fight; yet the Bravery and good Conduct of experienc'd Officers supply'd very much that Defect. However, Lord Charles Murray main∣tain'd
the Post, and oblig'd them to retreat with Loss; nor, had they been all old Soldiers, could they have beaten Lord Charles from that Barrier, which was very strong; the Number they had slain from the Barn-holes and Barrier it self added very much, so that at last the Officers themselves thought fit to give it over.

The third Attack was at the Windmill in the Street which leads to Lancaster, where the Barri∣er was defended by near 300 Men, under the Command of Mr. Mackintosh, who, with his Men, behaved very boldly, and made a dreadful Fire upon the King's Forces, killing many on the spot, and obliging them to make a Retreat; which, however, they did very handsomely. This was owing to the Common Men, who were but new∣listed; tho' the Officers and old Soldiers behav'd themselves with great Bravery.

Hitherto the Rebels seem'd to have had some Advantage, having repulsed the King's Forces in all their Attacks, and maintained all their Posts; and Night drawing on, no new Action happen'd; but during all this time, and all Saturday Night, and Sunday, and good part of that Night, the King's Forces kept incessantly Plattoons firing up∣on them, from Sir Henry Haughton's and Mr. Ayre's Houses. It's true, they kill'd but very few; those of Note were, one Mr. Hume a Cornet, one Mr. Scattery, and a Highland Gentleman belong∣ing to the Lord Nairn. There were several Hou∣ses and Barns set on fire by both Parties, both for covering themselves among the Smoak, and dislodging Men; so that if the Wind had blown almost from any Quarter, the whole Town had been burnt to the Ground, and the Men had been burnt to Ashes in it.

But the wiser Heads among them began now to see that they were not able to carry it on, or to defend themselves long in this Situation; and that which was yet more, their Ammunition began to fail them, having not above one Barrel of Powder left.

The Heads of them therefore began to think of Capitulating, and met together at Night to that Purpose; the Lord Widdrington, Col. Oxburgh, and some others, entred into a Consultation about it; the Result of which was, that Col. Oxburgh was sent out to treat.

The Highlanders, to give them their Due, scorn'd the very Name of a Surrender, and de∣manded to sally out, and die like Men of Honour, with their Swords in their Hands; but they were made believe, that General Wills had sent and of∣fer'd them honourable Conditions.

When the Colonel came to General Wills, he was received respectively, as to his Person; but was told positively, that there was no room to Treat, and that they had nothing to do but to Surrender at Discretion.

The Colonel urg'd it very hard, and sometimes insisted, that they were not reduced to such a Con∣dition; that they had their Arms in their hands, and knew how to die like Men of Honour, and to sell their Lives dear enough. The General told them, That they had nothing more to do than to prepare for it; and the Consequence should be, that he would not give one Man of them Quarter.
The Colonel insisted then, that the General would promise their Lives should be spar'd; which the General, it is said, denied; but encouraged them to expect his Majesty's Clemency.

I know there has been a Dispute in this Case; the one side claiming Life, as the natural Conse∣quence of a Surrender to Mercy; the other deny∣ing it: Nor can I pretend to decide it here. The Matter of Fact was no other but this, (viz.) That Colonel Oxburgh finding no better Bargain could be made for them, agreed at last to yield at Dis∣cretion; which was done.

The Common Soldiers were in a great Rage at the Thoughts of a Surrender, and all was in a Tumult for some time; nay, two or three were shot Dead by them, for but mentioning it. But there was no Remedy; the Gentlemen had con∣sented, and the rest were obliged to submit.

At the Time appointed therefore, which was at Seven the next Morning, the two Generals en∣tred the Town in form, at the Head of their Troops, with Trumpets sounding, and Drums beating. They came in at several Streets, from the Places they were posted at, and all met in the Market-place, where the Highlanders stood drawn up in very good Order, with their Arms. The Noblemen and Gentlemen immediately put them∣selves into their Hands, and were secured in seve∣ral Inns in the Town. Then the Highlanders were Commanded to lay down their Arms; which they did, and were secured in the Church, under a strong Guard, where their Accommodation was indeed but very indifferent; but it did not last long.

Thus ended this Affair. The Loss on both Sides was then cast up. Of the King's Troops, there was a great many Officers wounded, as Brigadier Honnywood, Brigadier Dormer, Lieuten∣ant-Colonel Lord Forester, Major Bland, Captain Ogleby, Major Lawson, besides 3 Captains, 2 Lieutenants, 1 Cornet, and 4 Ensigns.
Among the slain were, 1 Major, whose Name was Preston. And of Preston's Regiment, 3 Cap∣tains, 1 Ensign, and about 220 Private Men.
Of the others, only 17 kill'd, and 25 wound∣ed.

The Prisoners amounted to 7 Lords, and 1489 Gentlemen and Private Solders. The Noblemen were, the Earl of Derwentwater, the Earl of Nithsdale, the Earl of Winton, the Earl of Carn∣warth, Viscount Kenmure, the Lord Widdrington, and the Lord Nairn.
As to the Fate of these Gentlemen, it will be the Subject of the next Year's Account.
They were now drawing together in Scotland also, and Things ripened up for Action on that side too.

The last Account we had of the Earl of Mar, was, that being joined by all the Troops he had to expect, the Clans under General Gordon only excepted, who were also ready to join him on a March, he was now preparing to decamp, and make his grand Attempt for passing the Forth, and entring the South of Scotland, in order to sup∣port his other Adherents, and carry the War into England.

To this Purpose, he summon'd all his Forces together; and calling a great Council of War at Perth, where all their Measures were concerted, he left Colonel Balfour Governor of the Town, and march'd the 10th of November to Auchterarder, about 9 Ms from Perth, in order to draw his Army together, and settle the Order of Battle, as well as their Order of Marching: He had with him, if we may credit their own Report, 2300 Horse, and 5000 Foot, besides 3000 Foot which
join'd him the next Day; so that his Army con∣sisted of 10300 effective Men at the Time of the Battle: Only that they tell us, that 800 Men, whereof 400 were Horse, were drawn up as a Reserve on the other Side of the River, and ne∣ver came into Action.

It is plain, the Earl of Mar had no Expectation of being oblig'd to fight so soon, or that the Duke of Argyle, whose Forces were so much inferior in Number, would meet him half Way to give him Battle; and therefore, when the Royal Army ap∣pear'd, they had their Resolutions to deliberate; and calling a Council of War in the Field, it was unanimously resolved among them to fight, and, indeed, to begin the Attack.

The Duke of Argyle was not at all in any Un∣certainty; for when he had first an Account of the Enemy being advanc'd from Perth with his whole Army, Cannon, and Bread-Waggons, in which it was said he carried Provisions for 12 Days, it was easy to make a Judgment what his Intention was; and therefore the Duke resolving not to suffer him to dispute his Passage in Places inaccessable to the Horse, and where they could be of no Use in Battle, the Horse being the only Advantage he had, he passed the River at the Bridge of Sterling the 12th, with his whole Army, consisting but of 3500 Men, whereof about 1200 were Dragoons, all very good Troops, and com∣manded by experienc'd Officers, and advanced that Night to Dumblain.

The Enemy was at Ardoch, about 4 Miles di∣stance, and had, by their Countenance, seem'd as resolv'd for Action as the other, having given Signals, by firing three Pieces of Cannon that E∣vening, for all their Troops to assemble; which
being done, they advanc'd in Order of Battle the same Night, within about a Mile and half of the Royal Army, where they lay upon their Arms all Night, as the Duke of Argyle's Men did also.

On the 13th, by Break of Day, both Armies were again in Motion; and the Duke advancing to a Rising-Ground, a little before his Front, could easily discern the Enemy's Army in full March, tho' another Hill on his Left intercepted the Sight, so as that the Point of their Left Wing could not be discern'd; nor could he guess at the Extent of their Line for the same Reason, or how far they out-flank'd him. The Royal Army was drawn up upon the Hights above Dumblain, to the North-East of the Town, having the Town on his Left, at the Distance of about a Mile and half, and a wet boggy Moor, call'd Sherriffmoor, on his Right; which Moor was usually unpassable for the Cavalry, and was thought to be so then, only that a light Frost, which happen'd the two or three preceding Nights, had made it able to bear; and this the Earl of Mar it seems knew, and therefore extended his Lines to take the Royal Army in Front and Flank, marching his Men di∣rectly over the Moor. This caused the Duke to alter the whole Disposition of his Front to meet the Enemy, and prevent one Part of his Men be∣ing surrounded; and this occasion'd the Disor∣der on the Left, and gave the Enemy an Opportu∣nity to charge them before they were fully form'd, as shall appear presently: For to say the Enemy's Army, who had march'd in Order of Battle above a Mile, should be ready to charge the Duke of Argyle's Army before they were form'd, if that unforeseen Incident had not oblig'd him to change
the Dispositions he had made, would be to say, the Rebels understood their Business better than the King's General, which no body will pretend to. However it was, this is certain, that when the Royal Army, after the changing their Front as above, began to advance, and came up to the Rising Grounds, where the Enemy first appear'd, advancing also; they found themselves within Pistol-shot of the Enemy's Right, and heard their Bagpipes playing a great Way farther to the Left than the King's Line extended.

The Order of Battle of the Royal Army was thus: The first Line consisted of six Battalions of Foot, all old Troops; but the Battalions being upon the reduc'd Establishment, were but thin, not exceeding 300 Men each; the Right Wing consisted of three Squadrons of Dragoons, the choicest of the Army; and the Left likewise of three Squadrons: The second Line consisted of two Battalions of Foot, and two Squadrons of Dragoons, in each Wing. The Duke of Argyle was on the Right, at the Head of the Dragoons of Stairs and Evans: Brigadier Morrison had the Left; and Major-General Wightman commanded in the Center, or main Battle. Nor was it a small Loss that, in this Action, there was so great a Want of General Officers.

The Order of Battle of the Enemy, as we have it from their own Accounts, and from some of the Prisoners, who were taken in the Action, was thus: They were drawn up in two Lines, as fol∣lows: The Foot of the first Line, drawn up in 10 Battalions, but of unequal Numbers, form'd the main Battle, making about 4000 Men. On the Right they had five full Squadrons of Horse; and among them one, call'd the Sterling Squadron,
carrying the Pretender's Standard: On the Left, they had the new Regiment, call'd the Restorati∣on Regiment of Horse, all composed, as they gave out, of Gentlemen of Quality, and pretty well Hors'd, with six Squadrons of Huntley's and Seaforth's Cavalry.

Their second Line consisted of 8 Battalions of Foot, but also not equal in Number, making about 2000 Men, flank'd with three Squadrons of Horse on each Wing; and behind these, at a Distance, they had about 400 Horse drawn up as a Reserve, and who either were not ordered to come, or did not come into the Fight.

In this Order they advanc'd to the Moor, and in their March possess'd a Rising Ground on their Right, which so cover'd the Point of that Wing, that it could not be seen, as before, how far it extended.

Upon the Dukes first extending his Right Wing, the Rebels, who were marching down directly upon him from the Moor aforesaid, and expected to have flank'd his Wing, and have charg'd before his Men were form'd, were disap∣pointed in that Part; and the Duke, on the other hand, gave Order to his Cavalry immediately to charge the Enemy, the Infantry in the Center, at the same time advancing in good Order, as fast as they could.

The Enemy's Horse stood the first Charge very well, and fired very furiously upon the Dragoons; but these, being better Hors'd, press'd them very hard, and, at last, in Spite of the Vigour of the Men, who shew'd that they wanted no Courage, bore them down by the meer Weight of their Horses; and putting them first into Disorder, in little more than half an Hour they fled full Speed;
but as the Dragoons in pursuing kept their Order, the other rallied again in several Places, at great Distance one from another, and endeavouring to form again, shew'd they had Disposition enough to renew the Charge, if their Horses had been equal to those of the Royal Troops.

This very Thing takes off a little the Objection which some have raised against the Conduct of the Duke, as if he was too eager in the Pursuit, while, in the mean time, his Left suffer'd; for had he slack'd the Pursuit, and had not attack'd them in every Part as fast as they fac'd about, not giving them Time to rally any considerable Body together, he had had all his Work to do over again; especially, considering a Body of 400 Horse appear'd drawn up at a Distance, ready to have supported them, though, at that Time, there was a small River between.

This Manner of pursuing likewise had its Diffi∣culties, and the Enemy rallying thus continually, and every Minute making a bold Stand in one Place or other, may be guess'd at by the Length of Time which it took up to push them out of the Field, for that it was from One a Clock to near Four before they gave it over, and pass'd the little River Allan, which yet was not above two Miles and half in all.

While this was doing on the Right, the Left Wing had a far different Fate; for, advancing to alter the Scituation of their Front, according to the Right, they found the Main Body of the Ene∣my's Foot just in their Front, and extending be∣yond the Point of their Wing, the Enemy's Horse being still to the Left, and in Condition to take them in Flank, their Horse also not being come up. The Highland Men taking the Signal from
the Fire of their Left, fell on upon the three Re∣giments of Foot, which were on the Left of the Royal Army, General Wightman, with the other three, being advanc'd to support the Right Wing: The Charge which the Highlanders gave, was so furious, and their Officers led them on so daringly, that they came up to the very Muz∣zles of the Musquets; and notwithstanding the Thrust of the Bayonet, which the Musqueteers gave in upon them very bravely, yet they rush'd in among the Ranks, receiving all their Fire, putting their Bayonets by with their Targets, and cut down the Men with their Broad Swords in a Moment, putting them into the utmost Confu∣sion.

It is impossible to express the Horror which some of the Gentlemen of the English Regiments say their Men were possess'd with at that unusual and savage Way of Fighting: In a word, the three Battalions were broke, and a great many of them cut in Pieces in a few Moments; and those which were not kill'd or taken, were driven in among the Dragoons, and put them likewise into Confusion.

Had the Cavalry upon the Right Wing of the Enemy fallen in at that Time, the whole Left Wing of the Royal Army had been cut off; nor was it in the Power of the rest of the Foot to assist them, they being advanc'd after the Right Wing, to support them in the Pursuit of the Horse.

The Horse of the Left Wing seeing their Foot go thus to Wreck, after making a home Charge upon some Squadrons which stood on their Flank, and who they oblig'd to retire, finding the Re∣bels endeavouring to get behind them, and so,
either to march to Sterling, or cut off their Re∣treat, found themselves in no Condition to keep the Field, and retreated in good Order towards Sterling.

By this time the Enemy, who perhaps thought their Victory compleat on their Side, as, no doubt, the Duke did on his, had, as it was reported, an Account of the Misfortune of their Left; and having no Enemy in their Front, they form'd the Infantry of their first Line with some Horse, making near 5000 Men, and march'd directly back, following by a hasty March in the Rear of those Battalions which General Wightman com∣manded, and who were still advancing after the Duke of Argyle.

Had the Officer who led this Body, who, it is said by some, was Lieutenant General George Ha∣milton; others, Lieutenant General Gordon; o∣thers, that it was both; and that one was for charging immediately, the other for staying till their Rear was come up: We say, had they charg'd these Regiments immediately, the King's Army had been undone; but, by halting upon the Hill to form their Troops, they gave General Wight∣man Leave to face his Men to the Right about, as he himself says in his Account, and to get be∣hind some little Banks, or old Enclosures, which serv'd them for a Breast Work, and from that Cover, to draw off by little and little to Dum∣blain, whither the Duke of Argyle, when he had entirely defeated the Left Wing of their Army, follow'd.

The Enemy having lost the Advantage, and thereby the Victory, march'd off after their Horse, who were gathering together on the other Side
the little River; and so they all went away to Ardoch, both Sides pretending to Victory; but, doubtless, the Royal Army had the Tokens of Honour, by taking four Pieces of Cannon, tho' indeed they were not carried off till next Day; and any one that came for them with Horses to draw them, might have had them; nay, the Rebels say, the Country People drew them off to Dumblain; the Earl of Mar having lost the Artil∣lery Horses, who all run away at the first of the Battle, frighted with the Noise, as is not unusual. Thus ended this Day's Action; which, if it was not a Victory to the Duke, was certainly a Victo∣ry to the King; for by this Battle the Heart of the Rebellion was broke; the Earl of Mar was baulk'd in his Design; his Undertaking for a March to the South was laid aside, and never afterwards attempted, and the Superiority of his Majesty's Troops was acknowledg'd: Nor did the Earl of Mar, or any of his Friends, ever dis∣pute this Part of the Victory; for if they had not been broken in their Courage by the Terror of this Battle, why did they not continue the At∣tempt, and proceed on their March after the Fight, their Numbers being not so much dimi∣nished in Proportion as the Royal Army; for their Loss is not computed to be above 800 or 900 kill'd and taken, and the Royal Army is said to lose near 500 kill'd and taken; which is much more to 3500 Men, than the other was to 9000, or 10500, as was their Number before the Battle.

The Number of the Slain was reported as ei∣ther Side thought fit; but as for Prisoners on ei∣ther Side, those taken by the Royal Army a∣mounted to about Eighty four, most of whom
were Gentlemen, the Defeat happening wholly among the Horse; the Number of Prisoners taken by the Rebels, was said to be 200; but, as the other reported, was 110, besides Officers. The Earl of Strathmore, and the Captain of Clanra∣nald, were kill'd on the Spot, on the Rebel Side; and the Earl of Forfar, in the King's Army; the Earl of Islay, the Duke of Argyle's Brother, was wounded in two Places, but not mortally. The Earl of Penmure, among the Rebels was wounded very much, and taken, but retaken by his Bro∣ther, and carry'd off; and the Lord Strathalan was taken Prisoner.

I return now to the Civil Administration, which for a good while has been laid by: The Parlia∣ment of Great Britain was now under a Recess, which both the publick and private Affairs call'd for; which Recess being but by Adjournment, all the Impeachments given in to the House of Peers subsisted, the Parliament Prisoners remained, the Committee of Secrecy had Power to sit, and all the Publick Affairs were kept on in a State of formal Prosecution, as if the House had been still sitting.

But the King had another Kingdom to cast his Eye upon, and which was equally expos'd, if not more, than this; and which, as he could not withdraw his Care of, and Protection from, with∣out Diminution of the Glory of his Reign; so nei∣ther can my Account be compleat, unless I give some Account of what Steps were taken at this Time in that Part of the King's Dominions, and carry them on Hand in Hand with those of this Nation.

Ireland had been for some time under the Influ∣ence of the late Administration, without the Pre∣sence of a supreme Magistrate. The Earl of Sun∣derland, who had been nam'd Lord Lieutenant for that Kingdom, having been long indispos'd, was perswaded by his Friends to resign the Post of Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, and the Government was committed jointly to the Duke of Grafton, and the Earl of Galway; and, without entring in∣to the Times and Particulars of their being nomi∣nated, their Preparations, travelling to Chester, shipping off, &c. it is sufficient to say, they ar∣riv'd at Dublin the 1st of November, were receiv'd with the usual Solemnities, and immediately ap∣ply'd themselves to the proper Duties of that great Office, and to set to Rights the Affairs of that Country, which they found in Confusion enough.

A Parliament had been call'd by the King's Proclamation some Time before; and the Lords Justices being arriv'd in Time, the Two Houses met the 12th of November; and the first Thing to be done, being the Choice of a Speaker, that Choice fell unanimously upon William Connolly, Esq and as the Man was known, so the Choice of him gave every one a Knowledge of the Temper of the House then, viz. how they stood affected as to Parties.
The Speaker being chosen and approv'd, the same Day the Lords Justices made a Speech to both Houses, as follows:

P.HI: My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.Q:
“HIS Majesty having been pleas'd to appoint us Justices and Governours of this his Kingdom of Ireland, we are glad to meet you
in Parliament, where you will have an Oppor∣tunity of concerting such Measures as may tend” to the Publick Welfare.

“We heartily congratulate with you upon the King's most happy Accession to the Throne; being fully perswaded, that you have a due Sense of God's Mercy in this Act of his Divine Providence, which affords us so fair a Prospect of becoming a flourishing People under the Reign of a Prince, whose Wisdom, Justice and Clemency, entitle him to the Love and Obedi∣ence of his Subjects at Home, as his Resolution and strict Observance of Treaties, have gain'd him the Respect and Esteem of his Allies a∣broad.”

“We are commanded by his Majesty to assure you, that he will inviolably preserve our ex∣cellent Constitution both in Church and State; the Continuance of which Blessing is farther se∣cur'd to us by the eminent Virtues of the Prince of Wales, and by so numerous an Issue as God” has bestow'd upon his Royal Highness.

“It is with no small Satisfaction that we ob∣serve, the Calm which this Kingdom, hereto∣fore the Scene of so many Rebellions, at pre∣sent enjoys, while the traiterous Enemies to our King, and to our happy Establishment, disco∣ver'd by your early and steady Zeal for the Pro∣testant Succession, have thought fit to change the Place of Action, and attempt elsewhere to di∣sturb his Majesty's Government, whose un∣doubted Right to the Crown of these Realms is founded on the Laws of the Land, and secur'd by the Affections of his People Assembled in” Parliament.

“So desperate and wicked a Design must end in the Confusion of the Persons concern'd in it, and fix his Majesty's Throne upon a surer Foundation, by distinguishing the true Friends to his Royal Person and Government, from the Abettors of Popery and Slavery: Yet your Conduct will not be agreeable to your ac∣custom'd Prudence, if you neglect to put your selves in the best Posture of Defence upon this Occasion; for which Purpose, his Majesty has caused Arms to be delivered out of his Stores to the Militia, and has order'd an Addition to be made to each Company remaining in this Kingdom, 'till such Time as he can replace those Regiments, which the Necessity of his Affairs has oblig'd him at present to draw from hence, to suppress the Rebels in Great Britain; wherein your Safety is equally con∣cern'd” with that of his other Subjects.
“”Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

“We have order'd a State of the publick Accounts, together with the Charge of the Establishment, to be laid before you in the clearest and plainest Light; by which you will judge, what Supplies will be wanting to carry on the Service, and to defray such Ex∣pences as you may think proper for your own Security; nor can we in the least doubt, after so many Proofs of your Affection to his Majesty, but you will cheerfully contribute to the necessary Aids for the Support of a Government, whose Welfare is inseparable from” your own.
“You may depend upon a just and frugal Ap∣plication of the Money given to the Purpose” for which you design it.
“”My Lords, and Gentlemen,

“We have his Majesty's Orders to acquaint you, that he will readily consort to such good Laws, as may conduce to make you an easy and a happy People; and you may be assur'd, that we shall always concur with you in every thing that may be advantageous to the King∣dom; for which end we will willingly receive” your Advice.

“We must recommend to you in the present Conjuncture, all reasonable Dispatch in your Proceedings; and such Unanimity in your Re∣solutions, as may once more put an end to all other Distinctions in Ireland, but that of Pro∣testant” and Papist.

DIV1.P: It will not consist with the needful Brevity of these Annals, to repeat at large the Addresses of this Parliament, as well Lords as Commons; as well to the King, as to the Lords Justices; I therefore purposely omit them, being only Things in Course, and Matter of usual Form, expressing their Zeal for his Majesty's Service, Readiness to do all that was requir'd of them, Thanks for the Speech from the Throne, and the like.

This Parliament being of a much different Sort from their immediate Predecessors in the House, apply'd very early to unravel what had been done in the last Sittings, and to shew their Resentment at some Persons and Proceedings during the late Administration

First having resolv'd upon the Addresses of Thanks, as above, they began in the House of Peers with a Bill for recognizing his Majesty's Title to the Crown; and the Commons having first settled their Committees, began with falling upon the King's Enemies; which produced the several Bills for farther Security of the Person and Government of the King, &c. the Bill to attaint the Pretender, and give a Reward of 50000l. for his Head; and for attainting the Duke of Or∣mond, giving the Crown his Estate, and 10000l. Reward upon his Head.

These were follow'd of Course by a Retro∣spect upon the Councils of the last Reign; and a Resolve was pass'd, Nemine Contradicente, a∣gainst those who advis'd the Queen to prorogue the late Parliament, at a Time when a Bill to attaint the Pretender was depending; and they were unanimously voted to be Enemies to the Succession, and Favourers of the Pretender, and Popery.

They proceeded in the next Place to bring in a Bill to prevent Tumults, rebellious and rio∣tous Assemblies; All which Bills, together with the Supplies demanded, went thro the Houses in the usual Form, without the least Opposition; and being ratified in England, as the Constitution requires, were finish'd, and receiv'd the Royal Assent; as shall be observ'd in its Course.

But they did not end here; for on the 17th the Commons, while the publick Accounts, which were order'd to be laid before them, were pre∣paring, enter'd into another Enquiry, which brought a great many of their Members to their Peccavi on their Knees. The Case was this: The
last House of Commons in the Queen's Time, running pretty much the same way, had address'd the Queen against Sir Constantine Phipps, at that Time Lord Chancellor of Ireland, and one of the Lords Justices of that Kingdom, desiring her Majesty to remove him from his Employ∣ment; but as this Address seem'd at that Time not to be very acceptable to her Majesty, or to the Councils of that Reign, there were sundry other and counter Addresses procur'd and sent up from the several Counties and Towns in Ire∣land, in Favour of Sir Constantine Phipps; and desiring that he might not be remov'd, not∣withstanding the said Address of the House of Commons. This the House esteem'd to be a Breach of the Privilege of Parliament; and re∣solv'd to shew their Resentment at the Persons who sign'd those Addresses, especially such as were then Members of the sitting Parliament.

Accordingly they appointed a Committee to enquire what Addresses of that kind were sent up to her late Majesty, and who sign'd them; and they censur'd, or brought to Acknowledgment, a great many Gentlemen upon this Account; and then they address'd the Lords Justices, to issue out a Proclamation against the Popish In∣habitants of Limerick and Galway; It seems, those People in those Towns, presuming upon the Construction they thought fit to put upon the Articles of Capitulation made with King William, for the Surrender of those Places, had claim'd or pretended to an Exemption from the Penalties and Process upon the other Laws against Papists; upon Complaint whereof to the House, this Address was founded.
In this Current of publick Resentment, doing themselves Justice upon Excursions of the former ruling Party, they forgot not, even a mean News-Writer, one Richard Pue, whose Case was as follows.

There was in the latter End of the late Reign a Design much talk'd of, about breaking the Irish Army removing the Whiggish Officers and Regiments, and the like; which, however pre∣vented, is not our Business to enquire; but it seems it was only talk'd of, not done. But this News-Writer, in a publick Paper of his, call'd Pue's Occurrences, almost two Years before this Enquiry, viz. March 30, 1714. had printed the following Paragraph as a piece of News.

An Express is sent to Ireland for the immediate breaking the following Regiments there, viz. the Lord Mountjoy's, Col. Charles Churchill's, Col. Wade's, and Col. Corbet's, being all Foot; Col. Pepper's, and Col. Kerr's Dragoons. The honest People of Ireland will suffer by the ill Practices and Designs of their late factious House of Commons, which is a Pity; for these Draw-backs will be 40 or 50000 l. per Ann. out of that Kingdom's Way, besides the Loss of the Money the said six Regiments would spend in their Country; and another of their Regiments is to be sent to Port Mahone. Now, let their Whiggish Cloathiers and Cloth-Workers (instead of Wine every Night, as they had at the late Election for Parliament Men for your City and Country, at the Scots Ambassadors on the Comb,) drink Taplash, which they may have cheap, since the additional Duty is off.

P.Q: This Paper was censur'd in the House to be “a false, scandalous, and malicious Libel, high∣ly reflecting on the Justice and Honour of the late House of Commons of Ireland; and or∣der'd the said Pue to be taken into Custody of their Serjeant at Arms, for printing the” same.

DIV1.P: All this was but the first Week's Work of the House, so vigorously did they go on in their Work. The next Week began with laying be∣fore the House Abstracts of the publick Ac∣counts, and such Things as the House had called for, for their Guidance in the Supply; and the Excise-Bill being pass'd, the Lords Justices came to the House, and gave the Royal Assent to two Bills, Part of those mentioned before, viz. 1. An Act for an additional Duty upon Beer, Ale, &c. 2. An Act to recognize his Ma∣jesty's Titles, &c. The other Bills were not yet ready.
These Things and such like took up so much of their time, that for some Weeks they did little else except the dispatch of the Money-Bills, which indeed went on all the while.

Upon the like re-examination of the Case of Sr. Dudley Moor, in the late Reign, they censur'd all the Judges that had any hand in it; the Case was an alledg'd Partiality of the Judges, in Or∣dering the Clerk of the Crown to strike a Jury for that purpose; upon which, first they resolv'd upon the whole Debate, That by the Laws of the Land, and constant uninterrupted Usage of the Court of King's-Bench, all Juries in criminal Cases ought to be nominated and returned by the Sheriffs only, unless there be a legal Chal∣lenge
to his or their making such Return. This Resolution stated the Thing as it ought to have been; and then coming to examine how diffe∣rent the Conduct of the People concern'd had been from what, by the Usage of Court, &c. it ought to have been, they fell upon the Persons themselves in the following Resolu∣tions:

1. That the Rule made in the Court of Queen's-Bench in the Case of Dudley Moor, Esq where∣by the Clerk of the Crown was required to strike a Jury for his Tryal, was unprecedent∣ed, arbitrary, and illegal, and a high Invasion of the Rights and Liberties of the Subjects of Ireland.

ROW.CELL: 2. That Sir Richard Cox, late Lord Chief Justice of the said Court,
had, by making such Rule, acted partially, arbitra∣rily, and illegally, and contrary to the Oath and Du∣ty of a Judge.
3. That Thomas Coot, Esq late one of the Justices of the said Court,
4. That Richard Nutley, Esq late one of the Justices of the said Court,

DIV1.P: 5. That Philip Savage, Esq then Clerk of the Crown, &c. in naming the Jury, &c. in which Jury were several Persons who had Employ∣ments under the Crown, and others who had no Freeholds, acted partially, maliciously, and illegally.
This Case is too considerable to be omitted, as it stands as a Precedent upon Record to warn the highest Officers of Justice to act legally and up∣rightly in their Offices.

On the 16th of January they adjourn'd, most of the Bills they had depending being pass'd and sent to England, for the Council here to approve, as is requir'd by the Constitution of that Con∣quer'd Kingdom.

I go back now to the Affairs of England; the Lancashire or Preston Prisoners, being, as is ob∣serv'd before, secur'd, the Noblemen and most of the Gentlemen were Order'd to be brought to London, and they set forward accordingly, on the 23d of November; they arriv'd at London the 9th of December.

It is true, they were led through the Town as Prisoners, and pinion'd; that is, their Arms bound, as is usual in such Cases: Nor could they be brought in any other Posture with equal Secu∣rity; but this was but from Highgate to London; all the rest of the Journey they had as much Ci∣vility and good Usage shewn them as they could expect, which many of them have acknow∣ledged.

It is true, the common People in the Streets, as they passed, used them very scurvily, and with Curses, Reproaches, and a thousand Indignities, insulted them at an unsufferable Rate; but as the Guard with them, in the first place, did not en∣courage the People to do it, and were no way in a Condition to prevent it, the Blame of it lies wholly upon the Occasion.

As soon as they were lodg'd, they were all un∣bound; the Noblemen were treated with Ho∣nour
and Respect, at least with Decency, and were lodg'd in the Tower; neither had any of the other Prisoners any Irons put upon them, till their future Conduct made it absolutely ne∣cessary. Several of them were sent for up, after their Commitment, to be examin'd before the Council, and elsewhere; but their Answers seem'd to give no Token of any extraordinary Convi∣ctions on their Minds, but they pleaded they had been led by Principle, or hurry'd into a rash Un∣dertaking; that they were in the Hands of Pow∣er, and must undergo what they were pleased to inflict.

It is true, there was not Room for much to be said, the Fact, for which they were in Cu∣stody, being clear: There needed neither Evi∣dence or Confession as to that Part; to Men taken in Arms, what Accusation could be want∣ing? And as to those few Things the Govern∣ment desir'd to be inform'd of, they did not seem forward to answer; so they were remanded, as Persons the Government had no more to say to, but that they were to be dealt with in a judicial Way, which in the Sitting of the approaching Parliament we shall have farther Occasion to speak of.

From this Tragick Scene, we now cast our Eyes to that part of the Rebellion which still stood upon its Legs in Scotland. The Earl of Mar, as was observ'd before, remain'd at Perth, and his Troops canton'd in the Neighbouring Country, as the Duke of Argyle with his little Army, did at Sterling; but with this Difference, that the Duke's Army encreased every Day, and the Dutch Troops, especially those who went by Sea, began to arrive; whereas the Earl of Mar's
Men were exceedingly diminish'd by the going off of the Earl of Seaforth, the Marquis of Huntley, and others; tho' it is true, that they made Pro∣mises of returning again with larger Numbers; which Promises, however were never perform'd.

Yet was not the Earl of Mar altogether with∣out Supports in this Time; for as he was secure from any Attacks from the King's Troops on one hand, the violent Winter forbidding all Action, except by small Parties, for which here was very little Opportunity given; so he was at liberty to send Abroad his Agents, and Officers, by Persuasions, Orders, Menaces and Entreatics, to amass great Sums of Money, as well by Loan as by Cess and Contribution, and likewise great Quantities of Provision; nor was he idle in ma∣king use of the Opportunities he had.

But this was not all; on the 22d of December, the Pretender himself Landed: He had three Ships in Company, with about 36 Gentlemen, some Arms and Ammunition; but only that one, in which the Pretender came, was hear'd of for some Days; which being a small Vessel, but an excel∣lent Sailor, made the Voyage in seven Days from Dunkirk to Peterhead, near Aberdeen, where he came on Shore, with only six Gentlemen in his Retinue.

Now the Earl of Mar was arriv'd to the Top of his Expectations, and now he persuaded all his Party, that the Time of their Deliverance was come, and that they should be able to Tri∣umph over all their Enemies; and indeed, had the Pretender, as was expected, and as the most Part of his Friends at Perth had been made to believe; I say had he brought but 10000 Men of good Disciplin'd Troops with him, the Face
of their Affairs would have been very much chang'd: But, instead of this, it is apparent, he was as much surpriz'd that he did not find a very great Army ready to march, as the Army was to find that he had not brought 10000 Men with him; which, it seems, was the Number promised.

The Pretender was no sooner arriv'd, and Advice of it sent to the Earl of Mar, then at Perth, but he resolved to go and attend him, which he did, with the Earl of Marischal, Lieu∣tenant General Hamilton, and 20 or 30 Persons of Quality on Horseback, with a Guard of Horse to attend them. The Pretender Landing with this small Retinue, as above, pass'd Incog∣nito, in Seamens Habits, to Newburgh, a House of the Lord Marischal, and thro' Aberdeen to Feteresso, where he continued till the 27th, and where he was met by the Earls of Mar, Maris∣chal, and the Company above-mention'd, where he Dress'd and discover'd himself, and began to keep a Court, the Noblemen and Gentlemen be∣ing admitted to kiss his Hand. In his Retinue was the young Lord Tinmouth, Son to the Duke of Berwick, two French Officers, and three Scots.

He had some light Indisposition while he stay'd there, which proved an Ague, of which he had two Fits; and this detain'd him some Days; but on the 2d of January, he removed to Briechin; thence, on the 3d, to Keinard; the 4th to Glames; and thence, on the 5th, to Dun∣dee, where he entred the Town on Horseback, the Earl of Mar being on his Right Hand, and the Earl Marischal on his Left, with about 300 Gentlemen more attending him, besides some
Troops, which were for that Day only call'd his Guards.

Here his Friends desiring it, he continued in the open Market-Place on Horseback, to shew himself to the People, who crowded about him, and shouted and kiss'd his Hand, as is usual on such Occasions: After which, he went to .... Stuart, Laird of Garntully's House, where he Dined, and also lay there that Night. The next Day, Saturday the 7th, he went to Castle-lyon, a Seat of the Earl of Strathmre, where he Din'd, and Lodg'd that Night at Sir David Triplin's: The 8th being Sunday, he went to Schoon; and the 9th, he made his Publick Entry into Perth: He made no Stay at Perth, but return'd that Night to Schoon, except that he had the Curiosity to view some of the Soldiers Quar∣ter'd in the Town, and who were drawn out for him to see: they made a tolerable Ap∣pearance, tho' it was thought the Habit of the Highlanamen might at first seem very strange to him.

Before we dismiss this Scene, we must give, at large, those publick Transactions on his Side, on which the Story it self depends, and without which the History would not be compleat; And first, it is to be observ'd, that as soon as the Earl of Mar was come to Feteresso, and they had open'd the first Face of a Court; the first Thing done after the Person was own'd, and known, was, to cause him to be proclaim'd King at the Gates of the House.
Immediately from hence they publish his De∣claration, dated at Commercy in Lorrain, and dis∣perse printed Copies of it to be sent all over Britain.

Having begun thus to take upon him the Style and Majesty of a King, it follow'd, that he should receive the usual Homage of Subjects, and exercise the Regal Power: The first he receiv'd by the Addresses of the People, and the second by conferring Titles of Honour.

As to Addresses, the first was from the Epis∣copal Clergy of Aberdeen, and the second from the Magistrates, the Town Council, &c. of the City of Aberdeen, there having been no other Addresses presented to him in Form.

As to his Acts of Royal Authority which he took upon him, it was to confer Knighthoods, Nobility, and Ecclesiastical Dignities, on such as appear'd zealous for him: But as they all died, and are forgotten, so the Persons them∣selves, doubtless, decline the Honour design'd them.

Being returned to Schoon, he settled, and ap∣pointed a Privy-Council, and entred upon a formal Administration of his Affairs, publishing several Proclamations and Orders; as a Pro∣clamation for a Day of Thanksgiving for his Arrival; an Order for Praying for him in the Churches, and dispossessing the Ministers that refus'd it; a Proclamation for summoning a Con∣vention of Estates, an Order for the Currency of Foreign Coins; another for arming all the fencible Men, as usual, from 16 to 60; and lastly, one for his Coronation to be on the 23d of January; But he found other Employments for his Thoughts before that Time; and almost all these Proclamations and Orders had little other Ceremony attending them than their first Publication.

We meet with very little farther transacted, after this, till the Motions of the Duke of Argyle began to put them upon serious Reflections on the State of their Affairs; and, upon considering closely whether to stand the Attack of the Royal Army, or provide in Time for their own Safety. Some have said these Things took up long De∣bates; but I have been assur'd, that from the first of the Pretender's Landing, when they found the French declin'd him, and would not venture an open Declaration in his Favour; and he saw how divided, how naked of Defence, and how uncapable of engaging the Royal Army, they were at home, it was no more a difficulty with them, whether they should retreat or no; but it was resolv'd on in the very first Cabinet Consul∣tations, and that all the Appearance of Prepara∣tions for a vigorous Defence, the summoning all their Troops together, the sending Expresses for the Lords, Seaforth and Huntley, the holding a great Council, and every other Thing that look'd like Resistance, was to amuse the World, and to cover their Resolutions of retiring from the Knowledge of their own People, who, had the least Jealousy of what happen'd afterwards been in their Heads, had been more dangerous to them than the Royal Army.

From this Consideration, we cannot so much wonder at the Cruelty of their firing the Villa∣ges, and burning the Corn, &c. or say how ri∣diculous it was, when they had no Intentions to fight; the Reason is plain, viz, they were un∣der an absolute Necessity of making their own People believe that they resolv'd to fight the Royal Army, and it was not Words that would
do this; they were to make all the visible Ap∣pearances of it; they were to advance their Troops, fortify the Place, and make all the Dis∣positions for Action that they would have done if they really were designing to fight; and there∣fore, nothing could be in a greater Hurry and Bustle, than the People at Perth were in for a Week or ten Days before they were to go away; nor was there any thing to be seen but planting of Guns, marking out Breast-works and Tren∣ches; and, in a word, all possible Preparation for Action, insomuch that all our News-Papers, for some Days, assur'd us, that the Pretender's People resolv'd to fight, and were putting them∣selves in a Posture to give the Duke of Argyle a very warm Reception.

All this while the Duke of Argyle was at Sterling; and tho' he made no Motion, yet he was far from being idle; his Troops began to encrease: Newton's and Stanhope's Regiments of Dragoons had joyn'd him from England, and the Dutch Regiments were at hand; some of them having already pass'd the Border by Land, and about 2000 of them were arrived by Sea. Ge∣neral Cadogan was come, and Major General Vanderbeck, who commanded the Dutch Troops, was also with him. They had view'd the Coun∣try, and had consider'd the Scituation of the Enemy; and being resolv'd to attack the Gen∣tlemen at Perth, as soon as the Troops were all joyn'd, let the Frost and the Snows offer what Difficulty they might, he made Preparations for that Purpose.

In the Interval of these things, there hap∣pen'd some small Rencouters between the For∣ces
on both Sides; which, however small, serve to compleat our History of this unhappy Insur∣rection. And first, as to the Motions of the Earl of Sutherland, and the Gentlemen with him in the North, they had frequent Marches and Attempts to engage, between them and the Earl of Seaforth: tho' it never came to Blows; at last, by the Interposition of the Lady Dowager of Seaforth, a Submission was sign'd by the Earl; and a like Treaty was, with better Effect, con∣cluded also with the Marquis of Huntley; for as to Seaforth, he fell off, and run to Arms again, to his own Ruine, as shall be related afterward. Thus the Earl of Sutherland, and the Noblemen and Gentlemen on the King's Side in those parts, not only kept their Ground, but gain'd very much, and preserv'd all that part of the Country in the King's Interest, till the Duke of Argyle's Army came up to them to finish the Work.

From thence we come down to the South, to the Shore of Fife; and there the Duke of Argyle order'd one of the Men of War, Lying in Leith Road, to stand over towards the other Shore, and see if he could lie near enough to Brunt Island, to throw a few Shot into the Town, and batter them a little; the Captain of the Man of War did so, and Cannonaded the Town for an Hour or two; upon which the Earl of Mar's Men quitted the Place, imagining, as was said after∣wards, that as soon as the Cannonading was over, the Captain of the Man of War would at∣tempt to land; and there not being a sufficient Number of Men in the Place to defend it, they resolv'd to abandon it; they left behind them six Pieces of Cannon, being Ship Guns; some Arms, with a good Quantity of Provisions:
Upon Advice of this to General Cadogan, who was then at Edinburgh, he order'd a Detachment of Scots and Dutch Troops to pass the Firth, and take possession of the Place, under the Command of Sir John Montgomery: Upon his Arrival, the Rebels quitted likewise all the Towns on the North Side of the Firth. They had afterwards a little Skirmish with some of the Dutch Soldiers at Dysert, but of no Consequence; Nine of the Earl of Mar's Men coming to the Lord Sinclair's Coal-Pits, to fetch Coals to carry to Perth, were sur∣rounded by the Dutch; and, taking Shelter in a House, refus'd to yield, till two of them being kill'd, the rest surrender'd.

On the other Hand, to begin the Year, about the first or second of January, the Earl of Rothes, with a good Body of Volunteers, and about 30 or 40 Dutch Foot, march'd to attack Falkland, an old Royal House of the King's of Scotland, but decay'd; the Rebels having Notice of this De∣sign, sent a Body of their Troops into the Place, and with another Party surrounded the Dutch Sol∣diers, and about 30 Gentlemen in a Village; the Gentlemen got most of them off, but the Foot were made Prisoners.

Upon this Success of the Rebels, and to re∣strain their Excursions, the Duke of Argyle order'd three Battalions of the Dutch Foot to pass the Firth at Queen's Ferry, and take quarters at Inner∣keithing, Dumfermling, and the Towns thereabouts, which perfectly cover'd that part of the Country, and kept the Enemy within Bounds.

The latter end of December the Dutch Troops arriv'd, most of them took Post in the Army; there had been a Train of Artillery, and all
Stores suitable to the Service Ship'd at London, but had lain Wind-bound at the Buoy on the Nore so long, that the Duke of Argyle, whose Orders were to Fight without loss of time, thought fit not to run the risque of being disappointed of Cannon, thought convenient to send to Berwick upon Tweed for Ten pieces of Cannon, and four Mortars, which were accordingly sent, 1500 Hor∣ses being furnish'd at Edinburgh for the bringing them away.

But before they arriv'd, or at least before the Army march'd, the Train arriv'd from England also by Sea, and tho' there was no occasion for Guns, yet the Gunners, Engineers, Fire-Men, &c. were very much wanted.

As soon as General Cadogan came back to Ster∣ling, having been at Edinburgh some Days, a Great Council of War was held, where it was resolv'd to march with the whole Army, and at∣tack the Earl of Mar and all his Forces in their Quarters at Perth, or in their Camp, wherever they should be found.

The Measures concerted, the Order of Battle appointed, and Orders were immediately given out to prepare every thing needful against the Time; and because it was found, that the Depth of the Snow, which was in most places two or three Foot thick, would very much retard the March of the Infantry and Cannon, if not make it impracticable; Orders were given to Summon in several Thousands of the Countrymen to re∣move the Snow, and to open a plain Road for the Passage of the Carriages.

On the 21st, 200 Dragoons were detach'd to∣wards Perth, to discover the Country, and see if they could, into the Posture of the Enemy; and
to see in what Condition the Roads were for the Army's passing. Colonel Ghest, who commanded this Party, did as he was commanded, and brought back his Account to the General; but knew no∣thing that his advancing had alarm'd the Enemy to that Degree, as to put all the City of Perth into a Hurry, some Country People coming in full speed, and telling them, that the Duke of Argyle, with all his Cavalry, and 4000 Foot, mounted on Horses, was in full March to attack them; nor was this Fright over, till a Party of Horse being sent to Tullibardin, and from thence every way to view the Roads, sent express word, that all was quiet, and that no Enemy appear'd.

On the 24th, the Duke, with General Cado∣gan, and a strong Party of Horse, went out them∣selves to view the Country, and particularly the Roads, which the Workmen were all this while busy in clearing and making good: This March of the Duke caus'd a second Alarm, and made some of their Men, who were in the most ad∣vanced Posts, retire; but the Alarm did not reach to Perth, as the other had.
On the 26th, the Duke order'd two Regiments of Dragoons, and 500 Foot, to advance to Dumblain, with Directions to post a strong Party at the demolish'd Bridge of Down.

The same Day, viz. the 29th, the Army began their March, and marched to Dumblam; the Troops that were at Dumblain before, advancing at the same time, came to the old Castle of Brao, expecting some Resistance, but they found it abandon'd; the next Morning the same Party, with two Pieces of Cannon, advanc'd upon the Road to Tullibardin, to cover the Workmen, who were at Work to clear the Way, and to prevent
their being insulted by the Garison of Tullibardin. That Day the Army advanc'd to Auchteratder; and here indeed the Rebels having burnt all the Houses, as is said before, the poor Soldiers had cold Quarters, having no Lodging but in the Snow, nor any other Covering but the fine Ca∣nopy of Heaven; or, as the French say, les belles Estoilles, the beautiful Stars. The one and Thir∣tieth, they pass'd the River Ern, and came to Tullibardin, the Garison of which was with∣drawn, except 50 Men, who were made Priso∣ners; and here it was, the Duke receiv'd the welcome News, that the Pretender, and all his Army, had abandon'd Perth the Day before, and were retir'd towards Dundee.

Though the Army were as keen for Action as could be desir'd; yet as the Soldiers had now lain two Nights in the Snow; for at Tullibardin they could not get Shelter for the common Sol∣diers, they were not a little glad of warmer Quarters: The Duke had not the Account till near four a Clock in the Afternoon that the Ene∣my was gone; and therefore it being near dark it was not possible to get there that Day; how∣ever, he detach'd immediately four Squadrons of Dragoons, and 2 Battalions of Foot, to take Pos∣session of the Town, and went himself with them and marching all Night, they enter'd Perth by the Light of the Snow about two a Clock in the Morning, at the Head of the Dragoons; the two Battallions having march'd all the Day before, were fatigu'd with the length of the way, and Want of Rest, and could not reach the Place till Ten of the Clock the next Morning; in which had the Enemy had Intelligence, and been nimble enough to have taken the Advantage, the Duke
had been in some Hazard; but they had other Business upon their Hands.

The next Morning, the whole Army decamp∣ed from their cold Quarter, at Tullibardin, and, marching with what Speed they could make, ar∣riv'd at Perth that Evening, being the 1st of Feb∣ruary, where they had good Quarters.

I have given these Accounts from the most certain Narrations of them which were made publick at that time, even by the Whiggs them∣selves, and even in their very Words, except where the matters themselves may since have regu∣lated those Accounts; so that they cannot al∣ledge my History to be deficient, much less par∣tial in any thing.

The Fatigue which the Army had met with in this march however short, was such, that it was ab∣solutely necessary to give them some rest; and yet the necessity of the Service requir'd they should immediately proceed and follow the Enemy as close at the Heels as possible; especially con∣sidering they had already four Days start of the Royal Army; having quitted Perth the 30th of January, and it being now the 2d of February.

The Duke therefore set forward again with six Squadrons of Dragoons, three Battalions, and 800 Foot Detach'd out of all the Regiments, and came to Dundee the third, the rest of the Army following by more easie marches, came thither the next Day.

From hence sending still Detachments on be∣fore them to pursue on the Road to Montrose, some by the way of Brechim, others by that of Aberbrothick, the Duke with the whole Army marched the fifth; and as they were upon this march, they receiv'd an Account that the Pre∣tender
was gone, having taken Shipping at Mon∣trose, together with the Earl of Mar, and some others, and left the Army to make the best of their way to the Hills, in order to their Escape from the Royal Army, the Horse being of little or no Use there.

General Gordon, the Lord Tinmouth, the Earl Marischal, and several others, which our common Accounts mentioned to be left to shift for them∣selves, kept with the Army, and continu'd their March to Aberdeen; the Foot marching on be∣fore with General Gordon, and the Earl Ma∣rischal, with about 1000 House, keeping the Rear, to prevent Surprize; nor, if we may be∣lieve their own Relation, was the Earl Marischal, and General Gordon, in such extraordinary Transports of Anger and Despair, on the News of the Pretender's Escape; tho' perhaps, they might think fit to act such a Part, for the pre∣sent Occasion: But otherwise there is no Doubt but they were made acquainted with the Design; and, being well assur'd that their own Escape would be in Time provided for, they agreed to take the Hazard for the Service of their Cause, and continue with the Troops till they carry'd them clear of the pursuing Army; and this they did so effectually, as gave the Gentlemen Op∣portunity to make their Escapes afterward at more Leisure, and gave the common People Op∣portunity to disperse, and retire to their Dwel∣lings; so that in all the Pursuit which the Duke of Argyle made, tho' he lost no Time, and har∣rast the Troops very sorely; yet they were not able to overtake any Part of them, nor did they, except such as voluntarily surrender'd, make 100 Prisoners in the whole Pursuit from Perth to
Aberdeen, and from thence to Locqubaber, where they separated: But even after they had so sepa∣rated, they went every Man his own Way qui∣etly enough, till particular Detachments were sent under General Cadogan, near two Months after, upon Notice that they had appointed to rally their Forces again.

To confirm this Opinion, it appears, that General Gordon, who took upon him the Com∣mand after the Flight of the rest, march'd on to Aberdeen; and there, drawing up the Troops together, he pulls out a Paper of Instructions from the Pretender, which, as he said, he had Order not to open till he came to that City. In this Paper, the Pretender complains of Dis∣appointments from abroad principally, and of the Necessity he was under, for his own Preser∣vation, to leave the Country; that he thanked them for their cheerful Undertaking so hazar∣dous an Enterprize; which, had it been as well seconded by others, who had likewise engaged to do it, might have had better Success: He recommends to them to consult their own Secu∣rity, by keeping together till they can come to such Places, where they may separate without being made a Prey to their Enemies; and encou∣rages them to expect to hear farther from him in a very short Time.

It was the 4th of February that the Pretender embarkt, and the 6th in the Morning they reach'd Aberdeen; where their Friends receiv'd them with dejected Countenances, and that with good Reason, considering that they were now like to be call'd to a strict Account for their having formerly entertain'd them after another manner.

They had no Time to lose; for the Duke of Argyle, who made every Day fresh Detachments after them, was at their Heels. On the 7th in the Morning, they began to march out of Aber∣deen, and by two in the Afternoon had entirely quitted it; and here having in the short Time of their Stay, procured three Vessels for car∣rying off more Gentlemen, who resolv'd to escape, those Vessels receiv'd private Orders to meet them to the North of Aberdeen, under the Shores of Peterhead, Buchan-Ness, and other Parts, and about 200 Gentlemen, who were concern'd in that Design, parted from the Army, and march'd in a Body to the Places appointed, where, in several Creeks and Harbours, most of them embarkt, and got off; but one Ship, fall∣ing in with the English Cruisers, was oblig'd to stand in again for the Shore, and land their Cargo; yet the Gentlemen, knowing the Coun∣try perfectly well, found means to get Horses again, and make their Way to the Hills after the flying Army; nor did any of them, upon these Occasions, fall into the Hands of the pursuing Army: It was reckon'd that about 140 Gentle∣men made their Escape at that Time, and landed all safe in France.

On the 8th, the Duke of Argyle arriv'd at A∣berdeen with 400 Men; but the rest of the Army not being come up, the Pursuit could not be carry'd on, save that Major General Evans was detach'd with 200 Dragoons, and some Foot, to endeavour to cut off their Horse, who still kept in the Rear of their Army, from the rest; and particularly, to follow those two Hundred, who went towards the Sea to embark.

General Evans did his best to intercept these Gentlemen, and follow'd them to Frazersburgh, from thence they were gone to Bampff, whither he could not follow, but sent a Detachment of 40 Dragoons, with some Foot to follow them thither: It is true, the Letter which General E∣vans sent to the Duke, as it was made publick, does not mention that any were embarkt; but it seems to imply, that it was known to be so, seeing the General would venture to pursue the rest with but 40 Dragoons.

The main Body of the Rebels still kept toge∣ther, the Foot marching in the Van, and the Cavalry in the Rear, to prevent their being at∣tack'd by the small Detachments of Dragoons which follow'd them; and in this Order they march'd thro' Strath-Spey, and the Country about the River Don, to the Mountains of Badenoch, where they rested, being in perfect Safety from the Dragoons, who knew better things than to venture after them thither, those Places not be∣ing practicable for the Horse; and therefore the Duke on the t'other hand, contenting him to spread his Detachments over all the flat Coun∣try, put an end here to the pursuit, and sent a Body of Men to open a Communication with the Earl of Sutherland and his Friends at Inverness, which was done.

And thus we are come to an end of the Re∣bellion; that is to say, as far as relates to the Action in the Field. The Enemy having little left to do but to separate their Foot, and the Gentlemen to make their Escape beyond Sea in the best manner they could, which however so
many did, that it was unaccountable to think how few fell into the Hands of the King's Offi∣cers after the retreat from Perth, the great num∣ber of Gentlemen in Arms being consider'd.

One of the Salleys they made for this pupose, was so very bold, and yet so well executed, that it deserves to be recorded; it was at that time when their Army separated at Badenoch, when a certain Number of the Gentlemen, who had made secret Provision for their Escape, receiv'd Advice that two French Frigates, one of twenty six Guns, and one of eighteen, were arriv'd for their Relief, and that they would lie in the Road of the Okneys, in Pentland Firth, till they heard from them. Upon this Advice, the Lord Duffus, Sir Geo. Sinclair, Lieutenant General Eclyn, and about 160 Gentlemen in all, on Horseback, and well mounted, made a Sally from the Hills, and, crossing the Shire of Murray, came to the Sea∣side near Burgh; where getting ten large Boats, they quitted some of their Horses to their Ser∣vants, and killed the rest, to prevent their falling into the Hands of the Dragoons, so to be used against their Friends.
