And thus being embark'd, they committed themselves to the Sea, and sailed away for the Orkneys: They put in at Dunbeth, and 60 of them got there two large Barks, with which they pursued their Voyage, and went all on Board the French Frigate of 26 Guns; the rest landed in Arskerry, another of the Islands; and having press'd a Scots Vessel to carry them to the Place where the other Frigate lay, the Coun∣try began to rise upon them, fearing to be plun∣der'd: But at first, the French Ship coming to their Assistance, they were too strong for the
Country People; so secondly, telling them they were all Gentlemen, who were flying for their Lives; that they would hurt no body, and pay for what they had; the Country People acquiesc'd, and let them alone.
The other Ships coming in, they all embark'd, and, as we heard afterwards, they landed at Gottenbro', in the King of Sweden's Dominions.

There were yet with the Rebels, the Earls Marischal, Lithgow, Southesk and Seaforth, who about this Time came to them again; the Mar∣quis of Tullibardin, Lord Tinmouth, Drummond, Pitsligo, Rollo, &c. Also Sir Donald Mackdonald, the Clans of Glengary, Glenderule, Auchenbroek, Lo∣cheal, Clanranald, Glencoe, Keppoch, Appin, Cameron, and abundance of Lowland Gentlemen; but they were all taken to the Mountains, where they shelter'd themselves from the Pursuers for some Time.

As to the Duke of Argyle, having finish'd the Pursuit as above, and Cantoned his Men, he left the Army, which indeed wanted refreshment very sorely; and having made a reparation of Quarters, he left General Cadogan to Command them, and came back to Edinburgh the 27th of February; and was at the great Meeting of the Peers for Election of a Lord of Parliament in the room of the Marquis of Tweedal deceased.

The new Choice fell upon the Earl of Had∣dington. Here he receiv'd the Earl of Murray, who came now over to the Winning Side, and took the Oaths. And the Duke having been magnificently Entertain'd by the City of Edin∣burgh, set forward for Court, where he arriv'd the 6th of March.

I come back now to the Civil Administration; the Parliament of Ireland was in a recess for some time as above; they sat again the 16th of Ja∣nuary, where they receiv'd the Bills sent to Eng∣land, Voted an Association, and to shew their Zeal on account of the Rebellion. They Voted, that whatever Forces his Majesty shall think fit to raise, or whatever Expence his Ma∣jesty should think necessary for the Defence of the Kingdom, they would make good the same, and order'd this to be put into an Ad∣dress.

Also they resolv'd to Address the Lords Ju∣stices, to secure the Persons of all such as they should suspect to be disaffected to the Govern∣ment; also they declare it to be the indispensible Duty of all the Magistrates in that Kingdom, to put the Laws in immediate Execution against all Popish Priests, who shall Officiate contrary to Law; and that those, who neglect the same, shall be look'd upon as Enemies to the Consti∣tution.

The Reason of all these extraordinary Steps at that Time, was an Alarm just then given, both in England and in Ireland, of the Duke of Ormond being preparing a great Power in the Western Ports of France, and also in Spain, in order to invade the King's Dominions; and that it was expected he would make an Attempt to Land in Ireland, as well as England.

After this, they renewed the Enquiry into the misbehaviour of their Members in the late Reign, and after but a short Debate, they fell upon the Earl of Anglesea, who it seems they had a handle against upon the old Score, of advising the late
Queen to Prorogue the Parliament; and having first car∣ried the previous Question in their former Sit∣ting on the 15th of November, viz. That whoever advis'd the Queen to Prorogue the Parliament, &c. was an Enemy to the Succession, they founded ano∣ther Question now, and carried it, (viz.) That whoever advis'd the irregular breaking great part of the Army in this Kingdom, immediately after the said unseasonable Proroguing the late Parli∣ament, as aforesaid, were Enemies to the Prote∣stant Succession, and design'd to bring in the Pretender, and Popery.

The Way being thus clear'd to the Mark they aim'd at, the Question was put, That it is the Opinion of this House, that Arthur Earl of Anglesey, was one of the principal Advisers of her late Majesty to prorogue the said Parliament, and break the said Ar∣my; and that therein he gave pernicious Council to her Majesty, and is an Enemy to the King and King∣dom.

There were some Objections offer'd to a ge∣neral Vote of this Nature, as to censuring a Nobleman upon the Word Opinion; and some, who were yet no Friends to the Earl, were, however, against it as Unjust, or, at least, Un∣parliamentary, and would have had the Fact farther enquir'd into, that the Vote might have been thus, viz. It appears to this House, not, that it is the Opinion of this House: But the Que∣stion was carried, as it then was, by a great Majority: Upon which they pass'd the second Resolution with less Difficulty, viz. That an humble Address be presented to his Majesty, that he will be graciously pleas'd, for the Security of his Government, and of the Protestant Interest in Ire∣and,
to remove the said Arthur Earl of Anglesey from his Council and Service in this Kingdom.

A Committee being appointed for this Ad∣dress, they order'd, the same Day, the Associ∣ation, enter'd into by both Houses, to be con∣firm'd by an Act of Parliament. It seems to have been the declining to enter into and sign this As∣sociation, which brought this Storm upon the Earl of Anglesey, who was otherwise well with the Government, and would have probably had former Things forgotten.

On the 27th the Lords Justices came to the House, and passing the two following Bills, (viz.) An Act for an Additional Duty on Wines, and Strong-Waters, and an Act to Attaint the Pre∣tender, they made the following Speech, viz.

P.HI: My Lords and Gentlemen,

DIV1.P: HAVING receiv'd Letters this Morning from England, by Express from one of his Majestys Principal Secretaries of State, advising us, that there is reason to believe that this King∣dom will be very suddenly Invaded; we thought it our Duty to communicate the same to you without Loss of Time, that you may take such Measures thereupon, as may best conduce to the Defence and Security of your Country.

Nor have we any room to doubt, after the Assurances you have given in your Addresses, and by your Voluntary Associations, of your sincere and hearty Affection for his Majestys Per∣son and Government, but that you will exert your selves upon this Occasion, in the most ef∣ectual
manner, to defeat so horrid and treason∣able an attempt.

P.HI: Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

DIV1.P: It will be particularly incumbent on you to take such Resolutions at this Juncture, as may enable us to do what is necessary to put the Kingdom in a sufficient Posture of Defence, with the utmost Expedition.

Whatever Expence shall be made at this Time, will be so much laid out to preserve the whole; and you may depend upon it, whatever Powers you shall entrust us with, shall be made use of with the greatest Fruga∣lity, and for the Purposes only which you design them.

It is with much Satisfaction that we can ac∣quaint you, that his Majesty, upon our Repre∣sentation, has been graciously pleas'd, out of his tender Concern for this Kingdom, to direct, That the several Regiments taken from this Esta∣blishment, shall be paid in Great Britain, from the Time of their arrival there.

P.HI: My Lords and Gentlemen,

DIV1.P: As your presence will be absolutely necessary in the Country, we must recommend to you all possible Dispatch in your Proceedings, that you may have an Opportunity of shewing the same Zeal for his Majesty's Service, and the Preserva∣tion of this Kingdom, in your respective Stati∣ons, as you have done conjointly, and with great Unanimity in Parliament.

Upon this Speech the House of Commons fell upon the Article with great warmth and affection, and Voted an Address to the King, expressing their detestation of the Rebellion, and assuring his Majesty of their Fidelity to his Person, and Resolution to maintain his Title to the Crown; then they Voted an Address to the Lords Justi∣ces, full of Compliments and Thanks upon their early intimation of those things to the House, and desiring them to raise such Troops as may compleat the Establishment, and as many more as they should think necessary for the Defence of the Kingdom; and promising to make good the Expences; likewise, an Address to desire a Pro∣clamation with 10000l. Reward for apprehending that Duke of Ormond if he attempted to Land in that Kingdom; and order'd a Bill to subject the Estates of the Papists and Nonjurors, to make full Satisfaction for all the Loss and Damage which any Protestant may suffer by any Insurrection or Invasion, &c. And lastly, an Address that no Popish Soldiers should be suffer'd to List among the King's Troops; after which they were Ad∣journ'd again 'till the 8th of March following.

From their Proceedings therefore I come to the Parliament of Britain; who after several Ad∣journments met together the 9th of January, the same Year. At their coming together, the King opened the Session with the following Speech.

P.HI: My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.Q: “THE Zeal and Affection to my Govern∣ment, and the vigilant Care for the Safe∣ty of the Nation, which you have shewn in your respective Counties, have not only fully answered my Expectations, but give me As∣surances, that you are met together resolved to act with a Spirit becoming a Time of com∣mon Danger, and with such a Vigour, as will end in the Confusion of all those, who have openly engag'd in this Rebellion; and in the Shame and Reproach of such as, by secret and malicious Insinuations, have fomented, or, by an avow'd Indifference, encouraged this Trai∣terous” Enterprize.

“It is, I doubt not, a great Satisfaction to you, to have observ'd, That the Powers you entrusted me with, for the Preservation of the publick Safety, have been employ'd in the most proper and effectual manner, and made strictly subservient to those Purposes only, for which you intended them; and you must have had the Pleasure to reflect with me, that as the Measures taken for our Defence have been just and necessary, so it has pleased the Divine Providence to bless them with a Series of suit∣able Success: And I cannot but take this Op∣portunity, of doing Justice to the Officers and Soldiers of the Army, whose brave and faith∣ful Discharge of their Duty, has disappointed our Enemies, and contributed so much to the” Safety of the Nation.

“I did hope, that the detecting and prevent∣ing the designed Insurrections in some Parts of the Kingdom, and the defeating in others, those who had taken up Arms against me, would have put an End to this Rebellion; but it is plain, that our Enemies, animated by some secret Hopes of Assistance, are still endeavouring to support this desperate Un∣dertaking; and the Pretender, as I have Reason” to believe, is now landed in Scotland.

“It is, however, with Pleasure I can acquaint you, that notwithstanding these intestine Com∣motions Great Britain has, in some Measure, recover'd its Influence and Reputation Abroad The Treaty for settlsng the Barrier for the Ne∣therlands, is now fully concluded, between the Emperor and States General, under my Guar∣ranty. The King of Spain has agreed to a Treaty, by which that valuable Branch of our Commerce will be deliver'd from the new Im∣positions and Hardships, to which it was sub∣jected by the late Treaties; and will stand set∣tled for the future, on a Foot more advanta∣geous and certain, than it ever did, in the most floarishing time of any of my Predecessors; and the Treaty for renewing all former Alliances, between the Crown of Great Britain and the States General, is brought very near to its” Conclusion.
“”Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

“I must rely on your Affection to me, and your Care and Concern for the Safety of the Nation, to grant me such Supplies as may en∣able
me to restore, and to secure the Peace of the Kingdom; and I will order Estimates of the necessary Expences to be laid before” you.

“Among the many unavoidable ill Conse∣quences of this Rebellion, none affects me more sensibly, than that extraordinary Bur∣then, which it has, and must create to my faithful Subjects: To ease them as far as lies in my Power, I take this first Opportunity of declaring, that I will freely give up all the Estates, that shall become forfeited to the Crown by this Rebellion, to be applied to∣wards defraying the extraordinary Expence, in∣curr'd” on this Occasion.
“”My Lords and Gentlemen,

“It is Matter of the greatest Uneasiness to me, that the first Years of my Reign, the whole Course of which I wish'd to have trans∣mitted to Posterity, distinguish'd by the fair and endearing Marks of Peace and Clemency, should be clouded and overcast with so unna∣tural a Rebellion; which, however impotent and unsuccessful, a due Care may render it in all other Respects, does most sensibly afflict me, by the Calamities it has brought on many of my faithful Subjects, and by those indis∣pensable Returns of Severity, which their Sufferings, and the publick Safety, do most justly call for. Under this Concern, my great∣est Comfort is, that I cannot reproach my self, with having given the least Provocation to that Spirit of Discontent and Calumny, that has
been let loose against me, or the least pretence” for kindling the Flame of this Rebellion.

“Let those, whose fatal Counsels laid the Foundation of all these Mischiefs, and those whose private Discontents and Disappoint∣ments, disguised under false Pretences, have betrayed great Numbers of deluded People in∣to their own Destruction, answer for the Mi∣series in which they have involv'd their Fellow-Subjects. I question not, but that, with the Continuance of God's Blessings, who alone is able to form Good out of Evil, and, with the cheerful Assistance of my Parliament, we shall in a short Time, see this Rebellion end, not only in restoring the Tranquility of my Government, but in procuring a firm and lasting Establishment of that excellent Con∣stitution in Church and State, which it was manifestly designed to subvert: And that this open and flagrant Atempt, in Favour of Po∣pery, will abolish all other Distinctions among us, but of such as are zealous Assertors of the Liberties of their Country, the present Esta∣blishment, and the Frotestant Religion, and of such as are endeavouring to subject the Na∣tion to the Revenge and Tyranny of a Popish”Pretender.

DIV1.P:
After this Speech, and the usual Addresses of Thanks from both Houses, the House of Commons fell immediately to work upon the Enquiry into the Prisoners of State; for the Military Power having now almost finished that part which be∣long'd to it in the Field, the next Scene will be
of Course the Judicial Proceedings against the unhappy remains of the Rebellion which were fallen into their Hands.

Mr. Nicholas Lechmere made the first Motion in the House; and after a long Speech intimating what he aim'd at, the House Resolv'd Nemine Contradicente, to Impeach the Lords in the Tower of High-Treason.

I have not room to run thro' the former, ei∣ther of Voting these Impeachments, or carrying them up to the House of Lords; 'tis enough to mention, that they were all Impeach'd at the Bar of the House of Lords, and immediately Articles were found against them, and exhibited in Form, and being Engross'd, were carry'd to the Lords the same Night.

Such a Days Work has hardly been seen in the House of Commons of many Years past; and the Warmth of the Proceeding might easily di∣ctate to the Imprison'd Lords, what they had to expect, and that no Time would be lost in their Prosecution, as it farther immediately appeared, for the very next Day, viz. the 10th of January, the impeach'd Lords were all brought up to the Bar of the House of Lords, where the Articles of Impeachments against them were read, and Co∣pies of them were ordered to be deliver'd to them, and they were orderd to put in their An∣swer in six Days, viz. the 16th; and upon their Request, that such Persons as were proper to as∣sist them in their said Answer and Defence, might be admitted to come to them, it was immediately granted by the House.

The Impeachments being lodg'd, the Com∣mons went upon other Business, and first or∣der'd a Bill to be brought in, to continue the
Suspension of the Habeas Corpus Act for six Months longer; and then resolv'd, that Mr. Forster, Knight of the Shire for the County of Northum∣berland, who had been in actual Rebellion against the King, and was then a Prisoner for the same, should be expell'd the House, which was done; and, on a new Election for that County, Sir John Delavall was chosen in his stead.

The 16th, being the Day appointed for the Answer of the impeach'd Lords, they Petitioned for longer time, which was granted them, but only to the 19th; when they were brought to the Bar, where they all severally pleaded guilty to the Charge, except the Earl of Winton, who, upon his Petition, had Time given him till the 23d to put in his Answer.

The several Pleas of the impeach'd Lords, their Submission, their Application for Mercy, with their Speeches at the Bar, when they were brought up to hear and receive Judgment, toge∣ther with the Speech of the Lord Chancellor Cowper, Lord High Steward for the Day, when he pronounc'd the Sentence of Death against them, are made publick, and are too long for these Memoirs.

Upon the Lords having thus pleaded guilty, the House sent a Message the next Day, viz. the 20th, to the House of Commons, to acquaint them with it; upon which the whole House went the 23d in the Morning, with their Mace, and with their Speaker, and all their usual Attend∣ants, to the Bar of the House of Lords, to de∣mand Judgment against the said Lords.
In this Interval News came of the Pretender's being Landed in Scotland, and the King acquaint∣ed the House of it in the following Speech, viz.

P.HI: My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.Q: “I Had Reason to believe, when I spoke last to you, that the Pretender was Landed in Scot∣land; the Accounts I have received since do put it beyond all doubt, that he is Head∣ing the Rebellion there, and does assume the Style and Title of King of these Realms; his Adherents do likewise confidently affirm, that Assurances are given them of Support from Abroad. This Parliament hath on all Occasi∣ons expressed so much Duty to Me, and so true a Regard for the Religious and Civil Rights of my People, that, I am perswaded, this daring Presumption of our Enemies will heighten your just Indignation against them, and beget such farther Resolutions as, with the Blessing of God,” will enable me to defeat their Attempts.

P.HI: Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

P.Q:
“The most effectual Way to put a speedy End to these Troubles, will be to make such a Provision as may discourage any Foreign Power from assisting the Rebels; I do there∣fore hope, that every sincere Protestant and true Britain, will look upon the extraordinary Expence, which a timely Preparation may re∣quire, to be the best Husbandry; since it will in all humane Probability, prevent that Deso∣lation and those Calamities, which would un∣avoidably ensue, if the Rebellion should be
suffered to spread, and be supported by Popish” Forces from Abroad.

P.HI: My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.Q: “The World must be convinc'd by all you have already done, that you have nothing but the Honour and Interest of your Country at Heart; and for my own Part, I rely entirely upon you, and doubt not but you will take such Resolutions at this Juncture, as will be most for the present Safety, and future Ease of” my People.

DIV1.P: This we might be assured would rather quicken than delay the Fate of the Impeached Lords; they had indeed cast themselves upon the King's Cle∣mency, and receiv'd Sentence of Death; and great application was made to the King for their Par∣don, even the House of Lords were brought to take part in the intercession, which however the King did not think fit to grant, and it was thro' the Debates running so high upon that Subject, rather hasten'd the Fate of those, who it was en∣deavour'd to save.

The Question was for some time Debated, Whether it was in the King's Power to Reprieve or no in the Case of a Sentence upon an Im∣peachment. But this being carried in the Affir∣mative, the Grand Motion followed in the House of Lords, (viz.) That an Address be pre∣sented to his Majesty to grant a Reprieve to the Lords who lay in the Tower under Sentence of Death. There were long Debates upon this Sub∣ject, and the Terms of the Address took up some time; but that being agreed on, it was put to
the Vote, to be presented, or not presented, and carry'd TO BE presented by five Voices, and no more; accordingly it was presented the same Night, being the 22d of February; and the King gave an Answer, which evidently signified that his Majesty was not well pleas'd with these Pro∣ceedings, and by which the Lords concern'd might easily see what they were to expect. The King's Answer was: That on this and all other Oc∣casions, he would do what he thought most consistent with the Dignity of his Crown, and the Safety of his People.

The next Day, being the 23d, the Effect of this Resentment was more plainly seen, when the Orders were past in Council for Executing Three of the Condemned Lords, viz. the Earl of Derwentwater, Earl of Nithisdale, and the Vis∣count Kenmure, Reprieving the other Three till the 7th of March; The Dislike of these Proceed∣ings was farther seen in about four or five Days after; for the Order for Executing the Lords was not past in Council without some warm Words; and the Lord President, who had influenc'd the Vote in the House of Peers so much, fail'd not to offer the like at the Council-Board: But it ended in a different manner here, the whole storm of it falling upon the E. of Nott....m and his Family; for his Lordship was remov'd from his Post of Lord President of the Council, as was also his Son from being one of the Treasury; his Brother the Earl of Aylesford, was remov'd from being Chancellor of the Dutchy of Lancaster; and the Lord Guernsey, eldest Son to the Earl of Aylesford, from being Master of the Jewel-Office; as also Sir Roger Mostyn,, who marry'd the Earl of
Nottingham's Daughter, from being one of the Tellers of the Exchequer.

This, however, was not done till the Lords were Executed; that is to say, two of them; for the Earl of Nithisdale, happily for him, a∣voided the Blow, by getting out of the Tower in Disguise the very same Night, and within a very few Minutes after he had Notice, that he must die the next Morning.

According to this Order of Council, early the next Morning we saw the Scaffold on Tower-Hill surrounded with the Horse-Guards, Horse-Grenadiers, and a Detachment of Foot; and a little before Ten a Clock, the Earl of Derwent∣water, and the Lord Viscount Kenmure, were carried in a Hackney-Coach from the Tower to the Transport-Office on Tower-Hill, where there was a Room hung with Black for their Reception; and there was a Passage, or Gallery, rail'd in, which led from thence to the Scaffold, which was also cover'd with Black; and where, after a De∣cent time for their preparation, they were both Beheaded.

These two Lords being thus cut off, and the third fled, the Hand of Justice staid a while; the other Three were respited from time to time, and remain still in the Tower. The Earl of Nithisdale having escaped, an Advertisement of his Escape was publish'd in the Gazette, and a Reward of a Thousand Pounds offer'd to any one who should apprehend him; but there was soon after an Account from France, of his being safely landed there, and that he was seen at Paris.

The Course of Things now brings the Civil and Military Matters to join in History; for the
Pretender being gone, as has been related, the King came to the House on the 17th, of Feb∣ruary, and gave the Parliament an Account of it in the following Speech.

P.HI: My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.Q: “I Take this Opportunity of acquainting you, that my Forces have oblig'd the Pretender to fly out of Scotland; and he is since, as I am in∣formed, landed near Gravelines: But I don't yet know, whether any Country in Amity with us, will give him Protection, after having so” publickly invaded our Kingdom.

“The Dangers to which the Nation was ex∣posed, made me determine, that neither the extraordinary Rigour of the Season, nor any falacious Proposal of the Rebels, should divert me from using all possible Endeavours towards putting a speedy and Effectual End to this un∣natural” Rebellion.

P.HI: Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

P.Q: “I must return you my Thanks for the great Progress you have made in the Supplies. The necessary Dispositions are made for raising Ad∣ditional Forces: But as I shall always consult the Ease of my People, as far as it is consist∣ent with their own Security; I shall not make Use of the Confidence you have placed in me, unless the restless Malice of our Enemies should make it necessary to go on with those” Levies.

P.HI: My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.Q: “I promise my self, from the Zeal and Wis∣dom of this Parliament, that the future Hap∣piness and Tranquility of my Subjects will be establish'd on a solid Foundation; and such Measures taken, as may deprive our Enemies at Home of the Power, (since that alone can deprive them of the Inclination) again to at∣tempt the Disturbance of my Government. This therefore is what I think my self oblig'd to recommend to you, as a Deliberation of the utmost importance to the future Safety, Ease” and Prosperity of my People.

DIV1.P: Immediately upon this Speech, the Lords and Commons severally voted Addresses of Thanks and Congratulation, as usual: Both which, be∣ing in the usual Form, we leave out for want of Room, that we may not thrust out things of more Importance.

There was little remaining now to do, as to the Rebellion, except the punishing, and pur∣suing the Rebels; those who were fallen into their Hands, we shall soon see brought to Justice, by judicial Process; those who could not be ta∣ken, the King pursu'd to the utmost; at Home, by his Forces; Abroad, by his Influence.

The Judicial Proceedings went on all this while in the Inferior Courts, and a Commission of Oyer and Terminer was granted to Judges appointed for the Tryal of such of the Preston Prisoners as were confin'd in Lancaster and Chester Castles, of whom mention was made above.
The Judges appointed for this Work were, Mr. Baron Bury, Mr. Justice Eyre, and Mr. Baron Montague.

They set out for Liverpool with all their At∣tendants on the 4th of January, and arriv'd there the 11th, when the very next Day they opened their Commission, having first been at the Church, and heard a Sermon. In order to open their Sessions, the Grand Jury was sum∣mon'd; and the proper Informations having been laid before them, Bills of Indictment were found against 48 of the Prisoners by Name. It is to be Noted here, that there had been Com∣missioners formerly appointed to take Deposi∣tions with Relation to the Fact at Preston, and these Depositions were sufficient for the Infor∣mation of the Grand Jury, and to satisfy them in finding the Bills, tho' upon the Tryals the Witnesses were produced in Court, as is usual in such Cases.

The Bills being found, Copies of the Indict∣ment were deliver'd to the Persons, and the Court adjourn'd for 8 Days, viz. to the 20th of January, to give the Prisoners the legal Time to prepare for their Defence. In the mean time, other Prisoners had been order'd from Lancaster and Chester to Liverpool, and were arriv'd there, where Copies of the Indictments were also seve∣rally deliver'd to them, the Grand Jury having in that Interval found Bills again 113 more, where∣of 40 were Scots.
The Tryals begun with Englishmen, of whom, on the 20th, five were brought to Tryal, viz.

LIST.ITEM: Rich. Shuttleworth of Preston, a Papist.
Roger Moncaster of Garstang, an Attorney.

DIV1.P: The Proofs against these being very full and clear, they were all found guilty by the Jury, without much Debate among themselves.
The next Day, viz. the 21st, four more were Tryed, viz.
.... Walmsley of Sholey, near Preston, an At∣torney.

P.HI: Richard Chorley,

DIV1.P: .... Chorley .... his Son.
Drummond ...., near Relation to the Lord Drummond, who was in the Rebellion in Scot∣land; and was just then attainted by the House of Commons.

The three last were found guilty: Chorley the Elder rather behaving himself insolently, than making any Defence: But Mr..... Walmsley ob∣serving some hesitation in the Council concerning his being an Inhabitant with his Father in Pre∣ston, took hold of the Advantage it offer'd; and insisting on it, the Jury acquitted him. The same Day Sentence was pass'd upon the five Con∣demn'd the Day before.
The 23d, five more were Tryed, who were all Scots Men, viz.
These were likewise all found guilty; and the next Day, viz. the 24th, Nine more were Tried, being all Englishmen, viz.

The first Seven of these were found guilty; but the two last, viz. Henry Robowtham, and Ed. Sykes were acquitted; and the same Day the Court pass'd Sentence upon the eight who were con∣demn'd the two preceeding Days.
On the 25th, they proceeded to try seven Scots Men, who were all found guilty, viz.
On the 26th, they Tryed five more, some En∣glish, some Scots, viz.
James Blundell, Church-Warden of Standish.

ROW.CELL: These two took Arms with Mr. Townley of Townley, who was himself afterwards acquit∣ted at London.

DIV1.P: James Blakewood, a Dancing-Master of Edinb. Faile Ferguson.

The first four of these were found guilty, and the last, viz. Faile Ferguson, was acquitted; he prov'd not only that he was forced into the Rebellion, but that he was brought along un∣der a Guard, having refused to come; and also he proved, that he attempted several Times to desert, but was prevented, and was threaten'd to be hang'd, if he offer'd it again; and that they offer'd him a Lieutenat's Commission, but he refus'd it.

On the 27th, was Tryed Tom. Syddal, the Cob∣ler of Manchester, Captain of the Mobb there, when the Meeting-House was demolished, and with him five more, all Englishmen, but the two last, who were all found guilty, viz.
On the 1st of February was Tyed Seven Scots Men, six of whom were found guilty, viz.
On the 2d of February was Tryed five more, and the 3d one, and were all found guilty, viz.
On the 4th, were Tryed three more, who were found guilt, viz.
On the 7th were Tryed Kenneth Mackenzie, and John Kennedy, and were both found guilty.

There were now Threescore and Ten Tryed, whereof 66 were found guilty; some of whom had been executed, as we shall see presently: The rest began now to see that the Govern∣ment was in good Earnest with them; that they would proceed a far greater Length, if they did not make some speedy Application for Mer∣cy; that what had been suggested to them,
that the Government would not attempt a Pro∣cess against such a Number, was a mere Ficti∣on, and what had hitherto deluded them, and would continue to delude them, to their Ruin, if they continued obstinate: and being also gi∣ven to understand, that there might be some hope for Mercy, if sought for in a right Me∣thod and Temper. Upon these Circumstances, the rest of the Prisoners at Lancaster and Chester, or elsewhere, joined in an humble Petition to the Court, acknowledging themselves guilty, and begging Transportation; which the Court, as it is supposed, granted; for they put an End to the Proceedings thereupon, and on the 10th of Feb∣ruary set out for London.
Of the Prisoners condemn'd, the 22 follow∣ing, were Executed, at the following Times, and Places, viz.

ROW.CELL: The 28th of Jan. at Preston. Shuttleworth Head was set up upon a Pole on the Town-Hall in the Mar∣ket-Place at Preston.

DIV1.P: Richard Chorley, James Drummon, William Black, Donald Mackdonald, John Ord, Rorie Kennedy, John Robotham, February 9. at Preston.
James Blundell, James Finch, John Mac Gilli∣vrey, William Whealley, James Burne, February 10. at Wiggan.
Tho. Syddall, William Harris, Stephen Seager, Jos. Porter, John Finch, February 11. at Man∣chester.

It was in the next place in course to go to Work with the Preston Prisoners at London; there had for some time been a Dispute about Trying them in London, or whether they must be carried down into Lancashire to be Tryed, where the Fact was committed. But a Clause in an Act of Parliament regulated this, and a Commission of Oyer and Terminer was granted to Try them in London. Accordingly, on the 7th of April the Judges sat in the Common-Pleas Court at West∣minster, where Bills were found against some of them, and they were Arraigned, and had time given them to prepare for their Tryals. The Grand Jury of Surry at the same time found Bills against others of them, (viz.) such as were Prisoners in the Marshalsea.

In the interval between the Grand-Jury's find∣ing the Bills, and the Prisoners being brought to the Bar to be Arraign'd, Mr. Forster the Head of the Northumberland and Preston Army gave them the flip; for having obtain'd the Favour not to be Lodg'd in the Press-yard at Newgate, but in the Keeper's House, he put a Trick upon his Keeper's Man, by sending him down Stairs into the Cellar to draw Beer, and having fasten'd him down by the Stair-head Door, and having prepar'd a Counterfeit Key to the main Door, he let himself out, and then putting the Key in∣to the Door again on the outside, he double lock'd the Door, and left the Key in it; so that the Keeper Mr. Pitts, tho' he had presently dis∣cover'd it, could not get out to pursue him 'till it was too late: It was afterwards known that Mr. Forster had convey'd himself down to Leigh in Essex, where a Vessel lay ready for him, which
carry'd him to France, and Landed him so hap∣pily, that in 24 Hours he was a Prisoner in New∣gate, and a Freeman in Calais. There was a Proclamation immediately publish'd, with a Re∣ward of a Thousand Pound for Apprehending him, but he was out of their reach; this was the 14th of April.

Nor was this all, for a few Days after, and just the Evening before the Tryals were to begin, there had like to have been a general Goal-De∣liver at Newgate; for old Brigadier Mackintosh, who saw that Mr. Forster being gone, he was like to be the first Man to be made an Example of, broke out of Newgate; not by slight, as the other had done, but by meer Force, knocking down the Keepers, breaking thro' the Soldiers, and taking the Keys from the Turn-Key who kept the Door. This was done with such despe∣rate Courage, and he was so well Seconded by his Fellow-Prisoners, that above 30 of them got out of the Prison, into the Keeper's House, and about 17 of them, quite out of the Keepers Door.

The Old Brigadier got quite off, with 7 more, but the rest taking the wrong way in the Court, after they were out, and not able to find their way into the Street, were taken again. The Names of those who escaped were

The Government immediately published a Proclamation for apprehending them, promi∣sing a Thousand Pounds Reward for Mr. Mac∣kintosh,
and Five Hundred Pounds each for the rest; but in vain, except that Mr. Talbot was discovered in a House near Drury Lane, and retaken.

The Court was appointed to Sit that Day; but upon this Occasion it was put off to the 7th, when they began in Earnest with them: Fourteen more were arraigned, who also pleaded Not Guilty, and desired Time, as others had done, which was granted them. The first Man brought to Tryal, was Colonel Oxbourgh: This was the Gentleman who came out to General Carpenter from Preston, and offer'd to Capitulate, and at last agreed for them to Surrender; all which the Witnesses prov'd upon the Tryal: His Defence turn'd chiefly, (1.) Upon his not having acted but as a Mediator, to bring them to Sur∣render. And, (2.) upon the yielding at Dis∣cretion, being to be understood to be a Capitula∣tion for Life. But the Generals and Officers proving, that no Promises of Life were made; the Jury brought him in Guilty.

He was likewise told by the Court, that a Man being found among Rebels, any Way aid∣ing, abetting, comforting, &c. though he was not actually in Arms, or committed Hosti∣lities, yet it was Treason within the Law; and that the part of a Mediator, as it shew'd the Confidence the Rebels plac'd in him, so it was prov'd he Capitulated for himself, as well as the rest.

We set these things down more particularly in this Gentleman's Case; because this, of ha∣ving Capitulated, &c. and the Plea of being Forced into the Rebellion, was the Substance of what was pleaded by most of the rest, whose
Arguments we cannot pretend to repeat as they were pleaded, the Numbers being so great.
The next Day, being the 8th, the Court sat at the Marshalsea In Southwark, where Mr. James Hume was Try'd, and found Guilty.
Mr. John Farquarson was Try'd, and acquit∣ted.
On the 11th, Mr. Alex. Menzies was try'd, and pleaded very hard his being forc'd, as above, into the Rebellion; but he was found Guilty, after a very long Defence.
The same Day that Mr. Menzies was Try'd, Colonel Oxburgh was executed; he was the first that was singled out for an Example.
On the 12th five more were brought to Tryal, and pleaded Guilty; their Names were,
On the 15th, four others wery Try'd, and ac∣quitted,

Upon the acquitting the last two Men above∣to be clear'd, the common People offer'd divers Insults to the Court, and to the Juges; upon which the Judges caused two of the Principal to be laid hold of, and brought into Court, where they were fin'd, and imprison'd; one was a Tallow-Chandler at Lambeth, who was sin'd a Hundred Pound, and order'd to lie in Prison a Twelve Month: The other, a Looking-Glass-Maker on London-Bridge, who was fined Fifty Pounds, and likewise a Years Imprisonment; but the latter, upon his Submission and Acknow∣ledgment, was some Months afterwards excused.

Mr. Townley being acquitted, was immediate∣ly discharged; and going down to a Friend's House in Sussex, he was apprehended there again, though on no new Occasion, and brought up a∣gain; but the Government having no Charge upon him again, dismiss'd him.

The next Day, being the 16th, the Court sat at Westminster, where Thomas Hall of Otterburn, Esq in Northumberland, lately in Commission of the Peace; and Robert Talbot, Esq were Try'd, and found Guilty.
Soon after them, Mr. Gascoigne was Try'd; who made a very great Defence, and the Tryal took up some Time; they were at last all found Guilty.
On the 28th were Try'd at Westminster
Nicholas Wogan, Lancelot Macking tosh, Esqrs;
Charles Ratcliff, Brother to the Earl of Derwent∣water, and
Mr. John Blair.
The last retracted his forme Plea, and desir'd Leave to plead Guilty, which was granted; and the Three former were found Guilty by the Jury.

There were no more Tryals for some Days; the Courts being adjourn'd till after Whitsontide, the rest of the Prisoners Condemn'd, were all Re∣priev'd, except Mr. Gascoigne, who was executed the 25th at Tyburn.

The vigorous Prosecution and Punishment of these Men, alarm'd the Party, and gave Ground to expect a farther Course of judicial Proceed∣ings; as was also visible from the strict Enquiry into other Things and Persons: For Example, That of Committing Mr. Harvey of Comb to
Newgate, who had formerly been some Time in a Messenger's Hands; and of finding a Bill against the Dord Lansdown, and another against one Mr. Francia, a Jew.

In the mean Time, the Act empowring his Majesty to detain such People as he should suspect, &c. commonly call'd, suspending the Habeas Corpus Bill, drew near an End; and as the Court did not seem to desire its Continuance, those who had been detain'd, but without any Charge brought against them, began to hope for their Liberty, and to prepare to bring their Habeas Corpus.

On the 24th, the very Day that the Act ex∣pir'd, the Earl of Scarsdale, and the Lord Du∣plin, brought their Habeas Corpus, and were ad∣mitted to Bail before Mr. Baron Bury. On the 26th, the Lord Powis, commonly call'd Duke of Powis, did the same; as did also several private Gentlemen, both here and in Scotland.

On the 30th, the Court of Justice renew'd their Sitting at the Marshalsea in Southwarh; where John Dalton, and William Tonstall, Esqrs; were brought to the Bar; the last pleaded Guilty, and the first was Try'd, and found Guilty by the Jury,

The Month of July began with the Escape of two more of the Prisoners out of Newgate, viz, Angus Mackintosh, and James Mackquean; a third attempted the like, but was known, and stopt by the Centinels, who were posted at the Door of the Prison.
On the 4th, the Court of Justice sat again at Westminster, where
Richard Buttler, James Swinburn, Edward Swin∣burn, were Try'd, and found Guilty.
William Shafto, Basil Hamilton, James Robertson, retracted their former Pleas, and pleaded Guilty.
11th, James Dayell, James Ramsey, John Shaftoe, Pleaded Guilty.
14th, Duncan Mackintosh was Try'd, and found Guilty.
Edward Cassel,—Riddle, pleaded Guilty.
15th, William Paul a Clergyman pleaded Guilty.
George Gibson of Stonycroft, Esq James Men∣zies of Culdare, Try'd, and found Guilty.
16th, Ralph Standish of Standish, Esq Try'd, and found Guilty.
23d, William Mackintosh, Try'd, and Acquitted.
Andrew Pitcairn, Try'd, and found Guilty.
26th, Mr. Leybourn, Mr. Walton, Mr. Hutchen,—Hesketh,—Hesketh, Jun. all pleaded Guilty.
29th,—Thornton, pleaded Guilty.
James Cornwal was Try'd, and found Guilty; but recommended by the Jury to his Majesty's Mercy.
And Mr. James Menzies of Culdare, formerly mention'd, pleaded the King's Pardon.

Abundance of these Prisoners besides those al∣ready named, made their escape out of Newgate, and the Marshalsea, as out of the Prisons in Scot∣land, but as Mercy began now to take place, it was not look't upon as considerable, no more Proclamations were issued to apprehend them.

There was a general Order to set all those at Liberty in Scotland, without Bail, who surren∣der'd
according to Summons before the Rebel∣liou; as also all those, who, having been in the Rebellion, deserted from the Rebels before the Rebels were retreated from Perth; and after∣wards, for discharging all the Servants, who were Prisoners with their Masters in London.
Besides those mentioned before, who were admitted to Bail upon the expiring of the late Act, the following Persons, as well here as at Edinburgh, took the Benefit of the Habeas Corpus Act, viz.

LIST.HEAD: In England, Colonel Buttler, a near Relation to the Duke of Ormond.
LIST.ITEM: Mr. Murray, a Gentleman taken in Flanders with the Lord Clermont.

LIST.HEAD: In Scotland, The Earl of Wigtoun.
LIST.ITEM: Stewart of Garntully, And several others.

DIV1.P:
I come back now to the Proceedings in the Parliament, as well British as Irish; in the first of these the Earl of Winton took his Tryal, and after some small struggles was found Guilty by his Peers, and receiv'd Sentence of Death; but his Lordship sav'd his Friends the Trouble of
Soliciting for, and the Government of exerting their Mercy, by making his Escape out of the Tower; which however he was blam'd for, seeing it was said the Government enclin'd to have been very kind to him.

And now to end the Judicial part at once; the House went upon two Bills, which closed the Scene of Justice (viz.) one to attaint all the Per∣sons in the Rebellion, as well those taken, as those who were not taken; and the next was to cause all the Estates forfeited by the attainted Gentlemen, to be seiz'd for the use of the pub∣lick, and naming Commissioners for enquiring into their value, and disposing of them. Those Commissioners I shall have occasion to speak of hereafter pretty often; their Names are,

There was one great struggle yet in Parlia∣ment, after which Things began to draw to∣wards a Close; and this was the Proposal; To bring in a Bill to prolong the Time for the Sit∣ting of the Parliament. It was well known the Parliament could by Virtue of the Triennial Law subsist but three Years; but it was thought convenient for divers reasons of State, not to acquiesce in the Circumstances; and therefore a Bill was offered to continue the Parliament then Sitting to a farther Time, (viz.) for Seven Years.

This Bill was first brought into the House of Lords, where after long struggles, and two Pro∣tests it was pass'd in the Committee 96 against 61, and at last in the House by 69 against 36. In the House of Commons it was not so much con∣tended, where the Difference being at highest, was 284, against 162.

After this the Houses had little of Moment before them, except what they call winding up their bottom; that is to say, passing the Bills which were depending in the House, which be∣ing all brought to perfection by the latter end of June the King came to the House the 26th, and passing all their Bills, put an end to the Ses∣sion with the following Speech.

P.Q: “”My Lords and Gentlemen,

“I Cannot put an End to this Session, with∣out expressing to you my Satisfaction in the Proceedings of this Parliament. The wholsome and necessary Laws which have been passed with so much Steadiness, Resolu∣tion, and Unanimity, will (I trust in God) answer those good Ends, which, it is evident, you have had in View, by defeating the De∣signs, and reducing the Spirit of our Enemies; by encouraging our Friends, and raising the Credit and Reputation of the Nation Abroad to such a Degree, as that I may reasonably ex∣pect the Fruits of a settled Government, espe∣cially being supported by a Parliament, zealous for the Prosperity of their Country, and the” Protestant Interest of Europe.

“I am confident, my Conduct hitherto in suppressing the Rebellion, and punishing those
concern'd in it, has been such as demonstrates, that I desire rather to lessen their Numbers, by reclaiming them, than by making Examples; but I am sorry to find, that the numerous in∣stances of Mercy which I have shewn, have had no other Effect, than to encourage the Faction of the Pretender to renew their Insults upon my Authority, and the Laws of the Kingdom, and even to affect, with the greatest Insolence, to distinguish themselves from my good and faithful Subjects; acting with such Folly and Madness, as if they intended to con∣vince the World, that they are not to be re∣duced to Quiet and Submission to my Govern∣ment, by such gentle Methods as are most a∣greeable” to my own Inclinations.
“”Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

“I return you in particular, my Thanks for the Supplies you have given; which although they fall short of the Sums you found neces∣sary, and have Voted for the Service of the whole Year, yet by the Encouragement you have given to make them effectual, may, I hope, be so managed, as to carry on the cur∣rent” Service till another Session of Parliament.
“”My Lords and Gentlemen.

“I am very sensible, there are Matters of great Consequence still depending before you; but as they have hitherto been postpon'd, out of absolute Necessity, by intervening Affairs of a more pressing Nature, and of the most immediate Concern to the Peace and Safety of the Nation; I thought the Season of the Year requir'd I should defer your further Pro∣ceedings
till the next Session, rather than you should be retained out of your respective Coun∣tries longer than could be consistent with your” private Consent.
“”My Lords and Gentlemen.

“I am very sensible, there are Matters of great Consequence still depending before you; but as they have hitherto been post-pon'd, out of absolute Necessity, by intervening Affairs of a more pressing Nature, and of the most im∣mediate Concern to the Peace and Safety of the Nation; I thought the Season of the Year required I should defer your further Proceed∣ings till the next Session, rather than you should be detained out of your respective Coun∣tries longer than could be consistent with your” private Consent.

“I cannot doubt that, during this Recess, you will all use your best Endeavours to pre∣serve the Peace of the Kingdom, and to dis∣courage and suppress all manner of Disorders; since as the first Scene of the late Rebellion was open'd and usher'd in by Tumults and Riots; so you may be assured, upon what Pretence soever they are raised, they can have no other Tendency, but to support the Spirit of a Faction, restless and unwearied in their Endeavours to renew the Rebellion, and to subvert the Religion, Laws, and Liberties” of their Country.

“I design to make Use of the approaching Re∣cess to visit my Dominions in Germany, and to provide for the Peace and Security of the
Kingdom during my Absence, by constituting my Beloved Son, the Prince of Wales, Guar∣dian of the Realm, and my Lieutenant within” the same.

P.HI: The publick Bills pass'd on this Occasion were these as follow.

DIV1.P: An Act to continue the Duties for encoura∣ging the Coinage of Money, &c.
An Act for appointing Commissioners to en∣quire of the Estates of certain Traytors.
An Act for the continuing the Duty of Two Pennies Scots, or one sixth of a Peny Sterling, on every Scots Pint of Ale and Beer that shall be ven∣ded or sold within the City of Glasgow.
An Act to oblige Papists to register their Names and real Estates.

An Act for repealing so much of the Act of the Twelfth and Thirteenth Years of the Reign of King William the Third, as enacts, That no Per∣son, who shall come to the Possession of the Crown, shall go out of the Dominions of England, Scotland, or Ireland, without Consent of Parliament.
An Act for the more effectual securing the Peace of the Highlands in Scotland.
An Act to prevent the Mischiefs by manufactu∣ring Leaves, or other things, to resemble To∣bacco, and the Abuses in making and mixing of Snuff.
An Act for the more effectual and exemplary Punishment of such Persons as shall seduce Soldiers to desert, or who, being Papists, shall inlist themselves in his Majesty's Service.
An Act for holding the Assizes for the County of Cornwall, at a convenient Place within the said County.

An Act to encourage and preserve the planting of Timber Trees, Fruit Trees, and other Trees for Ornament, Shelter, or Profit, and for the better Preservation of the same; and for the preventing the burning of Woods.
An Act for the Attainder of Thomas Forster, Jun. Esq and William Mackintosh, Esq
An Act to disable any Person from being chose a Member of, or from Sitting and Voting in the House of Commons, who has any Pension for any Number of Years from the Crown.
An Act for making the Laws for repairing the Highways more effectual.
An Act for the better regulating Hackney Coaches, Carts, &c. and for preventing Mischiefs occasion'd by the Drivers riding upon Drays, Carrs, &c.
An Act to revive and continue a former Act for Repairing of Burlington Peers,
An Act for the more effectual reversing and making void the Attainder of Charles, Earl of Macclesfield, deceased.
An Act to discharge Sir Alexander Rigby Knt. from his Imprisonment, and vest his Estate and Effects in Trustees, for the Benefit of his Cre∣ditors.

An Act for vesting certain Lands and Tene∣ments of Peter Sunderland, Esq in Trustes, to be sold for Payment of Debts charged thereon be∣fore the making of his Marriage Settlement, and by Virtue thereof.

An Act to enable Thomas Proctor of Rock, in the County of Northumberland, Esq to raise the Sum of Four Thousand Pounds out of his Estate, for Payment of his Debts, and making Provision for his younger Children.
An Act for Naturalizing Erengard Melosine, Ba∣roness of Schulenburg.
After this the Lord Chancellor by the King's Command, Adjourn'd the House to the 7th of August, next following.

As to the Parliament of Ireland, they went on as before, proceeding with great rigor against the Miscarriages of the former reign, bringing their own Members (especially) to Submissions and Censures, and also several others.

I have given some account of their Resent∣ment against those who Address'd in favour of Sir Constantine Phipps, and who advis'd the Queen to prorogue the Parliament. Now they fell on the Affair of choosing Officers for the City of Dublin; in which Case, the Judges, their whole Court, and all the City Magistrates came under Censure of Parliament on that account.

First they Resolv'd, That soon after the Ar∣rival of Sir Constantine Phipps, late Lord Chan∣cellar, viz. in the Year 1710. a Design was form'd, and carry'd on, to subvert the Consti∣tution, and Freedom of Elections of Magistrates of Corporations, in order to procure Persons to be return'd for Members of Parliament, disaf∣fected to the Settlement of the Crown on his Majesty, and his Royal Issue: and that, in pur∣suance of that Design, indirect and illegal Me∣thods were taken to subvert the ancient and legal Course of electing Magistrate in the City of Dublin.

That, in pursuance of that Design, they pro∣cured, in less than five Months, in the Year 1711.
six Aldermen duly elected Lord Mayor, and four∣teen substantial Citizens duly elected Sheriffs, to be disapprov'd, on pretence that the senior Al∣derman ought to be elected.
That the said senior Alderman had no Right to be elected, either by Charter, Usage, or any By-Law in force in the said City.
That in the Year 1713, they set up a pretended Custom or Usage, for the Mayor in being to no∣minate three Persons, one of whom the Aldermen were obliged to chuse for Lord Mayor.
That the Lords Justices and Council, by their Resolution of the 4th of September, 1713. con∣firm'd, and encourag'd that pretended Custom as Legal.

That the Citizens of Dublin are in no sort li∣mited in their Choice, as is pretended by the said Custom; but that the Right of nominating the three Persons to be put in Election for Lord Mayor, is in the Lord Mayor and Aldermen of the City.

Upon these Resolutions, the House censur'd Sir Samuel Cook, then Lord Mayor of Dublin, for holding over, as it was call'd; that is, exercising the Office after his Year was expir'd, till another was chose and approved; and the Aldermen, Constantine, Mason, Town, and French, for join∣ing with him; these last they voted Enemies to the Constitution, and the Protestant Successi∣on, Betrayers of the Liberties of the City, and Friends to Popery and the Pretender.
They likewise censur'd,
Sir Richard Cox, Lord Chief Justice of the Queen's Bench.
Robert Doyne, Esq Lord Chief Justice of the Common Pleas.
Robert Rochford, Esq Lord Chief Baron.
Thomas Coote, Esq Richard Nutley, Esq Judges of the Queen's Bench.
Robert Johnson, Esq Sir Henry Eclin, Barons of the Exchequer.
Anthony Upton, Esq Judge of the Common Pleas.

These Judges were censur'd for signing a Re∣port, in Answer to Doubts stated by the Attor∣ney General in England, and confirming the holding over of the Mayors of Dublin, as the Custom and Usage of the City; and this with∣out summoning or hearing the Aldermen of the said City: For which they were declared seve∣rally to have acted partially and corruptly; that they are guilty of high Crimes and Misdemean∣ours; and that they should be Impeached for the same.

Then they Resolved, that the Twenty Alder∣men, and two Sheriffs, who opposed these ille∣gal Practices, did great Service to the Protestant Interest of Ireland, and to the Succession of the Crown; and order'd the Thanks of the House to such of them as were then living.

They farther censur'd Judge Nutley, for being a principal Manager of that Case, drawing up the Report, signing it, and solliciting a Matter, wherein he was a Judge; in which they decla∣red, he had violated his Oath, prostituted the Character of a Judge, and acted partially and corruptly.

Besides this, they Examin'd into the Case of the Corporation of Youghall, a Case too tedious for so short a Work as this: here they charged Sir Constantine Phipps with Illegal Practises, but he was out of their reach; and thus having suffici∣ently
shewn as well their Anger as their Power, and having pass'd all the Bills before them, they came to a Close also, the Lords Justices having Prorogued them the 25th of June, to the 25th of August following.
The Lords Justices Speech on this Occasion, was as follows.

P.HI: My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.Q: “THOUGH the Sessions has, by many unavoidable Accidents been protracted to an unusual Length, you cannot but think your Time well imployed, having reaped the Advantages of the many good Laws his Ma∣jesty has been pleased to give you; in which Number the Act for making the Militia more useful, is a singular Instance of the great Con∣fidence his Majesty Places in the Fidelity and good Affection of his loyal Subjects of Ire∣land, and will greatly contribute to the Secu∣rity of the Protestant Interest of this King∣dom.”

P.HI: Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

P.Q: “We are commanded by his Majesty, to re∣turn you Thanks for the Supplies you have so chearfully granted for his Service, and your own Defence; which, we assure you, will be ap∣plied with the utmost Frugality to the Purpo∣ses” for which they were given.

“We must likewise thankfully acknowledge the several Marks of Confidence you have pla∣ced in us; more particularly, your seasonable and unprecedented Vote of Credit, which will
remain a memorable Proof of your unbounded Zeal for his Majesty's Service; and an Obliga∣tion upon us, to continue our best Endeavours” for your Prosperity.

P.HI: My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.Q: “The Season of the Year is now far advanced, and it is time you should return to your seve∣ral Countries; where you will take Care, in your respective Stations, to see the Laws duly put in Execution, for the Support of our ex∣cellent Constitution both in Church and State. We shall recommend to you, the Continuance of that Unanimity and Resolution, which have hitherto preserved you in perfect Tranquility, and will best enable you to defeat the futre De∣signs” of your open and secret Enemies.

“It is a great Pleasure to us, to see this Ses∣sion conclude as it began, with all possible Marks of Loyalty and good Affection to his Majesty; and as we have constantly represented the Merit of so good a People in a just Light, to the best of Princes; so we have his Majesty's Commands, to assure you of his perfect Satis∣faction” in your dutiful Behaviour.

DIV1.P:
At the End of this Year it was that the Duke of Argyle fell under the Royal Displeasure, and was remov'd from all his great Offices and Employments, which were indeed very great ones; for he was at the same time General and Commander in Chief of all his Majesties Forces in Scotland, Lord Lieutenant of the Shire of Dunbarton in Scotland, and of Surrey in England, Colonel of the Royal Regiment of Horse, Go∣vernor
of Port Mahone, and of the Island of Mi∣norca, Knight of the Garter, one of the Privy Council, and first Lord of the Bedchamber to the Prince; enjoying besides all these, a Pension of 2000 l. per Ann, from the King; of all which, except Knight of the Garter, he was dispossess'd at once; the Reasons and Occasion is not my business to enquire, being not matter of History at this time.

The King was now preparing for his Jour∣ney or Voyage to Hanover; in order to which the Bill above-mention'd had been pass'd, and of which his Majesty had made mention in his Speech: Preparatory to this Voyage, a Patent pass'd the Seal, Creating the Prince of Wales Guardian of the Kingdom, and his Majesties Lieu∣tenant in the same.

It was on the 7th of July that the King set forward, and going by Barge to Gravesend, his Majesty embark'd there on Board a Yacht, a Squadron of Men of War lying at the Buoy on the Nore ready to join; and on the 9th the King Landed in Holland, at the Brill; from whence he went on Board one of the States Yachts to Utrecht, where he took Coach, and arriv'd at Hanover the 12th.

As soon as the News of the King's arriving in Holland came to Court, the Regent open'd his Commission. One of the first things which oc∣curr'd in this new Administration, was indeed very surprizing for a time, viz. that on the 8th, a dead Warrant was sign'd for executing 24 of the State Prisoners, who lay then under Sentence, but had most of them been repriev'd by the King; the Time of their Execution was ap∣pointed for the Friday after, when, it seems,
their former Reprieves expir'd; whether it was matter of Form, and that it was necessary to proceed in that manner, or whether it was in order to alarm the Prisoners, who, some said, began to behave as if they were secure, we know not; but the Surprize lasted no longer than the Thursday after, when a Reprieve came down for Twenty two of them; the other Two, being Mr. Paul the Clergyman, and Mr. Hall, for∣merly a Justice of Peace near Otterburn in Nor∣thumberland, were appointed to be put to Death.

Accordingly, on the 13th, at the usual time, they were brought to the Place of Execution, where, after reading their Papers to the People, they deliver'd them to the Sheriff, and desir'd they might be printed: signifying at the same Time, that they had given out Copies, which if the Sheriff declin'd to Print, the other would nevertheless be made publick: The She∣riff answer'd, he should lay their Request and their Papers also before the Secretaries of State, and Act as he should be directed. After which, they were executed according to their Sentence.
And thus I conclude the Second Year of this brief History.

DIV2.HEAD: Anno 1717.
DIV2.P: THIS Year the Scene alters, and the Face of Affairs is chang'd; as the last Year's began with Tumults and Riot, Dissaffection, and even Re∣bellion: This begins with Tri∣umph and Satisfaction; the King's Affairs establish themselves upon the Ruin of the Insurrection and Distractions of the last Year, his Arms being every where victorious; and many of the most considerable of the disaffected being fallen into his Hands, His Majesty has more Exercise now for the Sword of his Justice, than the Sword of War, and for his Clemency, than his An∣ger.

Not but that even in this Year there were some Remains seen of the Spirit of Dissatisfaction; the People were conquer'd, who had been in Arms, and the rest were taught by Experience, that
the King was not to be attack'd that way; yet it was impossible so entirely to check the great Dissaf∣fection which had been spread among the People, as that no Remains of it should appear; but this must be added, that whenever any such Excursions were made, it always ended to the Disadvantage of those that were concern'd. I shall give a brief Account of several Attempts to disturb the Peace, which happen'd about this Time; but to enter in∣to a long Detail of the manner how every little Fray of this Sort was began and ended, that I hope will not be expected, except of those volu∣minous Writers, who want Matter to fill up their yearly Labours, which at present is not my Case.

The King, as has been observ'd, at the Conclu∣sion of the last Year was Abroad; the Government was left in the Hands of the Prince, as sole Re∣gent; but acting by the Agency of the old Privy Council: The People had particularly, for some Time past, apply'd themselves on every Rejoicing-Day, of which we are now pretty full, to Street-Quarrels, Mobs, Riots and Tumults, in a very un∣accountable Manner, and such as even tended to a new Insurrection.

The first of these had been at Cambridge on the 28th of May last, which was the King's Birth-Day, and the 29th of May, which was the Anniversary of the Restoration; the Case was heard judicially, and both sides were censur'd, as indeed both de∣serv'd; but this gave great Offence to some People, whether it was, that they expected no Body should be allow'd to be tumultuous but themselves, or that they thought the Subject, viz. the King's Birth-Day gave them a Loose to be disorderly, that I do not determine; but the Judicature of the Univer∣sity condemn'd the Parties on both sides to be sus∣pended
for a Year, and if they offended a second time, to be expell'd.

This fell hard upon some of the Members of Clare-Hall, where Fame says the Fray began, but who it seems thought, that being on the right Side, the Superiors durst not censure them; in which they found themselves mistaken.

But the next Rabble was not so easily suppress'd, nor so cheaply answer'd for; the Whigs (in London especially) had set up their several Rendezvous, for Rabbling, in Places proper for their Turn, as if they had been a stated Garrison for the City, kept up to preserve the Places, and that these were the several Head Quarters: These they call Mug-Houses, Things which however the People might mean well to the Government, and the Government might at first encourage them, or at least wink at them; yet their Method appearing to be, in the very Nature of it, inconsistent with the Publick Peace, and the good Order which every civil Government is ob∣lig'd to maintain, and several Irregularities and Breaches of the Peace having happened, in Con∣sequence of their mistaken Loyalty, to say no more of them; the Government has since thought it con∣venient, not to take it ill that they drop and decay of themselves.

One of these Mug-Houses being set up in ¦ry-Court in Fleet-Street, there was. It Publick House before, not far off where the Party used to assemble; and I will not that many disorderly Things might be done in of these Houses, and perhaps more to insult and provoke one another, and yet it might not he with Design to produce the bloody Effects that followed but both will, without Question, shew the Consequences of any thing done in the way of
Riot and Tumults, let it be for what Cause or Par∣ty it will.

On the 25th of July, the Friends of the Tory-House assembled in the Street, resenting some Inju∣ry done to the House they used to assemble at for some Days; the Whig-House had been Aggressors, but be that as it will, these certainly went beyond their Bounds, threatning and insulting the Whig-House the first Day: However, they were beaten off, and so they laid aside their Enterprise for that Night: But came early the next Morning, reinfor∣ced by Detachments from all Parts, for Rabbling was at this time come to a very great Height. There were some Scuffles first in the Streets, and the Tory-House, of which mention is made, had its Sign broken and defaced, the Windows demolish'd, and the like; but the Rabble increasing, the Mug-House People were forced to retreat; in this Part of the Fray, one Read, the Master of the Mug-House, with a Firelock in his Hand, advancing to the Head of his Men, fir'd, and shot one Daniel Vaughan, for∣merly a Bridewell Servant, through the Body, of which he fell Dead upon the Spot; but the Rabble, rather enrag'd than dispirited by it, carried on their Attack with the more Fury, and by downright Force enter'd the House, plundered all below Stairs, de∣stroy'd the Drink in the Cellar, and every thing they could break or spoil; but they were repuls'd in their Attempt to force their way up Stairs, by some People who had barricaded the Head of the Stairs, and defended them obstinately. In the mean time, notice being sent to Whitehall, a Detachment of the Guards came immediately to the Place, and, tho' not without some Difficulty, the Rabble was disper∣sed; the People separated, and Seven or Eight of them being taken in the very act of assaulting the House, were carried to Prison.

As I profess the Office here of a Historian only, I shall not enter into the Reflections on either Side in this Affair, but only relate, that this being an extra∣ordinary Case, and the King being abroad, it made the Government resolve to shew their Resentment in a Severity that might be a Warning and Example to others. Accordingly five Persons taken in this hurly burly, were forthwith brought to Tryal at the Old-Baily, and being all convicted, they were Executed at the Corner or End of the Street where the Fray happen'd.

They were all Youths of ordinary Circumstances, mean, despicable, and would hardly have all suf∣fer'd, but that the unhappy Circumstance of the Time made it necessary: Their Names were as fol∣lows, (viz.) Thomas Bean, George Purchase, John Love, Richard Price and William Price: There was one Daniel Delander, a Watch-maker, Try'd and found Guilty of being a Party in the same Riot, but Mercy interposed, the Publick Justice being sa∣tisfied with the Executions above.

The Rebellion being now at an End, and the prin∣cipal Persons that the Government had their Eyes upon, being Executed, or under Sentence of Death, the Government had little before them for some Time, but to receive the Congratulations of the Subjects in Addresses, which came from all Parts; and the Government in Return exercised some Acts of Clemency, particularly the releasing out of Prison all the Servants who were in Custody, as being Per∣sons supposed to be led into the Snare by the Com∣mands of their Masters, or at least in Consequence of their particular Services, and consequently not altogether so Guilty as their Masters; these were a∣bout forty in number, (viz.) eleven out of Newgate,
twelve out of the Fleet, and seventeen out of the Marshalsea.

With these Acts of Clemency, however, the Ju∣dicial Proceedings went on in their Course, and the most remarkable Tryal was that of Mr. Pitts the Keeper of Newgate, who was Indicted for High-Treason, and Try'd on the same at the Old-Baily, the Charge being for wilfully suffering the Prisoners under his keeping to Escape, (viz.) Mr. Foster, Mac-Intosh, and others, but after a long Tryal, and a full hearing on all Sides, the Jury brought in their Verdict NOT GUILTY: So he was immediately Discharg'd, and returned to his Post, where he still remains.

Abundance of Printers, Publishers and Hawkers, came under Cognisance, for printing and publishing scandalous Lampoons, Satyrs, Libels, &c. But neither their Names or Crimes are so remarkable, as to require their being nam'd here, except one Mr. Redmayne, a Printer, whose Case being very particular, will come to be spoken of again on other Accounts of the like Nature.

It was within a little matter of raising another Tumult, that the Friends of Tho. Bean, one of the Five who were thus Executed, had the Imprudence, to call it no worse, to make a pompous and popular Funeral for him; having six young Maids to bear up the Pall, with white Scarfs and Favours, and six young Men to lead them. Nor was this all, but the next Sabbath-Day, the same Twelve came in Cou∣ples to St. Bride's Church, with their Scarfs and Favours, which drew a great Crowd together, and that had ended in more Disorders, the Mob be∣ginning to reflect upon the Barbarity, as they call'd it, of the Execution: But the Train'd Bands
of the City, a Company whereof were posted in Salisbury-Court, fell lustily upon the Rabble, and the young Men and Maids, tho' being with what speed they could gotten as far as Black Friars Stairs to take Water, were overtaken by a Party of Sol∣diers sent after them, who apprehended Five of them, but the rest escaped; these were afterwards Tried at the Old-Baily, and being found Guilty, were fin'd 20 Marks each, but with an Intimation, that the Court inclined to remit or abate their Fines, if they would acknowledge their Crime, and discover ingeniously who set them on Work; but they all stood out, and lay in Newgate till some of their Friends gather'd Money enough for them to pay their Fine.

And now in prosecuting the Prisoners taken in the Rebellion, it came in Course to consider what should be done with those in the North, where the Prisons were full of them, and where none had been yet Try'd, much less Executed, those in Lancashire ex∣cepted.

Of the Number I now speak, all the meaner Sort had been Discharg'd, as particularly 353 which were at Glasgow, and 160 out of the Prisons at Edinburgh had been all let go, but the Gentlemen and Leading Men which were in Custody required to be farther consider'd.

After some Time, and several long Debates, it was Resolv'd thus: 1. That the Prisoners in the se∣veral Prisons of Lancaster and Chester-Castle, espe∣cially such as had declined Transportation, as seve∣ral of them had, should now be Tried in the ordi∣nary Courts of Justice at the Assizes in Lancashire; and as for the Prisoners in Scotland, they should be all brought to Carlisle, and be Try'd there by a spe∣cial Commission granted for that purpose.
According to the first Resolution, the Summer Assizes being now at hand, the Prisoners in Chester-Castle were carried to Lancaster, where several of them were Try'd as follows, (viz.)
Mr. Shuttleworth of Alston, Mr. John Swarbreck of Wesham, Richard Hodgson of Walton, William Charnley of Walton; convicted upon Tryal.
John Winkley of Alston, Thomas Park of Croston, Henry Winkley of Alston, Captain John Bruce of Preston, Laurence Coop of Walton; withdrew their Pleas, and pleaded Guilty.
Robert Walker of Forton, Mr. John Daniel Dur∣ton. John Wareing of Aighton, Richard Singleton of Kirkham, acquitted upon Tryal.
George Coop and Richard Abbot were also clear∣ed by the Jury, though there seem'd plain Proof enough against them
Lawrence Thrope of Fishwick, Hugh Barton of Claughton, Richard Walmsley of Walton, were ac∣quitted for want of due Proof.
William esketh of Maines, Esq William Ward of Manchester, Rioter, Edward Burrow of Weeton, were respited till next Assizes.

By the Temper of the Jury, which appear'd in the Tryal of the first five, the Judges plainly per∣ceiv'd the Case was quite alter'd in that Country, and that this manner of proceeding would not do by any means; and in short, that if the Tryals were to go on, the whole Number would be acquitted, let the Evidence be as it would I say, the Judges seeing this, thought fit to put an End to the Proceedings, and break up the Assizes.

Of the condemn'd Persons, five were Executed the 2d of October; viz. three at Lancaster, and two at Preston; their Names were, Captain Bruce,
Tho. Shuttleworth, John Winkley, William Charnley, and Richard Hodgson.

This Captain Bruce was a Scotsman, had for∣merly been a Steward or Rent-gatherer to Duke Ha∣milton, but was on some private Breach with that Family, turn'd out of the Duke's Business, and liv'd at Preston; where, when the Rebels took Possession of that Town, he openly declar'd himself, and took Arms with them.
This Part being over, the rest of the Prisoners were remanded for the present, and most of them lay in Custody till released by the General Pardon, which came out some Months after this.

It comes next in order to mention what was done with the Prisoners in Scotland, which in particular occasion'd some warm Debates, some alledging, that they ought not to be removed, but that by the Treaty of Union, which reserved all the Scots Judi∣catures entire, they ought to be Try'd in Scotland: Likewise some of the Prisoners insisted, and shewed great Reluctance at their being ordered to remove.

However, positive Orders being sent to General Carpenter, who then commanded in Chief in Scot∣land, he gave them Notice to prepare, and tho' in Civility he gave them all the Time he could, and particularly he gave them time to send up their Peti∣tion or Representation to the King and Council, yet upon the Return of the Express, and their Re∣quest not being granted, he was obliged to remove them, and accordingly the 2d and 3d of September they set forward, with this Exception however, that he suffered some to remain behind, who were Di∣stemper'd and unfit to Travel, as particularly Dr. Gairns, Dr. Carmichael, and one Mr. Ogilvy.

The Names of the Prisoners that went, are in∣deed necessary to be known, and are as follows, (viz.)
In Edinburgh Castle.
Marquis of Huntley
Viscount of Strathallan
Lord Rollo
Mr. Carstairs of Kinnocder
Thomas Caddell
Gorden of Glenbucket
Brigadier Campbell of Ormondel
Colonel Ʋrquhart
M' Kenzie of Frazerdale
Fra. Stewart, Brother to the E. of Murray
Col. Balfour of Fairnie
Major Balfour of Danbogie
Tho. Drummond, Brother to the Ld. Strathallan
Murray of Auchtintyre younger
Drummond of Logiealmond
Burnet of Mountbody
Jo. Gordon of Aboyn, Uncle to the Earl of Aboyn
William Hay
Gairns of Layton
Ross, Son to the Bishop of Edinburgh
Smith of Methuen
In all 22.

LIST.HEAD: Prisoners in Edinburgh Tolbooth.
LIST.ITEM: Geo. Robinson, Gauger of Excise in Brunt-Island

ROW.CELL: Escaped since the Order for Removal

DIV2.P: In all 12.

LIST.ITEM: Skeliter Forbes, Bailie to the E. of Marr, alias Black Jockie
William Ogilvie, Chamberlain to the E. of Erroll

DIV2.P: In all 11.

LIST.HEAD: Prisoners in the Earl of Winton's Lodging.
LIST.ITEM: Maul, Factor to the Earl of Panmure

DIV2.P: In all 11.
These are excepted, as not having been in the List for Tryals; but are to take their Tryals in Scotland.

LIST.HEAD: In the Castle of Stirling.
LIST.ITEM: Mr. Robt. Murray, Brother to Abercairnie
Patrick Gordon, eldest Son to Abberdowre
Dr. John Killock, Dr. of Medicine.
Alex. Smith, of the House of Mac-Intosh
Dr. Alex. Gordon, Dr. of Medicine

LIST.ITEM: Tho. Robertson in Baltroon; all these taken at the Battle of Dumblain.
Pat. Robertson of Dungarthie; These three were taken passing the Forth with Briga∣dier Mackintosh.
James Carnegie of Balnamoon taken in Arms.

DIV2.P: In all 13.
In all 89.

The Guards which conducted them were, Mon∣tague's Regiment of Foot, and General Carpenter's own Regiment of Dragoons; and thus being on their Journey, we shall leave them for a Time, till we hear of them afterwards in a Judicial Way at
Carlisle, whither a Commission of Oyer and Termi∣ner being sent for their Trial, the proper Officers prepar'd to go down thither, to hold a Court of Justice for that Purpose; and abundance of People, as well Highlanders as others, were order'd from the Savoy, where they had been kept together some Time, to go down to Carlisle under a Guard, to give Evidence in the Trials appointed there.

Besides the three sick Gentlemen, there were left behind, the Lord Viscount Strathallan, and the Lord Rollo, as Peers, and Marquess of Huntley, Son to the Duke of Gordon, claim'd to be left behind; but it was referr'd to the Lord Advocate, and other Lawyers, who gave it against him; so he set for∣ward with the rest, but was by an Express from London, which met them on the Road, allowed to go back to the Castle, from whence he was some Time after released, by a particular Pardon to him∣self, under the Great Seal.

Some others also prevented their Fate, by break∣ing Prison at Edinburgh, a few Days before, as par∣ticularly Sir David Thripland's Son, Mr.—Wilson, a Mathematician, with two Servants also;—Bethune of Balfour, Son in-Law to General Hamilton,—Menzies of Pitfodels, Mr. Hut∣chins, Provost of Aborbrothick.

As the Prisoners arrived at Carlisle the 12th of September, the Judges appointed to try them ar∣rived there the first of December following. An Account of their Proceedings I shall take in its Course.

I come now to another kind of civil War, which employ'd the Pens, as the former had done the Swords of the Parties, and which has indeed run a farther length than a thing of that Nature could have been expected: This civil War began chiefly
among the Ecclesiasticks, tho' it proceeded to em∣bark the Government, and a great many private Per∣sons afterwards in the Quarrel: It consisted of two Parts; tho' I must acknowledge it to be in the main but one and the same Quarrel: The First was the Charge of Schism cast upon, or brought against all the Clergy of the Church of England, on Account of their breaking off from the Nonjuring Church, which it was insisted, was the only rightful Church of England.

This Contest was began and stated in a clear Draught, in Form of a Constitution, by that very learned Person Doctor Hicks, a Person eminent for Learning, exemplar for Life, and saving this par∣ticular Affair, an unexceptionable Man, even among his Enemies.
