He had in his Life-time published these Constitu∣tions, and this will bring, as I said before, the Story of Mr. Redmayne, the Printer, on the Stage again, for one Mr. Howell, a Clergyman, and also a Non∣juror, had written a Book, Entituled, The Case of Schism in the Church of England considered; he had not only written, but had printed it at Mr. Redmayne's Printing-House, in Jewen-Street; where the Govern∣ment having Information of it, some of them were seized: The Messenger having likewise a Warrant to apprehend Mr. Howell, he was also taken up, and his Papers seized.

Among his Papers were also found his Letters of Ordination, being an Original Instrument; by which it appears, that he received Priest's Orders, with Institution, &c. at the Hands of the late Dr.Hicks; who, as appears by those Instruments, stiled himself Suffragan Bishop of Thetford. There was also a Form of Absolution, and Reception of
Converts and Penitents, returning from the sup∣posed Schism, as on their being receiv'd into the Nonjurors Church.

But while the Town was amused with this bold Attempt of Mr. Howell's, one of the King's Mes∣sengers being in quest of some other Pamphlet, and searching the House of the said Mr. Redmayne the Printer, in Jewin-Street, happen'd upon another thing of ten Thousand times the Consequence of this of Mr. Howell's, and of which Mr. Howell seem'd to be only a Deducter or Abridger. This was the Book containing the Constitution mentioned above, and said to be written by the said Dr. Hicks. The Messenger found but one Copy, the rest of the Impression being conveyed away before he came; however, this one Book was sufficient to discover to the Government that such a Thing was on Foot, and had been published; and was sufficient also to bring the Printer upon the Stage, in order to a far∣ther Enquiry into the Particulars: The Book is en∣tituled, The Constitution of the Catholick Church, and the Nature and Consequences of Schism, set forth in a Collection of Papers written by the R. Re∣verend George Hicks, D. D.

The Contents of these Books are too long to be brought into a Collection of Facts; and as these make no Part of History, I refer the Reader to the Books themselves: But as to the Ordination of Mr. Howell, by the said Dr. Hicks, it is so far Mar∣ter of History, and cannot be omitted, as what may also be of use on other Occasions.
The Letters of Ordination, as produced in Court, upon his Trial both in Latin and English, are as follows, viz.

P.HI: TEnore praesentium nos Georgius Hickes, per∣missione divinâ, Episcopus Suffraganeus Thet-Jordiensis, notum facimus universis, quod nos prae∣fatus Episcopus in Oraterio nostro, in Parcohiâ Sancti Andreae Holburn in Comittu Middlesex: Sacros Ordines Presidio Divino celebrantes, Dile∣ctum nobis in Christo Laurentium Howell, A. M∣de vitae suae Probitate, morumque Integritats nobis sufficienti Testimonio commendatum, & sacrarum Literarum cognitione, & scientiâ laudabiliter in∣stitutum, & per nostrum Examinatorem nobis appro∣batum, ad Sacrum Presbyteratús ordinem, juxta morem & consurtudinem Ecclesiae Anglicanae in hac parte salubriter editam, & provisam, admisimus & promovimus; ipsamque instituimus & rdinavimus tunc & ibidem. In cujas rei Testimoni Syillum nostrum Episcopale praesentibus apponi sim se∣cundo die Measis Octbs mille∣simo septingentosimo duodecimo, nstrae Consecra∣tionis XVIII.

P.Q:
BY the Tenour of these Presents, We George Hickes, by Divine Permission, Surfragan Bishop of Thetford, make known to all Men; that our Beloved in Christ, Lawrence Howell, Master of Arts, being recommended to us by sufficient Testimonials of his Probity of Life, and Intregrity of Manners, laudably qualified by his Knowledge in the Sacred Writings, and by his Learning, and approved by our Examiner; We the said Bishop, administring the holy Offices in our Oratory in the Parh of St. Andrew Holbourn, in the County of Middlece have admitted and promoted him to the holy Order of the Priest∣hood,
and then and there have instituted and or∣dained him, according to the Manner and Custom of the Church of England, in this behalf whol∣somely appointed and provided. In witness where∣of we have caused our Episcopal Seal to be af∣fix'd to these Presents, the 2d of October, in the Year of our Lord 1712. and in the 18th of our Consecration.

DIV2.P: Sealed on a Label with hard red Wax, the Seal representing a Shepherd with a Sheep upon his Shoulders, and a Crook in his Hand, with this Mot∣to, The good Shepherd.

There were several other Papers taken at the same Time, and several other Things contained in these; as in particular, a Form or Office for Absolution of a Penitent, as they call'd them, or one returning from the Scism, that is to say, from the Church of England Establisht, to the Jacobite Church; which Office they add to the Liturgy of the Church.

Upon the whole, the Government thought it abso∣lutely necessary to prosecute these Things with Se∣verity, and accordingly Mr. Howell was Tried for his Part at the Old-Baily, where, after a tedious Hearing on all sides, (indeed he did not insist much on his not being the Author, neither did he decline the Principles of Jacobitism mention'd in his Book, tho' that was no Argument to his Conviction,) he was found Guilty, and his Sentence, which however, has not been yet fully executed, was as follows, viz.

To be twice Whipp'd, to pay 500 l. Fine to the King, to lie three Years in Prison without Bail, and to find two Sureties in 400 l. each, and him∣self to be Bound in 1000 l. to be of the good Beha∣viour during Life. The Sentence being pass'd, the Hangman was order'd to take his Gown off as he stood at the Bar, which was done accordingly.

Thus ended this Church Dispute, for the Sen∣tence against Mr. Howell was such as answered the End of such Sentences, viz. it deferred any one else from meddling with it any more; as for the Princer Mr. Redmayne, he was afterwards brought to his Tryal also, and was fined 500 l. five Years Impri∣sonment, and they both continue close Prisoners to this Day.

During this Church Controversie, which we shall find renew'd quickly in another, equally tending to Confusion and Distraction in Things religious; I say, during this, the publick Justice went on, pur∣suing the Remains of the Rebellion, in order, had it been possible, to root out the very Seeds of Disaf∣fection from among the People.

During this, I say, publick Justice proceeded, and three Particulars presented; the first was, that a Visitation, by Commission was made of the Universities in Scot∣land, but particularly at Aberdeen, where, upon the Landing of the Pretender, several of the Clergy, Members of the Colleges there, had too unwarily discover'd their Principles, and appear'd in the In∣terest; these were severally called before the Com∣missioners, and Witnesses examin'd against those that appear'd: Several of them, to prevent their be∣ing expell'd, voluntarily demitted, and expelled themselves, some were fled into Prince, and those that did appear, having en examin'd, and what
they alledg'd, being mark'd down, the Commis∣sioners gave no Sentence at that Time, but ad∣journ'd to Edinburgh, where meeting afterwards, the Persons were all expell'd the College.

The second Head of Justice, in these Cases, relates to the Commissioners appointed by Parliament, to enquire into the Estates of the Delinquents: These having separated themselves, part for Scotland, and part for England, according to the Act of Parlia∣ment, began about this Time to put the Law in Execution, and several Estates were enter'd upon, as well in England as in Scotland; as also several Parcels of Plate, of Jewels, and of Lands, said to be given to superstitious Uses; the Particular of all which, and of their farther Proceedings, will be seen together, when they come to make their Re∣port to the Parliament, from whom they receiv'd their Power.

But I come back to the Proceedings at Carlisle, which were the most considerable, and on which the Eyes of all the World were turn'd at that Time, a Summary of which take as follows, viz. The Judges being arriv'd, as I observ'd, the 1st of De∣cember, and all Things made ready for constituting a Court of Justice, they met on the 7th, and having read their Commission, the Grand Jury were called, and the Judges gave them the Sum of the Business they were to do, in the Form of a Charge as usual; after which, Bills of Indictment were pre∣sented to them against the several Prisoners respe∣ctively, who, when the Grand Jury had found the said Bills, were brought to the Bar, and the Clerk of the Crown read a Form to them, signifying that Bills were found against them for High-Treason, in Levying War, &c. That the Law allow'd Coun∣cil to plead for them, and a Copy of their In∣dictment
to be given them; and five Days Notice of their Tryals if they desired it, and thereupon another Clerk delivered them Copies of their seve∣ral Indictments accordingly, and they desiring the Time mention'd, the Court allow'd them seven Days, (viz.) to the 15th, and gave them Notice of Tryal accordingly.

Q.P: The Prisoners brought up the first Day were,

Colonel John Balfour, Major Henry Balfour, Pat. Auchmoutye, John Ratroy, Sir Tho. Calder, John Ro∣binson, Arch. Fotheringham of Powrie, Charles Gar∣den, Alexander Hay, Robert Rollo, Patrick Seaton; George Maul, Steward to the Earl of Panmure, was Discharg'd, the Jury having return'd the Bill against him (Ignoramus.)
On the 10th, the following Prisoners were brought in the same manner.

James Carnegie of Ballmoon, Tho. Tulloch, Alex. Forbes, Waltar Graham, John Ross, John Gordon, William Hay, Tho. Drummond, James Carnegie of Finhaven, Robert Murray, Col. James Urquhart, John Carstairs, Dr. Scot, Mr. Trotter, Mr. Ruther∣ford, Mr. Carr.
On the 11th, William Murray of Auchertyre, John Lyndsay, Pat. Gordon, Sylvester Douglass.
On the 12th, John Robertson, Dr. John Kinloch, James Carnegie, Surgeon, John Hamilton, George Taylor, James Rollo, Son to Rob. Rollo.
On the 13th, Patrick Robertson, John Stewart of Ross, John Stewart Junior, of Glenbucket.
On the 15th, Alex. Mackenzie of Frazerdale.
On the 17th, Brigadier Campbell.

DIV2.P: Besides these, the Two following were Discharg'd, the Bills against them being return'd (Ignoramus.) James Burnet of Monbeddo, and James Spence.

Alexander Carnegie was indicted by the Name of James, and had some Advantage by it; but as it might in the main be some Obstruction to the Mercy he resolv'd to hope for, he gave notice of it himself, and the Bill was given back to the Grand-Jury, and found a second Time.

On the 10th, when the second Twelve were brought to the Bar, Mr. Charles Garden, one of the first Twelve, broke the Way, and moving the Court that he might be brought to the Bar and Ar∣rain'd, pleaded Guilty, and threw himself upon Mercy.
On the 11th, Mr. William Murray of Auchter∣tyre, and Mr. James Carnegie of Tinhavin.
On the 12th, otheringham of Powrie, Colonel James Ʋqhart, and Alezander Hay.
On the 13th, Sir The Calder. All did the like.
On the 15th, the Court sat again, when instead of their taking Tryals as was appointed, more of the Prisoners pleaded Guilty, as the Six had done before, viz.
Colonel John Blfur, Major Henry Balfour, Pat. Auchmoutie, John Rattray, Robert Rollo of Powhouse, Pat. Seaton, John Ross, John Gordon, Robert Murray, Alexander Carnegie.

On the 17th, Mr. Carstairs, Alexander Mac∣kenzie of Frazerdale, James Carnegie, Surgeon, James Rollo, Son of Rob. Rollo of Powhouse, Alex∣ander Forbes, Waltar Graham, Tho. Drummond, All pleaded Guilty.

On the 19th, Mr.—Hay, who had demurr'd, and pleaded by Council to the Jurisdiction of the Court, finding his Plea was over-ruled, pleaded Guilty. As did also, John Robertson, who was set by as a Lunatick, Dr. John Kinlock, John Hamilton, George Taylor.
On the 20th, Pat. Gordon, Pat. Robertson.

All these having pleaded Guilty, there remain'd of all the Prisoners from Scotland that they had Evidence against, only Four to be Try'd, (viz.) Brigadier Campbell of Ormondell, Mr. Tulloch, Stewart of Ross, Stewart of Glenbucket.
Of these Four last mention'd Prisoners, the Ac∣count is very particular, viz.

The two Stewarts gave such Accounts of them∣selves, and the Court receiv'd such Satisfaction in that Account, that the Sollicitor-General thought fit to acquaint the Court that it would be for his Majesty's Service, to allow a Writ of Nli Prose∣qui to be enter'd in their behalf, which was ordered accordingly, yet without mentioning any thing in publick of the Reasons which procur'd them so much Favour.

Mr. Tulloch resolv'd to stand it, and took his Tryal the 26th, tho' the King's Council examin'd no less than seven Witnesses against him, who all testified his being in the Earl of Marr's Army, and named Time and Place to the several Actions in which he had appeared, and agreed very well in their Evidence, so that all that heard it, believed he would be found Guilty, and cast himself upon Mer∣cy, as others had done: But Mr. Tulloch went upon a quite differing Foot in his Defence, and not contending the Fact, or whether it was true or no that he was in Arms, or in the Army aforesaid;
his Council insisted, that he was not there in the Sense of the Indictment; that he was there indeed as a Prisoner, or as a Man not in his own Power; but that he was not sui juris, but was taken by Force by the Troops of the Marquis of Huntley, and carried along with them against his Will, which the Council alledged was not Rebellion with∣in the Words of the Indictment; that the Adverbs of the Indictment would not hold, for that it was not Trayterously, Seditiously, and Advisedly; but Unwillingly, Compulsively, and Forcibly; against his Intention, Resolution, and Design; the Witnes∣ses which he produced, proved that he was thus forcibly taken, and brought away from his own House; that he entreated them not to carry him a∣way, being ancient and infirm, I unfit for the Ser∣vice or for the Hardship of the Field; that he pro∣test against the Violence they used with him, and that he had declared, he would not serve them any otherwise than by For

His Witnesses also the Force upon him all to Way how he was guarded lest he should scope, and made to ride between two I into the Field, with several other Cir∣cumstances so satisfying to the Court, that the Judges in summing up the Evidence, were pleas'd to give tht's Opinion in his Favour; and the Jury him in not Guilty.

The next who was to take Trial, was Colonel Campbell of Ormendell, commonly call'd Brigadier Campbell; he was an old Soldier, and had been Twenty Years in the Service of the Czar of Musco∣vy, where he had attain'd from a private Gentle∣man, to be a Brigedier of Foot, and Colonel of a Regiment of 2000 Men; he quitted that Service upon the News of the Affair in Scotland; and no
doubt, having a different Account of the Circum∣stances of Things than he found true; for having got Shipping in the Sound, and landed in Scotland, he found the Pretender return'd to France, the Ar∣my dispers'd, and the Rebels on all Hands shifting for their Lives: However he got into the Isle of Skey, to the Interest of the Mac Donalds, and was at the Head of 1500 Men when the Troops sent thither to attack them, arriv'd there: After this he did his Part as a Soldier, tho' in a lost Cause, and encouraged the Men all he could. When the Troops appear'd, his Men all fled, but he being a Man not used to turn his Back, stood stock still with his Arms in his Hands, till an Officer came up to him, who offering him Quarter, he presented him his Sword, and was taken.

There was no Possibility of his making any De∣fence against all these Circumstances of Guilt, yet, whether it was that he expected no Mercy, or that he resolv'd to seek not we know not, he pleaded not Guilty: But when the Time for his Trial was come, and the Officers were sent to his Chamber to fetch him to the Bar, they found no∣thing in his Room but his Hat and Perriwig, for he had, it seems, found Means to escape out of the Castle, and has not been since heard of.

Things standing thus, and the Court being in∣form'd of it, and that there were no more Procee∣dings before them, the Petty-Jury were discharg'd, as the Grand-Jury had been some Days before, and then they proceeded to pass Sentence.
Accordingly the Prisoners who had pleaded Guil∣ty, were call'd up the same Day, and Sentence was pass'd upon them as is usual in Cases of Treason.
The Names of those on whom Sentence of Death was pass'd, is as follows, being Twenty-five in all.

The general Roll of the Prisoners was then call'd over, and there not appearing to be any Process be∣gun, or any Information offer'd against any more than as above, the Court order'd all the rest to be discharg'd, to their great Joy and Satisfaction: And in this particular at least, those Gentlemen are ob∣lig'd to be very well satisfy'd in the manner of Pro∣ceedings in our English Courts of Justice, seeing they could not have expected so effectual, and so quick a Discharge in their own Country.
The Proceedings being thus ended, and the Commission closed, the Court broke up.
The Names of those who were discharged for want of Proceedings, being Thirty-six in all, are as follows:

All Proceedings being thus at an End, the Com∣mission was also closed by the Judges, and the Court was dismissed, and three Days after the Judges came away, leaving however, no Order for the Executi∣on of any of the Persons Condemn'd, most of them being reserv'd to his Majesty's Mercy; so that it now appeared it was no ill Turn for them, that they were brought to England to be try'd.

At this Period I think I may put an End to all Things relating to the Rebellion, there being no more Executions on one hand, or Opposition on the other after this, except a Serjeant who was Try'd by a Council of War at Edinburgh, for the miscar∣ry'd Attempt of betraying the Castle, he was found Guilty, and accordingly hang'd over the Castle Wall at a prodigious Height from the Ground, where
he was left hanging also for some Days, till a Storm of Wind happening to break the Rope, he fell down the Precipice, and was so broken with the Fall, that they could not hang him up again.

As the rest of the Prisoners at Carlisle against whom no Evidence appe'd, were discharg'd, so Twenty-three more, most of them Scots, were on the same Foot discharg'd out of the Prisons at Lon∣don, so that now there remain'd only two Prisoners in Newgate on that Account, and none at all in the Marshalsea.

The hurry of Business being thus over for a while, and these Things being transacted at a great Distance from Court, the Regent took a Tour into the Coun∣try; the Occasion of this short Progress was no o∣ther as I could ever learn, but a meer Turn for Di∣version, and to take a little Air, and the short Stay the Prince made, confirms that Opinion, for he went out on the 24th of September, din'd at Knowl in Kent, the Earl of Dorset's Seat, and lay that Night at the Duke of Newcastle's House, near Lewes in Sussex: His Royal Highness diverted him∣self as he went, by making a short Stay at Tun∣bridge, to see the Wells and the Walks, and diver∣ted the People there also very much: The next Day he went thro' Chichester to Stansted, the Seat of the Earl of Scarborough, where he lay that Night: The 26th he went to see the Fortifications at Portsmouth, and returned the same Night to Stansted; and the 27th, returned to Court.

All Things were may in a State of Tranquillity, and seem'd to promise a Continuance, but an un∣foreseen Accident gave some Disturbance to it, and this was the Tumult at Oxford, an Affair which made great Noise at first, and was afterwards brought before, both the Council and the Parliament, where
tho' the Oxonians receiv'd some Checks, yet no Ju∣dicial Proceedings were ever had against the Towns∣men or Scholars, as was threaten'd, the Soldiers ha∣ving too much to be called in question for, to desire the Cause to be heard any where but where it was.

The Business was, in short, that the 30th of Octo∣ber being the Prince's Birth Day, and a Regiment of Soldiers, (viz.) the Regiment of Foot of Dubour∣gay being quarter'd in the Town, the Major of the Regiment resolving to celebrate the Day, and find∣ing the Inhabitants inclined to take but little Notice of it, some Bickerings happen'd between the Major and the Townsmen, about Ringing the Bells and such Things, afterwards they fell to throwing Stones on both Sides, breaking of Windows, and some Heads in the Quarrel, and it was said, the Mayor and Aldermen received some of the Knocks.

However it was the Magistrates made the first Complaint, and drew up a great many Affidavits of the Fact, and Mr. Rowney their Representative, wrote a Letter to Mr. Secretary Methuen about it, as did also the Vice-Chancellor of the University and the Mayor of the City, to my Lord Townshend: On the other hand, Major Offranville, the Major of the Regiment wrote likewise to the Lord Townshend, and the Soldiers drew up Affidavits also to every Particular; at length it came to be heard before the Council, who after some Debates, Resolved it in Favour of the Soldiers, which Resolve being after∣wards heard in the House of Lords, was confirm'd there Word for Word, as I shall note in its Place: The Report of the Committee of Council was as follows, (viz.)
Cockpit, December 31. 1716.

Q.P: THE Depositions on the Part of the Complainants relating to the Disturbances that happened at Oxford on the Prince's Birth-Day, and the Deposi∣tions on the Part of the Officers and Soldiers, and others concerned with them, having all been read, the Lords of the Committee are of Opinion, That the Heads of the Ʋniversity, and Mayor of the City, neglected to make any publick Rejoicings on the Prince's Birth-Day: But some of the Collegiates, with the Officers, being met to celebrate the said Day, the House where they were, was assaulted, and the Win∣dows were broken by the Rabble, which was the Be∣ginning and Occasion of the Riots that ensued, as well from the Soldiers as the Scholars and Townsmen, and that the Conduct of the Major seems well justified by the Affidavits produced on his Part.

DIV2.P: When these Things came to be heard before the House of Lords, their Lordships came to the like Resolution, (viz.) First they voted, That the Lords of the Committee of Council had sufficient Grounds to come to the Resolution they did come to, as above; and then they took into Consideration the Printing the Depositions, upon which they Resolv'd secondly, That the Printing and Publishing the Depositions upon which the Complaints relating to the Riots at Oxford were founded, while that Matter was under the Exa∣mination of the Lords of the Committee of Council, and before they had Time to come to any Resoluti∣on touching the same, was Irregular, Disrespectful to his Royal Highness the Prince, and tending to Sedition.

Tumults indeed took up a great Part of the first Month of this Year, for there was something so uneasy and dissatisfy'd in the People's Temper at that Time, that they made almost every thing an Occasion of Riot and Disorder: The Occasion how∣ever of this I am going to relate, did not begin up∣on any Matters of State or Politicks, which verifies what I have just now said of the tumultuous Dispo∣sition of the People.

There is a Fair for Cattle held at Edinburgh the 12th of November, call'd Hallow-Fair, or in English the Fair of Alhallows, or of All-Saints, a Soldier in this Fair, having some Dirt thrown upon him by a Cow running hastily by him, draws his Sword up∣on a Scots Highlander who was driving the Cow, and wounded the poor Fellow in the Arm; upon this other Highlanders came in, and seeing the poor Man hurt, fell upon the Soldier; the Soldier de∣fended himself a while, but seeing his Danger, made off, the Rabble following him to the General's Quar∣ters, where there was a Guard, and where the Mob demanded him, and one of them pressing in violently upon the Centinel, he fir'd and kill'd him; but this encreasing the Tumult, the Rabble had cer∣tainly storm'd the General's House and perhaps done more Mischief, if General Carpenter had not come timely in with a strong Party, and even then the Mob would not have been pacify'd, if the General by his very obliging and civil Treatment had not prevail'd more, than his Men did or could have done by their Fire-Arms and Swords.

The 9th of this Month, the Princess was delive∣red of a dead Child, and was not only very ill in her Travail, but in great Danger for two or three Days, after having been taken with Faintings and
Swoonings two or three Times, but it went off a∣gain, and in a Week she was out of Danger.

The Season advancing, and Winter coming on, the King, who had been now above four Months abroad, began to look homeward; and as his Affairs seem'd to draw to a close, the Squadron appointed to Convoy him over, with the Yatchts for his Re∣tinue, were order'd over to Holland, and the Par∣liament which stood prorogu'd to the 20th, now were order'd to be farther prorogu'd to the 8th of January, by which Time it was expected the King would have finished all his Business and be arriv'd.

This mentioning his Majesty's Affairs Abroad, car∣ries me naturally to enquire into the Particulars of them as far as they are proper to this History, and first passing over his Majesty's Houshold Business A∣broad, or as it Relates to the Government of his Hereditary Dominions; I say, passing these, the Affairs the King had there which Respected England or Great-Britain were principally two: (viz.) 1st Con∣cerning himself in the Affair of Sweden; to which purpose a Squadron had been sent to the Baltick, which now receiv'd it's Orders immediately from the King in Person; and 2dly, Negotiating a defensive Alliance with France, of which it is needfull to make some mention, because an Alliance with France was really a new Thing in the World, and People began to wonder what the meaning of it might be, expecting that by the Novelty of it some thing particular was intended, it is true that the Circumstances were very particular on both sides, and it is not easy to say by whom it was most wanted or most desired, either Great-Britain, or France: It is confess'd France sought it, perhaps their Necessity at that time prompted them; but it is as true that the Councils of Great-Britain came very willingly into it, and
that on the account of Interest also, as well as France, this is not ill stated by one, who a cer∣tain Writer need not be asham'd to own he took it from, and who I follow in this Case, tho' with more Honesty, because I acknowledge it: He ex∣presses it thus: The Duke Regent, says he, a Man of Prudence and Penetration, saw not only his own Safety absolutely depending upon it, in Case of the Demise of the present King; but happily for him, found his Neighbours had some certain nice Articles, which it was in his Power to yield them at that time, and which would infallibly render the Propo∣sal acceptable to them. For example, he could not but know, that the Pretender and his Friends, who were all in his Power, would be a Sacrifice highly agreeable to the King of Great-Britain, and necessa∣ry to the Peace of his Subjects; that the Affair of Mardyke would be a Pledge of too great a Value not to be earnestly desired by Great-Britain, and would be a singular Ease to the Merchants of such a Trading Country; he knew that when he offered two such Points, the Court of Britain were too penetrating not to listen to it, and if possible secure them upon any reasonable Terms.

He knew the Dutch, a Nation desirous of Peace upon just Terms, and depending wholly upon Trade, would be very glad of a Concession which France had in its Power to give, viz. the Tariff of Sixty Four; and finding it of the last Importance to him∣self to secure the Amity of these two powerful Neighbours, he resolved to deny nothing they could reasonably demand, in order to enter into new Engagements with them both; that if at any time he should come to have his Claim to the Crown of France disputed by the House of Spain, he might not
only be secure behind him, but also be powerfully Supported.

Upon these Considerations, he made no scruple to agree to expunge the Pretender, and all his Ad∣herents, entirely out of the Dominions of France; nay, even to oblige him to remove from Avignon, tho' it was a Place entirely in the Jurisdiction, and under the Sovereignty of the Pope. He made no scruple of Engaging to give no Sanctuary in the Dominions of France, to any of King George's Re∣bels, &c. and he made no difficulty effectually to demolish and destroy the new Canal of Mardyke, and all the Works there or at Dunkirk, which should be capable of making either of those Places Defen∣sible, or fit for receiving Ships of Burthen. Besides this, he made no difficulty of granting to the Dutch all they had to desire in their Commerce, and to give them a free Trade into France upon such Terms as they had formerly enjoy'd.

These Concessions made the Proposals of France relish very well both at London, and at the Hague; and it appears since, that the King took his Mea∣sures very right in accepting the Project of the Trea∣ty of Alliance, since he saw the Regent under per∣haps a greater Necessity of it, than even if he had been reduced by a War, and that now was the Time, not only to obtain of the French all that could be asked, but even to bring the French Court to be dependent upon the British, and always at∣tach'd to the British Interest, by the undissembling Tie, of a regard to their own.

These were some of the Motives to this Alliance on both sides; in which it was to be observ'd, the French proceeded with more Candour and Openness than usually was the Practice of that wily Nation.
His Britannick Majesty, though he found the Inte∣rest of his Kingdoms very visibly form'd in the Treaty, yet wisely suffered himself to be assiduously Courted to it, and gave the French Occasion to let the World know, it was their Motion, and at their Desire; which reserve in the Conduct of the Trea∣ty, gave his Majesty opportunity in many Cases to insist with Advantage on several Things, which per∣haps the French would otherwise with more difficul∣ty have given up, as the Manner and Circumstances of the Demolishing Mardyke, the Dimensions to which the Sluices were to be reduced, the sending o∣ver British Commissioners to inspect the Performance, and the like; also, as to the Entertaining of Fugi∣tives, the removing of the Pretender, and his De∣pendents, and such other Cases as were the most Es∣sential on the King's side.

Also, this distinguish'd Conduct on his Majesty's Side, put a Stop to all seeming Dissatisfactions that might affect the People on occasion of this Treaty. An Alliance with France was a new thing to be talk'd of in these Kingdoms; it had so often been entered upon in a scandalous Manner, and with an ill De∣sign, that it was something difficult to reconcile the People so much as to the very thing in general; but when it was answered, that the King, who it was suppos'd, always acted in such Cases with his Eyes open, and was not to be imposed upon by the Arts of the French Court, or to be deceived by their u∣sual Cunning; I say, when the Nation came to con∣sider, that the King himself was at the Head of the Treaty, and that he was upon the Spor, all that Jealousie, which began to infuse its self into the Minds of the People in general, vanished of a sudden, and they entirely depended upon it, that if the King engag'd in such a Treaty, he would
bring it to answer the Desires and Interests of his People, or not conclude it at all.
Nor has the Event deceiv'd their Expectation, every Article of the Treaty which relates to Great-Britain, being visibly calculated for her Interest and Advantage.

Thus the Treaty went on with Success, it was ma∣nag'd at the Hague by the Marquis Chateauneuf, and the Abbor Du Bois on the French Part; by the Lord Cadogan, and the ordinary British Resident on his Ma∣jesty's Part, the King himself being at Hand to give Instructions on any Emergency, viz. at Hanover; and by the Pensionary Hyensius chiefly, on the Part of the States, and about the middle of January was concluded and finished.

There was besides these Things of Weight, one Business of lesser Importance which was requisite to be manag'd at Hanover only, this was the vesting the young Prince Royal, the King's Grandson, with the Order of the Garter, as also his Majesty's Bro∣ther Prince Ernest, Bishop of Osnaburgh, and Duke of York, which was done with all the usual Cere∣monies, the King himself putting on the blew Rib∣band on his Brother, as also on the young Prince, in his own Closet; as to their Installment, it was not till many Months after, as shall be mention'd in its Place.

I omit smalier Matters here, which might perhaps take up some few Days between the Preparations for the King's coming over and his arriving; the main and more considerable Things which happen'd at this Time, drawing me off from Things of lesser Moment.

Breaches and Contention between the Parties were no Novelty, and History would be even clogg'd in the Repetition of them; but that the Whigs
should fall out among themselves, and that when the Game was all in their own Hands too, when they had their Enemies all under their Feet, when nothing could oppose or withstand them, this is what no History can equal, no Historian could expect, and can hardly be supposed to spring from any Founda∣tion but this, that something must be in hand to do, which the Resigners, for so they were call'd, cared not to have any hand in, or something proposed to them to be done, which they cared not to comply with.

Two Things indeed were in Agitation at that Time, which, it was expected by many, would have been brought into Parliament in the ensuing Session, and which some have said were entirely broken off and defeated by the demitting of those Men, with∣out whose Interest, the Persons concern'd did not think themselves sufficient for the Undertaking: These two Things were as follows, (viz.)
I. The taking off the Acts of Parliament which severally disabled the Dissenters in England from enjoying any Employment or Office of Trust in the Government, &c. And,
II. The repealing that Part of the Act for Secu∣rity of the Succession, made in the Sixth of Queen Anne, Prohibiting Foreigners, tho' Na∣turalized, to be capable of Sitting in the House of Lords.

The last of these seem'd to respect the enobling some Foreigners, who, it seems, had their Eyes, or their Friends for them, upon the Project of introducing them into the British Peetage, and a Pamphlet was written by one Toland, a Pro∣fligate of the Party, to prepare the Minds of the People, and perhaps of the Parliament for such a Thing; but this Pamphlet rather alarm'd the Peers,
than influenc'd them in Favour of the Design, and the Thing was so exposed and ridicul'd by other Pamphiets, that the Contrivers were easily convinc'd of the Impracticableness of the Thing, and laid down the Design.

As for the Sentiments of the great Men at Court, they were no less divided upon this Article than up∣on others, and as one Division generally introduces another, a strange Distrust, Uneasiness, and at last Dissati faction seem'd to spread itself among even the Ministry it self, so that the Clashings at length appear'd to be obstructing to the publick Business, and the King was in a few Words, obliged to take it into his own Hands.

Here began the Changes which follow'd, and as his Majesty found it convenient to change some Hands in the Administration, so some others believing they should not have the same Freedom in acting, which they had before, tho' necessary to the Ser∣vice, chose rather to demit, than serve with those who they had no Confidence in, and perhaps expe∣cted no Assistance from.
The first who was remov'd, was the Lord Viscount Townshend, Secretary of State; the King being yet at Hnover, sent his Lordship's Dismiss from thence on the 12th of December.

The Whiggs were Thunder-struck at this Blow, and receiv'd the News with the greatest Astonish∣ment and Coernation: But tho' the Lord Town∣shend was dismiss'd from the Office of Secretary, yet he seem'd for some time to keep his Interest in his Prince's Favour, seeing it was immediately re∣solv'd to make him Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, in the Room of the Duke of Grafton, and Lord Gall∣way, who were about that time dismiss'd; and tho' this was not immediately done, and we were told
for a while, that his Lordship declin'd that Post, yet soon after the King's Arrival it was fix'd, and my Lord Townshend was accordingly appointed Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, and entred upon the said Office, tho' that good Disposition of Things did not continue neither but for a little while, as we shall see presently.

In the mean time, this Remove was not attended for the present with any others as Consequences of it. There were indeed some other Changes in Court Offices, which it is meet to mention here. But the great Change which was made on Party-Account was not yet for some time, and is therefore referr'd to its proper Place. The immediate Changes were these, (viz.)

The Duke of Roxburgh was appointed Secretary of State, not, properly speaking, in the Room of the Lord Townshend, but rather in the Vacancy which had remain'd ever since the Duke of Mon∣tress laid down, as is mention'd in our last Year.

The Earl of Sunderland, Lord Privy-Seal, demit∣ted that Employment, and was made Vice Treasurer of Ireland for Life; an Employ of great Advantage; but as it was officiated by Officers under his Lord∣ship, we shall soon find him filling up a higher Sta∣tion on this side the Seas.
The Duke of Montross was made Lord Privy-Seal in Scotland, in the Room of the Duke of Roxburgh; and the Duke of Kingston, Lord Privy-Seal in Eng∣land, in the room of the Earl of Sunderland.
The Lord Polwarth, eldest Son to the Earl of Marchmont, and Ambassador at the Court of Den∣mark, was made Lord Clerk Register in Scotland, formerly possess'd by the Earl of Glasgow.

In this Disposition things remained till the King's Return; the Lord Townshend's Remove affected no
more for the present than himself; and tho' there were many Divisions talked of, which also seemed irreconcileable; yet the King's Judgment and Au∣thority reconciled them all again, till they broke out anew upon another Occasion.

In the mean time, the King prepar'd to come home, the Queen of Prussia his Majesty's Daugh∣ter, who came on purpose to make a Visit to her Father, had taken her Leave; the Treaty with France was finished, and the Dutch came into it, by which either Party were Guarantees to each other for the present State of Affairs, and Stipulations made for the Quota's of Troops to be supply'd to each in Case of being attack?d thus, France and the States-General were Guarantees to the King of Great-Britain for the Succession; Great-Britain and France Guarantees to the States-General for the Barrier Treaty; and Great-Britain and the States-General Guarantees to France for the Renunciations, all which are, it is said, included in the Treaty.

The next Thing the King had to do, was an Inter∣view with the Czar of Muscovy, which it was ex∣pected should have been in Holland; but the Czar was indispos'd, and the King's insisting upon the Czar's removing his Troops out of Mecklemburgh, gave that Prince some Distaste, which at present made People expect a Breach, but the Wisdom of both Sides prevented the ill Consequences; the good Understanding seem'd afterwards to be Esta∣blish'd, and the Czar did (tho' not without Regret) withdraw his Troops, whether there is not some se∣cret Distaste remaining upon that Score, Time may perhaps discover.

These Things being all over, the King having finished all the Foreign Business which lay before him, set out from Hanover on Tuesday the 19th,
New-stile, and arriv'd at Osnaburgh that Night, where his Royal Highness the Duke of York, his Majesty's Brother, and Bishop of Osnaburgh, was gone before to Entertain him, the 21st, his Majesty came to Loo, where he was met and complimented by the Princess Dowager of Nassau-Friesland, and her Children; the 23d, his Majesty came to Utrecht in the Afternoon, and making but a very short stay there, lay that Night at Vlaerden, having been at∣tended to Utrecht by the Earl of Sunderland, the Lord Cadogan, and Mr. Secretary Stanhope.

On Monday the 14th of January, O. S. His Ma∣jesty set out from Vlaerden at Four in the Afternoon, and lay that Night on Board the States Yatcht in the Maese. On the 15th, his Majesty pass'd through the Old Maese, and at Three in the Afternoon landed at Helvoet-Sluys, and lay there that Night. On the 16th, his Majesty Embark'd, and lay that Night on Board the Carolina Yatcht. On the 17th, about Two in the Afternoon, the Squadron, commanded by Admiral Aylmer, with the Yatchts, sailed out of the Goree: The next Day, about three in the Af∣ternoon, his Majesty landed at Margate, and lay that Night at Canterbury. On Saturday the 19th, about Six in the Morning, he came by Coach from Canterbury: Between three and four in the After∣noon, he was met on Black-Heath by the Prince of Wales, with a great Number of the Nobility and Gentry, and other Persons of Distinction. And ha∣ving, with great Affection, Embrac'd his Royal Highness in his Arms, took him in his Coach, and they came from thence together; then passing thro' the City, they arriv'd at St. James's about Six in the Evening; the People all the Way ma∣king Acclamations for his happy Return:
In the Evening there were Bonfires, Illuminati∣ons, and all other Demonstrations of Joy.

The King being return'd, all Eyes were turn'd to∣wards the Court, and it was surprising to find, that no farther Changes were made; the Breach at Court seem'd to be heal'd, and the King appear'd pleased with every Body, every Body seem'd pleas'd with one another; the Lord Townshend appear'd at Court on one hand, and the King shew'd him several Marks of particular Respect, and his Lordship on the other hand accepted to be Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, and was publickly declar'd to be so in Council, which he had for some time before declin'd; so that now all Things seem'd reconcil'd again at Court, nor were there any more Removes so much as talk'd of, except, that Mr. John ortescue-Aland, an eminent Council at Law was made one of the Barons of the Exchequer; and Sir William Thompson, Recorder of London, was made Sollicitor-General.

But this Harmony continu'd but a little while, and the second Rupture which follow'd, was so much worse than the first, by how much it seem'd impossible ever to be made up, and has continu'd so indeed ever since.

The King being arriv'd, the sitting of the Parlia∣ment was expected, and that with some Impatience, because it was in this approaching Session, that the great Attempt was to be made to reduce the Interest of the Funds, and lessen thereby, and at last pay off the Nation's Debts; the Proposals for this had been made Publick, and they came handed into the World with such seeming Authority, that it was not doubted, but they were the Result of those Schemes which were really laid for the putting it in Executi∣on, as indeed it afterwards appear'd to be, and the Divisions upon these Things without Doors, was so
great, that really the People wanted the Parliament to meet to put an End to them, for the Price of all publick Things was uncertain, none knew how or what to buy or sell, or how to value his own Estate.

But the meeting of the Parliament was yet far∣ther delay'd, upon a new Incident from Abroad, this was the Rumour of a Plot forming in Sweden for invading the King's Dominions in Favour of the Pretender by the King of Sweden.

This made so much Noise for a while, that tho' by the Event there may have been some room to doubt, whether there was any such Design or no, or whether there were any such Preparations at Gottem∣burgh as was pretended, yea or no, yet for a time the whole Kingdom was amused with it, and per∣suaded to believe, and expect every Day an Army of Veteran Swedes, and a strong Squadron of Men of War with them, to Land even in the Heart of the Kingdom, nay, some were so forward as to tell us, they would even come up the River, and Land with∣in a few Marches of the City of London, depending upon Thousands of People here to join them.

The Pretence was specious indeed, supposing it to be only a Pretence, which however I will not affirm, and the Nation exceedingly alarm'd at it for a while. It was about the End of January, as we were told, that the Government had secret Intelli∣gence of a concerted Design to Foment a new Re∣bellion, under the Protection of some Foreign Troops to be procur'd from Abroad, and that this Design was carry'd on between some Foreign Ministers Abroad, and some of the Pretender's Friends here at Home, and such Progress was made in the Discovery, that on the 29th, the King order'd an Account of it to be laid before the Privy-Council, that the farther Proceedings upon it might be carry'd on in a more
formal Method, according to the ordinary Course of Justice.

The whole Relation of the farther Proceedings on this Affair having been published at the Time of them by so many Hands, cannot be mistaken, and are Word for Word with very little Omissions for the Sake of Brevity, as follows, (viz.)

On the 30th very early, viz. about Two a Clock in the Morning, an Officer of the Guards with some Musqueteers, were sent to the House of Count Gyllenborg, the Swedish Envoy, with Orders to secure the Avenues to the House, and were fol∣lowed by Lieutenant General Wade, with Orders to Seize all his Papers, and to set a Guard upon his Person, and suffer none to speak with him; but not to remove him out of his own House.

The Count, surprized with the Message which was first delivered at his Door by the Officer, refused for some time to admit them, and Claiming the Pri∣vilege of an Ambassador, pretended to Defend him∣self; but being quickly made sensible, that if he attempted that, they should make very short work with him, that the Officer was not answerable for any Mistake in the Orders to seize him; but that his Business was to execute those Orders, which he was obliged to do, and would immediately perform; being, I say, made sensible of this, he found it convenient to submit; but, as it was said, took Oc∣casion in those few Minutes of Parley, to destroy such Papers as he had near at Hand, and which he was conscious he ought not to let be taken about him; and thus the Officer being let in, the Envoy was put under Arrest in his own House, the Officer who was left to guard him, having Orders to suffer no one to speak with him, nor him to speak with any one by Night or by Day, except in his hearing.

It will not be wonder'd at, that such an Affair as this made a great Noise, as is usual in such Cases: All the Foreign Ministers appeared the next Day at Court, to learn the Reasons of such a Proceeding, and to crave leave that the Swedish Minister might be allowed the Privilege of an Ambassador, accor∣ding to the Law of Nations. They receiv'd for the present, an Answer in general, that in a Day or two they should be fully acquainted with the Rea∣sons of such a Proceeding; and accordingly on the first of February, which was but two Days after, the following Letter was sent by Mr. Secretary Stan∣hope, and Mr. Secretary Methuen, to all the Foreign Ministers, to give them reasonable Satisfaction in this Affair.

LETTER.HEAD: Copie de la Lettre de M. Stanhope, Secretaire d'Etat aux Ministres êtrangers, le premier Fevrier, V. S. 1716/17.
LETTER.P:
LE Roy ayant receu des avis reiterés, & ayant des preuves incon∣testables de plusieurs pra∣tiques trés dangereuses, qui ont été ménagées & conduites depuis quelque tems par la Comte de Gyllenborg Ministre du Roy de Suede ici, & qui tendoient clairement à fomenter dans les Etats de sa Majesté une Re∣bellion
de ses propres Su∣jets, qui devoit être soutenuë par des Troupes etrangeres; & ce Comte ayant par une telle con∣duite viole la foy pub∣lique, & s'étant rendu indigne de la Protecti∣on dont autremont il devoit jeüir par le Droit des Gens, & des pri∣viléges dús à son Cara∣ctere; sa Majesté pour mettre fin à des pratiques si pernicieuses, & pour la conservation de la paix & de la tranquillité de ses Etats, a jugé qu'il étoit absolument necessaire de faire saisir le dit Comte de Gyllenborg, & de s'as∣surer de tons ses papiers, par lesquels les intrigues pernicieuses, dans les∣quelles il a été engagé, paroîtront à tout le monde, & justifieront fuffisam∣ment la demarche que sa Majesté à trouvé bon de faire. Je ne doute point, que le Roy dans peu ne m'ordonne de vous informer plus amplement des raisons qui ont porté sa Majeste à prendre cette resolution: Mais
en attendant, je suis chargé de vous communi∣quer par son ordre ce qui s'est passé, à fin que vous en puissiez donner part à vtre Cour; sa Majesté, ne doutant nullement, quand vtre Maître se∣ra pleinement informé du procédé de ce Comte, il ne soit entiérement convaincu, que non seule∣ment la paix & la tran∣quilité des Etats de sa Majesté, mais aussi le répos de l' Europe, & la seureté des Alliances pre∣sentes ont rendu cette demarche indispensable∣ment necessaire. Je suis, avec beaucoup d'estime,

CLOSER.SALUTE: Vôtre trés Humble, Et trés Obeissant Serviteur,

LETTER.HEAD: Copy of the Rt. Hon. Mr. Secretary Stanhope's Letter to the Foreign Ministers, the 1st of February, O. S. 17 16/17.
LETTER.P:
THE King having received reiterated Advices, and having incontestable Proofs of several very dangerous Practices which have been managed and con∣ducted, for some time by the Count de Gyllen∣borg, Minister of the King of Sweden here, and which plainly tended to foment, in his Maje∣sty's
Dominions, a Re∣bellion of his own Sub∣jects, which was to be supported by Foreign Troops; and the said Count having, by such Conduct, violated the publick Faith, and ren∣der'd himself unworthy of that Protection, which otherwise he ought to have enjoy'd by the Law of Nations, and of the Privileges due to his Character; his Majesty, to put an End to such pernicious Practices, and to preserve the Peace and Tranquillity of his Do∣minions, judg'd it abso∣lutely necessary to cause the said Count de Gyllen∣borg to be seiz'd, and to possess himself of all his Papers, by which the per∣nicious Intrigues where∣in he hath been engaged, will appear to all the World, and sufficiently justify the Measures his Majesty has thought fit to take. I don't doubt, but the King will, in a little time, order me to inform you more fully of the Reasons which have
induc'd his Majesty to take this Resolution: But in the mean while, I am charged to com∣municate to you, by his Order, what has been done already, to the end you may impart the same to your Court; his Majesty no ways doubting, but that when your Master shall be fully inform'd of the said Count's Behaviour, he will be entirely con∣vinced, that not only the Peace and Tranquillity of his Majesty's Domi∣nions, but likewise the Repose of Europe, and the Security of the pre∣sent Alliances, have ren∣der'd this Procedure in∣dispensably necessary. I am, with great Esteem,

CLOSER.SALUTE: Your most Humble, and most Obedient, Servant,

DIV2.P: All the Foreign Ministers, except the Marquis de Monteleone, Ambassador of Spain, appear'd satisfied with this Letter; but this Gentleman sent the fol∣lowing Answer to Mr. Secretary Methuen.

LETTER.P: I Receiv'd Yesterday in the Evening the Letter which your Excel∣lency did me the Honour to write to me that Day, in which you give me an Account of the Reasons his Majesty had for sei∣zing the Count de Gyl∣lenborg, Minister of the King of Sweden, and all his Papers.

After thanking your Excellency for your Goodness, in acquaint∣ing me with his Maje∣sty's Sentiments, accor∣ding to the Orders you received for that purpose; since I am thereby enabled to make a faithful Report of the Matter to the King my Master; I cannot but wait for an Answer, to communi∣cate the same to your Excellency.

I shall, however, own to your Excellency, that it is a very great Mis∣fortune, that no other Expedient could be found for preserving the Peace and Tran∣quillity of his Majesty's Dominions, the Repose of Europe, and securing the present Alliances, without Arresting the Person of a Publick Mi∣nister, and seizing all his Papers, which are the most sacred Reposi∣tories of the Secrets of his Master.
In whatever Manner these two Facts may be understood, they seem very sensibly to wound the Law of Nations.

JE receus hier au Soir la Lettre que votrè Excellence m'a fait Phon∣neur de m'écrire dattée du méme jour, par la∣quelle elle m'instruit des Raisons que sa Majesté a eüe de faire arrêter le Comte de Gyllenborg, Mi∣nistre du Roy de Suede, & de s'asseurer de tous ses Papiers.

P.HI: Aprés avoir remercié vôtre Excellence, de la Bonté qu'elle à eüe de m'informer des Senti∣ments de S. M. suivant les Ordres qu'elle en a re∣ceus, puisque cela me mot en état de les rapporter fidelement au Roy mon Maitre, je ne saurois qu'attendre ses Reponses pour les faire aussi savoir à vôtre Excellence.

LETTER.P: J'avoüerai pourtant à V. E que c'est un Mal∣heur fort grand, qu'il n'y ait eu d'autre Expe∣dient, pour assurer la Paix & la Tranquillité des Etats de S. M. le Repos de l' Europe, & la Seureté des Allian∣ces presentes, que celui d arrêter la Personne d'un Ministre Public, & de se saisir de tous ses Papiers, qui sont les Depôts les plus sacrez des Secrets de son Mai∣tre.

P.HI: De quelque maniere que l'on prenne ces deux Faits, ils paroissent blesser trés sensiblement le Droit des Gens.

DIV2.P:
But Matters did not End here, for the Govern∣ment had found Means to fix all these Negotiations upon a Person beyond the Seas; and tho' Count Gyllenborg's Letters had not pointed it out to them, yet they knew very well who the Count's Principal Correspondent was, viz. The Baron Gortz, a Per∣son, who, tho' he was properly a Minister of the
Duke of Holstein's, yet at this time was appointed by the King of Sweden to negotiate his Affairs in divers Courts abroad, and in particular, in the Treaty at Brunswick, if it had gone for∣ward.

Besides what private Information the Govern∣ment had of this, the Letters seiz'd among Count Gyllenborg's Papers, confirming every thing, led them as it were by the Hand into the Particulars, so that they now wanted no farther Light into that Part of the Conspiracy: It remained only to con∣trive some Method how to get this warm Agent of the Party into their Hands, which they quickly found means to bring to pass.

The Baron had been at the Court of France, and was come from thence into Flanders, from whence he was expected back at the Hague the 24th of January, N.S. and the Intelligence of this being well-grounded, Orders were dispatched to Mr. Leathes, the British Resident at the Hague, to apply himself with the greatest Secresie possible to the States General, to obtain leave to Arrest and Secure the Baron Gortz in the Name of the King of England, which, as he was under no publick Cha∣racter immediately to the said States, was a Favour they could not refuse. The British Resident dis∣charg'd himself of these Orders so well, that he obtained all that he desired, and executed the Au∣thority he obtained in the following manner.

The Baron arriv'd at the Hague perfectly secure, and on the Day he was expected; it seems, till then he was wholly ignorant of the Fate of Count Gyl∣lenborg, and appeared to be in a great Surprize when he receiv'd an Account of it, and was in the utmost Confusion when he was privately informed,
that he was in some Danger of the same Fate him∣self; for it seems some secret Friend of his had gotten knowledge of it time enough to inform him of it, and he lost no time to provide for his own Safety; for he immediately set out from the Hague in the privatest Manner he could in a Post Chaise, accompanied only with the Polish General Poni∣atowski, and went directly for Amsterdam, judging rightly, that he had no Time to lose; and indeed had he used the same Dexterity there, he had gotten perfectly clear: That he had no Time to lose was most certain, for he had not been many Mi∣nutes gone before a Detachment of the Blue Guards was sent to his House to Arrest him.

Mr. Leathes, Resident of Great-Britain, who arrived from Amsterdam much about that time, hear∣ing of the Escape of the said Baron de Gortz, went back thither immediately, and upon Advice that the 20th, being Saturday Morning, the said Baron de Gortz was set out from Amsterdam, he employ'd Commissary Vleertman to follow him, with another Gentleman; and they used so much Diligence, that notwithstanding the Swedish Minister was gone some Hours before them, they arrived at Night, much about the same time, at the Gates of Arnheim, which being opened, Mr. Vleertman followed, at some distance, the said Baron de Gortz to an Inn, and immediately went to the chief Burgomaster, who rising from Bed, upon Notice given him, that that Gentleman had something to impart to him from the States, was acquainted with the Orders given to secure the Baron de Gortz, whereupon two Town Officers and some Soldiers were sent to seize him and his Papers, and they brought him, with his Secretary, to the Town-House.

The Seizing this Gentleman made a great Noise, and the Swedish Resident in Holland reclaim'd him in the Name of the King of Sweden; and presented a Memorial to the States, to which he annexed an authentick Copy of the full Powers given by the King of Sweden to the Baron Gortz, alledging, That he ought to be look'd upon as a Publick Mini∣ster, and that the Law of Nations had been violated in the Seizing a Person, who was even in that Country under a publick Character.

Hitherto the Weight of Things lay upon Count Gyllenborg and the Baron Gortz, and it might be true that they were embark'd with the Preten∣der's Party here, for ought appear'd to the con∣trary; but the Question seem'd to remove from thence to the King of Sweden himself; who seem'd to be Charged with a Visible design in favour of the Pretender; what Evidence there was that the King of Sweden was concern'd in it, or that what these Gentlemen, tho' they were his Majestys Agents, had done by his Orders and structions, may be enquired as I go along: I must profess to see very little of it hitherto, and the dis∣missing the two Swedish Ministers afterwards, in the Manner they were dismiss'd, seems to me not to im∣port, that the Concern the King of Sweden was said to have in it, did sufficiently appear; but that is not the present Business, I return to the Fact.

On the 20th of the next Month, (viz.) February, the Parliament met pursuant to the Prorogation, and the King open'd the Session with the following Speech, in which his Majesty took publick Notice of this Affair.

Q.P: My Lords and Gentlemen,
I Was in hopes that the Success which it pleased God to give Ʋs, in Defeating the late Rebellion, might have secured to the Nation Peace, Plenty, and Tranquillity.

My Endeavours have not been wanting, during your Recess, to improve the happy Prospect which was in View, by entring into such Negotiations as I judged most conducive to those good Ends; and 'tis with Pleasure I can acquaint you, that many Defects in the Treaties of Utrecht, which very nearly affected the Trade, and even the Security of these Kingdoms, have been remedy'd by subse∣quent Conventions, the happy Consequences of which have already very sensibly appeared by the Flourish∣ing Condition of our Trade and Credit.

By the Alliance lately concluded with France, and the States-General, We are soon to be Eased of all future Apprehensions from Dunkirk and Mardyke: The Pretender is actually removed beyond the Alps; his Adherents are deprived of all Hopes of Support and Countenance from France; and even the Assistance of that Crown is Stipulated to Us in case of Exigency.

It seemed reasonable to expect, that such a Sci∣tuation of Affairs at Home and Abroad should have recovered from their Delusion all such of our Subjects as had Unhappily been Seduced by the Craft and Wickedness of Desperate and Ill-designing Men, and thereby have afforded Me the Opportunity, which I desired, of following the Natural Bent of My own Inclinations to Lenity, by Opening this Ses∣sion with an Act of Grace; but such is the Obsti∣nate and Inveterate Rancour of a Faction amongst
Ʋs, that it hath again prompted them to animate and stir up Foreign Powers to disturb the Peace of their Native Country; they will chuse rather to make Britain a Scene of Blood and Confusion, and to Venture even the putting this Kingdom under a Foreign Yoke, than give over their darling Design of Imposing a Popish Pretender.

I have Ordered to be laid before You, Copies of Letters which have passed between the Swedish Mi∣nisters on this Occasion, which contain a certain Account of the projected Invasion; and I promise My Self from your experienced Zeal and Affection to my Person and Government, that you will come to such Resolutions as will enable Me, by the Blessing of God, to defeat all the Designs of Our Enemies against Ʋs.
Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

P.HI: I did hope the putting an End to the late Re∣bellion would have so far secured the Peace and Tranquillity of the Nation, that I might, consistent∣ly with the Safety of My People, have made a con∣siderable Reduction of the Forces; but the Prepa∣rations which are making from Abroad to Invade Us, oblige Me to ask such Supplies as you shall find absolutely Necessary for the Defence of the Kingdom.

You are all Sensible of the Insupportable Weight of the National Dbts, which the Publick became Engaged for, from the Necessity of the Times, the Pressues of a long and expensive War, and the lan∣guishing State of Publick Credit; but the Scene being nw so happily changed, if no new Disturbances shall plnge Ʋs again into Streights and Difficulties, the general Expectation seems to require of You, that
You should turn your Thoughts toward some Method of extricating Your Selves, by Reducing, by Degrees, the Debts of the Nation.

Q.P: My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.HI: I have an entire Confidence in You, and have there∣fore nothing to ask, but that you would take such Mea∣sures as will best Secure your Religion and Liber∣ties: While you preserve those inestimable Blessings, I shall sit Easie and Safe on My Throne, having no other View but the Happiness and Prosperity of My People.

DIV2.P: According to the Contents of this Speech, the next Day the Letters of Count Gyllenborg were, by his Majesty's special Command, laid before the House of Commons, and were afterwards made Publick by the Order of the Government.

It would have been very necessary for the Infor∣mation of the Reader, and for convincing them more effectually of the Reality of this Conspiracy, which is so confidently ridiculed and denied: I say, it would have been very necessary to have transmit∣ted to Posterity the full Copies of these Letters at large; but the Brevity of these Annals will not per∣mit it.

The Addresses of both Houses to the King, in return to this Speech, tho' I have very little Room for such Things, cannot be omitted, because they shew how readily the Houses came into such Things as these, and that Readiness will occasion farther Speculations as I go on: The Addresses therefore, and Answers to them, are as follow, (viz.)

Q.P: The LORD's Address.
Most Gracious Sovereign,

WE your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal Sub∣jects, the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, beg leave to return your Maje∣sty our most humble and hearty Thanks for your Majesty's most gracious Speech from the Throne; and to congratulate your Majesty on your safe and happy Return to these your Dominions; and on the prudent Administration of his Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, under your Majesty, and the great Care he took of the Peace and Security of the Kingdom, during your Majesty's Absence.

We are sensible, that the gross Defects and perni∣cious Consequences of the late Treaty of Utrecht could not have been remedied, but by your Majesty's unweary'd Application for the Good of your Sub∣jects; and by that just Regard which is paid by Fo∣reign Potentates to your known Wisdom and Integrity. It is with unspeakable Satisfaction, that we see your Majesty's Endeavours Successful in such Conventi∣ons, as have already given new Life to our Trade and Credit; and particularly in the Treaty lately concluded with France and the States-General. As your Majesty has, by this Treaty, recovered to us, in so great a Measure, those Advantages, which might have been expected from a Glorious and Successful War, and were given up by a Treacherous and Dis∣honourable Peace; we beg Leave to congratulate your Majesty upon an Alliance, which opens to us so fair a Prospect of an undisturb'd Succession, an equal Balance of Power, and a flourishing Commerce.

P.HI: We return your Majesty our most humble Thanks for your Majesty's most gracious Condescension, in having laid before your Parliament the Discoveries concerning the intended Invasion; and cannot but regard, with the utmost Horror and Indignation, the Malice and Ingratitude of those, who have en∣courag'd such an Attempt against their King and Country.

Q.P: We are sorry to find, that your Majesty's Lenity has been ineffectual, towards reclaiming a Faction, who have render'd themselves so Obnoxious to your Justice; and We do assure your Majesty, that we will, to the utmost of our Power, support your Ma∣jesty against the design'd Invasion, and all your Ene∣mies, both at Home and Abroad, in such a manner, that, by the Blessing of Almighty God, neither the Rashness of the one, nor the Wickedness of the o∣ther, shall be ever able to prevail.
The King's Answer to this Address was as fol∣lows.
My Lords,

I Thank you for this Address, which is so full of Expressions of Duty to Me, and Zeal for your Country; and I make no doubt, but that, with your Support and Assistance, under God, We shall get the better of all Our Enemies, both at Home and Abroad.
The Commons Address is as follows:
Most Gracious Sovereign,

YOUR Majesty's Dutiful and Loyal Subjects, the Commons of Great-Britain in Parliament assem∣bled,
return your Majesty their humblest Thanks for your most gracious Speech from the Throne. Your Majesty's safe and happy Return into your Kingdoms, gave an universal Joy to all your People; and as the prudent Administration of the Government, by his Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, under your Ma∣jesty, did, in some degree, make the Want of your Royal Presence more easie to us, we beg leave to con∣gratulate your Majesty upon the Peace and Security, that, during your Majesty's Absence, was, by the great Care of his Royal Highness, preserv'd in the Kingdom, to the general Satisfaction of all your Sub∣jects. We can never sufficiently acknowledge the re∣peated Instances of your Majesty's Goodness, and un∣wearied Concern for the Welfare of your Kingdoms; We see with Admiration, many of the fatal Defects of the Treaties at Utrecht, and the great Disadvan∣tages that were imposed upon this Nation, at the Head of a victorious Army, and powerful Confedera∣cy, happily remedy'd by your Majesty, even in the midst of intestine Dangers and Troubles. Your con∣summate Wisdom has renewed those Alliances that were basely betray'd and dissolved, and concluded such new Treaties, as may render the Peace safe and lasting; and we are at a Loss to determine whether, in future Ages, the suffering the Demolition of the Port of Dunkirk to be scandalously evaded, will be a greater Reproach, or the procuring the Destruction of the Sluices of Mardyke, a greater Honour to the British Nation.

P.HI: We cannot at the same Time, but with the highest Resentment and Indignation, look upon the obstinate and inveterate Rancour of those, who are again en∣deavouring to embroil their native Country in Blood and Confusion: It is astonishing to find, that any,

who call themselves Protestants, can be so inflexible and restless in their Endeavours, to impose upon us a Popish Pretender, and rather venture to subject the Kingdom to a Foreign Yoke, than depart from their darling and avow'd Design of altering and sub∣verting the present happy Establishment in the Pro∣testant Succession. We adore the watchful Eye of Heaven, that has so wonderfully guarded and pro∣tected your sacred Person, and cannot too much ex∣tol the Wisdom and Vigilance that has been used, in so early and seasonably discovering this desperate Attempt: And in order most effectually to defeat it, your faithful Commons, with Hearts sincerely Zea∣lous in the Cause of their King and Country, as∣sure your Majesty that they will, to the utmost, stand by and support your Majesty against all your Enemies at Home and Abroad, that shall, in any manner, pre∣sume to aid and abet the Pretender to your Crown, and will most chearfully grant to your Majesty such Supplies as shall be found necessary for the Safety of your Royal Person, and the Defence of the King∣dom.

We are all but too sensible of the unsupportable Weight of the National Debts, and therefore will not neglect to apply our selves, with all possible Di∣ligence and Attention, to the great and necessary Work of reducing and lessening, by Degrees, this heavy Burthen, which may prove the most effectual Means of preserving to the Publick Funds a real and certain Security.

Q.P: To which Address the King was pleased to return the following Answer:
Gentlemen,

P.HI: THE Duty and Zeal, which you express in this Loyal Address, to my Person and Go∣vernment, your affectionate Concern for the Welfare of your Country, your Promises of an effectual Sup∣port against all our Enemies at Home and Abroad, and your Resolution of applying your selves to ease my People, by reducing gradually the heavy Load of the Publick Debts, deserves my hearty Thanks.
You shall never have Cause to repent of the Confi∣dence you repose in me: The Honour, Welfare, and Prosperity of the Nation being what I have chiefly at Heart.

DIV2.P: Whether the King of Sweden was Party to the Designs of his Ministers, as above, or not; a thing which has not since appear'd to me so plain as might be expected; I say, whether his Swedish Majesty was Party to it or not, the Resentment of the Parliament seem'd levell'd at him in Particular, in the very first Step the Parliament took in this Affair; for they immediately voted a Bill to be brought in, to empower the King to prohibit Com∣merce to Sweden.

This, I say, was, the next to arresting the Two Gentlemen, the first Act of Resentment shew'd on this Affair against Sweden as a Nation, and was carried with such Readiness and Alacrity in the Two Houses, that it was brought into the House but the d, and it receiv'd the Royal Assent the 27th; and immediately the King, by Proclamation, reciting the said Act, and the Reasons of it, prohi∣bited the Swedish Trade for a Year certain.

This Act being pass'd, the House meddled no more with it, but left it all in the Breast of the King, applying themselves to the more immediate Business of their Session, (viz.) raising Money, which was first by a Land Tax, which was settled at 3 s. per l.

It was observable that the Land Tax, which usually was pass'd before Christmas, being not now voted till the middle of March, the Publick Af∣fairs were in Danger of being put to some Streight for Money; that is to say, as to Time, whereupon the House passed a Resolution as follows.

Q.P: Resolv'd, Nemine Contradicente,

That whosoever shall advance, or lend any Sum, not exceeding Six Hundred Thousand Pounds, for the Service of the Publick by Sea or Land, shall be repaid the same with Interest at 4 per Cent. out of the first Aid to be granted this Session of Parlia∣ment.

DIV2.P:
This prov'd a wrong Step, for this Clause of ad∣vancing Money at 4 per Cent. Interest, put the Question out of all manner of Dispute among the Money'd Men, that Interest of Money would be reduced this Session to 4 per Cent. especially, that the Interest of the Funds would fall to 4 per Cent. and this put the City Misers, and the Money'd Men, into a terrible Fright; and in a Word, no Body, for some Time, brought any Money, that is, any Sums considerable upon the Credit of that Vote, nor did it at all answer the Expectations of the People who contrived it; and because this great Affair was now very quickly brought to a Conclusion, I shall put the whole Transaction of
it together: That the Reduction of the Interest of the Funds was projected, and Schemes for it prepar'd in the Treasury, Mr. Walpole, who was then first Commissioner, and therefore at the Head of that Affair, had publickly own'd and declared in the House, that by a fix'd Day he would make a Pro∣posal to the House for reducing the publick Debts.

In the mean Time the Discontents of the Peo∣ple about the Funds, and the Fears they were un∣der for their Properties, grew very popular, and Mr. L—mere proposed a Vote to the House, which whether it was ill-natur'd or not, as some said, or that it was pointed in particular at the Schemes which were preparing, I do not affirm; but had it pass'd as propos'd, Mr. Wa—le might have put an End to that Part of his Work: The Vote was this, (viz.) That this House will make good all Parliamen∣tary Engagements. Mr. W—le was too penetrating not to see what would be the Consequence of this Vote, and too ready in his Turns not to give it a Cast that quite overset the Design, (viz.) by mo∣ving that the Vote might pass, with the Addition of the Word Deficiencies; this was thought reason∣able, and so the Vote pass'd thus: Resolv'd, That this House will make good the Deficiencies of all Par∣liamentary Engagements.

This Addition entirely destroy'd and disarm'd the Motion it self, and yet it had the Effect it was mov'd for, (viz.) That it satisfy'd the People, that they should not have any unjust Invasion of their Proper∣ties; and so Mr. Wa—le went on as he began.

In the Interval, between this Vote and the Time Mr. Wa—le took to bring in his Scheme, the House ordered in An Account of the Publick Debts at the Exchequer, as they then stood, distinguishing what
the Funds were, when granted, how long since gran∣ted, what Term remain'd, how much the Original Principal Money was, how much had been since paid off, and how much remain'd, and what the Annual Interest was, that is paid or payable for the Principal Sums advanced: Which Account, three Days after, was laid before the Commons, by a Person from the Earl of Hallifax, Auditor of the Receipt at the Exchequer.

TABLE.HEAD: An ACCOUNT of the PUBLICK DEBTS at the ing what the Funds are, when granted, how the Original Principal Money was, how much has what the Annual Sums are that are paid or payable Interest, Exclusive of the Deficiencies of Parliamen

ROW.CELL: 10 l. Lottery, Michaelmas, Anno 1710. by way of Annuity.
Act of the 8th of Queen Anne, 9 l. per Cent.
Charges a Duty of 3 s. per Chaldron on Coals, and an additional Duty on Win∣dows, for the Term of 32 Years.
Act of the 9th of Queen Anne, 6 l. per Cent. and the Principal to be repaid,

Charges a Subsidy of Tonnage and Poundage upon Exported Goods from the 8th of March 1710, a Duty of 2 s. a Chaldron on Coals from the 8th of March 1710, an additional Duty of a Half-penny a pound on Tallow-Candles, and 4 d. a pound on Wax-Candles, from the 25th of March 1711, for the Term of 32 Years.
Another Act of the 9th of Queen Anne, 6 l. per Cent. and the Principal to be repaid.

Charges 700 l. a Week out of the Post-Office from Michaelmas 1711, the Duty on Leather, &c. 1 d. a pound from the 24th of June 1711, new Stamp Duty on Bills of Lading, Almanacks, Licences and Certificates, from the 1st of August 1711, Duty of 5 s. a Week on 800 Hack∣ney Coaches from the 24th of June 1715, and 10 s. per Annum on 200 Hackney Chairs from the 24th of June 1711, and a Duty of 6 d. a Pack on Cards. and 5 d. a Pair on Dice, from the 11th of June 1711, all for the Term of 32 Years.

TABLE.HEAD: EXCHEQUER as they now stand, distinguish∣long since granted, what Term remains, how much been since paid off, and how much remains; and for the Principal Sums advanc'd, with the Rate of tary Grants.

ROW.CELL: How much the Ori∣ginal Principal Mo∣ney was.
How much has been since paid off.
Act of the 10th of Queen Anne, 6 l. per Cent. and the Principal to be repaid.

Charges the Duty of 1 d. a Pound on Soap from the 10th of June, 1712; 15 s. per Centum ad valorem on Foreign print∣ed, painted, or stained Linen; 6 d. a Yard on Silks; 3 d. a Yard on Callicoes, and 2 d. a Yard on Linen and Stuffs printed, painted, and stained in Britain, from the 20th of July 1712: Several Du∣ties on Paper, Pastboard, and Books, from the 24th of June 1712; a new Stamp Duty on Surrenders; 2 s. 3 d. on every Transfer of Stock in any Compa∣ny, and the Stamp Duty on News-Pa∣pers, &c. from the 1st of August 1712, all for the Term of 32 Years.
Another Act of the 10th of Queen Anne, 6 l. per Cent. and the Principal to be repaid.

Charges the additional Duty of a Half-penny a Pound on Leather from the 1st of August 1712; 1 s. a Pound on Cof∣fee; 2 s. a Pound on Tea, and 20 l. per Cent. ad Valorem on Drugs from the 1st of August 1712: Duty of 8 d. an Ounce on Gilt Wire, and 6 d. an Ounce on Sil∣ver Wire Imported from the 1st of July 1712; and a Duty of 2 s. 4 d. upon Po∣licies of Insurance, &c. all for the Term of 32 Years.
How much the Origi∣nal Principal Money was.
How much has been since paid off.
By Letters Patents of the 13th of October 1713, and by an Act of the 11th of Queen Ann, 4 l. per Cnt. the Principal to be repaid.
Charges the Civil List Revenues with the Annual Sums of 35000 l. for the Term of 32 Years.
Act of the 12th of Queen Anne, and 1st of King George.
and the Principal to be repaid.

Charges a Duty of 1 d. a Pound on Fo∣reign Soap, and a Half-penny a Pound on Soap made in Great-Britain from the 2d of Augut 1714; additional Duty on Paper, &c. from the same Time; Coals Exported on Foreign Bottoms, 5 s. a Chaldron, and on British Bottoms 3 s. a Chaldron; and the Deficiency to be yearly computed at Michaelmas, and to be made good out of any unappropri∣ated Money, for the Term of 32 Years.
How much the Ori∣ginal Principal Mo∣ney was.
How much has been since paid off.
For the Bank upon their Annuities.
Act of the 5th and 6th of King William and Queen Mary.

Charges five seventh parts of the se∣cond additional 9 d. per Barrel Excise, for raising 1200000 l. granting to all Per∣sons Liberty to subscribe any Sum, not exceeding 2000 l. in one Name, for which an Annuity of 100000 l. shall be paid, and the Subscribers be incorpo∣rated by the Name of the Governour and Company of the Bank of England, from the 1 st of August 1694, to the 1st of August 1705. when, upon a Year's Notice, and Repayment of the Capital, the Corporation to cease.
And by an Act of the 7th of Queen Anne, 6 l. per Cent.

The Bank lent 400000 l. more without any additional Interest, (that is to say) they reduced the Interest of their primi∣tive Stock from 8 l. to 6 l. per Cent. which with 4000 l. per Ann. for Management, fills up the Original 100000 l. Annuity, this 400000 l. and the 1200000 l. to be repaid before the Corporation be dis∣solved.
How much the Ori∣ginal Principal Mo∣ney was.
How much has been since paid off.
Act of the 5th of Queen Anne, 4l. 10 s. per Cent.

Charges the Duty upon Houses or Windows from the 1st of August 1710, for ever, for raising 1500000 l. by issu∣ing Exchequer Bills to that Value; by this Act, the Bank undertook to circu∣late these Bills upon the Consideration of 4 l. 10 s. per Cent. per Annum, and Ex∣chequer Bills to be issued for the Inte∣rest till the Fund commences.
