The Bank to remain a Corporation till the Bills be redeemed.
And by another Act of the 7th of Queen Anne, 6 l. per Cent.

It was enacted, That the Bank should pay off and cancel all the Exchequer Bills before extant. which amounted to 1775027 17 s. upon allowing 6 l. per Cent. Interest for that Sum; to which purpose an Annuity was establish'd of 106501 17 6 to be paid to the Bank out of the Duty aforesaid, until the Principal be paid off upon a Year's Notice.
Several Acts of the 7th and 12th of Queen Anne,
Grants 4676812 l. 12 2. by issuing Ex∣chequer Bills.
Act of the 1st of King George. 7 l. 4 s. o d. Three Farthings, per Cent.
The Fund for these Exchequer Bills in the General or Aggregate Funds.
How much the Ori∣ginal Principal Mo∣ney was.
How much has been since paid off.
Two Acts of the 9th of King William,

Grant additional Duties on Stamp Pa∣per and Parchment from the 1st of Au∣gust 1698, and a Duty of 28 s. per Bush∣el on Salt from 1698 and 1699 for ever; both these Duties are given for 160000 l. per Annum, to raise by Subscriptions 2000000 l. at 8 l. per Cent. per Annum; the Subscribers to have the sole Liberty of Trading to the East-Indies; redeemable upon Payment of the Principal, and three Years Notice after Michaelmas 1711.
By one Act of the 6th of Queen Anne, 5 l. per Cent.

It is enacted, That the East-India Company shall pay into the Exche∣quer 1200000 l. to have their 8 l. per Cent. granted them in the 9th of King William reduced to 5 l. per Cent. per An∣num, and to have the Trade to India con∣tinued to them solely to Lady-Day 1726; this, together with the former Sum ad∣vanced, with all Arrears of the 160000 l to be repaid before the Company should be determined.
By the Act of the 10th of Queen Anne.

The Corporation of the East-India Company and their sole Trade made perpetual, but the Fund may be redeem∣ed upon 3 Years Notice after the 25th of March 1733, upon repayment, by Par∣liament, what is due to such Compa∣nies as shall be then entituled thereunto.
How much the Ori∣ginal Principal Money was.
How much has been since paid off.
Two Acts of the 9th and 10th of Queen Anne, and 1 Act of the 1st of King George, 6 l. per Cent.

600000 l. per Annum is charg'd upon several Duties, Impositions, &c. to the South-Sea Company, and 8000 l. per An∣num for Management, for paying the In∣terest of 10000000 l. at 6 per Cent. per Annum; the Company to continue for ever, but the Annual Sum of 608000 l. to cease upon a Year's Notice after the 25th of December 1716, repaying what shall then be due to the Company.
Annuities 14l. per Cent. 25 Jan. 1692 afterwards turn'd into a certain Term of 99 Years.
Years Purchase. Act of the 4th of King William and Queen Mary, and of the 7th, 9th, 10th, 11th of King William, and 1st of Queen Anne. 11 Years and half, 12 Years, 11 Years, and 25 Years.
Grants 9 d. per Barrel Excise upon Beer, Ale, and other Liquors, for the Term of 99 Years.
Act of the 4th of King William and Queen Mary, 7 l. per Cent.

The same 9 d. is charg'd with a far∣ther Sum on the Benefit of Survivor∣ship, till the Number of Survivors be reduced to 7, and then the Share or 7th Part of each of them as they die to re∣vert to the Crown.
How much the Ori∣ginal Principal Mo∣ney was.
How much has been since paid off.
Act of the 5th of King William and Queen Mary, and of the 7th, 9th, 10th, 11th, of King William, and 1st of Queen Anne.

Grants two seventh Parts of a 9 d. per Barrel Excise to Subscribers for raising 300000 l. in Annuities, from the 29th of September 1694, at the rate of 14 per Cent. on one Life, 12 per Cent. on two Lives, or 10 per Cent. on three Lives, which was thus advanced.
A half, 12 Years, 11 Years and 11 Years.
Afterwards by subse∣quent Acts the full Term for 96 Years is given to the Purchasers, and ac∣cordingly the Reversi∣on of 1 Life was made up to that Term, for which there was paid

The Contributors of the 2 and 3 Lives did not purchase the Re∣mainder. And in the Year 172, it appear'd, there was fallen into the Crown of the 2 and 3 Lives, 565 l. per Ann. which by an Act then pass'd were sold for 15 Years Purchase. which produced
much the Ori∣ginal Principal Mo∣ney was.
How much has been since paid off.
There is so many of the Contributors dead of the 2 and 3 Lives, which abates the an∣nual Charge—
So the present Annual Charge for all these Annuities is—
Annuities on 3700l. per Week Ex∣cise, Lady-Day, 1704.
Act of the 2d of Queen Anne, 15 Years,
Charges the 3700l. a Week issuing out of the Hereditary and Temporary Excise, for the Term of 99 Years.
Act of the 3d of Queen Anno, 15 Years,
Charges the same 3700 l. a Week Excise, for 99 Years.
Act of the 12th of King William, 6 l. per Cent.
Charges the same 3700 l. a Week Excise with Bankers Annuities, redeem∣able by Parliament, on Payment of a Moiety of the said Principal, which is
Act of the 4th of Queen Anne, 15 Years and a half,
Grants one third additional Customs of Tonnage and Poundage, and the third additional 9 d per Barrel Excise upon Beer, Ale, &c. for 99 Years.
How much the Ori∣ginal Principal Mo∣ney was.
How much has been since paid off.
Act of the 5th of Queen Anne, 16 Years,

Grants Duties on Low Wines from the 23d of June 1710, for 96 Years, ad∣ditional Duty on Stamp Paper and Vel∣lum, from the last of July 1710, for 96 Years; Duty of Hawkers and Pedlars from the 23d of June 1710, for 96 Years; Duty on Sweets for 99 Years, from the 24th of March 1707; and the additio∣nal Customs of Tonnage and Poundage granted in the 4th of the Queen, for 98 Years, continued one Year more af∣ter that Term, the Overplus of the An∣nuity Fund granted in the 4th of the Queen, computed at Lady Day yearly, or within 6 Days after, for 99 Years.
40000 l. per Annum Annuities. March 25, Anno 1708.
Act of the 6th of Queen Anne, 16 Years,

Charges the Overplus of the Annui∣ty Funds before-mentioned, granted in the 4th and 5th of the Queen, to be computed at Lady-Day yearly, as also the Overplus of the first 9 d. Excise, granted from the 25th of January 1692, after the 29th of September 1710, to be computed at Midsummer yearly, for 99 Years.
How much the Origi∣nal Principal Money was.
How much has been since paid off.
80000 l. per Annum Annuities, 24 June, Anno 1708.
Another Act of the 6th of Queen Anne, 16 Years.

Charges one Moiety, or half Part of the old Subsidy of Tonnage and Poundage upon Wines, Goods and Mer∣chandizes, for 96 Years, from the 31st of July 1712, the intermediate Interest was supply'd out of the Purchase Mo∣ney, and also by an Act of the 10th of the Queen, out of several unappropri∣ated Branches of the Revenue for 99 Years.
Annuities, at 9 l. per Cent. 25 March, 1710.
Act of the 8th of Queen Anne, 9 l. per Cent.

Charges 3 d. a Barrel on Beer, Ale, and other Liquors, 18 d. a Pound on Pepper, 5 s. per 100 l. Weight on Rai∣sins, a double Duty on Nutmegs and other Spices. 3 s. a Pound on Snuff, from the 6th of February 1709, and if there be a Deficiency, to be supply'd out of the Duty on Coals and Window Tax, for 32 Years.
How much the Ori∣ginal Principal Mo∣ney was.
How much has been since paid off.
Two Acts of the 1st of King George, 5 l. per Cent.

Charges the General or Aggregate Fund, after the Interest and Allowan∣ces, to Exchequer Bills, and after 120000 l. for his Majesty's Civil Go∣vernment, with these Annuities pay∣able at the Bank of England at 5 l. per Cent. per Annum, redeemable by Parlia∣ment.

DIV2.P: ABSTRACT.

P.HI: Exchequer,
JOS. FOX.

ROW.CELL: How much the Ori∣ginal Principal Money was.
How much has been since paid off.

DIV2.P: Upon the Day appointed, Mr. Walpole brought in his Scheme for the reducing the Debts, and ha∣ving in the mean time negotiated with the Bank and the South-Sea Company, to perform their Parts if required, he presented it to the House, and had it debated at large; the Scheme indeed met with some Opposition, and, as is often the Case in other Things, more perhaps from those who did not un∣derstand it, than from those who did: However in the End the House came into it, and from thence proceeded the Reductions which now take Place, and which are express'd in the following Vote.

I. That all the Publick Funds, redeemable by Law, that do not exceed 5 l. per Cent. per Ann. be redeemed according to the respective Proviso's or Clauses of Redemption, contained in the Acts of Parliament for that Purpose, or (with Consent of the Proprietors) be converted into an Interest or Annuity, not exceeding 5 l. per Cent. per An∣num, redeemable by Parliament.

II. That His Majesty be enabled to borrow of any Person or Persons, Bodies Politick or Corporate, such Sum or Sums of Money as shall be requisite to redeem the said redeemable Funds, at any Rate, not exceeding 5 l. per Cent. per Annum, and to secure the same upon the Funds so to be redeemed.

III. That the Annuity of 106, 501 l. 10 s. 5 d. per Annum, payable to the Governour and Com∣pany of the Bank of England, out of the House-Money, by virtue of several Acts of Parliament in that Behalf, for the Principal Sum of 1, 775, 027 l 17 s. 10 d. Half-penny, by them advanced, be re∣deemed, or (by Consent of the said Governour and converted into an Interest or Annuity
not to exceed 5 l. per Cent. per Annum, redeem∣able by Parliament.

IV. That so much of the Fund, commonly called the Aggregate Fund, settled by an Act of Parlia∣ment in the first Year of the Reign of his present Majesty, as is applicable to the Interest, Circulati∣on, Exchanging or Cancelling the present Exchequer Bills, be also redeemed.

V. That his Majesty be enabled to authorize the High-Treasurer, or the Commissioners of the Trea∣sury for the Time being, to treat and agree with a∣ny Person or Persons, Bodies Politick or Corporate, for circulating such a Number of Exchequer Bills, at a Rate not exceeding 4 l. 10 s. per Cent. per Annum, for Interest, Exchanging, and Circulati∣on, as may be charged and secured upon that Part of the said Aggregate Fund so to be redeemed.
VI. That the Annuities of 600, 000 l. and 8000 l. per Annum, payable to the Governour and Company of Merchants of Great-Britain, Trading to the South-Sea, be also redeemed.

VII. That the Annuities payable by an Act of Par∣liament of the Twelfth Year of the Reign of King William (of glorious Memory) to certain Patentees therein named, their Heirs and Assigns, out of the Weekly Sum of 3700 l. charged on the Excise, be also redeemed.

VIII. That the several Terms of Years remain∣ing in the Duties appropriated by the Two Lottery-Acts, made and passed in the Ninth Year of the Reign of her late Majesty Queen Anne (of blessed Memory) and by the Two Lottery-Acts made and passed in the Tenth Year of her late Majesty's Reign, be made Perpetual.
IX. That the said Duties, comprehended in the said Four Lottery-Acts, be made one general Fund for the Future.

X. That the Proprietors of the Orders grounded on the said Lottery-Acts, do, within a limited Time, make their Elections, either to accept An∣nuities after the Rate of 5 l. per Cent. per An∣num, redeemable by Parliament, out of such gene∣ral Fund, or be paid so much as remains due to them on their Orders respectively.

XI. That in all Cases where the Proprietors shall chuse to have their Principal, the 5 l. per Cent. per Annum saved thereby, be made another Fund, towards answering such Sums of Money as shall be advanced (towards discharging the said Principal) by Loans, or other Securities, as shall be thought proper.

XII. That his Majesty be enabled to give Power for receiving voluntary Subscriptions from any Person or Persons entituled to any of the Annuities issuing out of the Publick Funds, for the Residue of the respective Terms of 99, 96, 89, or 32 Years, formerly purchased therein, (not being subject to Redemption) who shall be willing to accept, in lieu thereof, perpetual Annuities redeemable by Parlia∣ment, and to allow for the remaining Terms in the said Annuities, which were purchased for 99, 96, or 89 Years, (at the Election of the respective Sub∣scribers) either so much as the same Annuities shall amount to at 19 Years Purchase, to be made good by new Annuities of 4 l. per Cent. per Annum, re∣deemable by Parliament, or 17 Years and a half Purchase, to be made good by new Annuities of 5 l. per Cent. per Annum, to be redeemable in like manner; and to allow for the remaining Terms in the said Annuities, which were purchased for 32
Years (at the Election of the respective Subscribers) either so much as the same Annuities shall amount to at 14 Years and a half Purchase, to be made good by new Annuities of 4 l. per Cent. per Annum, redeemable by Parliament, or 13 Years and a half Purchase, to be made good by Annuities of 5 l. per Cent. per Annum, redeemable in like manner, and that the said New Annuities shall be settled and secured accordingly.

XIII. That all Savings that shall arise upon any of the present Funds, by the proposed Redemptions or Reductions, be reserv'd and apply'd, after all Deficiencies that may happen upon any of the said Funds are made good, towards discharging and re∣ducing the National Debt.
XIV. That all the said Duties now in being, or to be continued, shall immediately cease and deter∣mine, after the said National Debt, and all Inte∣rest due thereupon, is discharged and paid off.

These Votes give us a full View of that Affair, and the Acts of Parliament subsequent to them, which are to be found upon Record, will fully in∣form those who are curious to enquire farther; and thus this troublesome Affair was ended, to the general Satisfaction.

As for the Disputes which happen'd about a far∣ther Reduction of Forces, and the Regulation of those which were to be kept on Foot, they did indeed stir a little; but the Affair of the Swedish Invasion, which was now upon the Anvil, silenc'd all those Things for this Session, we shall hear more of them in the next: I will not justify the Words of those who ventur'd to talk as if that were one of the Causes of bringing it upon the Stage.

But Debates of another Nature came upon the Stage, in which the Ministers so unhappily clash'd with one another, as reviv'd all the Strife mention'd before, and entirely broke the Harmony of the pub∣lick Measures for a while.
It was on the 3d of April, when the King sent the following Message to the House of Commons.
GEORGE R.

HIS Majesty being desirous, above all Things, not only to secure his Kingdoms against the present Danger, with which they are threaten'd from Sweden, but likewise to prevent, as far as is possible, the like Apprehensions for the future, thinks it necessary, that such Measures should be early con∣certed with other Princes and States, as may con∣duce most effectually to this End.

P.HI: And as this may require some Expence, His Ma∣jesty hopes that his Commons will, by their Assi∣stance at this Juncture, enable Him to make good such Engagements, as may case his People of all future Charge and Apprehensions upon this Ac∣count.

DIV2.P:
This Message gave Ground of new Contention, and occasion'd very warm Debates, too long to be set down at large, but the Substance of the Objecti∣ons was, that the manner of demanding it without communicating the particular Uses to which it was to be appropriated, was unparliamentary; it was alledg'd, that as they were entrusted to give the Peoples Money for the Publick Occasions, so they could not answer it, as to the Trust their Country reposed in them, to give away that Mo∣ney without knowing what the Occasion was; and indeed, this Argument went a great Way, and
brought some into the Question, who it was not thought could have joined with that Party upon any Account whatever; and tho' it was answered, that there were good Reasons why the Terms of the Alliances to be made, could not safely be Com∣municated; and that to make the Measures pub∣lick, was, in the Nature of the Thing, to destroy them; yet even this did not satisfie: It was then urged, that the King was a Prince of that Integri∣ty and Honour, and had given such convincing Proofs of his disinterested Concern for the true Inte∣rest of the People of Great-Britain in general, and for their Liberties and Privileges in particular, that they could not scruple to depend, in a Matter of this Nature, upon his Majesty's Justice and Pru∣dence in general, as well as upon his Care for the Nation in particular, and that his Majesty had many ways merited such a Trust as this at their Hands.

But to this a Medium was proposed, viz. to pass a Vote in general Terms, viz. That the House would effectually make good all such Alliances and Engagements as his Majesty should think fit to enter into for the publick Safety of his Dominions: And this was urg'd against the Argument above, of de∣pending upon his Majesty's Integrity and Honour, viz. That such a Vote was a Testimony of their entire Dependence upon the Honour and Integrity of his Majesty, and that in so high a manner, as that more could not be desired of them, and that his Majesty could have no reason to distrust his faithful Commons making good such a Vote.

It would be endless to repeat the Particulars of all the Arguments warmly urged on both sides on this extraordinary Occasion. But upon the whole, it is to be observ'd, that this Question not only di∣vided
the House, but divided the Court, and that to a surprizing Degree, and it was taken notice of in the House; for when one of the contrary Party had in a long Speech insisted, that it was Unpar∣liamentary to grant Money before the Occasion of it was known, and an Estimate of the particular Expence to which it was to be appropriated was laid before the House, he concluded, That the Mes∣sage was so strange in it self, that even the Mini∣stry themselves were unhappily divided about it, and knew not whether they had best be for it, or against it.

And indeed, this was the Difficulty which principally prevented the better receiving this Mes∣sage, and caused a great Party to join in the Oppo∣sing it, who were otherwise very hearty in the King's Interest, and upon all Occasions had shewn themselves so; and in this wrong Step began the Discovery of all the ill Blood that was afterwards found to be among the Statesmen, and which cau∣sed that great Turn at Court, of which we are go∣ing to speak.

And First, It was found that Mr. Walpole, tho' he had always strenuously push'd on the King's In∣terest in every thing, and had been a zealous Asser∣ter of the Protestant Succession, against all that had formerly opposed it, yet in this he seemed at a full stop, and appearing cold and silent in the hot∣test of the Debate, gave every one room to judge, that he was against the Thing; tho' when the Que∣stion was put, he could not decline giving his Vote in favour of it: Even the Speaker of the House al∣so seemed to be on the other side, and in the Com∣mittee spoke against the Thing, as it was stated; being, as he said, not against the Supply, but against
the Demanding and Granting it in such an unparlia∣mentary Manner.

Nor indeed was it possible to prevent a great ma∣ny other Gentlemen, who were otherwise entirely well affected, and even devoted to the present Settle∣ment, from falling in with that popular Notion, of its being Unparliamentary; so that when it came to be put to the Question in the Committee of the whole House, it pass'd by a Majority of but 15 Voices, viz. Yeas 164. Noes 149.
The Vote that was put and pass'd was in the following Terms: viz.

P.Q: Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, that a Sum not exceeding Two Hundred and Fifty Thousand Pounds be granted to His Majesty, to enable His Majesty to concert such Measures with Foreign Princes and States, as may prevent any Charge and Apprehension from the Designs of SWEDEN for the future.

DIV2.P: Nor was this all, for when it was reported by the Chairman, and came again to be Debated in the House, the Struggle was yet harder: And the Question, whether the House should agree with the Committee, was carried but by 4 Voices, viz. Yeas 153, Noes 149. So that it seem'd to be a Point gain'd with the utmost Difficulty, and the Consequences of bringing up a Party so near to an Equality with the Interest of the Government, were threatning enough.

In the Debates of this Affair, the future Mea∣sures took their Rise, and the King seem'd resolv'd to let some People know his Mind upon it; for the next Morning Mr Secretary St inhope, by particular Command, let the Lord Townshend know, that he
had no farther Occasion for his Service as Lord Lieutenant of Ireland; and this is the last Time our Annals will find this noble Person at Court. But this was but a bare opening of the Scene, for as the King sent this Person Word he had no farther Occasion of his Service, other Gentlemen prevented the Government as it were, and sent Word they had no farther Occasion to serve, that is to say, gave up or quitted their Employments; these were they who were afterward call'd the Resigners: The first of these was Mr. Walpole himself, Mr. Methuen Secretary of State, Mr. Pulteney Secretary of War, and several others follow'd this Example: It is too long to enter into the Particulars of this Part, or state the Case of every particular Person, with the supposed Reasons of their Conduct; 'tis enough to Record here the Names of those which resign'd or were dismiss'd, and the Names of those who succeed in their Places; of the first were these, viz.

LIST.ITEM: Lord Viscount Townshend, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, &c.
The whole Commission of the Treasury dis∣solv'd.
The whole Commission of the Admiralty dis∣solv'd.
Mr. Methuen, one of the Secretaries of State.
Mr. Horatio Walpole, Secretary of the Trea∣sury.
Mr. Baber, Comptroller of the First Fruits.
Duke of Devonshire, Lord President of the Council.
Earl of Dorset and Middlesex, Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports.

LIST.HEAD: The Names of the Persons particularly advanc'd upon this Occasion were these.
LIST.ITEM: Duke of Bolton, Lord Lieutenant General, and General Governour of Ireland.
Duke of Newcastle, Lord Chamberlain of the Houshold.
Earl of Sunderland, Secretary of State.
Jos. Addison, Esq Secretary of State.

LIST.HEAD: The new Commission of the Treasury.
LIST.ITEM: The Right Honourable James Stanhope, Esq first Commissioner and Chancellor of the Ex∣chequer.

LIST.HEAD: The new Commission of the Admiralty.
LIST.ITEM: The Right Honourable the Earl of Berkley.
James Craggs, Jun. Secretary of War.
Charles Stanhope, Esq Secretary of the Treasury with Mr. Lowndes.
Matth. Ducy Moreton, Esq under Treasurer of Ireland.

—Tilson, and Charles De-la-fay, under Secretaries to my Lord Sunderland.

Earl of Romney, Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports.
Earl of Haddingtoun, made Governour of Edin∣burgh Castle in Scotland.

DIV2.P: Upon these Removes it appear'd necessary to grant the House a short Recess, and particularly, there being so many Men advanc'd to publick Employ∣ment, who were Members of the House, and who could not sit again in the House unless they were Re-elected, it was needful to give them some Time to form their Interests in the Country, and be cho∣sen again, as most of them indeed were; for this, and perhaps other Reasons less Publick, the King ordered Mr. Stanhope to acquaint the House, that it being his Majesty's Pleasure that the Parliament should be adjourn'd, his Majesty desir'd that they would adjourn themselves to the 18th of May. This was the 16th of April, so that the Recess was much longer than was expected, being a full Month.

This Recess of the Parliament, gives us room to bring forward the Story of what other material Affairs occurr'd, as well before, as during this time,
that things may be carried on Hand in Hand, one with another, in the same order of Time as they happen'd.

All this while, the Preparations for a vigorous Dealing with the Swedes went on; the Fleet, which was determined to be sent to the Baltick, began to be ready, and the 2d of April set Sail with a fair Wind, under the Command of Sir George Bing, and arriv'd the 12th in the Sound, in all, 33 Sail.

And here it is to be noted, that by the late Trea∣ty of Alliance with France, one of the Particulars stipulated in the Alliance was, that the Regent of France should undertake to remove the Pretender from Avignon, where he had resided for some time, indeed for almost all the Time since his Retreat from Scotland. This was done publickly by the Regent, and not without some ill Nature and Re∣sentment on both Sides; for the Regent insisted that he should Remove, and the Chevalier refused a good while, and at last comply'd with Reluctance; nor perhaps had not remov'd at all, but by Force, if the Regent had not plough'd with the Heifer, and used some such Arguments with the Queen Dowager, as obliged her to write to the Chevalier to dispute it no longer; in which Particular the Regent shew'd, that he knew how to manage that Affair in a Manner, that he was sure would not be opposed.

The Journal of Circumstances of his Removal are publick, but need not to be reported here at large; this being not a History of the Chevalier, but of King George, it is sufficient to observe, that he removed from Avignon the 6th of February, with a Retinue of about 30 Persons; he had a Captain with a Troop of Dragoons, appointed by the Re∣gent to attend him thro' the Territories of France,
and also four Commissaries, who were order'd to defray their Expences, which was done till he pass'd the Pont à Voisin, being the Bridge which parts or rather joins the Dominions of France to those of Savoy, where the French Officer, having Votaries with him, took proper Instruments of Protest, with Witnesses, that the Chevalier, with all his Retinue, were pass'd the said Pont à Voisin, the 17th, into the Dutchy of Savoy, and on the Road to Cham∣berry; from hence he travel'd on thro' the Duke of Savoy's Dominions into those of the Pope, where he still remains, and where I shall have occasion to speak of him again.

I return now in the Course of Story to the Affairs of Sweden, and the Alarm given here upon that Occasion, the Troops the King had on Foot were very considerable, no less than 27000 Men, and up∣on this Occasion were fill'd up and encreased consi∣derably, and a Fleet was fitted out with such Expe∣dition, that 30 Men of War were ready to put to Sea, and did put to Sea by the 2d of April, no Swedes nor any one else being in any Posture to op∣pose them, nor when they came to the Sound did they find any Fleets prepared, or Army embarking, or indeed any visible Appearance of an Enemy to oppose them.

Upon this News the Hurry went over, the Con∣sternation abated, and repeated Assurances coming over every Day that the Danger was all over, the King resolved to reduce his Army, and to grant the long expected Act of Clemency which so many wanted, and which the several Disorders mention'd had caused to be so often delay'd; all which is fully express'd in the King's Speech which he made to the Parliament, when they return'd after their Ad∣journment above-mention'd: The Speech is as fol∣lows.

Q.P: My Lords and Gentlemen,

IT is with great Satisfaction, that, after this short Recess, I can acquaint you with the certain Advice I have received, that my Fleet is safely ar∣rived in the Sound, which, by the Blessing of Al∣mighty God, will secure these Kingdoms against any immediate Danger of an Invasion.

P.HI: I have, by this means, an Opportunity, which is very acceptable to me, of making a considerable Re∣duction in our Land-Forces, having establish'd it as a Rule with my Self, to consult the Ease of my Peo∣ple in every Thing, so far as is consistent with their Safety. And for my own part, as I shall always place my Greatness in the Prosperity of my Sub∣jects, so I shall always desire, that my Power may be founded in their Affections.
It is upon these Considerations, that I have given Orders for the immediate Reducing of Ten Thousand Men.

That nothing may be wanting in me to quiet the Minds of all my Subjects, I have likewise given Di∣rections to prepare an Act of Grace; and however it may be received by those who are obstinately bent on the Ruin of their Country, I promise my self, that it will raise a due Sense of Gratitude in all such as have been artfully misled into Treasonable Practices against my Person and Government, and preserve them from standing in need of the like Mercy for the future, when such an Instance of Clemency may not be so expedient for the Publick Welfare, as it would be agreeable to my own Inclinations.

Q.P: Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

P.HI: I thank you for your readiness to Support me in the present Juncture of Affairs, and for the Supplies
which you have given me, and do promise you, that they shall be employ'd for the Ʋses to which you de∣sign'd them.

I shall order such faithful Accounts to be laid before you the next Session, as will make it appear, there was no other View in asking any particular Supply, than to prevent a much greater Expence, which the Nation must have unavoidably incurred without it.
I must recommend to you, as I did at the Beginning of the Session, to take all proper Methods for Re∣ducing the Publick Debts, with a just Regard to Par∣liamentary Credit.

Q.P: My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.HI: The Year being so far advanced, I hope you will go through the Publick Business with all possible Dis∣patch and Ʋnanimity, it being my Intention to meet you early the next Winter, that the Sitting of Par∣liament may be brought into the more usual and con∣venient Season.

DIV2.P: The Addresses and Answers which follow'd this Speech, being Matters of meer Form, I omit as not material to the Story, and to be found in the Votes of this Session.

At the same Time the Parliament was sitting here, the General Assembly was conven'd in Scotland; but when I have noted, that the Earl of Rothes was Commissioner, that he went down, deliver'd the King's Letter, open'd the Assembly the 2d of May with a Speech, received an Answer the 4th to the King, and closed the Assembly with another Speech the 16th: I say, when this is said, I think every thing of Moment which pass'd there is sufficiently mention'd.

In the mean Time, a new Broil agitated the House of Commons for some Days, and raised great Heats among the Members; this related to General Cado∣gan, about the Expence of bringing over the 6000 Men, which the Dutch lent his Majesty against the Rebellion, the Transporting these Men, it seems, cost the Government 11000l. whereas they were ship'd back again for less than a 4th Part of the Mo∣ney: This Question was argued warmly, and the extravagant Sum was accounted for, only by the Haste and Hurry of getting the Men over, the length of their March, and the difficulty of getting Ships to Transport them at so short a Warning: However, it was pass'd over, and the Committee coming to no Resolution, the Speaker resumed the Chair, so that it was not so much as mention'd in the Votes, or taken Notice of, that any such thing had been debated in the House.

The House had now little Business before them but that of the Money, and as the Payment of the Publick Debts was the great Thing in View, so the Manner of doing it for this Year, is best understood by the Proposals negotiated, as I had observ'd be∣fore, by the Bank and South-Sea Company, and by which the Government was enabled to have answer'd the Demands of the Proprietors of the Funds, whose Interest was to be reduced, if they had come for their Money. These Proposals therefore, being with a very little Variation accepted and enacted, it is ve∣ry proper to record them here, that they may be of use to those Readers, who cannot on all Occasions have Recourse to the Acts themselves: The Propo∣sals are as follow, (viz.)

DIV3.P: The Governour and Company of Merchants of Great-Britain, Trading to the South-Seas, and other Parts of America, and for encou∣raging the Fishery, having under their Con∣sideration, how they may be most servicea∣ble to His Majesty and his Government, and to shew their Zeal and Readiness to concur in the Great and Honourable Design of Re∣ducing the National Debts, in such manner as may be consistent with, and for the Sup∣port of Parliamentary Credit, do humbly propose,

I. THAT they will be content, and do submit, that their present Capital Stock of Ten Millions, be encreased to the Sum of Twelve Mil∣lions, either by Subscription or otherwise, as by their General Court shall be thought most expedient.

II. That the Two Millions so to be advanced, shall be paid into his Majesty's Exchequer by Four equal Payments, the last whereof to be on or before the 24th of December next, and shall be employed towards Redeeming the Principal and Interest charged on the Four Lottery Acts of 1711, and 1712; and the Annuities of Three Pounds per Cent. paya∣ble for the Bankers Debt contracted in the Reign of Charles II. and not otherwise.

III. That the present Annual Sums of 600, 000 l. and 8000 l. payable to the Company, be continued to them, for and in respect of their said Ten Mil∣lions, until the Twenty-fourth of June, One Thou∣sand Seven Hundred and Eighteen; and that for the Two Millions to be advanced as aforesaid, there shall be allowed to the Company an Annuity, after the Rate of Five Pounds per Cent. per Annum,
from the respective Times of Payment thereof into the Exchequer, until the said Twenty-fourth of June, One Thousand Seven Hundred and Eigh∣teen.

IV. That from and after the said Twenty-fourth of June, One Thousand Seven Hundred and Eigh∣teen, there be payable to the Company, by Weekly Payments, as the Funds shall produce, an Annual Sum of Six Hundred Thousand Pounds, being af∣ter the Rate of Five Pounds per Cent. per An∣num for the whole Twelve Millions, together with their present Allowance of Eight Thousand Pounds per Annum, to continue until redeemed by Parlia∣ment, as herein after is mentioned.

V. That the present Duties and Revenues charge∣able with the Payment of the present Annual Sum of Six Hundred Thousand Pounds, and Eight Thousand Pounds, together with such Duties and Revenues as shall be redeemed by the said Two Mil∣lions to be advanced as aforesaid, shall be continued and made the Fund for, and chargeable with the Payment of the several Annuities, which, pursuant to this Proposal, shall become due or payable to the Company, and with all Arrears thereof, incurr'd and to be incurr'd, and that the Surplus of all the said Duties and Revenues, after such Payment to the Company as aforesaid, shall be apply'd and appro∣priated for and towards paying and discharging some other of the present National Debts.

VI. That the Sums unpaid, charged on the ge∣neral Mortgage, One Thousand Seven Hundred and Ten, which is part of the Company's present Funds, be paid out of the Aggregate Fund, to arise out of the Savings of the several Funds which shall be redeemed or reduced this Session.

VII. That all Transfers of the Company's pre∣sent and increased Capital Stock, shall be free and exempt from any farther Duties than the Transfers are at present subject to by Parliament; and that their present and increased Capital and Stock in Trade be exempt from all Taxes and Impositions whatsoever.

VIII. The Company do submit, That the said Annual Sum of Six Hundred Thousand Pounds for the said Twelve Millions, and the said Annual Sum of Eight Thousand Pounds, may be redeemable by Parliament upon a Year's Notice to be given by Authority of Parliament, on any of the Four usual Quarterly Feast Days in the Year, after the Twenty fourth of June, One Thousand Seven Hundred and Twenty five; and upon Payment to the said Go∣vernour and Company of the said Capital Sum of Twelve Millions, and all Arrears of the said An∣nual Sums of Six Hundred Thousand Pounds, and Eight Thousand Pounds.
By Order of the General Court of the afore∣said Governour and Company, May the 10th, 1717.
JOHN URY, Secretary.
To the Honourable the Commons of Great-Britain in Parliament Assembled.

The Governour and Company of the Bank of England, being willing to contribute their Assistance in the proposed Design of easing the National Debts, in such manner as may
be consistent with the Support of Parliamen∣tary Credit; humbly propose,

Q.P: THAT the Original Fund of One Hundred Thousand Pounds per Annum payable to the Bank, in Consideration of Sixteen Hundred Thou∣sand Pounds advanced for the Service of the Go∣vernment, remain secured to them to the first Day of August, One Thousand Seven Hundred and Forty-two, and a Year's Notice, as it stands con∣firmed to them by several Acts of Parliament.

That they are content to accept an Annuity of Eighty eight Thousand Seven Hundred and Fifty one Pounds, Seven Shillings and Ten Pence Half∣penny, being after the Rate of Five Pounds per Cent. per Annum, on the Principal Sum of Se∣venteen Hundred Seventy five Thousand and Twen∣ty Seven Pounds, Seventeen Shillings and Ten Pence Halfpenny, in lieu of the present Annuity of One Hundred and Six Thousand Five Hundred and One Pounds, Thirteen Shillings and Five Pence, payable to the said Governour and Company out of the Duties on Houses, to commence from the Twenty fifth Day of March, One Thousand Seven Hundred and Eighteen, subject to Redemption by Parliament, on Twelve Months Notice, after the Twenty fifth Day of March, One Thousand Seven Hundred and Twenty three, and Repayment of the Principal and all Arrears of the said Annuity.

As to the Exchequer-Bills, issued by Virtue of se∣veral Acts of Parliament, and now standing out for Four Millions Five Hundred Sixty one Thousand and Twenty five Pounds Principal Money, or thereabouts.

The said Governour and Company are content to accept an Annuity after the Rate of Five Pounds per. Cent. per Annum, for the Sum of Two Mil∣lions, part thereof to commence from the Twenty Ninth Day of September, One Thousand Seven Hundred and Seventeen, subject to Redemption by Parliament, on Twelve Months Notice, after the Twenty Ninth Day of September, One Thousand Seven Hundred and Twenty, and Repayment of the said Two Millions, and all Arrears of the Annuity attending the same.

And to continue the Circulating and Exchanging for Money at demand, the Remainder of the said Bills, at the present Allowance of Three Pounds per Cent. per Annum: And are also content, that the Interest, now payable on such Bills, may be reduced to One Penny per Cent. per Diem, from and after the Twenty ninth Day of September, One Thousand Seven Hundred and Seventeen; and that the said Interest may cease on any of the said Bills, during the Time that such Bills may lie in the Exchequer, or in the Hands of any Publick Officers; provided that the Exchequer-Bills here∣by proposed to be circulated and exchanged for Money, or any of them, be not redeemable but upon Twelve Months Notice, after the Twenty ninth Day of September, One Thousand Seven Hundred and Twenty four, and Repayment of the Principal and Interest, and all Arrears of the said Allow∣ance of Three Pounds per Cent. per Annum; and that the Allowances of Forty five Thousand Pounds per Annum, and Eight Thousand Pounds per An∣num, payable to the said Governour and Company, by several Acts of Parliament, for making Exche∣quer-Bills Specie, until the same should be redu∣ced to Nineteen Hundred Thousand Pounds, be con∣tinued
to them until the Twenty fifth Day of March, One Thousand Seven Hundred and Eigh∣teen.
That no more Exchequer-Bills, or Bills of like Nature, be issued without Consent of the Bank, un∣til such Redemption be made.

The said Governour and Company are willing to advance the Sum of Two Millions Five Hundred Thousand Pounds to the Publick, or such Part there∣of as may be wanted, in order to redeem the Pub∣lick Funds, at such Time and Times, before the Twenty-fifth Day of March, One Thousand Se∣ven Hundred and Eighteen; and in such Propor∣tions as shall be found necessary, at an Interest of Five Pounds per Cent. per Annum, redeemable by Parliament.

Provided that the Five Sevenths Excise, House-Money, and Duties of the Aggregate Fund, be set∣tled to answer all these Payments, with Preference to all others, and that the Corporation of the Bank do continue with all its Capacities, Privileges and Advantages, till all these Redemptions are made.

And that all such Privlieges and Clauses as shall be thought necessary and reasonable, to enable the Bank to perform the respective Services proposed, be inserted in the Bill to pass on this Occasion, and that no farther Duties or Taxes may be laid on their present or increased Stock, nor in any Transfer of the same, nor on any Bonds or Bills to be issued by the Bank for Support of their Credit.
Sign'd by the Order of the Governour and Company of the Bank of England.
JO. INCE, Secretary.

DIV3.P: The Proposals were acceptable enough to the House, except that of the Term of Years to be ad∣ded to the Company, &c. and the giving Five Years Notice for the Redeeming the Loan, which the House rejected after some very warm Debates, particularly about the latter. However, in the End, the Communities, as they were called, receded from the Demands of Time, leaving it to the Par∣liament, who referred the adding Time, as before, to another Session, and reduced the Time for No∣tice of Redemption to one Year; and so this great Affair pass'd, and the Two Companies engag'd to advance, the Bank Two Millions and an Half, and the South Sea Company Two Millions, if call'd for; and this Proposal was pass'd into a Law.

The Acts being pass'd upon these Proposals, the Government was now furnished to pay all Men their Principal Money if they had demanded it; and there∣fore the Lords of the Treasury set the Thing imme∣diately on Foot, in order to make the Experiment whether the Publick Credit was able to support the Loans, tho' with an Abatement of Interest, and whether the People would come for their Money or no.
Accordingly the Books were opened, and the fol∣lowing Publication was made in the Gazette, and other Publick Papers, that all People might come for their Money, as follows, viz

P.Q:
“WHereas by an Act now passed in Parlia∣ment, the Proprietors of the Orders hereunder described, or others authorized by wri∣ting under their Hands in this behalf, are to sig∣nify and declare by Subscriptions, in Books to be laid open for that Purpose, until the 29th Day of September, 1717, unless the said Subscriptions be
sooner compleated, their Option or Choice, either to accept in Lieu and Discharge of their princi∣pal Money, and the Interest thereupon from Midsummer, 1717, to Michaelmas following, an Annuity or Annuities after the Rate of 5 l. per Cent. per Annum, redeemable by Parliament, or to have their Principal and Interest paid and satis∣fied in ready Money, as by the said Act is directed: The Managers and Directors nominated and ap∣pointed in pursuance of the said Act to this Ser∣vice give Notice, That the Books for taking the said Subscriptions were opened at the publick Of∣fice for that Purpose, adjoining to the Banqueting-House in Whitehall, on Wednesday the 24th of July, 1717, at Eight a Clock in the Forenoon, and will continue open at the same Place every Day (Sundays excepted) from Eight in the Fore∣noon, to Two in the Afternoon, until the said 29th Day of September, 1717, unless the said Subscriptions be sooner compleated. Therefore the Proprietors, Executors, Administrators, Guar∣dians, Trustees, Femmes Covert, and others en∣titled to, or interested in the said Orders, are to take Notice hereof, and before the said 29th Day of September, 1717, at farthest, to bring their Orders, and make their Subscriptions either for” Annuities, or for ready Money accordingly.
'The Books of Subscriptions do contain as 'followeth,

LIST.ITEM: 1. Books for the Subscriptions of the Orders in the Lottery, called the 10 l. Lottery, Anno 1711
2. Books for the Subscriptions of the Orders in the Class-Lottery for 2,000,000 l. Anno 1711
3. Books for the Subscriptions of the Orders in the Lotteries No. 1, No. 2, and No. 3. called the 10 l. Lotteries, Anno 1712.
4. Books for the Subscriptions of the Orders in the Class-Lottery for 1, 800, 000 l. Anno 1712.
5. Books for the Subscriptions of the Or∣ders for Annuities, commonly called the” Bankers Annuities.

DIV3.P: The Right Honourable the Lords “Commissio∣ners of his Majesty's Treasury give Notice, that they have required the Paymasters and Comp∣trollers of the Orders in the Lotteries now sub∣scribing for Annuities, their Deputies and Clerks, to give constant and diligent Attendance in their Offices daily (Sundays excepted) from Eight in the Morning to One, and from Three to Six in the Afternoon, to direct and pay, with the utmost Expedition, all Arrears of Interest on the Orders in every of the said Lotteries, to and for the Quarter ended at Midsummer last 1717, Money sufficient being put by their Lordships into the Hands of the respective Paymasters of the said” Lottery Orders for that Purpose.

This Publication being made, and the Books opened, it was soon seen which way the Stream would run; for as in the first Place, there were few or none that desired to take their Money, so if there had been ever so many, there were People al∣ways ready, and Money lodg'd by private Hands with the Clerks, to buy the Interest of any that de∣sired to part with it, and to be entred in their stead; so that if the Proprietors of all those Lottery Orders had demanded their Money, it was plain, that the Government needed not to have call'd upon
the Bank or South-Sea Company for one Farthing, and thus at the Time of the Writing these Sheets, we find, the Books being closed, there is but 471 l. 4 s. 0 d. demanded in Money, all the rest being subscrib'd to continue upon the same Security at 5 l. per Cent. Interest, the Sum amounting to Nine Mil∣lions, Two Hundred and Thirty Thousand, Eight Hundred and Seventy Three Pounds, Eighteen Shil∣lings and Four Pence; so that, we say, 'tis evident, the Government will not have occasion on this Ac∣count for one Penny of that Money which the said Communities are to furnish.

I am now coming to the close of the Session, which was chiefly taken up with Disputes between the two Houses, in their judicial Affairs, and parti∣cularly the famous Case in Parliament of the Earl of Oxford.

That truly great Man had been now under Con∣finement almost two Years, and had this Session been let slip, and was likely enough to lie there ano∣ther Year; whether uneasy at the Length of his Confinement, or with his usual Penetration, percei∣ving the critical Juncture of his Deliverance to be before him; I say, whether of these I do not en∣quire: But the Earl, with the same calm Courage with which he put himself into the Hands of the Parliament at first, when he might, had he doubted his Innocence, or their Justice, have secur'd himself: I say, with the same calm Courage he now resol∣ved to Court his Danger, and casting the Die for Life or Death, Petitions the House to have his Case taken into Consideration: I cannot omit some Lines which I have met with, as Part of a Descrip∣tion of his Case on this Occasion, and which, I think, do but Justice to the inimitable Resolution and Bravery of Mind with which he put himself
into the Hands of publick Justice, when it must be own'd, the Stream of popular Feud ran so high, that it was enough, if possible, to terrifie even In∣nocence it self: The Lines were these.

Q.L: Great Heart who taught thee thus unmov'd to Die,
To Rate thy Blood to Law, thy Fame so high:
Did the least Spot upon thy Soul appear?
It could not be: Such Courage speaks thee clear.
For Guilt must ha betray'd it self by Fear.

DIV3.P: And as I am mentioning the Courage of the Earl's Surrender, as an Argument of his Innocence, so without trespassing upon the Impartiality of an Hi∣storian, I must in Justice say, that never more Ho∣nour was done to the Justice of the House of Peers, by any Man that ever I read of in History, than was done by this noble Person, in casting himself into their Hands so boldly, so chearfully depending up∣on their Justice, Honour and impartial Proceedings; and this when his Life was in the most manifest Ha∣zard, as well from both the Number as the Rage of his Enemies: And when this Temper, or rather want Temper, discover'd so evidently a Thirst after his Ruin; when his Friends dispair'd for him, and lay at him Night and Day, with the Exhortations of the fainter hearted Apostle, Master, save thy self; when others more fam'd for Courage durst not stand it, and when the Voice of Numbers were evidently against him.

It will not be pretended that he was ignorant how easily the Constitution itself sometimes gives way to popular Clamours, how often Innocence is run down by Crowd, and the clearest Truth smo∣ther'd with the Breath of a Majority.
He was not ignorant how many there were who pursued him with personal Pique, how numerous his Enemies were, or how powerful even among the P—t.

He knew indeed, that his Cause depended upon the strict Appeal he made to the Laws of his Coun∣try; but he was not ignorant how frequently Consti∣tutions are violated, by straining the Constructions both of Law and of Offences, especially when the Humour of the Times condemns, or a Man falls a Sacrifice to popular Resentment.

But knowing what Justice would demand of the House of Peers, and believing they would always act as became their Dignity, and as Honour and un∣byass'd Justice directed them, he cast his Life into their Hands, honour'd them with believing they were what they ought to be, and that they would never taint their Blood with the unbecoming Cruelty of dipping their Hands in his; unless the Law un∣constrain'd, and Evidence unconfuted, should con∣vince them of his Guilt, which he was well assur'd could not be.

In this, I say, he put the greatest Honour upon the Peers that it was possible for any Man to do; and I persuade my self it will be granted, that as the History of the past Ages can scarce shew a Pre∣cedent, so it may be long enough before any of his Enemies who boast of their new Advancements to a Rank which they know not how to deserve, will ever give either a like Testimony of Innocence, or the like Veneration for the Persons and Honour of the British Nobility.

But I return to the History. It was the 22d of May, the Earl caused a Petition to be presented to the House of Lords, sign'd by his Name, setting forth, That he had been long confin'd, upon an Im∣peachment
brought up against him to their Lordships House, by the Commons of Great-Britain, for High-Treason, and other High Crimes and Misdemeanours; submitting his Case to their Lordships Consideration, and praying that his Imprisonment might not be in∣definite.

This Petition was something surprizing, and was taken by some to be a Calling upon the House to bring him to Tryal, and for some time was resented as such, at least in the House of Com∣mons; however, the Lords, who acted with the utmost Calmness and Sedateness, proceeded without taking it by any such Handle, and heard with Pa∣tience whatever the Earl's Friends had to alledge in his Favour, and several long Speeches were made upon the Niceties and Scruples which offer'd on one side as well as on the other; particularly, some of the Lords insisted in his behalf, that the Im∣peachment was ipfo facto destroy'd and determin'd, seeing he was not brought to Tryal the same Sessi∣ons in which he was Impeached; and that the Prorogation was an actual Supersedeas to the whole Proceedings; this was warmly Debated, and the Earl of Nottingham insisted so strenuously upon it, that he demanded Leave to enter his Protestation a∣gainst the Vote pass'd on the other side: A strange Change in this noble Person, from the Temper which he shew'd at the Time of the Impeachment!

However, this being over-rul'd or rejected, the Duke of Buckingham mov'd to appoint a Day for the Earl's Tryal, which after some Debates, and appointing a Committee to search Precedents, was fix'd and appointed; and 'tis to be observed here, that the appointing a Day for the Tryal, did not occasion so long a Debate, as the shortening the Day; and it was something wonderful to find the Earl's
Friends pressing the House to appoint a short Day; and the Governments Friends, if we may be allow∣ed that Distinction, pleading for Time; as if the Earl was in a greater Readiness or Forwardness to make his Defence, than the Commons were in to make good their Charge.

But so it was, the Duke of Buckingham, who made the Motion, press'd earnestly for a short Day, and nam'd the 6th of June to be the Day of Tryal; this caused several Speeches and Debates, needless to be repeated here. However, on a Divi∣sion, it was carried for a Week longer, 85 Voices against 44, and the 13th of June was fix'd for the Earl's Tryal.

As these Things caused long Debates in the House of Lords, so the Message sent to the Commens, to acquaint them that the Lords had appointed the 13th of June for the Tryal, caused long Debates among them: The Commons saw the Face of their Affairs a little changed; some People, who were active and vigorous in this Prosecution when it was first begun, and upon whom the House might be said, in some measure, to depend for the carrying it on, seem'd to look coldly upon the Matter, and to de∣cline the Work, or at least, to have less of that Con∣fidence which the House usually shew'd them, and was due to them before. This caused a Vote in the House, to appoint a Committee to enquire into the State of the Impeachments at that time depending before the House.

This Committe found, upon their Enquiry, that the Secret Committee had suffered some Dislocati∣on of Members since the last Session, viz. several Members were called up from it to the House of Peers, as the Lord Onslow, the Lord Coningshy, and others; and some other Members seemed, as is said,
to be gone off, &c. So that the first Thing the New Committee for Enquiry, &c. did, was to move the House that more Members might be added to the Committee, and the House was mov'd accordingly; upon which Lawrence Carter, Esq Sir William Thompson, Recorder of London, Ser∣jeant Birch, and Serjeant Pingelly, were added to the Secret Committee; and now they acted open∣ly, dropt Mr. Walpole out of the Chair, for he was Chairman of the former Committee, whereas now they made Mr. Lawr. Carter, Member for the Town of Leicester, Chairman, and then four more were added to the Committee, viz. Mr. Addison Secretary of State, Mr. James Craggs Secretary at War, Mr. Serjeant Mead, and Mr. Jessop; and at another time after that Mr. Nicholas Lechmere, who was just then rechosen into the House, after his being made Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster.

Having thus gotten all the eminent Lawyers of the House to be nam'd of the Committee, they fell immediately to the Business, viz. preparing to make good the Articles of Impeachment, in case the House should agree to proceed to the Tryal; but all this while they left the World in suspense as to their Resolution, even till the Day before the Day ap∣pointed for Tryal, when the Commons sent a Mes∣sage to the Lords, to demand longer Time for their Preparations. This was, according to a Report made to them by the Committee, in the Terms fol∣lowing, viz.

P.HI: That the Committee had met several Times, and made some Progress in the Matters to them referr'd; but that the Prosecution of the said Impeachment ha∣ving been interrupted for so many Months, by the Intervention of many weighty and urgent Affairs, which

more nearly and immediately concern'd the Welfare, Defence, and Security of the Kingdom; it was be∣come absolutely necessary for those who should be ap∣pointed to manage the said Impeachment, to review, and carefully peruse all the Treaties, Records, Let∣ters, and other Papers proper and necessary for sup∣porting this Prosecution; which being very volumi∣nous, it would be impossible, within the Time ap∣pointed for the Tryal, to adjust and apply the pro∣per Evidence to the several Articles.

DIV3.P: This Message being sent to the Lords, they gran∣ted Time to the 24th of June, upon which, the Commons seriously apply'd themselves to prepare for the Tryal; and here it was to be observ'd, that the Earl's Party, (as they were called) in the House of Peers, argued and insisted some time upon the first Day, alledging, that the Lords having fix'd a peremptory Day for the Tryal, they ought not to put it off, or allow any farther Day: What the Mystery of their hurrying on the Tryal so warmly was, was not seen till afterwards; but the Question being put, it was carry'd for a longer Time, as above.

And now the Commons began to let it be seen, that they resolv'd to go on with the Tryal; and accor∣dingly voted Managers for carrying it on: These were the whole Committee of Secrecy, and no other excepting such as they then added to the Committee; then they resolv'd, that the House would be present at the Tryal, as a Committee of the whole House, and then voted the usual Method for their going, no sitting at, and coming from the Tryal.

The 24th of June the Tryal began: The Ac∣counts of it, which were published by Authority, are my best Guides in stating the whole Affair, which
however long, requires to be recorded by my Pen, that pretends to write the History of those Times: I shall however contract it within as narrow Com∣pass as Justice on both Sides will admit.

The Day being come for the Tryal, and the Earl of Oxford, Prisoner, being brought up from the Tower, the Lords about Eleven a Clock mov'd from their House Two by Two in great State, and with all the usual Formalities, too long to require a Repe∣tition in our Annals. The Lord Cowper, who was appointed Lord High-Steward for the Day, going also in great State, with the Judges, and with all his proper Officers, into Westminster-Hall.
On the other Hand, the Commons, according to the Orders above, appeared in the Place assigned for them, the Managers being in a Place separated for them.
His Majesty was also in the Place appointed for the Royal Family, with the Prince and Princess of Wales.

The whole Assembly being plac'd, the Lord High-Steward constituted the Court, by causing his Com∣mission to be read, receiving the White Staff, and ascending some Steps to his Seat of Justice; and immediately Proclamation was made, to order the Lieutenant of the Tower to bring the Prisoner to the Bar, which was done: The Earl coming up to the Bar, kneeled down, and continued kneeling till the Lord High-Steward told him he might rise; he be∣hav'd Grave and Decent, yet Chearful and not De∣jected, and when he rose up from his Knees, bowed with Tokens of Respect to the Lord High-Steward, and to the Peers, which Civility was re∣turned with great Courtesie by them all.

These Matters of Ceremony being over, the Ar∣ticles of Impeachment were read, the Earl's An∣swer,
and the Replication of the Cammons, which are too long to enter upon here.
After the Reading these Things, the Lord High-Steward addressing himself to the Earl Prisoner, spoke as follows:

P.Q: “Robert Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer, it has been usual, before the Commons proceed, to say something from this Place to Persons in your Lordship's present Condition; partly by way of Exhortation to a reasonable Confidence in the great Honour, Justice, Wisdom, Integrity and Candour of their Judges, their Peers, the House of Lords in Parliament assembled; and partly by way of Direction, to assist them in their Behavi∣our and Conduct during the Course of their” Tryal.

“But considering the many great Offices your Lordship has born in the State, your long Expe∣rience and known Learning in all Parliamentary Proceedings, I cannot but think it would seem im∣proper for me to be speaking to your Lordship” in that manner.
“Wherefore I proceed barely to acquaint your Lordship and others whom it may çoncern, with such Orders as the Lords have made, which 'tis fit should be taken Notice of thus early in this” Tryal.
“1. Your Lordship, and all other Persons who have occasion to speak to this Court, must ad∣dress their Speech to the Lords in general, and” not to any Lord in particular.

“2. Your Lordship's Council may be present at the Bar, in order to be heard to any Point or Matter of Law, if such shall arise on either of the Articles for High-Treason; and that you may
make your full Defence by Council, if you think fit, on the Articles for High-Crimes and Misde∣meanours,” as well on Matters of Fact as of Law.
“3. That your Witnesses are to be examin'd on Oath, as well to the Articles for High-Treason, as” those for High Crimes and Misdemeanours.

DIV3.P: Then the Lord High-Steward, with the Lords Leave, went down, and having seated him∣self by the Table, told the Gentlemen of the House of Commons, That they might now proceed: Upon which Mr. Stanhope said, My Lords, the Distance of the Lord High-Steward from this Place, may have been the Occasion, that We have mistaken some∣thing that fell from thence; We do therefore desire to avoid all Mistakes, (and I believe We might be mistaken) for we understood by my Lord High-Stew∣ard, that Council should be allowed the Prisoner at the Bar, as well to the Defence of the High-Treason, as to the High Crimes and Misdemea∣nours: It is possible we misapprehend his Lordship, but we hope his Lordship will be pleased to explain it to Us. Hereupon the Lord High-Steward said, “To prevent Mistakes, I repeat what I said, That Council for the Lord (the Prisoner at the Bar) may be present at the Bar, in order to be heard to any Matter or Point of Law (if any such shall arise) relating to the High-Treason, and likewise to make that Lord's Defence on the Articles of Impeachment of High Crimes and Misde∣meanours, as well in Matters of Fact, as Matters” of Law.
Hereupon the Managers began; Mr. Hampden being the first, who open'd the Case in a long Speech.

After Mr. Hampden's Speech, Sir Joseph Jekyl was going on, when the Lord Harcourt made a Mo∣tion to adjourn to the House of Lords, where, up∣on a long Debate, it was resolv'd, not to admit the Commons to proceed in making good the Articles for High Crimes, &c. till Judgment be first given upon the Articles for High-Treason.

This being declared to the Managers at the Lords return to the Hall, the Managers reply'd: That they conceived it to be so much the undoubted Right of the Commons to proceed in their own Method, in Maintenance of the Articles exhibited by them, and did apprehend that this Resolution of their Lord∣ships might be of so fatal Consequence to the Rights and Privileges of all the Commons of Great-Bri∣tain, that they could not take upon them to proceed any farther, without resorting to the House of Com∣mons for their Direction therein.

Upon this Proceeding, Conferences, searching Precedents, and the like Methods of managing such Disputes, took up some Days, and in particular, on the 27th, the Commons at a Conference, deliver'd the following Paper to the Lords, viz.

The Commons having taken into their Conside∣ration your Lordships Resolution communicated to their Managers, relating to the Proceedings on the Tryal of Robert Earl of Oxford and Earl Morti∣mer, and being desirous, as far as in them lies, to maintain a good Correspondence with your Lordships, have desired this Conference, and have commanded us to acquaint your Lordships, That they conceive it to be the undoubted Right of the Commons, to impeach a Peer, either for High-Treason, or for High Crimes and Misdemeanours, or, if they see
occasion, to mix both the one and the other in the same Accusation.

The Impeachment preferr'd against Robert Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer is one continued Ac∣cusation, consisting of High Crimes and Misdemea∣nours, and also of Charges of High-Treason. The Facts on which the Articles preceding those of High-Treason are grounded, are laid together in order of Time, and follow one another successively, in the Manner they were committed.

As the Commons thought this the most natural Method for exhibiting the several Articles against the said Earl, they were of Opinion, That they should proceed in the Proof of these several Facts after the same Method, since it is manifest, that in laying open the Course of such a wicked Admini∣stration, the preceding Parts of it give Light to those which follow; and that, the Proof of those of High-Treason.

Your Lordships received these several Articles of Impeachment, without making any Exception a∣gainst the Form in which they were exhibited. The said Earl made his Answer to them in the same Or∣der, and has no where insisted to be Try'd in any other Method; so that the Commons are surpriz'd to find a stop put to their Prosecution by an Ob∣jection which has never been started by the said Earl, and which your Lordships had given them so little Reason to expect.

To this must be added, That as the Commons only are Masters of the Evidence, and as upon that Ac∣count they are best able to determine, what to Charge first, and what next; so they are most proper to determine in what Method to proceed for the Advan∣tage of the Prosecution, in the Event of which all
the Commons of Great-Britain are so highly concern'd.

To which they farther add, That they see no Rea∣son but that your Lordships may as well invert the whole Order of the Articles, as prescribe to the Commons those particular Articles on which they are first to proceed, which will necessarily produce such a Confusion, both in the Facts and Evidence, as is by no means consistent with that Clearness and Perspicuity in which the Commons think this Affair ought to appear.

The Commons, upon examining Precedents, do find divers Precedents of Impeachments for High-Treason, and other High Crimes and Misdemea∣nours in the same Accusation; and do not find that the Lords ever objected to such Proceeding, or e∣ver gave Judgment upon any particular Article of an Impeachment before the Commons had gone through, and concluded their Evidence upon all the Articles, or so many of them as they thought fit; and the Commons are at a loss to conceive what Argu∣ments or Precedents can be brought to support the Resolution of your Lordships, to give Judgment upon one part of the same Accusation, reserving the other part for a subsequent Tryal, as they are to know what your Lordships mean by admitting the Commons to proceed upon the Articles of High-Crimes and Misdemeanours, after the Judgment is given upon the Articles for High Treason, supposing the Judgment proper for High-Treason should be gi∣ven against the said Earl.

For these Reasons, the Commons assert it as their undoubted Right to proceed on the Tryal of Robert Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer, after the Method in which their Managers were proceeding, when interrupted by your Lordships Resolution.

These Heads being Debated in the House of Lords, brought it to the Question a second Time, Whether the Commons should be admitted to pro∣ceed, or whether the House should insist, and it was carry'd to insist on their former Resolution; and they also ordered a Paper of Reasons in Main∣tenance of their Resolution to be drawn up and de∣livered to the Commons at another Conference: Which Reasons are as follow.

Q.P:
Their Lordships, in order to preserve a good Cor∣respondence with the House of Commons, (which they shall always endeavour to do as far as lies in their Power) have desired this Conference upon the subject Matter of the last Conference, and have di∣rected us to acquaint you, That their Lordships judge it a Right inherent in every Court of Justice, to or∣der and direct such Methods of Proceedings as such Court shall think fit to be observed in all Causes depending before them, which can have no Influence to the Prejudice of Justice; and where such Methods of Proceedings are not otherwise settled by any posi∣tive Rule. The Power of Judicature on all Im∣peachments being a Right unquestionably inherent in their Lordships, and it not being determined by any positive Rule, whether the House of Commons may proceed to make good the several Articles exhibited for Misdemeanours, in such Order as they shall think fit, before they proceed to make good the Articles ex∣hibited for High-Treason; and there being no Pre∣cedent where the Commons, upon the Tryal of any such Impeachment, attempted to proceed in the first Place, to make good any of the Articles contain'd in such Impeachment for High Crimes and Misdemea∣nours; their Lordships considering the Nature of the Impeachment now depending before them, and the Me∣thod
wherein the Managers for the House of Com∣mons were beginning to proceed upon the Tryal, to make good the first Article thereof, which is a Charge for High Crimes and Misdemeanours only; and also considering, the very different Methods of Proceed∣ing on an Impeachment of a Peer for High-Treason, as well before, as upon the Tryal thereof, and the Circumstances attending such a Tryal, thought them∣selves obliged to come to the Resolution communicated to the Commons on the 24th Instant, as well for the doing Justice in the Case depending before them, as for the preventing a new President to be made on this Tryal; in Consequence whereof, a new and un∣justifiable Form of Proceeding against a Peer upon an Impeachment for High Treason and High Crimes might be introduced at his Tryal upon those Articles in which he is charged for High Crimes and Misdemeanours only, to the Prejudice of the Peer∣age of Great-Britain in all Time to come, viz. The Trying a Peer on Articles for High Crimes and Mis∣demeanours without the Bar, the detaining in Custo∣dy a Peer so accused, and repeated Commitments of him to the Tower, during the Time of such Tryal, and subjecting a Peer to as ignominious Circumstan∣ces on his Tryal, on Articles for Misdemeanours, as if he was then on his Tryal on Articles for High-Treason: Whereas a Peer on his Tryal on Articles for Misdemeanours only, ought not to be deprived of his Liberty, nor sequestred from Parliament; and is entitled to the Privilege of sitting within the Bar during the whole Time of his Tryal: In all which Particulars, the known Rule of Pro∣ceedings in such Cases may be evaded, should a Peer be brought to his Tryal on several Ar∣ticles exhibited against him on High Crimes and Misdemeanours, and for High Treason mixed to∣gether,
and the Commons be admitted to pro∣ceed in order to make good the Articles for High Crimes and Misdemeanours before Judgment be given upon the Articles for High-Treason. Their Lordships have fully considered the Matters offered to them by the House of Commons at the last Conference relating to the Proceedings against Robert Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer; and their Lordships are fully satisfied, That the Resolution they have taken and communicated to the Commons on the 24th Instant, is just and reasonable; and that the House of Commons are not put under any real Inconvenience thereby, in carrying on their present Prosecution. Their Lordships have commanded us to let you know, That they do insist on their said Resolution, viz. That the Commons be not admitted to proceed in order to make good the Articles against Robert Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer for High Crimes and Misdemeanours, till Judgment be first given upon the Articles for High-Treason.

DIV3.P: Thus far the Two Houses debated Things with some Calmness, but they grew warmer the next Day, when the Commons having consider'd the Rea∣sons above, sent a Message to the Lords to desire a free Conference, and the Lords refused it; and now the Party of the Earl of Oxford began to see his Deliverance at hand; for the Lords refusing to grant the Commons a free Conference, set the Two Houses into a new Dispute, and they were going on to great Heights; the Commons desiring a Conference of the Lords upon this Subject, they gave in a Paper there:

Q.P: The Commons having taken into Consideration your Lordships Message, viz. That your Lordships did not think fit to give a free Conference on the subject Matter of the last Conference, as was de∣sired by the Commons: And they being still desirous, to the utmost of their Power, to preserve a good Cor∣respondence with your Lordships, have asked this Conference; and have commanded us to acquaint your Lordships, That they are very much surprizd to find your Lordships deny a free Conference, after your Lordships have already agreed to a Conference desired by the Commons on the same subject Matter, and after your Lordships have on your Parts also desired a Conference upon the same Subject. That free Conferences are the most ancient and establish∣ed Methods for adjusting the Differences that have at any time arisen between the Two Houses, and, as the Commons conceive, is the only Method to preserve a good Correspondence between them on such Occasions, which, at this Time, is of the highest Importance; because a Misunderstanding on this Ac∣count, would tend to defeat the Tryal of the Im∣peachment of the Commons. That the Commons conceive clearly, that the subject Matter of the last Conference is not a Point of Judicature, but a Point relating only to the Prosecution of the Commons, it having arisen before any Matter of Judgment had come before your Lordships upon the Tryal. For which Reasons the Commons conceive, that your Lordships ought not to have denied them a free Conference upon the subject Matter of the last Con∣ference.

DIV3.P:
These Things were read and considered, but the Lords being clear in it, that the Commons were in the Wrong, resolv'd to insist upon it, that they
ought not to grant them a free Conference upon this Subject; and having put the Question again in their House, it pass'd, not to grant a free Confe∣rence, which was signified to the Commons; as also that the Lords would presently proceed farther on the Tryal of the Earl.

The Commons took no notice of this Message at all, nay, some mov'd, as we were told, not to re∣ceive it. However, seeing the Lords were resolv'd to proceed, the House adjourn'd; some suggested, that this Adjournment was ordered, that they might not receive any more Messages about it, or be sent to from the Hall to appear at the Tryal.

In the mean time, the House of Lords proceeded in the Formalities of Judicature; they went down to the Hall, took their Places in Judgment, ordered the Lieutenant of the Tower to bring the Earl to the Bar, and made Proclamation in these Words: “Whereas Robert Earl of Oxford and Earl Morti∣mer, stands Impeach'd of High Treason and other High Crimes and Misdemeanours, by the House of Commons, in the Name of themselves and of all the Commons of Great-Britain, all Persons concern'd are to take Notice, that he now stands upon his Tryal, and they may now come forth in” order to make good their Charge.

After this, the Court sat perfectly silent, and looking upon one another as if expecting the Com∣mons should appear, this Silence held about a quar∣ter of an Hour, when the Lords adjourn'd to their House; where the Question was put, that the Earl should be acquitted, and it pass'd in the Affirmative; and then the Method of giving Judgment was dis∣cuss'd, the very Words prescribed, and Directions given to the Lord High-Steward concerning the far∣ther Proceedings in the Hall.
The House was then again adjourned into West∣minster-Hall, and being there resumed,

SP.SPEAKER: L. H. Steward.
SP.P: Make Proclamation for Si∣lence.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser. at Arms.
SP.P: O yes, &c.
O yes, &c. Lieutenant of the Tower of London, bring forth your Prisoner to the Bar.

SP.SPEAKER: L. H. Steward.
SP.P: My Lords, the Clerk acquaints me, that, for want of Light in the Passage, he could not take an exact List of your Lordships; I therefore desire that he may now take a List of the Lords present.
Then the Clerk took a List of the Lords present.

SP.SPEAKER: L. H. Steward.
SP.P: If your Lordships think fit, your Names shall now be called over.

SP.SPEAKER: Lords.
SP.P: Ay, Ay.
Then their Names were called over.

SP.SPEAKER: Lords.
SP.P: The Earl of Oxford is not yet gone from the Bar.
Then the Earl was ordered to withdraw from the Bar. And being withdrawn,

SP.SPEAKER: L. H. Steward.
SP.P: My Lords, I shall now state the Question, upon which your Lordships are to give your Votes; it is this, That Robert Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer, be acquitted of the Articles of Impeachment exhibited against him by the House of Commons, for High Treason, and other High Crimes and Misdemeanours, and of all Things therein contained, and that the said Impeachment be dismissed.

SP.SPEAKER: L. H. Steward.
SP.P: The Clerk should attend near the Lords with Candles, as they give their Votes.
Then the Lord High Steward put the Question to their Lordships, beginning at the youngest Baron, in manner following.

SP.SPEAKER: L. H. Steward.
SP.P: My Lord, your Lordship has heard the Question stated, what says your Lordship, is your Lordship Content, or not Content?

LIST.HEAD: The Names of the Lords present, who were all Content, are as follow.
LIST.ITEM:
BARONS.
Newburgh
Parker

Boyle

Gower
Haversham
Herbert
Ashburnham
Guildford
Stawell
Carteret
Lumley
Osborne
Cornwallis
Berkley of Stratton
Leigh
Bruce
Teynbam
Compton
St. John
Hunsdon
North and Grey
Willoughby of Brooke
Fitzwalter
Delawar
Willoughby of Ersby
Abergavenny

BISHOPS.
St. Asaph
Chester
Bristol
Rochester
St. Davids
Hereford
Landaff
Bath and Wells
Carlisle
Litchfield and Coventry
Winchester
London.

VISCOUNTS.
Castleton
Tadcaster
Lonsdale
Longueville
Townshend
Say and Seal
Hereford.

EARLS.
Halifax
Bristol
Carnarvon
Uxbridge
Dartmouth
Strafford
Ferrers
Ilay
Deloraine
Orkney
Loudoun
Buchan
Cholmondeley
Poulet
Greenwich
Rochford
Plimouth
Abingdon
Rochester
Litchfield
Burlington
Carlisle
Anglesea
Cardigan
Clarendon
Scarsdale
Manchester
Northampton
Salisbury
Dorset
Pembroke

DUKES.

Ancaster
Rutland
Buckingham
Devonshire
Shrewsbury
St. Albans
Grafton
Cleaveland & Southampt.

Kingston.

SP.SPEAKER: L. H. Steward.
SP.P: My Lords, upon the Question stated, I am Content.

SP.SPEAKER: L. H. Steward.
SP.P: My Lords, Robert Earl of Ox∣ford and Earl Mortimer is acquitted of the High-Treason and other High-Crimes and Misdemeanours wherewith he stands charged, by the Unanimous Vote of all your Lordships here present.

SP.SPEAKER: L. H. Steward.
SP.P: Call the Earl to the Bar.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser. at Arms.
SP.P: O yes, &c. Lieutenant of the Tower of London, bring the Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer to the Bar of this House.

SP.SPEAKER: L. H. Steward.
SP.P: Robert Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer, I am to acquaint your Lordship, that your Lordship is acquitted of the Articles of Im∣peachment Exhibited against you for High-Treason, and other High Crimes and Misdemeanours, by the House of Commons, and all Things therein con∣tained; and thereupon I am to pronounce this Judg∣ment, which I pronounce accordingly.

It is Considered, Ordered and Adjudged by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assem∣bled, that Robert Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer shall be, and is hereby acquitted of the Articles of Impeachment exhibited against him by the House of Commons for High-Treason, and other High Crimes and Misdemeanours, and of all Things therein con∣tain'd, and that the said Impeachment shall be, and is hereby dismissed.

SP.SPEAKER: L. H. Steward.
SP.P: Lieutenant of the Tower of London, you are now to discharge your Pri∣soner.

SP.SPEAKER: L. H. Steward.
SP.P:
My Lords, This is all that re∣mains to be done by Vertue of his Majesty's Commis∣sion,
I do therefore declare the same to be dis∣solved.
Then the Lord High-Steward broke his Staff.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Chancellor.
SP.P: Is it your Lordships Pleasure to adjourn to the Chamber of Parliament?

SP.SPEAKER: Lords.
SP.P: Ay, Ay.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Chancellor.
SP.P: This House is adjourn'd to the Chamber of Parliament.
