DIV3.P: Thus ended this great Affair, and the Earl's being immediately Discharg'd at the Bar, and paying his Respects to the Court, and to the Lords, and ha∣ving receiv'd the Compliments of his Friends, went away directly to his own House.

However, the Commons did not rest here, but on the Wednesday after, reassuming the Debate men∣tioned above, and resolving to shew their Resent∣ment at this Proceeding, they, after a very close Debate, resolv'd, that an Address should be presen∣ted to his Majesty, to except the Earl of Oxford out of the Act of Grace, which was intended to be brought into the House.

The Parliament drew now towards a Recess of their Session, and little Business seem'd to lie before them, except such Bills as were ready for the Royal Assent; when on the 26th of July, the Earl of Sun∣derland, by his Majesty's Order, deliver'd into the House of Lords, the (so long expected) Act of Grace.

It was immediately ordered to be read, and had accordingly all the formal Reading as the Thing re∣quir'd, and was pass'd Nemine Contradicente, and sent down to the House of Commons, where it was likewise read and pass'd without any Amendment, and return'd to the Lords the same Afternoon, when
in the Evening the King came to the House, and put an end to the Session with the following Speech.

Q.P: My Lords and Gentlemen,

I Cannot put an End to this Session, witbout expres∣sing my Thanks to you, for the Dispatch you have given to the Publick Business, and declaring the Sa∣tisfaction I promise my Self in Meeting you again early the next Winter, with the same good Disposi∣tions for the Service of your Country. The Mea∣sures we have taken in this Parliament, have, by the Blessing of Almighty God, effectually defeated all the Attempts of our Enemies, both at Home and Abroad; and, as the Principles on which those Mea∣sures are founded, are equally conducive to the Sup∣porting the just Rights of the Crown, and the Liber∣ties of the People, I shall always persevere in them my self, and distinguish those who adhere to them with the same Steadiness and Resolution.
Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

P.HI:
I thank you, in the most affectionate Manner, for the Supplies you have granted me, and for that Con∣stancy and Zeal which you have shewn in Reducing our National Debts, notwithstanding the many Inci∣dents and Obstructions you have met with in the car∣rying on of that great Work. As you have furnish∣ed me with the Means of disappointing any Designs of a Foreign Enemy against these my Kingdoms, so I cannot but ascribe, in a great Measure, the happy Prospect of our Affairs Abroad, to that Publick Spirit which has appeared in your Proceedings; and has convinc'd the World, that no Insinuations or Ar∣tifices can divert you from your Duty to your Sove∣reign,
and a disinterested Regard to your Fellow-Subjects.

Q.P: My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.HI: It is with great Pleasure that I see the Tranquil∣lity of the Nation so well establish'd, as to admit of an Act of Grace, which I have long desired a fit Op∣portunity to grant. I hope that such as shall, by this Means, be restored to the Enjoyment of Secu∣rity, and the Protection of those Laws against which they have offended, will have a due Sense of this my Indulgence, and give me the most acceptable Return they can possible make me, that of becoming Friends, instead of Enemies, to their Country.

DIV3.P: And then the Lord Chancellor, by his Majesty's Command, said:

Q.P: My Lords and Gentlemen,

IT is His Majesty's Royal Will and Pleasure, That this Parliament be prorogued to Monday the Twelfth Day of August next, to be then here held; and this Parliament is accordingly prorogued to Monday the Twelfth Day of August next.

DIV3.P: The Parliament being now gone home, and the Act of Grace pass'd, the Prison Doors were every where open'd, and the Miserable obtain'd their Freedom in every Place; the Castle of Chester set open her Gates to upwards of 200, the Remains of the Rout at Preston; some of whom were reduced so low by the Misery of their Circumstances, that they were not able to stand on their Feet, or to take the Benefit of the Liberty that was offer'd.
At the Castles of Lancaster, Carlisle and Edin∣burgh, it was the like, only the Numbers were not so many.
As to the Persons excepted out of it, not reckon∣ing the ordinary Exceptions which are in all Pardons, they were only these.
First, The Earl of Oxford, in pursuance of the Address of the House of Commons abovementioned.
2. Simon Lord Harcourt, Lord Chancellor in the Reign of the late Queen.
3. Matth. Prior, Esq he was private Agent in the French Court, in the late Transaction of the Peace.
4. Tho. Harley, Esq he also was supposed to be sent over upon private and unjustifiable Practices, at the Time when the Treaty of Uroom was negotia∣ting, and to carry Instructions, &c.
5. Arthur Moor, he was one of the Commis∣sioners of Trade, and a private Negotiator in the Spanish Affairs.
6. James Duke Crisp.
7. Butler Nodes.
8. Daniel O Bryan.
9. Will. Redmayne, a Printer.
10. Robert Thompson.
Besides the Five Prisoners in Newgate, commonly call'd Assassinators, were excepted and continued, of which by it self.

I find nothing material remaining for this Year, but the long Contest among the Ecclesiasticks in the Case of the Bishop of Bangor, and his Antagonists, of which I avoid as much as possible to make any mention, as a Thing scandalous, not to the Parties concern'd only, but even to the Refor∣mation it self.

As to the Court, the King having determined not to go into Germany this Summer, removed with the Royal Houshold to Hampton-Court; where they remained till the Princess was obliged, being great with Child, to come up to St. James's to lye in; whither the King himself and the whole Court followed, a few Days after she was brought to Bed; the farther Particulars of all which, be∣long properly to the ensuing Year.

DIV2.HEAD: Anno 1717-18.
DIV2.P:
THE Pacifick Entrance into this Year, promised fair for a happy Conclusion of it; and had it not been for Factions and Divisions at Court, the King had seen his Reign flourishing and calm, with all the Prospects of a settled Peace that his Heart could desire. The Judicial Proceedings against the Remains of the Rebel∣lion, were all closed by the Act of Grace, of which mention has been made: The Judges (says
a certain Author,) now upon their Circuits, are em∣ployed rather in the pleasant Part of the Law, viz. of receiving the Plea of such who have laid hold of the King's general Pardon, than that more unsa∣tisfying Work of passing Sentence upon the Persons found Guilty.

The chief, if not the only Thing which was now upon the Stage on the Head of the late Troubles, was the Proceeding of the Commissioners for for∣feited Estates, so they were call'd, of whom menti∣on was made, in the preceding Part, and who had now separated themselves, to act in Vertue of their Trust, some in Scotland and some in England.

Those who sat in Scotland had met with great, and to them, insupportable Difficulties; not so much from the Proprietors of the Estates which were forfeited, for they were most of them out of the Capacity of offering any Obstruction to them, but the Opposition was from the Creditors of the At∣tainted Persons, who proceeding in the ordinary Course of Justice, and by the Authority of the Law, had actual Possession of the Estates in the Right of their Registred Bonds and Specialties, and refused to pay in the Rents which they received, into the Exchequer.

The Commissioners applied by a Petition, which is the usual Form, to the Lords of the Session, who are the Bench of Civil Judges in Scotland. The Sum of the said Petition is concluded thus: May it therefore please your Lordships to recal the Factors, formerly granted by your Lordships, upon the said Forfeited Estates, leaving the Care thereof to the Commissioners of Inquiry, according to the Intent and Meaning of the Act of Parliament? Upon this Petition, their Lordships, after many Debates, gave it for the Creditors: So that the Commissioners had
had no other Remedy but to lay it before the Parlia∣ment to be redress'd there; but it had not all the Success, even there, that was expected.

I know the more curious Readers will be very well pleased to know how the Creditors came to carry their Point so effectually against the Commis∣sioners in Scotland, and what were the Arguments which were so clear, and so convincing, that the whole Bench of Judges gave it against the Com∣missioners; for which Reason we have here given the Plea of the Creditors at large, as delivered into the Lords of the Session, by way of Answer to the Petition abovementioned: In which celebrated Piece the Reader will see the whole State of their Case, and upon what Foundation they obtained the Sentence of the SESSION, or Court of Civil Justice there, to keep the Possession even before the King himself.

P.HI: Answer on the Behalf of Claimants or Creditors to the said Bill or Petition.

DIV2.P:
HIS Majesty's Advocate and Sollicitor having been pleased to give in a Petition to your Lordships, for removing the Factors lately appointed for the Management of certain forfeited Estates, now vested in His Majesty by a late Act of Parlia∣ment; which Factors were Authorized by your Lordships, upon the Application of the Creditors on the said Estates, according to the ordinary Form of our Procedure in such Cases; the said Creditors be∣ing justly apprehensive of the Prejudice that may arise to them in Case of any alteration in the Ma∣nagement, and in bringing of the Rents of the said Estates: Do humbly presume to lay before your Lordships the Reasons why they conceive that any
Change in that Matter, will not only be highly prejudicial to them, but likewise of great Disad∣vantage to the Crown; and that the continuing the present Management by your Lordship's Factors, is no ways inconsistent with the late Act of Parlia∣ment appointing Commissioners to Enquire into the forfeited Estates, nor tends in any sort to incroach upon the Powers wherewith these Commissioners are vested.

The Creditors at the same time cannot but be under some Concern, that they are necessitate to state themselves in Opposition to a Demand made for the Interest of the Crown, to whose Justice and Favour they owe the Security that has been lately given them by Act of Parliament; but they hope, when they plead only in support of their just Debts in Consequence of that Act, they will not be understood to do any thing unbecoming that Duty and Gratitude they owe to his Majesty and the Par∣liament.

The Declaration for saving the Creditors Rights from any prejudice by the Forfeiture of their Deb∣tors, is contain'd in the Act of Parliament, Primo Georgij, Intituled, An Act for Encouraging all Su∣periors and Vassals, &c. whereby it is provided, “That no Convictions or Attainder, upon the Ac∣count of the High-Treason or Treasons mentioned in the said Act, shall hurt or exclude the Right or Diligence of any Creditor remaining Peaceable and Dutiful, for security or payment of any true, just and lawful Debts, contracted before the Com∣mission” of any such Crimes.

The Creditors do, with the greatest Cheerfulness, rely upon the publick Faith, and make no question but that all effectual Methods will be taken for sa∣tisfying their just Claim; and in order to constitute
the same; and carry on such Diligence as the Law requires, for compleating and securing their several Rights, they did make Application to your Lord∣ships for Sequestrating the said Estates: That in the mean time, the Rents might be managed by your Lordships Direction, for the common Benefit of all Persons claiming Interests, as your Lordships are accustomed to do in all such Cases, where there are many competing for the same Subject; and this Method of Sequestration is a known Course of Di∣ligence by the Law of Scotland, and what every Creditor has a Right to Demand, as a Common Se∣curity for all Parties concern'd: And the Nature of this Diligence by Sequestration, is an effectual Seiz∣ing the Possessions of the Estates, Goods, and Chat∣tels of the Debitors, for payment and satisfaction of their Debts, which therefore must continue till that End be obtained, otherwise it cannot be said, that the Diligence of Creditors are preserved to them according to the true Meaning and Intent of the above Clause, in the Act in Favour of the Creditors.

And here it may not be improper to observe to your Lordships, That according to the Laws and Constitutions of Scotland, it was the private Right of Creditors upon Forfeited Estates as well as others, to have their Debtors Estates put under Se∣questration; for which End, they were always in use to apply to your Lordships, which never was looked upon as any Incroachment upon the Right of the Crown: And 'tis certain, that the Court of Session was the only Court competent to Cognosce and Determine in all such Matters. And by the 18th Article of the Treaty of Union it is Provided, “That no Alteration be made in the Laws which concern private Rights, except for evident Utility
”of the Subjects within Scotland. And farther by the 19th Article, “That the Court of Session, after the Union, and notwithstanding there Remain in all time coming within Scotland, as it is now con∣stitute by the Laws of that Kingdom, and with the same Authorities and Privileges as before the” Union. From whence the Creditors hope they may justly infer, that if any Alteration, with Re∣gard to the private Right of the Subjects of Scot∣land had been intended, it would have been done in the most direct and positive Manner, and can very little be expected to be found in such Acts of Par∣liament as take notice of private Rights, in no other view, than in order to Ratify and Confirm them, and to declare they shall be in no manner Hurt or Excluded by any thing contained in the said Acts; which is the Case of the Act for Encou∣raging Superiors and Vassals, &c. as likewise of the other Act appointing Commissioners to Enquire into the Estates of certain Traytors: Which last Act, lest it should be understood any ways to impair or diminish any of the Advantages or Privileges given to Superiors, Vassals, Creditors, or others by the soresaid first Act, contains a saving Clause, whereby it is Enacted, “That nothing in the same shall Ex∣tend, or be construed to Extend to Take away, Alter, or Diminish, any Right, Title, Benefit, or Advantage whatsoever, which any Superior, Vas∣sal, Landlord, or Tenant, or any Creditor or o∣thers continuing Peaceable, and in dutiful Alle∣giance to His Majesty, are, shall, or may be Enti∣tled unto, in vertue of the first cited Act, or to Repeal, Alter, or make Void, any Provisions, Matters, or Things in that Act contained; any thing in the Act (appointing Commissioners) to the” contrary notwithstanding.

And when the Tenor of this Clause is consider'd, with the Ampleness and Extensiveness of the Terms with which every Privilege given to Cre∣ditors by the first Act, is preserved in the second, there can be little Reason to doubt, but that the Enquire Act leaves the Rights and Diligences of the Creditors upon the same Foot, as if the said Act had never been made. So that unless the first Act for encouraging Superiors, &c. be found in∣sufficient for securing the Rights and Diligences of Creditors, notwithstanding of the express and posi∣tive Declaration for that Purpose, the second Act can have no Influence, which neither gives nor takes away any Privileges with Regard to the Cre∣ditors, but only ratifies whatever Privileges they had a Right to by the said first Act.

In the Petition they do acknowledge the Bene∣fit given to Creditors by the aforesaid Act, for encouraging Superiors and Vassals, &c. And that the Rights and Diligences of all Creditors remain∣ing peaceable and dutiful, are preserv'd for any Prejudice that may arise from any Conviction or Attainder upon the Account of the High Treason of their Debitors, but does alledge, that as to the Inbringing and Receiving the Rents of the said for∣feit Estates, a particular Method is appointed by the other Act in the same Year of his Majesty's Reign, Intituled, An Act for appointing Commis∣sioners to enquire into the Estates of certain Tray∣tors; by a Clause of which Act (recited at large in the Petition) the Right and Possession of all the said forfeit Estates are vested in the Person of his Majesty; and all the Possessors of such E∣states are appointed to pay in the Rents thereof to the Exchequer, after previous Notice given to the said Commissioners of the particular Quantity and
Quality of the said Estates, and the Yearly Rents and Values thereof; from whence they are pleased to infer, that the Sequestrations appointed by your Lordships must cease, and your Lordships Facto∣ries be recalled, leaving the Care of these Estates to the said Commissioners of Enquiry, according to the Meaning and Intent of the said Act for bring∣ing in the Rents to the Exchequer, in the Method the said Act prescribes.

The Creditors with great Submission think, that there is no Inconsistency in the continuance of your Lordships Factories, notwithstanding of what the said Act provides, either as to the Inbringing of the said Rents to the Exchequer, or for discovering the true Value and Extent of them; and they crave Liberty to observe, that his Majesty's Advocate and Sollicitor seems not to Notice, that the Act does not simply appoint the Rents to be paid into the Exchequer; but the Clause runs with an alter∣native in these Words, “and shall yield and pay into the Receipt of the Exchequer of Scotland, all and every the Rents payable, and of the said Estates, or otherwise account for the Profits of the same, during the Time of their Occupation, from the said 24th of June 1715, until the Sale or Sales so to be made thereof.” Whereby it appears, there is no absolute Order for paying the Rents into the Exchequer; but where a Possessor has just Reasons, either for retaining the whole Rents, or any Part of them, which may happen in many Cases, according to the various Circum∣stances of the Rights of such Possessors, there is no Obligation lies, save only to Account during the Time of their Possession, which does sufficiently an∣swer the Design of the Law, which here appears to be, to discover the full Extent and Value of the
said Estates, and in whose Hands the same are, to the End that such Persons may afterwards be made liable for their Intromissions; but there appears nothing in the said Clause, and indeed, in no part of the Act, that points at the turning any Man out of his Possession; the Act only declaring all Possessors to be accountable to the Publick: At the making of which Accounts, the Titles of the re∣spective Possessors will fall to be Examined, and if found insufficient, can only then be set aside; so that those who possess by your Lordships Authority, as Factors, are in no different Case from any other Possessors, and stand accountable, as all other Pos∣sessors do, to the Publick, in the manner the Act of Enquiry has appointed; and are in the common Case with others, obliged to give Notice of their being in Possession, and of the Value and Yearly Rent of their Intromissions; which is all that the Act does require.

By which your Lordships will easily perceive, that neither the making the said Rents payable unto the Exchequer, nor the declaring all Possessors ac∣countable for their Intromissions, can afford any Ar∣gument for removing of your Lordships Factors, as if there were any Inconsistency in their continuing in the Possession, any more than any other Person; for they are accountable in the same manner as those must be, who may be put in their Places; and the Act plainly requires nothing farther, than that all Possessors in general shall be answerable for their Intromissions, without giving any Directions or Pow∣ers to the Commissioners of Enquiry, for making choice of particular Persons for the Management of the said Estates.

It will easily appear to your Lordships, That the Orders for paying in the Rents to the Exchequer,
could not have been made Absolute, but must have had the Alternative for Accounting; for if all Pos∣sessors had been without Distirction ordained to pay∣ing, the Act for encouraging Superiors and Vas∣sals, &c. could not have taken Effect, which never∣theless is Ratified by the Act of Enquiry; for Supe∣riors remaining dutiful, could not be said to have had the Benefit of their rebellious Vassals Forfeitures, if they were instantly to advance and pay these Rents into the Exchequer; and no more could Landlords have the Benefit of the Tacks of Leases, which the Law makes void in case of the Tacksmens Rebelli∣on; neither could the Tenants retain the Two Years Rents, and continue free of Payment of any Duty, if whatever belonged to the Rebels, without Di∣stinction, were to be paid into the Exchequer; which makes it obvious, That the Alternative was abso∣lutely necessary to prevent the excluding any Man's Right, until it were Judged and Cognosced upon in a legal Way.

Neither does the Clause vesting the Right and Possession of the said forfeit Estates in the Person of his Majesty; nor that other Clause, appointing the Commissioners to take in all Claims upon the said Estates, to the End the said Claims may be deter∣mined by such Acts of Parliament as shall afterwards be made, much contribute to make out that Incon∣sistency which his Majesty's Advocate and Sollici∣tor pretends there is in your Lordships Factors con∣tinuing their Management; for as to the said Estates being vested in his Majesty, that must be understood to be in the same manner as they were in the Person of the Rebels, and consequently with the Burthen of the Debts and Diligences, chargeable upon the said Estates, which are preserved in the most exten∣sive manner, by the two above cited Acts of Par∣liament;
and besides, whatever is under Sequestra∣tion by your Lordships Authority, is in Custodia Le∣gis for the behoof of the Crown, and of the Cre∣ditors, and all concerned, whose different Rights are unquestionably by the Law and Constitution of Scotland, determinable by your Court of Session, as the supreme Court in such Cases, and which, in all its Privileges and Authority, is expresly solved by the aforesaid Eighteen Articles of Union; and the declaring the Debts and Claims of the Creditors determinable by subsequent Laws, can be no hin∣derance; that in the mean time, all such Diligence may proceed as is competent to be used by the Laws of Scotland.

The Creditors must beg Liberty here to observe, the great Damage that must necessarily arise both to them and to the Publick, in case any stop should be put to your Lordships Factors, who as your Lordships know, are tied to many Regulations in their Management and manner of Compting, that the other Possessors or Factors will not be subject to; as particular, they are liable for the Interest of the Rents in their Hands after a certain time, which takes away a great Temptation others will have to delay the making of their Accounts: They are (besides several other Restraints put upon them) expresly made incapable to purchase any of the Cre∣ditors Rights upon the Estate they have in Manage∣ment; which Practice, before it was Discharged by your Lordships by a particular Act of Sederant, was of most pernicious Consequence to the Interest of the Creditors; and it's too much to be feared, may be used by such as are not legally debarred from it, to the Ruin of many poor necessitous People, whose Circumstance must force them to enter into any
Transactions for their present Relief, though never so disadvantageous.

Another Consequence of the Removal of your Lordships Factors, will, in all appearance, be, that those who had the Possession before the Sequestra∣tion, will re-assume their Possession again, and insist upon their being only liable to Account as Possessors, according as the Act of Parliament does appoint; and tho' new Factors should be named by the Com∣missioners of Enquiry, yet it is so probable, the Tenants and Possessors of the said Estates may de∣cline to pay to these Factors, upon pretence that they have a Right to Compt immediately with the Publick; or may, perhaps, insist upon the said Fa∣ctors Discharge to them not being sufficient to acquit them in Law, since there is not any direct or express Power given to the Commissioners of Enquiry for naming such Factors; which Difficulties, as they will not easily be removed without Processes at Law, so, during such Disputes, 'tis but too certain the Subject must perish, to the Prejudice both of the Crown and the Creditors.

His Majesty's Advocate and Sollicitor seems to acknowledge the Necessity there was from the then situation of Affairs, for your Lordships interposing and appointing the Method of managing of the said Estates; but does alledge, that now that the Com∣missioners are in the Exercise of their Trust, and with the Exchequer have special Powers for the Pre∣servation and Ingathering of these Rents, the Clause of your Lordships granting the Factories has now ceased.

If his Majesty's Advocate and Sollicitor had ap∣pointed out the special Powers given the Commis∣sioners for ordering the Collecting and Ingathering of the said Rent, the Creditors should have been
less selicitous by whom the Factories had been granted. But it is not asserted in any part of the Petition, that there is any express Clause in the aforesaid Act, naming the Management to be only by such Persons as should be appointed by the Com∣missioners; the Petition only insinuating it as a Mat∣ter of Expediency, that the Commissioners should have that Power for the better Executing of their Office, which the Creditors cannot but take as an Acknowledgment, that at least the Commissioners Powers, as to that particular, is doubtful; and so long as it remains so, your Lordships will be satis∣fied how great an Inconveniency would follow in case of removing those Factors already in the Ma∣nagement, when those to be put in their Places will be liable to such Exception, as cannot but occasion the greatest Confusion, as has been already noticed.

As to the Argument the Petition makes from the Power of the Commissioners of Enquiry, as to the disposing of the personal Goods and Chattels of the Rebels, that it ought to be equally extensive with regard to the real Estate; your Lordships will ob∣serve, that the Reason of committing the Goods and Chattels to the Commissioners Charge, which the Act takes notices of, was for preventing the Priesting of such Goods, or any Loss or Embezzlement that might happen; which was not to be feared, as to the Rents of the real Estates for which the Possessors are answerable, and which seems to be a good Rea∣son why the Law has not thought fit to commit the securing of those likewise to the Commissioners Charge.

The Petition takes notices, that the said Factors were appointed by your Lordships upon the Appli∣cation of the Creditors, and the Security taken be∣ing only in view of their Interest, without regard
to the Concern the Publick had in these Estates; there was no Reason for the Publick to acquiesce, or think so great Sums as may happen to come to the Hands of these Factors, to be safely lodged as to this Point; 'tis humbly thought there will be little Reason to doubt of the sufficiency of the Security with regard to the Creditors Debts only, but accor∣dingly to the value of the Subject to be intromitted with; and no doubt, whatever the Publick can pro∣pose for making the Security unexceptionable, will be gone into by your Lordships, and will be very acceptable to the Creditors; but even the altering any of the Factors upon the Account of any Obje∣ctions against the sufficiency of their Security, will not take off the Sequestration it self, which stands upon the sort of a Judicial Sentence of your Lord∣ships, and so cannot be removed, but according to the Form and Procedure of the Court, by an Action of Reduction; so that upon the whole, it must cer∣tainly be acknowledged, that no Method of Ma∣nagement can be supposed to be more advantageous in all Respects, both for the Interest of the Crown, that of the Creditors, and all others concerned, than the present, under your Lordships Direction, which the Creditors humbly hope will not be alter'd.
In Respect whereof, &c.
Dun Forbes.

After this there needs no farther entring into the Case: Upon this Answer, the Lords gave Sen∣tence, that they could not recal the Factors which they had granted upon the forfeited Estates, &c.
This Sentence is called in their Law an Interlocutor, and is as follows:

Q.P: Decree or Interlocutor of the Court of Session thereon, denying the recalling the said Seque∣strations.

P.HI: THE Lords having again considered the Petition for his Majesty's Advocate and Sollicitor, desi∣ring the Factories formerly granted upon the forfeited Estates to be recalled, and the Care thereof left to the Commissioners of Enquiry, and the Answers to the said Petition for the Claimants upon the said Estates, and having advised the same with the Debate, they find, that the Rents and Issues of forfeited Estates may be legally Sequestrated by Authority of the Lords of Session, upon Application of Creditors and others, claiming Interest therein by virtue of their several Rights and Diligences, and therefore re∣fuse the Desire of the Petition, without Prejudice to the Petitioners to insist, that the Factors, after just Satisfaction made to Creditors, and other just Clai∣mants preferable to the Crown, should pay into the Exchequer the superplus for the behoof of the Pub∣lick, as Law directs; as also after extinguishing of the said preferable Claims by Payment or otherwise, to apply for removing the said Sequestration as ac∣cords; and also reserving to the Petitioners to object, in the mean time, against any particular Sequestra∣tion granted, or against the Choice of any Factor named, or against the Sufficiency of the Security gi∣ven by any of the Factors named.

DIV2.P: Hugh Dalrymple, J. P. D.
The general Value on the List of the Estates in Scotland, seiz'd by these Commissioners, was as fol∣lows, viz.

The first Parliament Business we meet with this Year, is in Ireland, where the Duke of Bolton being Lord Lieutenant, the Parliament set down the 27th, when the new Peers who were Created as above, being Introduc'd, the Duke open'd the Session with the following Speech.

Q.P: My Lords and Gentlemen,

HIS Majesty has commanded me to acquaint you, That it is to His great Satisfaction, your pre∣sent Meeting in Parliament is in a Time of publick Peace and Tranquillity, and after the entire Sup∣pression of the late unnatural Rebellion, which your seasonable Loyalty and Zeal, not only kept out of this Kingdom, but contributed likewise to extinguish in Great Britain. As the Miseries this Nation hath heretofore experienced from a Popish Government, could not but animate you to distinguish your selves on that Occasion, you may be assured that His Majesty will make suitable Returns to such Instances of your Duty and Affection, by supporting and maintaining you in the full and free Enjoyment of all your Reli∣gious and Civil Rights.
Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

P.HI: Your vigorous Resolutions, added to your Vote of Credit in the late critical Juncture, were so accepta∣ble to his Majesty, that tho' He has, by His Act of Grace, Pardoned those who were ingaged in the late Rebellion, he will always remember the Loyal and Affectionate Endeavours of such who were so active to defeat it.

You must be sensible, that the Charge occasion'd by those Disturbances, has considerably augmented the National Debt, which has been chiefly incurred since that time; an exact and just Account of which,

and of what it consists, shall be laid before you. And I am to acquaint you, that His Majesty, to prevent its Increase, has given Orders for such Reductions in the Military List, as He thinks may be consistent with your present Security, and has put the new Establishment into such a Form, as will shew you the real Number of effective Men you have to depend on. His Majesty has likewise thought fit to lessen the Civil List on the Head of Pensions, and has di∣rected such Rules to be observed, as may annually abate the Expence upon them: But as the yearly Charge of the Establishment exceeds the annual Pro∣duce of the Revenue, His Majesty doubts not to have such Aids and Supplies granted him, as will sup∣port the Establishment and discharge the Debt; and that you will agree on the Means of doing it with the same Unanimity, as you did when it was necessa∣ry to contract it.

DIV2.P: My Lords and Gentlemen,

I think my self obliged to take Notice to you, of His Majesty's great Goodness, in having lately passed an Act in the Parliament of Great-Britain, for the Encouragement of the Linen Manufacture in this Kingdom. And am commanded by his Majesty to recommend to you, in a very particular Manner, Unanimity and Agreement amongst your selves in all your Proceedings, which His Majesty conceives must be of the utmost Importance to His Service, and your own Security, in a Country where there is so great a Disproportion between the Friends and Enemies of our Religion, Laws and Liberties.

I cannot conclude, without expressing the Satisfacti∣on I have, in His Majesty's sending me again to a Kingdom, where I had formerly the Honour to serve the late King William of Glorious Memory, as one of
the Lords Justices, and where I then received so many Instances of your good Will towards me. I shall endeavour still to preserve your Affections, by repre∣senting your Actions in a just and true Light to His Majesty, and by doing every thing in my Power, that may conduce to the publick Good.

As soon as the Commons were gone back to their House, and their Speaker had reported the Speech, they unanimously Voted an Address of Thanks to the Lord Lieutenant for his Speech, and the Lords did the like in their House; These Addresses being as well to the King as to the Lord Lieutenant, and being only Things of Course, consisting of Compli∣ments to the Lord Lieutenant, and Assurances of Duty and Loyalty to the King, I omit, as too long to take Place here.

This Parliament, to give them their due, pass'd a great many excellent Laws for the Improvement, Advantage and Security, as well of Religion as of Commerce, Planting, Manufacturing in the King∣dom, &c. Also they revived a great many expiring Laws, of all which I shall speak in their Place.

But with these good Things, they forgot not beginning where they left off, viz. in the prosecu∣ting the Offenders of the former Times: And tho' the King had shewn them an Example of Clemency, in publishing an Act of Grace for the Ease of his People, they did not think fit to let the Example be sufficient to recommend itself to them, in the Case which at that Time was before them; nay, as a Wri∣ter of that Time published, so vindictive was the Temper reigning at that Time, that they took so little Notice of the Pattern set by his Majesty, that they even refused to accept the Penitence of a Gentleman of their own House, who humbly ac∣knowledged
his Offence, declared himself to be hear∣tily sorry for it, and begg'd Pardon of the House, or at least was ready to do so; but when it came to the Question in the House, Whether his humble Ac∣knowledgment should be accepted by the House? it pass'd in the Negative; and they order'd him to be expelled the House; and yet this great Crime was much less than those forgiven by his Majesty, for it was neither Treason, or Rebellion; only that it seems he had signed an Address to the late Queen from the County of Lowth, in Opposition to an Address of the late House of Commons.

For this capital Offence, tho' abundance of Gen∣tlemen has been excused the last Session upon their Submission, and others had been censur'd, the Re∣sentment was not thereby allay'd; but on the 9th of September, or thereabout, they call'd upon one John Leigh, Esq for signing the Address from the Coun∣ty of Lowth in the late Queen's Time, and the Ad∣dress being read, they order'd that Mr. Leigh be now called upon in his Place, to give an Account of his Reasons for signing the said Address; which be∣ing done, Mr. Leigh stood up in his Place, confessed he had sign'd the said Address, that he was heartily sorry for his Fault, and humbly begg'd Pardon of the House.

Upon this the Question was put, That the Sub∣mission of Mr. Leigh be accepted as a Satisfaction to the House; and a Debate arising upon it, the Debate was put off to that Day Sevennight, when being called again, and the Debate revived, it pas∣sed in the Negative, viz. That the Submission should not be accepted, and thereupon Mr. Leigh was expelled the House.

In this Manner the House went on, not omitting, however, the publick Business; all the Supplies the King demanded they readily came into, and made effectual Provisions for: Likewise they recom∣mended several Sufferers in the former Reign to the Government for Relief and Rewards; so that they exercis'd some Charity as well as Justice.

There was indeed one Thing moved in the Par∣liament, which we shall only touch here, hoping to hear more of it, viz. That the Archbishop of—, moved in the House of Peers, that for the Honour of Religion, and for propagating the Reformation in Ireland, he was willing to divest himself of a considerable Part of the Revenues of his Bishoprick, to augment the Stipends and Income of poor Livings in the Country, and for the Encou∣ragement of the inferior Clergy to do their Duty; that their Maintenance may be sufficient to support them in the Discharge of their Duty. We find lit∣tle Notice taken of this Piece of Christian Genero∣sity; but we shall not fail to Record it, and give due Acknowledgments to it, that Posterity may see there have been some among us, in this Age of the Church's Degeneracy, who have yet been moved with a Spirit of true Christianity, and a disinterested Zeal for the Protestant Religion, and the Reforma∣tion, even in Ireland it self: We do not hear yet what Encouragement such a pious Proposal has met with; we know it was at first seconded by very few; but there is Hope yet that it may revive.

Tho' 'tis some Interruption to the Story of the Parliament, yet I cannot omit here, that 'tis to an Accident in this Year, that we say the Rise of the formidable Body of Pirates is owing, who to this Day infest our Commerce and Colonies in America, commonly call'd the West-Indies; the best Ac∣count
I meet with of this Affair, is as fol∣lows,

To begin at the beginning of it, we must observe, That sundry Causes are assign'd to this Evil, but principally this, viz. The Spaniards in America are very chary of their Commerce, that is to say, to prevent our Sloops and Brigantines appearing upon their Coast from Jamaica, and other Places, to car∣ry on a private Trade there; and two or three Spa∣nish Men of War plied so diligently upon the Coast of Cartagena and St. Martha, that our Sloops could not Trade there without great Danger, and one or two were taken: This so exasperated our Jamaica Traders, that taking a sufficient Force with them, they resolved upon a private Expedition, to be re∣veng'd of the Spaniards.

Accordingly two Ships and three Sloops were fitted out, some from Port-Royal, others from St. Christophers, but Mann'd among the Adventu∣rers, as they call them, or at least Mann'd with some of them; these are they we call Campeachy Men, but who are indeed no better or worse than Buccaneers; that is, Fellows ready for any Adven∣ture, to Rob or Plunder any one they could fall up∣on. These Vessels being joined, go away to the Gulph of Florida, where the Spanish Galleons or Plate Fleet, had, two Years before, been Wreck'd and cast away, and where they were at Work with several Vessels from the Havana, with divers En∣gines, to Fish up the Silver that was on Board the Galleons.

The Spaniards had recover'd several Millions of Pieces of Eight, and had carried it all to the Hava∣na; but they had at present about 350000 Pieces of Eight in Silver then upon the Spot, and were daily taking up more. This Money was left on Shore,
the Men in the Vessels sending on Shore every Night what they Fished up in the Day; and there it was deposited in a Store-house, under the Government of two Commissaries, and a Guard of about Sixty Soldiers.

Our Rovers come directly to the Spot, bring their little Fleet to an Anchor, and, in a Word, landing Three Hundred Men, they attack'd the Guard, who immediately run away, and thus they seized the Treasure, which they carried away, making the best of their way to Jamaica.

In their way they unhappily met with a Spanish Ship, bound from Porto Bello to the Havana, with a great many rich Goods, viz. Bales of Cochineal, Casks of Indico, and 60000 Pieces of Eight more, which their Hands being in, they took also, and ha∣ving rifled the Vessel, let her go.

They went away to Jamaica with their Booty, and were followed thither, that is, in View of the Port, by the Spaniards, who having seen them thither, went back to the Governor of the Havana with the Account of it, who immediately sent a Vessel to the Governor of Jamaica to complain of this Robbery, and to reclaim the Goods.

As it was in full Peace, and contrary to all Justice and Right that this Fact was committed, they were soon made sensible that the Government at Jamaica would not suffer them to go unpunished, much less protect them: They therefore saw a Necessity of shifting for themselves, and so to make Bad Worse, they went to Sea again, tho' not without disposing their Cargo to good Advantage, and furnishing them∣selves with Ammunition, Provision, and better Ships, and being thus made Desperate, they turn'd Pirates, robbing not the Spaniards only, but their own Coun∣try-men, and any Nation they could lay their Hands on.

Add to this, another Misfortune, viz. That the Spaniards, with Seven or Eight small Men of War, falling about this Time upon the Buccaneers, or Log∣wood-Cutters, in the Bay of Campeachy, and taking all their Ships from them, and forcing the Men to Surrender upon Condition of having their Lives given them, and a Vessel, tho' with no Fire Arms or Ammunition, to carry them Home: These Men, made desperate, fell in with the rest, and encreased their Number.

It would be too long to give an Account here of their Piracies; it may suffice to observe, that they took abundance of Ships, and plundered them always of Three Things, viz. Money, Ammuni∣tion, and Victuals, and by this Means grew vastly Rich: and, as in such Cases it always happens, all the loose, rakish, desperate Fellows in the Islands, that had nothing to do, or live on, and were bent for Mischief and Adventures, got toge∣ther, and went to them, till at last growing very strong, they consulted together about getting some Retreat, where they might lodge their Wealth, re∣pair their Ships, and make themselves a kind of Abode.

They were not long in resolving; but sailing di∣rectly to the Isle of Providence, or New Providence, they seiz'd upon it, landed their People, and fell to work to fortify. Here they now reign, and be∣ing, as we hear, about Four Thousand Men, and Twenty or Thirty Vessels of all Sorts, they rove about the Sea, scouring the Coasts of our Colonies of Carolina, Virginia, nay, up as high as New-Eng∣land, to the inconceivable Prejudice of Commerce, and Ruin of our People.

The Government having been applied to for Re∣lief in this Case, have, at the Motion of some
People, who know something of the Disposition of these Pirates, first taken the gentle Method of of∣fering them a Pardon by Proclamation: which Pro∣clamation Sir Nicholas Lawes, the New Gover∣nour of Jamaica, who is now going over, is to carry with him; in which also is included, Re∣wards to all those who shall seize and apprehend any of them, after the Time for accepting that Pardon is elaps'd. The Proclamation is very par∣ticular and worth Recording, and that with the Proclamation may be seen the Account the Go∣vernment had of them, and the Means used for sup∣pressing them, we have also given the Appoint∣ment of the Men of War for that Service, and the Measures taken for the attacking them, as fol∣lows:

P.HI: Whitehall,

DIV2.P: COmplaint having been made to His Majesty, by great Numbers of Merchants, Masters of Ships, or others, as well as by several Gover∣nours of His Majesty's Islands and Plantations in the West-Indies, that the Pirates are grown so numerous, that they infest not only the Seas near Jamaica, but even those of the Northern Conti∣nent of America; and that unless some effectual Means be used, the whole Trade from Great-Bri∣tain to those Parts, will not only be obstructed, but in imminent Danger of being lost: His Ma∣jesty has, upon mature Deliberation in Council, been graciously pleas'd, in the first Place, to or∣der a proper Force to be employ'd for suppressing the said Piracies, which Force so to be employ'd, is as follows:

P.Q: “A List of His Majesty's Ships and Vessels em∣ploy'd, and to be employ'd, at the British Go∣vernments” and Plantations in the West-Indies.

ROW.CELL: Sailed from hence thither the 5th of last Month.
Surveying the Coast of the West-Indies, and then to return Home; but during her being at Jamaica, is to join the others for Security of the Trade, and inter∣cepting the Pirates.
Sail'd thither from hence the 7th of last Month, and is to cruize about the Capes.

P.Q: “Those at Jamaica, Barbadoes, and the Lee∣ward Islands, are to joyn upon Occasion, for an∣noying the Pirates, and the Security of the Trade: And those at New-England, Virginia, and New-York,” are to do the like.

DIV2.P: And that nothing may be wanting for the more effectually putting an End to the said Piracies, His Majesty has also been graciously pleased to issue the following Proclamation.

DIV3.HEAD: By the King, A PROCLAMATION, For Suppressing of PIRATES.

Q.P: GEORGE R.

WHereas we have received Information, that several Persons, Subjects of Great Britain, have since the Twenty fourth Day of June, in the Year of our Lord, One thousand seven hundred and fifteen, committed divers Piracies and Robberies up∣on the High Seas in the West Indies, or adjoyning to our Plantations, which hath and may occasion great Damage to the Merchants of Great Britain, and others, trading into those Parts; and though we have appointed such a Force as we judge sufficient for suppressing the said Piracies, yet the more ef∣fectually to put an End to the same, we have thought fit, by and with the Advice of our Privy Council, to issue this our Royal Proclamation; and we do here∣by and declare, that in Case any of the said Pirates shall, on or before the Fifth Day of Septem∣ber, in the Year of our Lord One thousand seven hundred and eighteen, surrender him or themselves to one of our Principal Secretaries of State in Great Britain or Ireland, or to any Governour, or Deputy-Governour of any of our Plantations beyond the Seas, every such Pirate and Pirates so surrendring him or themselves, as aforesaid, shall have our gracious Par∣don of and for such his or their Piracy or Piracies, by him or them committed before the Fifth of January
next ensuing. And we do hereby strictly charge and command all our Admirals, Captains, and other Officers at Sea, and all our Governours and Com∣manders of any Forts, Castles, or other Places in our Plantations, and all other our Officers Civil and Military, to seize and take such of the Pirates, who shall refuse or neglect to surrender themselves accordingly. And we do hereby farther declare, that in case any Person or Persons, on or after the Sixth Day of September, One thousand seven hundred and eighteen, shall discover, or seize, or cause, or pro∣cure to be discovered, or seized, any one or more of the said Pirates, so refusing or neglecting to surren∣der themselves, as aforesaid, so as they may be brought to Justice, and convicted of the said Offence, such Person or Persons, so making such Discovery or Seizure, or causing or procuring such Discovery or Seizure, to be made, shall have and receive as a Reward for the same, viz. for every Commander of any private Ship or Vessel, the Sum of One Hundred Pounds; for every Lieutenant, Master, Boatswain, Carpenter, and Gunner, the Sum of Forty Pounds; for every Inferior Officer the Sum of Thirty Pounds; and for every private Man the Sum of Twenty Pounds. And if any Person or Persons belonging to, and being Part of the Crew of any such Pirate Ship or Vessel, shall, on or after the said Sixth Day of September, One thousand seven hundred and eigh∣teen, seize and deliver, or cause to be seized or de∣livered, any Commander or Commanders of such Pi∣rate Ship or Vessel, so as that he or they be brought to Justice, and convicted of the said Offence, such Person or Persons, as a Reward for the same, shall receive for every such Commander the Sum of Two Hundred Pounds; which said Sums, the Lord Trea∣surer, or the Commissioners of our Treasury for the
Time being, are hereby required and directed to pay accordingly.
Given at our Court at Hampton-Court, the Fifth Day of September, 1717, in the Fourth Year of our Reign.
God Save the KING.

DIV3.P:
And whereas it has also been represented to His Majesty, that in March, 1705-6, the House of Lords did, in an Address to Her late Majesty, set forth, “That the French and Spaniards had twice, during that War, over-run and plunder'd the Bahama Islands; That there was no Form of Go∣vernment there: That the Harbour of the Island of Providence might be easily put in a Posture of Defence, and that it would be of dangerous Consequence should those Islands fall into the Hands of an Enemy; wherefore the Lords hum∣bly besought Her Majesty, to use such Methods as she should think proper, for taking the said Island into her Hands, in order to secure the same to the Crown of this Kingdom, and to the Security and Advantage of the Trade thereof:” But that there were not any Means used, in Com∣pliance with that Address, for securing the said Bahama Islands; and that at this Time the Pi∣rates have a Lodgment with a Battery on Harbour Island, one of the Bahamas; as also, that the usual Retreat and general Receptacle for Pirates is at Pro∣vidence, the principal of those Islands: His Ma∣jesty has been farther graciously pleas'd to give Di∣rections for dislodging those Pirates who have ta∣ken Shelter in the said Islands, as also as for secu∣ring those Islands, and making Settlements and a
Fortification there, for the Safety and Benefit of Trade and Navigation in those Seas for the fu∣ture.

But I return to the Proceedings in the Irish Par∣liament; their Resentments at some Proceedings by the Mayor of Gallway, and some other of the Citi∣zens there, were carried so high, that the Mayor Mr. Coates, with one Mr. Staunton and others, fled from them to England, where they publish'd their Case, and laid it before the Parliament in England; but it is too long for these Sheets, and as we are told it is likely to come upon the Stage again be∣fore an English Parliament, I may refer it to that Time.

They had the like Dispute before them on Account of the City of Kilkenny, in both which Cases things went with an high hand against the Proceed∣ings in those Cities in the late Times, the opposite Party were all censur'd, and those who did not abscond, were order'd to be taken into Custody.

Likewise this Irish Parliament did one thing which we very rarely see done in England; this was, that whereas several Members had been order'd to be ta∣ken into Custody the Year before, but had abscon∣ded till the Sessions was over, believing themselves secure after the Prorogation, as is the Custom here, the House caused enquiry to be made after it, and issued new Orders for taking them into Custody now on the former Account; but they also absconded again: And as for the Citizens of Kilkenny, who they censur'd, they order'd a Bill to be brought in to disfranchise them, (viz.) four Aldermen, one Common-Council Man and one Freeman; and for the better regulating the said Corporation.

They continued sitting till the 23d of December, when all Things being arrived from England, were
pass'd by the Lord Lieutenant, and then they were prorogued.

At their presenting the Money-Bills, their Spea∣ker made a long Speech, and at the conclusion of all, the Houses deliver'd very dutiful Addresses to the Lord Lieutenant, to be transmitted to the King, and thus their long Session ended, and we are likely to hear no more of them for a good while, being since that prorogued to August 1719.
Before I come to the Meeting of the British Par∣liament, several material Things occur to be re∣corded, of which I shall speak what is necessary, but as briefly as possible.

The King having resolv'd not to go into Germany this last Summer, resided at Hampton-Court all the Summer Season, where his Majesty drank the Wa∣ters of Pyrmont, which he had caused to be brought over on purpose, and having finished the usual Course of taking the Waters, the King resolved to take a Tour into the Country, and particularly to New-Market to see the Horse-Races.

The King set out from Hampton-Court the 2d, and tho' he was much stopp'd by the tedious pas∣sing thro' Southwark, over the Bridge, and thro' the City, yet fresh Horses being laid at short Stages, they drove thro' in a Day, and the King came thither about Seven a Clock in the Evening.

It would take up too much Room here to enter into the Particulars of the Journey; how the Coun∣try People flock'd to see the King; and what Joy they shew'd on that Occasion: But his Majesty's visiting the University cannot be omitted. The Vice-Chancellor, Mr. Gregg, with the Heads of the Colleges, waited on his Majesty in Form at New-Market, and made their Compliment; to which the King returned the following Answer:

Q.P: Mr. Vice-Chancellor,
I Thank you for the Assurance you give me of your Duty and Affection, and the Ʋniversity may al∣ways depend on my Favour and Encouragement.

DIV3.P: Then they invited his Majesty to the University, which was accepted, and accordingly the King went, as we shall see presently. In the mean time, the Gentlemen were very magnificently treated at Din∣ner by his Majesty's special Order, and went Home to prepare to do the like to the King.

At New-Market, the Sport and the Pleasure of the Country was very much abated, by the violent, and almost incessant Rains; but the King was, how∣ever, on Horseback early, hunted a Hare in the Morning, and then came upon the Course, and saw the Races.
The next Day his Majesty din'd at Chippenham, a fine new built Seat of the Earl of Orford's, built all new, and which, with the Gardens, it is said cost his Lordship Forty Thousand Pieces.

The next Day being Sunday, the King went to Cambridge. His Reception there, and what pass'd upon that Occasion, I shall give in a few Words. His Majesty was first met out of the Town by the Magistrates, or Corporation, according to the Usage on such Occasions; when the Mayor addressing him∣self very handsomly to the King, made the Town's Present, which is a Purse with a certain Number of Pieces of Gold, which it seems they are obliged to, as often as, or perhaps the first Time, that the Sovereign comes to the Place.

For the Reception of his Majesty by the Univer∣sity, the Schollars were placed in their Habits, and in the College Order, in a Line on each Street, and
were ordered to Shout in Latin as the King passed by, VIVAT REX: It is said they were or∣der'd to kneel at the same time, but the Croud made that impracticable. The Mayor and Corporation came on before his Majesty in their Formalities bare-headed, and stopping at the School, his Ma∣jesty was received there with a Latin Oration pro∣nounced kneeling, by Dr. Ayloff, the University O∣rator: After this, his Majesty entred the Schools, where the Vice-Chancellor Mr. Gregg, who till then was not a Graduate, was made Doctor, as also another, that the King might see the Manner of the Commencement; after which, the King gave them a List of Names, being such as his Majesty thought fit to have created Doctors, or of other Degrees.

From hence they went to King's College Chap∣pel in the same Order, where his Majesty heard Di∣vine Service, the Bishop of Norwich turning over the Common Prayer Book, and pointing out the Prayers to the King. After the Sermon, his Ma∣jesty went to Trinity College; he was received in the College Hall by Dr. Bentley, attended by the whole Body of the Fellows and Students: The Doctor made a Speech to his Majesty, and, after the usual Ceremony, the King din'd in the Master's, Dr. Bentley's Appartment, the said Master waiting at Table. In the Evening his Majesty having been pleased to let the University know that he was well pleased with his Entertainment, and having Knight∣ed Mr. Thompson of Trumpington, returned to New-Market, and the next Day came back to Hamp∣ton Court.
The Names of the several Graduates advanc'd up∣on this Occasion were as follow:

It was observable, that when the King went thro' the City for New-Market, as above, a poor Fellow, by Trade a Weaver, crowding to see the King in the Street of White-Chappel, was thrust down so under the Coach that the King's Coach Wheel wnt over his Leg and broke it: The King call'd out to
some of his Servants to order the Man to be taken Care of, which was done, and when the Man was cured, upon Application to his Majesty by the King's own Surgeon, the King order'd him 50 l. in Money to pay for the Cure, and a Pension of 20 l. a Year during his Life.

In this Interval of the King's Progress to Cambridge, the Princess of Wales being great with Child, re∣moved to St. James's for her lying in, and on the 2d of November she was safely deliver'd of a Prince, which was for a while the occasion of great Rejoi∣cings; but all that soon inverted, and the unhappy Infant was innocently the Original of a melancholy Scene at Court, which is not yet removed.

By this I mean the Breach between the King and the Prince, his Majesty's only Son, which begin∣ning at the Solemnity of the Christening of the Prince's Son, ended in banishing the Prince himself from the Court, and from the Presence and Council of the King his Father, which Breach and Distance remains so to this Day.

In a few Days after the Princess was brought to Bed, the Season growing extreme Wet, and the sitting of the Parliament, or at least the Preparati∣ons for it, requiring particular Application, his Ma∣jesty with the whole Court came to Town.

About the beginning of November, and as it were to anticipate the Applications which were preparing to be made from several Parts of the Country to the Parliament, for disbanding the Army, the King of his own accord seeing all things in Peace, order'd a Reduction of the Forces.

This Reduction was very considerable, tho' not so much as some thought reasonable, for the re∣maining Army amounted to above 16000, which being near double the Number of the usual British
Establishment in Time of Peace, caused great Strug∣gles in the ensuing Parliament for a farther Reducti∣on, as shall be shewed in its Place.
This Reduction being once Resolv'd on, was put in Execution with such Celerity, that between the 13th and the 23d of November all the Troops were reduc'd, and the new Model of the Army form'd.

In this Interval, the Convocation met pursuant to their former Prorogation, but found no Access to enter upon the Business which was expected, viz. the Controversy with the Bishop of Bangor: On the contrary, they met with a farther Prorogation for some Months longer. Some thought, that up∣on the Occasion of this Prorogation, the Bishop of Bangor would have been desired, or at least of his own accord, and to shew himself a fair Adversary, would have likewise forborn entring any farther into the Controversy in Print, and that consequently, his Answer to the Report of the Convocation, of which the World had frequent Hints that it was preparing, would have been laid aside, till the Convocation had been at Liberty of Acting, and might have had Opportunity of replying again.

But they who thought so, either knew not the Bishop, or knew nothing of his Designs; for upon Assurance of the Prorogation being at hand, his Answer was prepar'd; but whether upon Assurance of its being Prorogued the Answer was resolved to be published, is not equally certain: Be that as it will, on the Monday after the Parliament met, his Lordship's Answer to the Convocation was pub∣lished.
On the 21st of November the Parliament met, and the King open'd the Session as usual with a Speech, as follows, viz.
My Lords and Gentlemen,

I Am very glad I have been able to bring the Sitting of Parliament into a more proper and usual Sea∣son of the Year: I hope such an early Meeting will not only be a Benefit to the Publick, but a Conveni∣ence to your Private Affairs.

P.HI: As I have always had at Heart the Security and Ease of my People; so I never kept up any Troops but for their Protection, and have taken every Op∣portunity to Disband as many as I thought consistent with their Safety. I have Reduced the Army to very near one half, since the Beginning of the last Session of Parliament, and Lessened them to such a Num∣ber, as will neither be a Burthen to my good Sub∣jects, nor an Encouragement to our Enemies to In∣sult them.

DIV3.P: You cannot but be sensible of the many Attempts which have been set on foot to disturb the Peace of Europe, and of these Kingdoms: They only pretend not to see, who are not afraid of them. But as no Application has been wanting on my Part to preserve the Publick Tranquillity; I have the Pleasure to find my good Offices have not been altogether Ʋnsuccessful, and have Reason to hope they will, in the End, have their full and desired Effect.

Q.P: Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

P.HI: I question not but you are very well pleased to find that your Endeavours for lessening the National Debts, have at the same time rais'd the Publick Cre∣dit; and that whatever was proposed for that End, is actually and compleatly effected. This Success must chiefly be attributed to that just and prudent
Regard you have shewn to Parliamentary Engage∣ments.

It was with the View of procuring and settling a lasting Tranquillity, that I demanded the Extraordi∣nary Supply which you granted Me last Session. The Credit which this Confidence reposed in Me hath gi∣ven us Abroad, his already been so far effectual, that I can acquaint you we have a much better Pro∣spect than we had. I have ordered an Account to be laid before you, of the very small Part of that Sup∣ply which as yet has been expended; any farther Issues that may be made of it, shall be also laid before you: And you may be assured, that every Part of it shall either be imployed for your Service, or saved to the Publick.

I have ordered to be laid before you a State of the Deficiencies of the present Year, and the several Esti∣mates for the Service of the next, which you will find considerably diminished. I rely upon your ma∣king the necessary Provision for them; not doubting of the Continuance of that Zeal for the Good of your Country, which hath been so eminently Conspicuous in every Session of this Parliament.

I cannot, in Justice, avoid putting you in mind, that several Arrears of Pay and Subsidy, incurred before My Accession to the Crown, are claimed by Fo∣reign Princes and States: I shall order them to be laid before you, to the End you may put them in a Method of being Examined and Stated; which will very much tend to the Honour and Credit of the Na∣tion.

Q.P: My Lords and Gentlemen,

I could heartily wish, that at a Time when the Com∣mon Enemies of our Religion are, by all manner of
Artifices, endeavouring to undermine and weaken it both at Home and Abroad, all those who are Friends to our present happy Establishment, might unanimously concur in some proper Method for the greater strengthning the Protestant Interest; of which, as the Church of England is unquestionably the main Sup∣port and Bulwark, so will She reap the principal Be∣nefit of every Advantage accruing by the Union, and mutual Charity of all Protestants.

P.HI: As none can recommend themselves more effectually to my Favour and Countenance than by a sincere Zeal for the just Rights of the Crown, and the Liberties of the People; so I am determined to Encourage all those who act agreeably to the Constitution of these My Kingdoms, and consequently to the Principles on which My Government is founded.

Q.P: The Eyes of all Europe are upon you at this Criti∣cal Juncture: It is your Interest, for which Reason I think it Mine, that my Endeavours for procuring the Peace and Quiet of Christendom should take Ef∣fect. Nothing can so much contribute to this de∣sirable End, as the Unanimity, Dispatch, and Vigour of your Resolutions for the Support of My Govern∣ment.

DIV3.P: The Addresses and Answers following this Speech as things of Course, I also of Course omit, being too tedious and of too little import to interrupt the Thread of my Story; it is enough to say they were full of dutiful Expressions, Promises of complying with, and dispatching what the King demanded, and the like.

Besides the usual Addresses, the Houses took up some Time in congratulating the Royal Family on the Birth of the young Prince; this they did to the
Prince by a Message, but to the King by an Ad∣dress.

The Part of the King's Speech, which pointed at the Liberty of the Dissenters, and taking off the restraining Laws from them, gave great Um∣brage for a while; but as the House offer'd no∣thing at it, and the Court push'd it no farther, all the Strife and Dissatisfaction which that Affair threaten'd in its Time, was happily and wisely prevented.

While these Things were doing, we had a little Spice of Rebellion in the West of England; but tho' some People went a great way to persuade us there was some Jacobitism and Treason in it, yet it must be confess'd, upon a clear Enquiry into the Fact, there was nothing of that kind to be found in it; only a little popular Discontent between the Weavers, Wool-combers, &c. in Devonshire, and their Employers about the Rates of their Wages, working Irish Yarn, and the like; and yet we will not say, but the Disorder was such as may bring a few of them to the Gallows, if his Majesty's Cle∣mency do not interpose.

It was the latter End of November, that Sir George Eyng, with the English Squadron of Men of War returned from the Baltick, after a very rough, stor∣my, hazardous Voyage, bringing over with him under his Convoy 200 Sail of Merchant Ships, and not having yet found any occasion of Hostility against the Swedish Fleet, or been able to discover any thing of the great Design which it was said the Swedes had against us in Favour of the Preten∣der.

It was the third of the same Month that the Prince of Wales's Son was baptiz'd, and upon the occasion
whereof, some Words happen'd between the Prince and the Duke of Newc—e; which Words, and the Circumstances of them, were such, as gave the King great Offence, and from which has proceeded all the Misunderstanding that has happen'd since between the Prince and the King his Father.

I will not enter into this Story in my own Words, but keeping only to the Truth of that Fact as near as I can give it in the Form in which it has been already published; for I shall be very loth to give Offence on one Side or on the other.

The Third of December was appointed for the baptizing the young Prince, the King's Grandson; his Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, Father to the Royal Infant, had it seems pitch'd upon the Duke of York, Bishop of Osnburgh, his Majesty's Brother, to be one of the Godfathers, as being the true Parain, viz. the next of Kin; after the King himself (as I suppose) intended the Lord Cham∣berlain of the Houshold, viz. the Duke of New∣castle, to represent him; and as his Royal Highness expresses it (in one of the Letters, which it is said he wrote to the King) if those Copies we see in Print are Genuine, he was made to believe that the King appeared easie in the Choice he had made.

But when the Ceremony came to be perform'd, the Duke of Newcastle stood Godfather with the King, not as Proxy, or representing the Duke of York, but for himself in his own Name and Person. This the Prince says in the same Letters (if genuine as above) he thought an unaccountable Hardship, and there is no doubt his Royal Highness made some Steps to have prevented or avoided it as a Hardship; at least while he thought there was room for it, and while he might imagine that it was not
a Thing so fix'd as he afterwards found it to be But the same Letters tell us, that as soon as his Royal Highness found that his Majesty thought proper to command it: He submitted.

Had his Royal Highness thought fit to have stop'd here, perhaps all had been well; but as he took it extremely ill from the Duke of Newcastle, it seems as if his Royal Highness must be persuaded that the said Duke had taken some steps in it of himself, or other than his Majesty's Command oblig'd him to because the Words in those Letters, this Treat∣ment of the Duke, and as it is in the French, this Proceeding of the Duke of Newcastle, immediately follows.

It seems therefore to me, that the Prince resented the Proceedings of the Duke, not as he acted in O∣bedience to his Majesty's Command, but as if the Duke had done something which he was not com∣manded, or at least seem'd officious to do in the Matter; I do not take upon me to say, or so much as to suggest, that the Duke did so, but 'tis evi∣dent the Prince seem'd to understand it so; and therefore in the Paper mentioned before, which is publish'd as his Royal Highness's Letter, supposing only they may be the Prince's Words, he says, “This Proceeding touch'd his Royal Highness sen∣sibly, and so far rais'd his Indignation, as that” he could not help shewing it.

It remains to relate how his Royal Highness shew'd his Indignation to the Duke on this Occasion, and this indeed is rather to be buried in Silence, then recorded to Posterity, I mean as to the Parti∣cular, because of the unhappy Consequences: It suffices then to say, that his Royal Highness seeing the Duke after the Ceremony was over, spoke some
warm Words to him, shewing his Resentment at what he had done.

This, as I heard, being reported to the King, his Majesty has been pleased to take in a quite different Manner, from what I have supposed the Prince in∣tended it: Note, as you go on, I do not say the King took these Things in a different Manner from what they were design'd or intended to be under∣stood, but different from that which I have sup∣posed to be the intent; for in this I go only upon the supposition of their being intended as is menti∣oned in the said Letters, and still supposing, tho' not undertaking to say, that those Letters are Genuine.

Upon the Report of the Words, his Majesty thought fit to give a sudden Mark of his dis∣pleasure by some Commands to the Prince, con∣fining his Royal Highness to his own Apartment, till his Majesty's farther Pleasure was known; to which his Royal Highness immediately sub∣mitted.
Soon after this, his Majesty's farther Plea∣sure was signified to the Prince, viz. That he should leave St. James's, &c. I need say no more.
Accordingly his Royal Highness quitted the Pa∣lace, the Princess going along with him, but not the Children, and retir'd to the Lord Gran∣tham's House.

The Parliament was now Sitting, and the King's Speech mention'd above lay before them, and the main Thing that they entred upon the Debate of, was that Part which relates to the reducing the Troops: In this Case several extraordinary Speeches were made, and among the rest, one
by Shippen, a Northern Member, who using a distasteful Freedom of Speech, was call'd to the Bar, and committed to the Tower; the Words which the House resented were these, viz. That the second Part of the King's Speech seem'd rather to be calculated for the Meridian of Germany, than Great-Britain; That the King is a Stranger to our Language and Constitution.

Upon these Words, the House immediately cal∣led him to the Bar: In a Word, they were warm∣ly resented, and no Room being left for Extenua∣tions or Explanations, at least none offering that were sufficient, it was insisted, that Mr. Shippen be Committed to the Tower: The committing was oppos'd by many Members, Friends to Mr. Ship∣pen, and occasioned a long Debate, which lasted till Eleven a Clock, when it was carried to send Mr. Shippen to the Tower, by a great Majority, being 171 against 84. Accordingly, the next Day he was committed to the Tower, where he still remains, having, as we hear, been very much indispos'd there, and as some say, dangerously ill.

Upon this Committing Mr. Shippen, some Mem∣bers mov'd that the Words which gave Offence might be printed, which was resolv'd, and accor∣dingly they were made publick; that the Vote of the House for committing is thus express'd, viz. That the said Words are highly dishonourable to, and unjustly reflecting on, His Majesty's Person and Go∣vernment.

After this the House went on with the Debate, and after a long Struggle, the Court carry'd it, that the standing Forces upon the Establishment for Great-Britain should be 16347 effective Men, including Officers.

The Number of Men being thus Resolv'd on, the House immediately voted the Money for their Sup∣port for one Year, which amounted to 681618 l. not including in this Establishment the Garrisons and Troops beyond the Seas; such as those in our Plantations in America, which amounted to

ROW.CELL: For Provisions for the Garrison there
In the Bahama Islands and New-Province
For Half-Pay Officers of Land-Forces and Marines
Add to this the grand Sum for the Army at home

DIV3.P:
This Struggle about the Army being over, the House of Commons fell upon a long Debate about lowering the Interest of Money, and regulating the Value of our Coin. As to the first of these it was pass'd over for this Session, but the last enga∣ged the whole House in a great Labyrinth of Dis∣pute. The State of our Coin at that time admits this brief Description: Our Coin consisted of Cop∣per, Silver, Gold; the Copper Coin is at a low Ebb for want of Quantity, and it is to be rectified, or the deficiency to be supplied by renewing the Species only, and encreasing the Quantity; to which
purpose several Orders have been issued, and the Me∣tal in sufficient Quantity being now provided, it is expected we shall in a little while have a full Sup∣ply of Halfpence and Farthings, which are indeed greatly wanted for common Occasions in Petty-Pay∣ments, and the lowest Part of Commerce. It seems there has been some defect or delay in this Matter; and some have publish'd, that the Metal was bad which was furnished for this Work; but as others again have contradicted the Report, and promised a speedy Production; we wait with as much Satisfa∣ction as other People, the compleating that Work.

The next Species is the Gold, of which there was no want; but on the other hand it is alledged, that our Guinea going at One Pound One Shilling Six Pence is more than the Gold is worth, as it ought to go; as it seem'd we have some inequality con∣cerning the rate of Gold in other Parts (as they stood proportioned to the rate of Silver Coin in those Parts) to the rate of Gold and Silver here.

This made the rate of our Gold Coin appear too high, and the rate of our Silver Coin appear too low; and the House taking this into Conside∣ration, tho' without much Debate, resolv'd to re∣duce the rate of Guineas to Twenty One Shillings each, and other British Gold Coin in proportion. This being resolv'd in the House, the Method was next enquir'd into, which was concluded to be, not by Act of Parliament; but by addressing his Maje∣sty to Issue out his Proclamation for it, which was done.

Q.P: By the King, A Proclamation, Declaring the Rates at which Gold shall be current in Payments.
GEORGER.

P.HI: WHereas the Value of the Gold, compared with the Value of the Silver in the current Coins of this Realm, as Paid and Received, is grea∣ter in Proportion than the Value of Gold is to the Value of Silver in the Neighbouring Nations; and the Over-valuation of Gold in the current Coins of this Realm hath been a great Cause of carrying out and lessening the Species of the Silver Coins there∣of, which is highly Prejudicial to the Trade of this Kingdom: And whereas the Commons in Parlia∣ment have by their Address humbly besought Us, That we would be Graciously Pleased to Issue Our Royal Proclamation, to forbid all Persons to utter or Receive any of the Pieces of Gold, called Guineas, at any greater or higher Rate than one and twenty Shillings for each Guinea, and so proportionably for any greater or lesser Pieces of Coined Gold; Which We have Graciously Condescended unto. Now for and towards Remedying the said Evil, We have thought fit, with the Advice of Our Privy-Council, to Issue this Our Royal Proclamation, hereby strictly Prohibiting all and every Person and Persons what∣soever to Utter or Receive any of the Pieces of Gold Coin of this Kingdom, commonly called Guineas (which in our Mint were Coined only at Twenty Shil∣lings each, but have been by Our Subjects Paid and Re∣ceived at the Rate of one and twenty Shillings and Six Pence each) at any greater or higher Rate or Value than one and twenty Shillings for each Guinea, and so proportionably for the Pieces of Gold, called Half-Guineas, Double-Guineas, and five Pound

Pieces; And the other Pieces of Ancient Gold Coin of this Kingdom, which by their Wearing may be Diminished in their Weight, at any greater or higher Rate or Value than as followeth, That is to say, The Piece of Gold now Received and Paid for three and twenty Shillings and Six Pence, to be hereafter Re∣ceived and Paid for Three and twenty Shillings, and no more; The Piece of Gold now Received and Paid for Five and twenty Shillings and Six Pence, to be hereafter Received and Paid for Five and twenty Shillings, and no more; and so proportionably for smaller Pieces of the like Gold Coin: At which Rates and Values, We do hereby Declare the said respective Pieces of Coined Gold to be Current. And we do hereby strictly Charge and Command all Our Loving Subjects whatsoever, that they do not presume to Receive or Pay the Gold Coins of this Realm at any greater Rates or Values than the Rates and Values aforesaid, upon Pain of Our highest Dis∣pleasure, and upon Pain of the greatest Punishment that by Law may be inflicted upon them for their Default, Negligence, and Contempt in this Behalf.

Q.P: Given at Our Court at St. James's the Twenty second Day of December, 1717. In the Fourth Year of Our Reign.

P.HI: God Save the KING.

DIV3.P:
There was a Rumour, that the Value of the Sil∣ver Coin would be raised in Proportion to what the Gold had fallen; but this had a sudden Influence upon Trade, which was very near being fatal to us, viz. That on a sudden, all the Silver Coin disap∣pear'd, and People were put to the greatest Incon∣venience
imaginable to carry on petty Trade, for no ready Money was to be seen but Gold.
This oblig'd the Parliament, when they came together again, to pass a Vote, that they would not alter the Value of Silver Coin, and this in a few Months brought the Money out again.
