As the Difference between the King and the Prince grew rather wider every Day than other, and no Prospect appear'd of its being reconcil'd or made up, the Prince removed from the Lord Grantham's, and bought himself a House in Leicester-Fields, former∣ly the Dwelling-house of Seymour Portman, Esq a private Gentleman, but of an immense Wealth, and we since find his Royal Highness has adjoin'd Leicester-House to it; so that together he will have a large handsome Palace: As to his Summer Residence, he has fix'd upon a House near Richmond, the same that the Duke of Ormond formerly liv'd in, where his whole Family, his Children excepted, who were always kept at Court, were very well ac∣commodated.

His Royal Highness had before this written se∣veral Letters to the King, which it was hop'd would, with the Intercession of those who wish'd well to both Sides, have prevail'd; but these not being sa∣tisfactory, the Family settled as above, and our Hi∣story will not have the Felicity to relate the End of this Breach, at least not in this Part of it.

It was in Prosecution of this Difference between the King and the Prince, that the King thought fit to cause himself to be made capable of being nomi∣nated Governour of the South-Sea Company, a Tran∣saction very particular and remarkable; the brief Hi∣story of the Fact I shall relate, as to the Reasons and Designs of it, that I have no Room for, or ra∣ther no Inclination to run the Risque of the Enquiry.

The Prince of Wales had, ever since the coming of King George to the Crown, been Governor of the South-Sea Company: The first Governor, who was the Earl of Oxford, having thought fit to lay down, and having also unqualified himself by sel∣ing out his Stock, from being any more elected, the Company made their Court to the Prince, and as it is necessary by the Constitution of the Company, that whoever is Governor of the Company, must be entituled to Ten Thousand Pounds Original Stock, the Company in their first Transports, were pleased to compliment the Prince with such an Article of Stock, in order in the next Place to chuse him their Governor.

Upon the late unhappy Misunderstanding be∣tween the King and the Prince, and the latter being under the King's Displeasure so far as to be banished, or removed rather from his Majesty's Councils and Presence, the Company was given to understand that the King was become a Proprietor of their Stock; his Majesty it seems had transferred to him in his own Name, and accordingly had Credit in the Com∣pany's Books for above Ten Thousand Pound Stock. This was Intimation sufficient to the Company, that his Majesty might, if he pleased to accept of it, be nam'd their Governor. I do not at all pretend to say, that this Stock was purchased in order to such an Election; but if it may be said to seem to be so, it must also be allowed to seem to be on the Companies side, that if the King did them the Ho∣nour to become a Proprietor of their Stock, they could not but think it their Duty to name his Ma∣jesty as Governor of the Company; not to do this, had been indeed to have made the King, so far as he was a Member of the Company, a Subject to whoever should be the Company's Governor; and
on the other Hand, if the Prince continued in the Post of Governor, as but on this Occasion was likely e∣nough, this would be to make the Prince Governor over the King, and the Son Governor over the Fa∣ther; I mean at least as far as concern'd their share in the Stock of the South-Sea Company.

This being the Situation of the Company's Af∣fairs, they agreed upon an Address to the King, to desire his Majesty would do them the Honour to use his Name as Governor of the Company in their en∣suing Election; this was the last Day of the last Month, and accordingly the Address being drawn up, and approved in the usual Form, and the Per∣sons nominated who were to go up with it, on Sa∣turday the first of February, “a considerable Number of the Principal Proprietors in the South-Sea Com∣pany waited on his Majesty at St. James's, and be∣ing introduc'd by his Grace the Duke of Newca∣stle, Lord Chamberlain, presented the following Address to his Majesty. They were all admitted to kiss his Majesty's Hand, and his Majesty was pleased to confer the Honour of Kinghthood on” George Caswell Esq
DIV3.Q: To the King's most Excellent Majesty.

P.Q: “THE General Court of the South-Sea Company, crave Leave to acknowledge, with the greatest Sense of Gratitude, the many Marks of your Roy∣al Favour, which the Company have received ever since your Majesty's happy Accession to the Crown; and in particular, the Honour done them in be∣coming” a Proprietor in their Stock.

“They therefore do, in the most humble and du∣tiful Manner, beseech your Majesty will be
graciously pleased to grant them the farther Honour of using your Royal Name for their” Governor in the ensuing Election.

DIV3.P: His Majesty's most Gracious Answer.
Gentlemen,

P.Q: I Thank you for this Address, and take this as a “Mark of your Duty and Affection to me: 'Tis a very great Satisfaction to me, that I have had it in my Power to do you Good; and you may depend upon the Continuance of my Favour and Protection” upon all Occasions.

DIV3.P: The King having thus accepted their offer, was on the 4th unanimously Elected their Governor, an Act of Parliament having pass'd the Houses for that Purpose, and having receiv'd the Royal Assent the Day before. It seems there were some Reasons in the Nature of the Royal Sovereignty of the King's Person, or as a reserve to the Dignity of the Throne, which required that a Law on purpose should be made, before Subjects could in any Case be said to elect their Sovereign to be their Governor, who was in all Cases their supreme Governor before in Right of the Royal Prerogative: But whether this was all the Reason or not, I do not pretend to determine; but it is certain such an Act was necessary, and therefore was previously concerted, and having pass'd through both Houses in two Days time, was pass'd by the King on Feb. 3. and the King declared Go∣vernor the next Day.

Now tho' the Election of Governor was car∣ried, as is said, unanimously, yet this Affair could not but create some Fractions, we are loth to say Factions, tho' if we should go that length, the ill
Conduct of some People among them might ex∣cuse it.

The Disputes among them seem'd to be managed in the Election of their new People, such as the Sub-Governor, Deputy-Governor, and Directors for the coming Year; but the Reason and Cause of those Things pointed higher a great deal: Sir James Bate∣man had distinguished himself in the Prince's Interest on many Occasions, and more particularly in this of the Governor of the Company: It was said for Ex∣ample, That he did not deliver the Prince's Surren∣der of the Office of Governor in the Manner, and at the Time they ought to have had it. That he ad∣journ'd the General Court in an irregular Manner, and when Business of Moment was before them. And in a Word, That he thwarted the Design of ha∣ving the King be address'd and elected Governor of the Company, as much as he could.

This disgusted a great many of the Members of the General Court, and immediately a Party was form'd against Sir James, viz. To set up another against him in the Election for a Sub-Governor, which was to be the same Day that the King was to be declar'd Governor.

To oppose Sir James, the new Party made a Meeting at the Crown Tavern behind the Exchange, mustred all their Friends, told Noses, and, as all Factions do, flatter'd themselves they were strong∣er than they were, and set up Sir Theo. J—n against Sir James: As there was no Comparison in the Interest, so neither was there in the Merit of the Persons: The one a Purse-proud Foreigner, full of popular Notions, and long practised in Riding the Rabble of Parties, wise to a Degree that few envies, and wiser much in his own Opinion than in other Mens.

Sir James could not have desir'd a better Adver∣sary, not only for the just Character of the Person, but because he was of a Temper himself, and join'd with a Party who generally push'd their Projects not so much by the Knowledge of their Strength, as the Warmth of their Passions; not making a Judg∣ment so much by the Solidity of Calculations, as the Presumption of their Party; For this Image they set up was so unfit to make an Idol of, that it appear'd, in the Event, he had not Merit enough to be made a—Step to it: He was so far from having Interest enough to be made a Sub-Gover∣nour, that he could not get in to be made a Dire∣ctor; so he walk'd off: Like a certain Draper, who being set up at his own Request to be chosen Common-Council-Man, was sent back to his Parish to serve Scavinger and Constable.

In a Word, after much Clubbing and Caballing, much Huff and Bluster, on one Side or other, Sir James was, by a Majority of some Hundreds, chosen Sub-Governor, and Mr. Samuel Shepheard Deputy-Governour of the Company, the same Day that the King was Nominated, I am loth to call it Elected, Governor.
The like Struggle was made by the same Party a few Days after in choosing Directors; but the new Dividers lost their Cause, by a vast Majority.

The Directors being chosen and declar'd, a Ge∣neral Court was call'd the 8th of February, in which they had little offer'd but to make themselves Friends with one another again, after all these Squab∣bles; this however they did very well, by joining in with a Motion for an Address of Thanks to His Majesty, for the Honour done them in accepting the being their Governour; which was done, and pre∣sented
to the King by the new Governour and Di∣rectors; at which time another of the Directors was dubb'd a Knight, viz. Mr. Jacob Jacobson. I have heard Mr. Shepheard, the Deputy-Governour, was intended for that Honour, but that he made his Escape. The Address and Answer is as follows:

P.HI: To the KING's most Excellent Majesty.

P.Q: “THE General Court of the South-Sea Com∣pany do, in the most humble and dutiful Manner, return their unfeigned Thanks to Your Majesty for Your most Gracious Answer to their late Address, and for Your great Condescension in permitting them, at their late Election, to use Your Royal Name for their Governour; the just Sense whereof they have endeavour'd to ex∣press by their entire Unanimity in the said Ele∣ction: And do most humbly beseech Your Ma∣jesty will be Graciously pleased to accept of being their Governour; and they do most sincerely assure Your Majesty, that they will constantly exert themselves in demonstrating their Duty and Affe∣ction to Your Majesty; and never cease their ser∣vent Prayers that Your Majesty's Reign may be” long, easie, and prosperous.

P.HI: By Order of the General Court,

DIV3.P: James Bateman, Sub-Governour.
Samuel Shepheard, Deputy-Governour.
His Majesty's most Gracious Answer.
Gentlemen,

P.Q: “I Thank you for this repeated Instance of your” Duty and Affection to me, and accept of this Mark of it as you Desire.
P.HI: I am glad of this Oc∣casion of assuring you again of my Favour and Pro∣tection.

DIV3.P: Thus this South-Sea Storm blew over, and things began to run in the former Channel; the Stock∣jobbers made the best they cou'd of the Bargain, and pretended to raise the Stock on the great Pro∣spect of this new Favour; as if some particular Advantage more than the Honour of having the King to their Governour had been in view: What that Advantage may be, we yet cannot say, but Time may discover it.

After this unhappy Court-Breach had thus taken Root, the young Prince who had been, tho' invo∣luntarily, the Occasion of his Father's Misfortunes, was removed by that Fate, which doubtless deter∣min'd his short stay to be fruitful of that remarka∣ble Event: Upon the Death of the Child, the Bo∣dy was open'd by the Surgeons, who made the fol∣lowing Report.

P.Q: “IN opening the Corps of his Highness Prince George William, we found a great Quantity of Water in the Head, lodged between the Pia∣mater and Brain, all the Substance of the Brain softer than usual, and the Ventricles fuller of Wa∣ter.”

DIV3.P:
“All the Entrails of the Lower Belly were in good Condition. In the Breast, we found the
”lowermost part of the left Lobe of the Lungs in∣flam'd, and in cutting it, a small Quantity of pu∣rulent Matter issu'd. The lowermost part of the right Lobe was also inflam'd, but without puru∣lent Matter.

P.Q: “In the Heart there was a great Polypus in each Ventricle, which had Branches in all the Blood” Vessels, and hinder'd Circulation.

DIV3.P: The Funeral of this Prince was private; it was appointed the 12th, when the Corps was deposi∣ted in the Royal Vault, under the Chapel of King Henry VII. in Westminster-Abby, with the following Inscription:

LG.HEAD: DEPOSITED.
LG.L: Son of the most Serene Prince of Wales,

DIV3.P:
The Dean of Westminster, Bishop of Rochester, perform'd the Office, and read the Service at the Interment; the Direction of the whole Funeral being ordered by the Lord Chamberlain, viz. the Duke of Newcastle, his famous Godfather. Upon
which it has been wittily observ'd, that the Lord Chamberlain had the Honour to introduce the Prince twice into the Church, viz. once into the Bosom of it, and once into the Bowels of it.

The House of Commons was all this while sitting, and among the rest of their Transactions, this was not the least significant, viz. The selling the for∣feited Estates, in which they met with great Diffi∣culties, especially in Scotland, as has been said; and therefore it was necessary to bring in a Bill for the empowering the Commissioners to Sell absolutely, without any Reserve or Appeal, after all Claims that were come in had been adjusted, and a reasona∣ble Time given for bringing in more.

But now they met with an Interruption of ano∣ther Nature, viz. the Petitions of the miserable Fa∣milies who were Reduc'd by this Misfortune, lying at their Feet for Bread; and these being to be re∣fer'd by the House to the King, in the Course of Things his Majesty refer'd it back to the House by Message, intimating, that the King had nothing to object, if the House pleas'd to grant any Relief to the distress'd Families that petition'd.

The first of these was the Lord Widdrington, whose whole Estate being seiz'd, he had not the least Subsistence for himself and Children; and the King gave a favourable Answer, referring him to the House of Commons, ordering it to be signify'd to the House, That he will not obstruct their Cha∣rity, or decline granting any Thing the House shall think fit to do in it; and when his Lordship Peti∣tion'd the House, Mr. Comptroller acquainted them. That he was commanded to acquaint the House with it accordingly: And we hear that 700 l. per Annum has been allotted his Lordship,
and to descend with some Limitation to his Poste∣rity.

The Petition of the Lord Widdrington was fol∣low'd by many more, viz. John and Henry Balfour, John Carstairs, Patrick Seaton, Rob. Rollo, late Lord Rollo, Lady Philippa Standish, Daughter to the late Duke of Norfolk, Margaret Thornton, Frances Dalton, Mary and Dorothy Hodgson, Anne Walton, Elizabeth Ibasto, and others. Upon these Petitions, and considering that many Petitions were expected to follow these, it was offer'd at by some, That a certain Part of the Estates of the forfeited Persons should be in his Majesty's Power, to dispose as his Royal Clemency might dictate, for the Re∣lief of their distressed Wives and Children. But the House would not agree to that neither; so what Petitions are not granted, will never be gran∣ted; nor will it be in the Power, even of the King himself to relieve Persons Petitioning afterwards, except out of his own Pocket.

The first of these Estates that was actually Sold, was the Lord Widdrington's, being an Estate in Lincolnshire, valued at 1460 l. per Annum, and bought by Sir Robert Chaplin; it was set up at 26000 l. and sold by Inch of Candle or Auction for 34500 l. being a very noble Estate, and well Wood∣ed: This Sale however was not made till Septem∣ber the following Year.
About this time most of the Parliament Business seem'd to give way a while to a long and warm Debate, upon the main Point so often mentioned be∣fore, about disbanding and reducing the Army.
The Dispute began under the Consideration of a Bill, entitul'd, For punishing Mutiny and Desertion, and better regulating the Forces.

The Sum of the Question was in two Parts; 1st, About the Number of the Troops to be Esta∣blished, which however it had been debated and determined before, yet admitted some Debate now again, for those Gentlemen who were for the Redu∣ction of the Army, never gave it over, when they had any opportunity to take up the Argument.

But that being carry'd as far as it would go, they came 2dly, To Laws for Government of the Sol∣diers, and the manner of Proceeding against them in capital Cases, which after several Reserves and Regulations, some in Favour of the Constitution, and some empowering the Civil Magistrate to act; at length a Law was settled for the Soldiery, such as it is, and the Heads of it were published by the King's Order, for preserving them in their Duty, which Rules however being pretty equally observed, the Soldiery take no great Advantage, and it being but for a Year also, I do not hear it complain'd on.

The Parliament being now in full Business, it is to my Purpose to give the Heads of their Proceed∣ings, particularly in what pass'd of Moment among them, and so bring the Session to a Close, that the Story may suffer no injurious Intervals.

The Coin came frequently before them, the Scarcity of Silver was an unsufferable Grievance in Trade, and made the People very uneasie, and the Noise of any one encreasing the Grievance made it still worst, yet one Case I may touch upon, and I have wondred often that no farther Occasion was taken at it among the common People, viz. That while both the Houses were severally imploy'd in finding out the Causes, as well as Remedies, for the lessening, and indeed the suddain vanishing of the Silver Coin of this Nation; some Suggestions were made, That
a certain Cunning Worker in such convertible Spe∣cies, had turn'd Coin into Bullion to a prodigious Quantity, some talk, of above an Hundred Thou∣sand Ounces that were within the Compass of Dis∣covery, and that much more might be heard of.

If this had been found effectually out, and prov'd, one would have suppos'd the Houses need go no farther in that Part of the Enquiry which relates to finding out the Causes of the Decrease of our Coin; and therefore we suppose proper Means will one Time or other be still used to fix the Discovery, as no doubt the guilty Persons are diligent to con∣ceal it. I do not hereby say, however we may have been told, that the cunning Gamester was Sir Geo. Casw—l, or any other Person concern'd by or for him; but I leave it to the farther Enquiry of the Parliament, who, I hope, will do their Coun∣try Justice in a Proper Season.

The Abundance of Petitions which were coming from all Parts of the Kingdom for Remedy of this Mischief, but which were stop'd by finding the House enclined to go effectually upon it, may serve to give a Taste to any one of the great Grievance it was to the Publick to have such a suddain Scar∣city of the Species of Coin, that petty Commerce could hardly be carried on, and even Men that em∣ploy'd the Poor, were at a loss to pay their Wages. But what then will be the Anxiety of the People, and what the Damage to Trade, especially the Re∣tailer, which is that Part of Trade on which all the rest depends, when they shall find that the Houses either have not, or perhaps cannot find out effectual Remedies for the Mischief, we must leave to Time.

But I leave this as I find it, in some Confusion, and much Uncertainty, and proceed to another Case
before the House of Commons, viz. That of the Demands of Foreign Princes upon Great Britain, for Arrears due to them for Subsidies or Quota's, agreed to be paid to them, to enable them to support the War, and for Pay of Troops, &c. The Sum the Dutch demanded was considerable; and his Majesty having promised them at their Request to recommend it to the Parliament, and having men∣tion'd it at the opening the Session, a State of the Demand was now ordered by the King's particular Direction to be laid before the House, and was up∣on the House's taking it into Consideration referred to the Commissioners, who were appointed to state, take, and determine the Debt due to the Army and Navy, &c. And in this Scituation I must leave it for the Present.

The Application to the House made by the Mer∣chants, and others, for the opening again the Swe∣dish Trade, was next in Course; where we are to note, that several Petitions had, previous to this, been presented to the House, from the Countrey Places where our Iron Manufactures are carried on, such as Birmingham, Sheffield, Newcastle, and others; inwhich they set forth the great Discouragements of their Trade, and the Difficulties they were put to in carrying on their Manufactures by the Prohibition of the Trade to Sweden; by which the Importation of Iron, which is the Product of that Country, was stop'd and interrupted, and without which they could not carry on their Trade.

Here, by the Way, I might enlarge upon the ma∣nifest Injury which Trading Nations always bring upon themselves, when, through the Necessity of their Affairs, or for any other Consideration, they are obliged to prohibit any Branches of their Fo∣reign Trade, whether it be of Importation or Ex∣portation,
there being very few Countries so poor, so barren. so remote, but from whence something is to be fetch'd that we find wanting to our selves, and absolutely necessary for the carrying on our own Manufactures.

This was much the Case of our Commerce with Sweden, and which, as I suppose, occasioned these Petitions from the Iron Workers: If there were any private Reasons, or Agents employed to bring this on Foot with other Designs, that I have nothing to say to; but this above seemed to be acknowledged in the Consequences of the Thing; for that the Go∣vernment thought fit, a few Days after, to publish a Proclamation for the admitting the Importation of Swedish Iron, with this Limitation, viz. That it should not come directly from Sweden, but from o∣ther Places. This Proclamation, because it seems something particular and extraordinary, as to what followed especially, it is needful to insert here, and is as follows, viz.

DIV3.HEAD: By the KING, A PROCLAMATION, For allowing the Importation of Swedish Iron from Places other than from the Dominions of the King of Sweden.

Q.P: GEORGER.

WHereas in and by an Act of the last Session of Parliament, entituled, An Act to enable his Majesty effectually to prohibit or restrain Com∣merce with Sweden, for the Reasons there contain∣ed, it is, amongst other Things, enacted, That it should and might be lawful for us, by one or more
Proclamation or Proclamations, to be issued at any Time or Times before the twentieth Day of March, which will be in the Year of our Lord one Thousand seven Hundred and seventeen, to prohibit or re∣strain all and every Person and Persons, Na∣tives and Foreigners, Bodies Politick and Cor∣porate whatever, to import or bring, or cause or procure to be imported or brought, directly or indi∣rectly, by way of Merchandise, into Great Britain, Ireland, or any of the Dominions thereunto be∣longing, any Goods, Wares, or Commodities whatso∣ever, of the Growth, Product, or Manufacture of Sweden, or any of the Dominions under the Power of the King of Sweden, being mix'd or unmix'd with the Goods of any other Countrey, or such particular Goods, Wares or Commodities of Sweden, or of any of the Dominions under the Power of the King of Sweden mixed or unmixed, as afore∣said, except as is therein excepted, as in such Pro∣clamation or Proclamations should be enumerated, de∣scribed, and forbidden, for and during such Time and Times, not exceeding one Year, to be reckoned from the twentieth Day of March, one Thousand seven Hundred and sixteen, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament, under the Penalties in the said Act mentioned, and in such Manner and Form as in and by such Proclamation and Proclamations respectively should be prescribed. And whereas by our Royal Proclamation, bearing Date the second Day of March, one Thousand seven Hundred and sixteen, We did, under the Penalties in the said Act, prohibit and forbid all and every Person and Persons, Natives and Foreigners, Bodies Politick and Corporate whatsoever, before the End of the next Session of Parliament, which should be after the twentieth Day of March, one Thousand seven
Hundred and seventeen, amongst other Things, to import or bring, or cause or procure to be imported or brought, directly or indirectly, by way of Mer∣chandize, into Great Britain, Ireland, or any the Dominions thereunto belonging, any Goods, Wares, or Commodities whatsoever of the Growth, Product, or Manufacture of Sweden, or any of the Dominions under the Power of the King of Sweden, other than such of the said Goods, Wares, or Commodities, which were, or at any Time or Times, on or before the fif∣teenth Day of April, one Thousand seven Hundred and seventeen, should be laden or put on Board any Ship or Vessel in Sweden, or other Foreign Parts, to be brought into Great Britain, Ireland, or any the Domi∣nions thereunto belonging, unless we should think fit, before the End of the next Session of Parliament, which should be after the said twentieth Day of March, one Thousand seven Hundred and seventeen, by our Royal Proclamation, to open the Commerce between our Subjects and those of Sweden, or to alter the Pro∣hibition therein contained. Now we judging it may be convenient for the present to alter the Prohibitions in our said recited Proclamation contained, in Man∣ner herein after mentioned, have thought fit, by and with the Advice of our Privy-Council, to issue this our Royal Proclamation: And we do hereby declare, that it shall and may be lawful for any of our Subjects to import Swedish Iron into Great Britain, Ireland, or any of the Dominions thereunto belonging, in any Ship or Ships, Vessel or Vessels whatsoever, which shall truly and without Fraud belong only to the Peo∣ple of Great Britain, or Ireland, or of any of the Do∣minions thereunto belonging, as the Proprietors and right Owners thereof, and whereof the Master and three Fourths at least of the Mariners shall be British, from any Place or Places whatsoever, other than from
the Kingdom of Sweden, or from any of the Domini∣ons or Countries under the Power of the King of Swe∣den, at any Time or Times before the End of the next Session of Parliament, which shall be after the twentieth Day of March, one thousand seven hun∣dred and seventeen, any Thing in our said recited Proclamation contained to the contrary thereof not∣withstanding, unless we shall think fit within the Time aforesaid to alter this our Royal Proclamation.
Given at our Court at St. James's, the Thirteenth Day of February, 1717. in the Fourth Year of our Reign.
God Save the KING.

DIV3.P:
It may be very profitably observ'd here, that this Difficulty in the Iron Trade, and the absolute De∣pendance, which we seem to have, on the Impor∣tation of Swedish Iron, and the Inconvenience which would always occur to our selves by any Prohibition, were the Reasons of State ever so just or so pressing: I say this Difficulty encourag'd, or rather reviv'd the Designs of some of our Enter∣prizing People for the making a Tryal of finding and improving the Mines of Iron, Copper, &c. which they had long been of the Opinion were to be found in the Colonies of the English, on the Continent of America. And accordingly several Petitions were presented to the House, in the Names of the Merchants, Shipwrights, Ironmongers, Smiths, and Dealers in Iron, and in the Iron Manu∣factury, &c. from London, from Bristol, and other Parts, praying that Encouragement may be given to those who are willing to engage in erecting Iron Works in his Majesty's Colonies in Virginia, Mary∣land, Pensilvania, and New-England. This Peti∣tion had an Appearance of Improvement, and was sufficient in its self to recommend it to the House,
so a Committee was appointed to enquire into it, to see what Encouragement the Petitioners de∣sir'd, &c. But this Month will scarce give us the Result of their Considerations on that Head, so we must leave it with them till we hear farther.

Whether these Things were a Concert with the same Persons who applied themselves afterwards in the Swedish Affair, as if the first having miscarri∣ed of the Design, was therefore the Reason of the other, I know not; but some Days after this, there appear'd several Petitions in more express Terms, to desire the Prohibition of the Trade to Sweden might be taken off, or to that Purpose.

This was call'd by the following Title, viz. A Petition of several Merchants and Owners of Shipping, in behalf of themselves and others, tra∣ding to and from Sweden; the Prayer of the Peti∣tion was in short, That the present Circumstances of the Trade to Sweden might be taken into Confi∣deration, &c.

In the Consequence of this Petition, the Mer∣chants on every side were brought into the House, and what they had to say was heard fully; also the British Resident, Mr. Jackson, was heard re∣specting the Memorial, &c. presented to the Swe∣dish Court; and the Merchants, who complain'd of Losses and Captures of Ships by the Swedes, were also heard.

After this the Arguments for restoring and open∣ing the Trade on one hand, and the Reasons for continuing the Prohibition, till Satisfaction was obtain'd for the Losses of the Merchants, &c. were also debated at large, but upon the whole, the Com∣mons did not think fit to resolve to take off the Prohibition of the Swedish Trade; so that Matter stands just as it did.

We are told, That it was warmly debated in these Cases, whether the Dutch had done us Justice in the Affair of prohibiting Commerce with Swe∣den or not, and the Papers were call'd for by the House, which pass'd between the Secretary of State here, and his Majesty's Resident in Holland; and the Letters from the said Resident in Holland, back to the Secretary of State; as also a Memorial deliver'd by the said Resident in Holland to the States General, on the Subject of the Dutch pro∣hibiting Commerce with Sweden; which, by the way, they never had done, whatever Reasons we had to expect they would.

But as no Resolutions were made upon these Debates, I can say little more than this, That the Dutch had not done what we expected, and the House did not think fit, however, to take off the Prohibition on our Side, and in this Posture it stands for the present.

About this Time, to make a short Digression, a Truce was made with the Emperor of Morocco, which, as it relates to Trade, I think may well be call'd an Affair of the Administration at home; the Reason and Negotiation of this Truce may be too tedious to enter into here, but the Truce itself is material, especially because it afterwards broke out into a War, and is as follows, viz.

P.Q:
“I. It is consented and agreed upon, that there be a firm and inviolable Truce between the most serene and potent Prince, George, King of Great-Britain, &c. and the most powerful and noble Prince Maley Ismael, &c. for Three Months from the Date hereof; and between the Dominions and Subjects, Ships and Imbarkations of both Nati∣ons; and during the said Term no Injury shall
be offered from one to the other by Word or Deed; but on the contrary they shall treat one the other” with all possible Respect and Friendship.

“II. That all the Ships, or any Imbarkations whatsoever, as well those which belong to his Britannick Majesty and his Subjects, as those which belong to the Emperor of Morocco and his Vassals, shall pass the Seas freely, and without the least Molestation, shewing their Colours to each other. And if either one or the other shall order their Boat aboard, there shall not go in her above two Persons besides those that Row, and those two only, shall be permitted to go on board the other Ship: And when they are satis∣fied that the major Part of the Ships Company are Subjects either of one or the other Prince, they shall permit them to pass without any Mo∣lestation; as also all Passengers, Money or Mer∣chandize, that shall belong to any Nation what∣soever, and shall be found on board the said Ships or Imbarkations, shall be intirely free, neither shall they be subject to be taken, detained, or plundered, nor shall one or the other receive any” Damage or Injury.

“III. It is farther agreed upon, that during the Term of the said Truce, no Ship or Imbarkation, either of the one or the other Part, or any of their Subjects that shall be shipwreck'd on the Coast of the Dominions of either the one or the other Prince, shall be made Prize; neither shall their Goods be taken, or ersons made Slaves. But this Truce does not take off the Prohibition of Commerce; but the same is to remain in full” Force, to the Conclusion of the general Peace.

DIV3.P: Concluded at Tetuan, on the Second of January, 1717-18, O. S. which answers to the Tenth of” the Moon of Safar, in the Year 1130.
Coningby Norbury (L. S.)
Bashaw Hamed, &c. (L. S.)

This put some End for a Time to the Rovers of Sallee, tho' they soon broke out again: But the Irruption of our West-Indian Pirates grew still worse and worse, nor will the Limits of this Hi∣story extend to bring us an Account of any Abate∣ment of their Rapine and Violence, but rather the Encrease of it.

It is certain, that this wicked Insurrection was begun by Englishmen, and even now, the greatest Part of the Pyrates are English, tho' a great many French from Martinico have join'd them at several times since, and some Run-away Negroes also from Jamaica. Their first Irruption was from Jamaica, but in private, and they never came to any con∣siderable Head, till some People, tempted by Pro∣fit, robb'd the Spaniards, who had recover'd part of the Treasure of the Galleons lost in the Gulph of Florida, and finding that being return'd to Ja∣maica, they could not be protected there, but that upon the Application to the Government there, they would be prosecuted, and perhaps hang'd, they took to Sea again, and have committed since that, the most unnatural Violences against their own Coun∣try that ever Pyrates did, for they have chiefly di∣rected their Robberies against the Ships and Mer∣chants of their own Nation.

The House of Commons, upon the Petition and Representation of the Merchants, took this Part in∣to Consideration, and ordered an Account to
be given them of what Men of War are already in those Parts, in order (as I suppose) to consider what other Ships to send thither; and the King, we are told, has Commission'd Captain Rogers, the same, who, as it is said of Sir Francis Drake, gir∣dled the World, and took the Ships from Acapulco.

Captain Rogers was now commission'd to go in Search of those Robbers; and has taken with him three Men of War; and that he may make use of all the possible Methods for reducing them, carries the King's Proclamation of Pardon to those who will return to their Duty.

What Success this Gentleman will meet with, or what other Remedies may be applied by the Par∣liament for this Evil, I cannot yet see; but I fear this Wound will not be so soon healed as all the Friends to Trade desire.

In the mean time, the Spaniards arm against them as well as we; and indeed the Usage which the Spaniards give them is very just, whether it will intimidate and terrify them, or harden and make them desperate, we cannot answer: But the Spaniards have spar'd none that have fallen into their Hands. One Crew of Sixty Seven they took by meer Fighting, and tyed the Men Back to Back, and threw them all into the Sea. Another Vessel they fir'd, and when the Men leap'd into the Sea to avoid the Fire, refused to save any one of them. And a third that they took, they cut them all to Pieces, refusing to give them any Quarter. Nor are the Pyrates behind hand with the Spaniards, whom they serve in the very same Manner.

As for our Part, we do not hear yet of any of 'em that have fallen into the Hands of the British Government except one Ship, which was cast away in New-England; of the Men, one hundred and
ten were drown'd, and only Six sav'd, Five of which Six were hang'd, and the Sixth proving that he was taken by the Pirates; and was only a Prisoner on board, and not engag'd with them, was sav'd.

In the mean time, they do a World of Mischief, and every Post or Express from the Islands or Conti∣nent, brings us Account of Ships and Men taken, murder'd, or plunder'd by them; among which, the South Sea Company have the Misfortune to lose a stout Ship, and very Rich, coming home from Buenos Ayres, which besides other Goods, had as they report, Four hundred thousand Pieces of Eight on board, the Men having, it seems, fought the Pyrates a good while, were, when they were forc'd to yield, all murder'd to a Man; and that which is still more, the Pirates have by this means gotten a stout Man of War, able to carry, as they write, 44 Guns.

Since this we have an Account, that the Pyrates cruize among the Islands openly, so that no Ship can stir; and in particular, the Islands of Nevis and Antegoa are, as it were, block'd up with them, and reduc'd thereby to the utmost Distress for want of Provisions.

People have entertained some Hopes that the new Governour of Jamaica, Sir Nicholas Laws, who is lately enter'd upon his Government, and is a Person in particular acquainted with the Affairs and Inte∣rests of those Parts, having resided Forty Years in that Island, will be able to direct to some Methods, how to reduce these desperate People, either by fair or foul means, to their Duty; and I hear he is par∣ticularly instructed for that purpose.

But I return to the Parliament, who were now drawing towards a Close of their Session; abundance of Bills had pass'd thro' their Hands, which lay in
the House of Lords for the Royal Assent, so many, that the House of Commons having little Business, were oblig'd to adjourn for some Time, to give the Lords Time to go thro' the Work that was before them: In this Interval They voted to give the Bank of England Notice, that they would redeem and pay off the Sum of 76803 l. 15 s. per Annum, pay∣able to the said Bank for circulating Exchequer Bills; this was done, and the Notice order'd to be given the Bank, pursuant to a Contract with the Bank, that they should have a Year's Notice, before such Sums were to be paid off.

It is to be observ'd, that upon this Notice, the Stocks fell immediately Two or Three per Cent. which by the way, is a Testimony of the preposte∣rous Principles of Stock-Jobbing, viz. that they should value their publick Stocks and Funds at less than before, upon an Occasion, which in it self, manifestly tends to Raising and Establishing the Publick Credit, upon which all their Funds depend; but that is by the way, for this is not the only visible Contradiction that is to be found in Stock-Jobbing.

The same 17th Day of the Month, when the Speaker made this Report, the King sent the fol∣lowing Message to the House, a Message which, as it seem'd to imply the using a greater Strength than was intended in the Mediterranean, gave many People new Ideas of the Situation of Affairs between the Spaniard and Us; nor did the Notions of a War with Spain, which many People appre∣hended as the Consequence of these things add at all to the rise of our Stock. The Message is as follows:
GEORGE R.

HIS Majesty being at present engaged in seve∣ral Negociations of the utmost Concern to the Welfare of these Kingdoms, and the Tranquillity of Europe; and having lately received Information from Abroad, which makes Him judge that it will give Weight to His Endeavours if a Naval Force be employed where it shall be necessary, does think fit to acquaint this House therewith; not doubting, but that in case He should be obliged, at this Critical Juncture, to exceed the Number of Men granted this Year for the Sea-Servite, the House will at their next Meeting provide for such Exceeding.

The House readily complied with this Demand as most Reasonable, and immediately Voted an hum∣ble Address, to signify their Resolution to make good such Exceedings of Men for the Service of the Current Year, as his Majesty shall find necessa∣ry, adding their humble Compliment of Thanks for his Majesty's unwearied Endeavours for the Wel∣fare of his People, and to preserve the Tranquillity of Europe.
The King returned his Thanks in Answer to this Address, which was afterwards repeated at the Close of the Sessions: Of which in its Place.

And now all publick Business being finished, at least so much as could be expected for that Time; the King came to the House the 19th of March, and making a Speech to them, prorogued them to the 20th of May. The King's Speech was as follows, viz.
My Lords and Gentlemen,

I Cannot put an End to this Session, without re∣turning my hearty Thanks to so good a Parlia∣ment,
for the Dispatch which has been given to the publick Business. You will, I hope, in your private Capacities, feel the Convenience of an early Recess; and I am persuaded, the Publick will receive great Benefit by the seasonable Zeal and Vigour of your Resolutions in Support of my Government.

P.HI: Nothing can add so much to the Credit and Influence of this Crown, both at home and abroad, as the re∣peated Instances of your Affection to me. This Stea∣diness and Resolution of yours, will, I hope, enable me to procure, against our next Meeting, such Trea∣ties to be concluded, as will settle Peace and Tran∣quillity among our Neighbours.

If, through the Blessing of God, my Endcavours to this End prove successful, I shall have the Satis∣faction to silence even those who will never own them∣selves convinc'd; and to let all the World see plain∣ly, that what I have most at Heart, is the Good and Welfare of my People, who may then be eased in their Taxes, and enriched by their Trade.

DIV3.P: Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

P.HI: I must return you my particular Thanks for the Supplies you have so cheerfully granted, and for the late Instance of your Confidence in me. I promise you, that my Endeavours shall not be wanting to make use of both to the best Advantage, for the Good of my People.

DIV3.P: My Lords and Gentlemen,

P.HI: The Practices which are daily used by a most rest∣less and unhappy Set of Men, to disturb a Govern∣ment, by whose Clemency they are protected, require our utmost Attention and Vigilance. I must there∣fore recommend it to you, that in your several Sta∣tions and Countries, you will endeavour to quell that
Spirit of Disaffection, which our common Enemies are so industrious to foment.

DIV3.P: The Accounts of the several publick Acts pass'd on this Occasion, are as follow:

P.HI: An Act for continuing the Duties on Malt, Mum, Cyder, and Perry, for the Service of the Year One thousand seven hundred and eighteen, and for making forth Duplicates of Exchequer Bills, Lot∣tery Tickets, and Orders lost, burnt, or destroyed, and for appropriating the Supplies granted in this Session of Parliament.

DIV3.P: An Act for vesting the Forfeited Estates in Great-Britain and Ireland in Trustees, to be sold for the use of the Publick; and for giving Relief to lawful Creditors, by determining the Claims; and for the more effectual bringing into the respe∣ctive Exchequers the Rents and Profits of the said Estates till sold.

P.HI: An Act for punishing Mutiny and Desertion, and for the better Payment of the Army and their Quarters.

DIV3.P: An Act for making the Dividend of subscrib'd Lottery-Annuities, and other Annuities, established by several Acts of Parliament, payable Half-yearly at the Bank of England.

P.HI: An Act to appoint Commissioners to take, exa∣mine, state, and determine the Debts due to the Army, and to examine and state the Demands of se∣veral Foreign Princes and States for Subsidies during the late War.

DIV3.P:
An Act for finishing the Tower of the Parish Church of St. Michael, Cornhill, London, out of the Duties arising, pursuant to the Act of the Ninth Year of the late Queen, for building Fifty new
Churches in and about the Cities of London and Westminster, and the Suburbs thereof.

An Act to impower the Commissioners appointed to put in Execution the Acts of the Ninth and Tenth Years of Her late Majesty's Reign, for building Fifty new Churches in and about the Cities of London and Westminster, and Suburbs thereof, to direct the Pa∣rish Church of St. Giles in the Fields, in the County of Middlesex, to be rebuilt instead of one of the said Fifty new Churches.

P.HI: An Act for enforcing and making perpetual an Act in the Twelfth Year of Her late Majesty's Reign, intitled, An Act for the preserving of all such Ships and Goods thereof which shall happen to be forced on Shoar or stranded upon the Coasts of this Kingdom, or any other of Her Majesty's Dominions; and for inflicting the Punishment of Death on such as shall wilfully burn or destroy Ships.

DIV3.P: An Act for the Relief of the Wholesale Traders and Dealers in English Bone-Lace, by obviating several Doubts in the several Acts for Licensing Hawkers and Pedlars.

An Act for making more effectual an Act made in the Eighth Year of the Reign of the late Queen Anne, intitled, An Act for employing the Manufa∣cturers, by encouraging the Consumption of Raw-Silk and Mo-hair Yarn.
An Act for enlarging the Term of Years granted by the Acts of the Eleventh and Twelfth Years of King William the Third, and Second and Third Years of Queen Anne, for the Repair of Dover Harbour.

An Act for the better explaining several Acts, therein mentioned, for erecting of Hospitals and Work-Houses within the City of Bristol, for the em∣ploying
and maintaining the Poor thereof, and for making the said Acts more effectual.
An Act for amending the Roads from the City of London to the Town of East-Grinsted, in the Coun∣ty of Sussex, and to the Towns of Sutton and King∣ston, in the County of Surrey.

An Act for repairing the Highways leading from the Stones-End of Kent-street, in the Parish of St. George's, Southwark, in the County of Surrey, to the Lime Kilns in East-Greenwich, near Black-Heath, and to Lewisham Church, being the Tun∣bridge Road in the County of Kent.
An Act for repairing the Highways from Maiden∣head-Bridge to Sunning-Lane-End, (next to Twiford) in the Road to Reading, and from the said Bridge to Henly-Bridge, in the County of Berks.

An Act for repairing the Highways from Crown Corner in the Town of Reading, (leading by and through the several Parishes of Shinfield and Heck∣field, in the several Counties of Berks, Wilts, and Southampton) to Basingstoke, in the said Coun∣ty of Southampton.

P.HI: An Act for the farther preventing Robbery, Bur∣glary, and other Felonies, and for the more effectual Transportation of Felons, and unlawful Exporters of Wool; and for declaring the Law upon some Points relating to Pirates.
And to Eighteen private Acts.

Q.P: Then the Lord Chancellor, by his Majesty's Command, said,
My Lords and Gentlemen,

HIS Majesty's Royal Will and Pleasure is, that that this Parliament be Prorogued to Tuesday the Twentieth Day of May next, to be then here
held; and this Parliament is accordingly prorogued to to Tuesday the Twentieth Day of May next,

DIV3.P: The King as soon as the Parliament was gone Home, removed with the whole Court to Kinsing∣ton; publick Business began to take a Recess, the Preparations for fitting out a strong Squadron of Men of War for the Mediterranean, went on with the utmost Vigor, as the Thing which the Eyes of the whole Nation seem'd now to be bent upon.

It was about this time that the famous James Shepheard appeared upon the Stage, this was a Youth who has been the Astonishment of the World upon many Accounts, having without any View, or for ought that yet appears without any Support, any Accomplices or any Conspiracy, openly professt a fixt Resolution to assassinate The King, how he with a voluntary Boldness upon all Examination be∣fore at and after his Tryal declared it, yielded to Death, courted no Favour, ask'd no Mercy, and with an unmov'd Courage look'd Death in the Face to the last Gasp, tho' all Men know, not one can account for.

He was apprehended by a Clergyman, one Mr. Leak, a Nonjuror, to whom he conveyed a Letter, delaring his Intention to kill the King. Had he stopt here, and when he was carried before a Magistrate, put his Accuser upon Proofs of the Fact and of the Treason supposed, he had evidently baffled the Accuser; for Mr. Leak had burnt the Letter, had taken no Copy of it, nor could swear to the Contents. The Reason, it seems, which Mr. Leak gave for burning the Letter was, That not being at Home when the Letter was left, and see∣ing the Treasonable Nature of it, he was surpriz'd, and took it to be some villainous Whig Plot of some that had a Design upon his Life, who having left such a Letter in his House, would come again
with Constables, &c. to search his House on Pre∣tence of other Things, and so find this Paper there. But this was a weak Part in him too, for had he carried the Letter it self to the Justice of Peace, as he did an Account that he had received it, he had been right, and at the same time had been safe too; whereas, as it was circumstanced, he would cer∣tainly have been very much reflected on for burning the Letter, had not the Boy clear'd up all the Case by an unexampled Conduct.

For the Boy coming, as he had appointed, for an Answer to the Letter, was apprehended and car∣ried before a Magistrate of the City of London swhere he not only own'd the Letter, but the Trea, son contain'd in it, and offer'd to write it over∣again, which he did too in their Presence, setting his Hand to't, and thereby signing his own Destruction; declaring to them all, that his Intention was to kill the King, and that he believ'd the Action would be meritorious if he had executed it; Things which nothing but a Lunatick could, till this Creature ap∣pear'd, be supposed capable of.

It is too long to repeat all these Things as they pass'd in the several Examinations of this young Man, as well before the Justice, as before the Un∣der-Secretaries at the Secretaries Office, all which were repeated at his Tryal; but 'tis sufficient to say, he was the same every where, readily own'd all, and that he meant and intended it all, and would do it still if it were in his Power; and this he did, not only at those several Examinations, but even upon his Tryal, and to the last; offering nothing in his Defence, refusing to call any Wit∣nesses, but telling the Court he own'd every Thing that was depos'd by the Witnesses, and that he in∣tended and meant what he had written; and thus
he receiv'd the Sentence of Death, shewing no more Concern than at his first Examination.

It was astonishing to see the Conduct of this Youth! What Assistants or Instructors he had been furnished with, to bring him to receive such Prin¦ciples, and to be so fix'd in them, as to contemn Punishment, and we may say, to court the Grave and the Gallows, is hard to determine; nor per∣haps, if any such are in Being, may they be even discover'd; for to press him to tell, who boldly defied Death, and took all upon himself at the Price of his Life, had been to do nothing.

But to come now to his Execution: It was thought by some, the nearer View of Death would perhaps move him, and that when he saw Death just before his Eyes he would relent: But they were deceiv'd who entertain'd such Notions if him; for no Man in the World, had his Cause been indisputably Good, could have brav'd Death it self, in a manner, more like a Christian and a Hero, and yet died a Murtherer; that is to say, intentionally so, and this, without the least yield∣ing the thing it self to be a Sin.

The same Day in the Morning that this Youth suffer'd, a remarkable Piece of Justice was executed upon an Italian Nobleman, the Marquiss de Pal∣leotti, Brother to the Dutchess of Shrewsbury, for killing his own Servant. The Murther committed was so barbarous, the Provocation so little, and the Conduct of the Person so scandalous, that the Government did not think fit to give him the Fa∣vour of a Person of Quality, viz. of being Be∣headed; but this was all he obtain'd, viz. to be Hang'd about Six a-Clock in the Morning, and to be buried afterwards in St. Giles's Church-yard.

He made a short kind of Speech in Italian, and gave it to the Sheriff at the Place of Execution. As it was very short and significant in it self, so it was most ridiculously Translated into English, and yet because both are published, we must give them in the very Words they appear'd in: Any one that understands Italian will see the Difference. They are as follow:

Q.P: A True Copy of the Paper delivered by Ferdinando Marquiss of Palleotti, &c.

P.HI: PER scarica della mia Conscienza & acio che niscere altro sia Sospetato del facto per cui jo sono condemnato confesso che ne la ma collera diedi un stuccato al infelica mio Servitor chiado per dono a quel che mi hanno condannato a morte, & a tuto il mondo che dio sia Miserecordioso al anima mi un dichiare Di Morire Catholico Romano par novesse lusanza del mis Poese di fore haringa ai luogni del supplicio sinisco pregando l' oratrone di tutti ifiacli.

DIV3.P: That none should be accused or suspected of the Fact that I suffer for, I declare to all Mankind, I have killed my Man: I ask Pardon of God and all the World. I likewise declare to die a Roman Catholick: I beg the Prayers of all the Faithful The Use of making Speeches being not the Fa∣shion of my Country, I have no more to say,

P.HI: Palleotti.

DIV3.P:
As now I draw near to that Part of the King's History which relates to Foreign Affairs, I must clear up such of the Transactions of the particular Year I am upon, as though relating to Foreign Af∣fairs, yet were managed at Home; and this in par∣ticular respects the Neutrality of Italy, and the Pro∣ceedings
of the King of Spain against the Domini∣ons of the Emperor in Italy, a Subject which will take up much Room in the future Story of the Reign of King George, as well as in the General History of Europe.

It cannot be questioned, but that upon the ap∣pearance of a Rupture between the King of Spain and the Emperor, two Powers which bore so consi∣derable a Figure in Europe, the Neighbouring Po∣tentates would concern themselves to prevent the Consequences of such a Breach, and more particu∣larly the King of Great Britain; but it was for some Time not known by what Measures or Me∣thods his Majesty would think fit to act; the most that was to be gather'd, was from the King's Words to the Parliament, in the Speech mention'd above.

As for the King of Spain, he having declined to accept of these Heads of Agreement, or of such o∣thers as are settled among the other Powers, suppo∣sing them to differ from these; the King of Great Britain has since entred in to such other Alliances and Conventions with the Emperour and France for the enforcing them; which Conventions and Alliances have been finished since the Conclusion of these An∣nals, as weshall perhaps see in a little Time: The Spaniards will be obliged to comply with.

I find little more of Consequence in the whole Four Years of this Reign, except what will come of Course to be spoken of again in the following Years as we go on; (as for Example) the End of that preposterous Fewd among the Clergy, I mean the Bishop of B—'s Adherents and Antagonists: This, I say, if ever it shall come to an End, may once for all be sum'd up in a general Head, containing the Source of the Quarrel, the scandalous Manner of
carrying it on, the Parties to it on either or on every Side, the Consequences of it to themselves and others, and the End of it all, with an Account who had the Victory, and what has been gained or lost. All these, I say, may be taken Notice of under one Article at last, but to engage in it now, is but to leave it the same unfinished Broil, and the same Piece of Confusion that we find it.

There had been, as is observed before, a little Tu∣mult in the West of England among the Clot hiers which some of our Writers would willingly have made a Rebellion of if they could, but if fell at once as it began without much Design, a few of the most boysterous being taken hold of, were kept in Prison and brought to Tryal at the Lent Assizes this Year; the Issue of which was only this, that one Read the Leader or Ensign of the Mob was find 100 Nobles and Six Months Imprisonment, another of them 10 Nobles and Five Months Imprisonment, Four or Five other lesser Sums, from 30 to 15 No∣bles proportioned to their Guilt and their Capacities of Payment, and so that Affair ended.

One of the principal Things remaining and with which I shall close this History as to home Affairs, is the Account of the Lord Chancellor Cowper who now lay'd down the Seals, and of placing the Lord Parker in the Office of Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain.

Among the many Persons on whom the Eyes of the Government seem'd to be fix'd for this Employ, the Lord Parker, at that time Lord Chief Justice of the King's Bench, was found to be the only Person in view; yet some Difficulties being necessary to be adjusted in removing a Person seated in such a Post, as that of Lord Chief Justice of England, it was some time that we were uncertain whether his Lord∣ship
would be the Man or no. At length, viz. the 12th, we were put out of Doubt, the King gave the Seals to my Lord Parker, and he was declared Lord High Chancellor: What the Considerations by way of Equivalent were, on which his Lord∣ship quitted so advantagious and so established a Post as that of Lord Chief Justice, we cannot de∣termine, tho' great Sums were talked of; all we find visible is, that a Patent is said to be passed, or passing the Seals, to settle a Pension of 1200 l. per Annum upon his Lordship's eldest Son; and it is added, that he is to have the Office of a Teller in the Exchequer, upon the first Vacancy.

His Lordship having received the Seals, it was the 15th, that he appeared for the first time in the Chancery Court at Westminster, whither he went in State and Ceremony, attended by a numerous Train of Nobility and Persons of the first Qua∣lity; his Lordship's new Officers were also appoint∣ed, as is usual in such Cases; the Names of them, as by the Lists that are made Publick, are as fol∣low: viz.

P.Q: “Sir John Doyley of Oxfordshire, Purse-bearer, and Mr. Fuller Deputy Purse-bearer. Mr. Peter Cottingham, Esq Secretary, and Christ. Duppa Deputy Secretary, Nicholas Rowe, Esq Secreta∣ry of the Presentations, John Hughes, Esq Se∣cretary of the Commissions of Peace,—Bark∣er, Esq Secretary of the Bankrupts, Tho. Parker, Esq Secretary of Lunacy, Ideocy, and Appeals, Mr. Butler Secretary of the Briess, Jonathan Johnson Secretary of the Decrees, William Oaker, one of the Gentlemen of the Chamber, Mr. Mason, his Lordship's Clerk, is continued in the same Em∣ployment” to the Lord Chief Justice Prat.

DIV3.HEAD: Of CHANGES, DEATHS, &c.
DIV3.P: THE frequent Turns of State, placing and displacing publick Ministers and Favourites, in a Time so long, cannot well be brought into a common List, neither is it needful; the Story supplying that Part as it goes along with Re∣spect to the most significant of them; nor can all the petty Removes of Men in Office be of Moment enough to take place in History as they do or may do in Monthly Collections.

As to the Death of great Persons it may in∣deed take up a Place where the Persons are of Note, and yet even such are generally menti∣oned in the Course of the Story; also the most eminent of those dead in the Course of this Hi∣story are as follow, (viz.)

LIST.ITEM: Lord Stafford, Son of Lord Stafford, beheaded for the Popish Plot.
Earl of Errall, Hereditary Constable of Scotland.
Lord Forfar, killed at the Battle of Dumblain.

LIST.HEAD: BISHOPS.
LIST.ITEM: Dr. Watson, formerly Bishop of St. Davids, de∣prived for Simony.
Dr. Hicks, a Nonjuror, nominal or titular Bi∣shop of Thetford.

LIST.HEAD: Eminent but not Noble.
LIST.ITEM: Sir John Trevor, Master of the Rolls.
Lord Chief Baron Dod, of the Exchequer.

DIV3.P: N. B. There were many particular Persons of great Worth and Characters who died in this Time, but being not of the Nobility I have o∣mitted them, the Numbers being too great; nei∣ther have I mentioned any of the Children of the Nobility, nor any of the Ladies except the Queen Dowager, and the two Dutchesses of Ha∣milton and Newcastle, because they were both Heiresses and great Families.

DIV3.HEAD: Remarkable EVENTS during the Reign of King George.
DIV3.P: A Woman brought to Bed of a Child in Grace∣church-street, which had the Mark of the Eclipse of the Sun plainly figured on its Fore∣head; the Child lived but two Days.

A strange Phoenomenon in the Air, being Streams of Light from the North in the Evening, so bright as to represent a pale Light, equal to the set∣ting of the Sun; but this being a common Thing in the more Northern Climates, the Wonder of them did not merit so much Notice as we found some People willing to take of them.
A most furious Tempest of Wind so violent that next to the great Storm in Queen Anne's Reign, the like had not been known in England in the Memory of Man.

A long Frist continuing from the End of No∣vember to the 9th of February, with some small In∣tervals, so that the Thames was frozen over for several Weeks together, Booths built upon it,
and whole Oxen roasted upon the Ice in several Places.
A terrible Storm of Thunder, Lightning and Rain, in which abundance of People, Horses, Houses and Stacks of Corn were burnt with the Lightning.

An unheard-of Earthquake, with an Erup∣tion of fiery Mountains or Volcanoes at the Island of St. Vincent, which has entirely destroyed the greatest Part of that Island; if not the Whole, the Parts of which blew up into the Air to so prodigious a Heighth, and with such Violence, that the Dust and Sand of it fell down in Show∣ers at Barbadoes, Martinico and other Islands, at the Distance of near an hundred Miles, to the great Surprize of the Inhabitants.

The like Earthquakes and Eruptions of Fire with dreadful openings of the Earth, happened at the same Time at the Terceras and Canaries Islands, to the Terror of the Inhabitants, many of whom were frighted to Death.

DIV3.HEAD: FOREIGN AFFAIRS.
DIV3.P:
WHEN King George came to the Crown he found the Nation just taking Breath after a tedious, wasting and bloody War; what∣ever Complaints were at home against it, and the Conditions of the Peace of Ʋtrecht, the Man∣ner of making it, and the Persons employed in it, yet this Happiness accured to his Majesty by it, and of which all the Kingdom shared with him (viz.) that when Providence called the House of Hannover to the Succession, the Hands of all their Enemies were tied up by the very Peace which themselves had made,
so that not the least Opposition was any where offered to the quiet Possession of the Crown at home or abroad.

The King of France, the most potent Enemy to the Protestant Settlement, was engaged by Treaty and bound in Honour, not only not to oppose it, but even to contribute to the free and uninterrupted Accession, and accordingly ordered Monsieur Ibberville, his Minister at London, and the Marquess de Chasteauneuf, his Minister at the Hague, to signifie, the first to the Regency of London, and the other to the Ministers of Hannover and Great Britain at the Hague, that his most Christian Ma∣jesty would offer his Britannick Majesty no Di∣sturbance in his Accession to the Crown; and when his Majesty afterwards came to the Hague in his way to England, the same French Ambas∣sador waited on him, and in the Name of his Master, the most Christian King, congratulated his Accession, paid the Compliment as they cal∣led it of Febicitation, and gave him the same Assurances in Words at length; so in a Word the Peace of Ʋtrecht had stopped every Mouth, and tied every Hand from acting against the In∣terest and advancing of King George to the Throne, a Circumstance which in my Account would have atoned for abundance of the bad Things which otherwise, as they say, attended the Peace.

But the People of that Side shut their Eyes against this Part, nor did they abate any Thing of their Complaints against the Peace it self, any more than they did against the Persons who made it, as has been shewn in the forego∣ing Sheets.

As the whole World was thus at Peace with King George and his Accession, so King George evi∣dently desired to be at Peace with all the World, and it was his Majesty's Interest to be, consider∣ing the Temper of his People and Situation of his Affairs at Home; and without doubt it was with a View to this that the King so rea∣dily entered into a defensive Alliance with the French and the Dutch, at a Time when some People here were not, for want of Ignorance, warm for renewing the War with France.
Of this Alliance, the Nature and Reason of it, I have given a large Account in the second Part of this History, Page 32, to which I refer.

From this to the Affairs of Spain our Admini∣stration has had little Concern; in the Affairs abroad, the World, though full of Intrigues and Embarrasses, had little or no War upon their Hands, except that in the second Year of the King a bloody War broke out between the Empe∣ror and the Turks, which indeed began in the Quarrel of the Venetians; for as to the War in the North, there was nothing done in it deser∣ving the Name of a War, except driving the Swedes to their close Quarters; for as to the at∣tacking them in their own Country, the Allies durst not venture upon it.

But the War with the Turks was carried on in earnest, and the very first Campaign Prince Eugene of Savoy, who commanded the Imperial Ar∣my, gave the Turks an entire Overthrow in the great Battle near Semlin, or rather at Peterwa∣radin, where, if we may believe the Accounts which the Germans gave of it, they killed a∣bove 26000 Turks, took all their Baggage and Carriages, all their Tents, Treasure, and 150
Pieces of Canon, and after that passed the Da∣nube and the Theysse, and laid Siege to Temeswaer, which after a long Siege they took also, with all the District and Dependency of it, as far as Orsowa on the Danube one way, and as far as the River Alauta the other way, even a good way into the Country of Wallachia.
